Description: CONTINUE OUR INVESTMENT IN BULL TROUT RESCUE (OVER 5,900 FRY AND JUVENILES IN TWO HIGH-RISK POPULATIONS OVER 6 YEARS) IN STREAMS THAT ARE SLATED FOR HABITAT RESTORATION IN 2023 AND 2025. DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS TO REDUCE BULL TROUT MORTALITY IN DEWATERING STREAMS BY CONTINUING TO CONDUCT DEMOGRAPHIC SURVEYS AND COLLECT HABITAT DATA. ULTIMATELY, THESE UPCOMING HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS ARE EXPECTED TO ELIMINATE THE NEED FOR RESCUE. ADDITIONALLY, WE NEED TO ANSWER CRITICAL DATA GAPS BY VERIFYING 1) BULL TROUT PRESENCE OR FUNCTIONAL EXTIRPATION IN STREAMS TARGETED FOR UPCOMING REINTRODUCTION AND 2) DETERMINE IF A NEW DISCOVERY OF SIGNIFICANT BULL TROUT PRESENCE (VIA EDNA) IN THE HEADWATERS OF THE LITTLE NACHES RIVER IS A NEW POPULATION OR EXPANDED DISTRIBUTION OF AN EXISTING POPULATION.

IN THIS 18-MONTH (1.5 YEARS) PROJECT, ECOSTUDIES INSTITUTE WILL CONTINUE OUR OVERALL GOAL OF ADVANCING STREAKED HORNED LARK RECOVERY THROUGH TWO OBJECTIVES. THE FIRST OBJECTIVE IS TO ADVANCE STREAKED HORNED LARK RECOVERY BY FACILITATING THE WORKING GROUP AND WORKSHOPS THAT HAVE PROVEN EFFECTIVE IN ACCELERATING STRATEGY DEVELOPMENT AND ON-THE GROUND-ACTIONS TO ADDRESS THE MOST IMPORTANT RANGE-WIDE RECOVERY ACTIONS. WITHOUT FUNDING TO CONTINUE THIS WORK, THE ABILITY OF INDIVIDUAL ENTITIES TO REMAIN UP-TO-DATE ON PARTNER ACTIVITIES, ADVANCES IN KNOWLEDGE, AND NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR SPECIES RECOVERY IS LOST AND EFFICIENT SYNERGIES ARE WASTED WHEN INDIVIDUALS AND ENTITIES ARE SILOED. THIS OBJECTIVE WILL SUPPORT RECOVERY BY MEETING OBJECTIVES IN THE DRAFT RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY AND SUPPORTING WFWO PRIORITIES. THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTATION OF ONE WORKING GROUP MEETING FOR THE STREAKED HORNED LARK WORKING GROUP, ONE WORKSHOP, AND IMMEDIATE ACTION ON EMERGING ISSUES.THE SECOND OBJECTIVE IS TO SUPPORT THE ONGOING STREAKED HORNED LARK REINTRODUCTION PROJECT FUNDED BY THE STATE OF THE BIRDS PROGRAM. THE FUNDING REQUEST IS FOR ONE MONTH OF TIME FOR THE PROJECT MANAGER TO HELP THE PI COMPLETE THE DETAILED IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY FOR THE STREAKED HORNED LARK. THIS PLAN WILL DESCRIBE PROPOSED REINTRODUCTION AND TRANSLOCATION METHODOLOGIES, IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE RELEASE SITES AND REINTRODUCTION STRATEGIES BASED ON A DECISION-ANALYTIC FRAMEWORK (IN COLLABORATION WITH USGS AND UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON), AND DESCRIBE AND EVALUATE LIKELY FUNDING POSSIBILITIES, INCLUDING DEBIT-CREDIT OPTIONS FOR DOD AND FAA ACTIVITIES.

SOUTHERN APPALACHIAN MOUNTAIN WETLANDS ARE AMONG NORTH AMERICA S RAREST NATURAL COMMUNITIES AND SUPPORT NUMEROUS RARE AND FIVE FEDERALLY-LISTED SPECIES.THE WETLANDS GENERALLY OCCUR AT THE BASE OF SLOPES, HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY PREVIOUS LAND USE AND HYDROLOGIC ALTERATIONS, AND ARE VULNERABLE TO THE EFFECTS OF UPSLOPE LAND USE AND CLIMATE CHANGE. THEY ARE FED PRIMARILY BY GROUNDWATER DISCHARGE AND LOSE LARGE QUANTITIES OF WATER THROUGH EVAPOTRANSPIRATION (ET). DR. JEFF WILCOX HAS BEEN STUDYING MOUNTAIN WETLAND HYDROLOGY SINCE 2010. A USFWS I M GRANT IN 2012 ESTABLISHED BASELINE HYDROLOGIC MONITORING AT 12 PRIORITY MOUNTAIN BOG SITES, WHILE TWO ADDITIONAL SITES WERE ADDED IN 2017 AND 2021 WITH ADDITIONAL FUNDING FROM USFWS, NC WILDLIFE RESOURCE COMMISSION, AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY. DATA COLLECTED OVER THE PAST 10  YEARS HAVE BEEN USED TO DESIGN AND OR ASSESS MAJOR RESTORATION PROJECTS AND INFORM CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT PLANS. THIS PROJECT WILL FUND CONTINUED MONITORING AT MOUNTAIN BOGS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE PRIORITY SITES TO ASSESS THE LONGER-TERM IMPACTS OF PAST RESTORATION EFFORTS, NEARBY LAND-USE CHANGES, SHORT-TERM DROUGHT, AND LONG-TERM CLIMATE CHANGES. FUNDING FROM THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO BE USED TO INITIATE MONITORING AT TWO NEW SITES AS REQUESTED BY USFWS.

LIATRIS HELLERI PORTER (ASTERACEAE), HELLERS BLAZING STAR, IS A RARE PERENNIAL HERB FOUND ON ROCKYFACES AND SUMMITS IN WESTERN NORTH CAROLINA (ASHE, AVERY, BURKE AND WATAUGA COUNTIES). MYRESEARCH GROUP AT APPALACHIAN STATE UNIVERSITY DEVELOPED 17 POLYMORPHIC MICROSATELLITE MARKERSTO INVESTIGATE SPECIES BOUNDARIES BETWEEN L. HELLERI AND L. TURGIDA(CLARK ET AL, 2019). WEDOCUMENTED A LARGE NUMBER OF ALLELES PER POPULATION, BUT REDUCED HETEROZYGOSITY, SUGGESTING THATISOLATION AND INBREEDING ARE THE LIKELY DRIVERS OF GENETIC CHANGE. WE ALSO IDENTIFIED A GROUP OFPOPULATIONS IN AVERY COUNTY THAT MOST LIKELY REPRESENT THE CORE RANGE FOR THE SPECIES L. HELLERI ASWELL AS SEVERAL POPULATIONS THAT APPEAR TO BE ADMIXED WITH L. TURGIDA IN BOTH BURKE AND AVERYCOUNTIES (CLARK, 2019).THIS UNEXPECTED RESULT MAY HAVE BEEN INFLUENCED BY UNDOCUMENTED AUGMENTATION EVENTS AROUNDTHE GRANDFATHER MOUNTAIN POPULATIONS IN AVERY COUNTY. THIS HYPOTHESIS IS BASED ON THE DISTINCTDIFFERENCES WE IDENTIFIED AT THE ATTRACTION SITES OF GRANDFATHER MOUNTAIN AND THE MORE NATURALSITES IN THE SURROUNDING AREA. OUR EARLIER EFFORTS ALSO FAILED TO SAMPLE THE TYPE LOCALITY (BLOWINGROCK) OF L. HELLERI AND A POPULATION LOCATED ON THREE TOP MOUNTAIN IN ASHE COUNTY.IN ORDER TO FULLY DOCUMENT THE GENETIC DIVERSITY AND POPULATION STRUCTURE OF L. HELLERI, WE WILLGENOTYPE THE TWO MISSING POPULATIONS AS WELL AS ADDITIONAL INDIVIDUALS FROM BURKE, AVERY, ANDWATAUGA COUNTIES TO FURTHER EXPLORE POPULATION STRUCTURE.

IDFG IS PROPOSING A COMPREHENSIVE, LONG-TERM IDAHO GRIZZLY BEAR CONFLICT MANAGEMENT PROGRAM FOCUSING ON TWO SPECIFIC RECOVERY AREAS (1) THE GREATER YELLOWSTONE ECOSYSTEM (GYE) AND (2) THE SELKIRK, CABINET-YAAK ECOSYSTEM (SCYE). THE IDFG ENVISIONS A STATEWIDE PROGRAM APPLICABLE THROUGHOUT IDAHO INCORPORATING MANAGEMENT PERSONNEL AND THE CONFLICT TOOLS THEY NEED TO BE EFFECTIVE (INCLUDING EVERYTHING FROM OUTREACH MATERIALS TO ELECTRIC FENCING). THERE ARE TWO SPECIFIC GOALS TO THIS PROJECT: 1) DEMONSTRATE IDFG MANAGEMENT AND MECHANISMS IN SUPPORT OF EVENTUAL DELISTING AND 2) INCREASE OUTREACH, EDUCATION, AND HUMAN-BEAR CONFLICT PERSONNEL THROUGHOUT IDAHO.

THE RECOVERY CHALLENGE GRANT PARTNERSHIP WILL BUILD OFF THE SUCCESSFUL FWS RECOVERY CHALLENGE GRANT PROGRAMWHILE ADDING NFWFS ABILITY TO ATTRACT PROJECTS FROM DIVERSE PARTNERS AND BRING ADDITIONAL RESOURCES TO SUPPORTTHE EFFORT. THIS NEW AGREEMENT WILL BE A MULTI-YEAR AWARD THAT IS ANTICIPATED TO BE FUNDED AT  1 MILLION PER YEARFOR THREE YEARS (FY23-FY25). NFWF WILL WORK WITH FWS TO IDENTIFY SPECIFIC PRIORITY SPECIES THROUGH NFWF PROGRAMSWHERE RECOVERY INVESTMENTS CAN BE FOCUSED. FOR FY23, THE PARTNERSHIP WILL FOCUS ON A SUITE OF POLLINATOR SPECIESINCLUDING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE, FRANKLINS BUMBLE BEE, KARNER BLUE BUTTERFLY, DAKOTA SKIPPER, POWESHIEKSKIPPERLING, MITCHELLS SATYR, AND TAYLORS CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY. THE PROJECTS RECOMMENDED FOR FUNDING WILL BEPROVIDED TO THE ASSISTANT DIRECTOR OF ECOLOGICAL SERVICES FOR APPROVAL. PROJECTS WILL CONTINUE TO BE SOLICITEDTHROUGHOUT THE YEAR UNTIL THE PARTNERSHIP FUNDS ARE FULLY OBLIGATED.

THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF ILLICIT CANNABIS CULTIVATION HAVE JUST RECENTLY BEGUN TO BE UNDERSTOOD. THE FISHER, A SPECIES RECENTLY LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN THE ISOLATED SOUTHERN SIERRA NEVADA POPULATION, IS KNOWN TO BE SUBJECT TO THE THREATS FROM PESTICIDES AND OTHER POISONS USED AT CULTIVATION SITES THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE IN CALIFORNIA. THE SUBLETHAL THREATS, HOWEVER, ARE LESS UNDERSTOOD. HOW THESE SITES AFFECT FISHER SPACE USE, BEHAVIOR, AND REPRODUCTION ARE NECESSARY PIECES OF INFORMATION THAT WILL HELP QUANTIFY THE CUMULATIVE IMPACTS THESE SITES HAVE ON FISHER POPULATION VIABILITY. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL INVESTIGATE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS OF FISHERS KNOWN TO USE CULTIVATION SITES WITH ASSOCIATED PESTICIDES AND HABITAT DESTRUCTION IN COMPARISON TO FISHERS OUTSIDE OF CULTIVATION-IMPACTED AREAS. WE WILL ALSO TRACK FISHER MOVEMENT AND USE OF THE RISKY FEATURES OF CULTIVATION SITES USING REMOTE CAMERAS AND GPS-COLLARED FISHERS, BOTH BEFORE THE SITES ARE RECLAIMED (CLEANED-UP) AND AFTER RECLAMATION. THIS WILL ALLOW FOR A QUANTITATIVE EVALUATION OF HOW THESE SITES AND THEIR ASSOCIATED ENVIRONMENTAL THREATS AFFECT THE NORMAL ACTIVITY PATTERNS AND MOVEMENT BEHAVIOR OF FISHERS. BY CONTINUING TO TRACK THEM AFTER RECLAMATION, WE CAN IDENTIFY IF RECLAMATION ALLOWS FISHERS TO RESUME NORMAL ACTIVITY PATTERNS THROUGH THE COMPARISON OF PRE- AND POST-RECLAMATION HOME RANGES, MOVEMENT, AND SPACE USE.

BULL TROUT ARE AN IMPERILED SPECIES OF FISH NATIVE TO WESTERN NORTH AMERICA. TO HELP PROTECT EXISTING POPULATIONS OF BULL TROUT, WE WILL POST INFORMATIONAL SIGNS THAT WILL AID RECREATIONAL ANGLERS IN NORTHEAST OREGON WITH PROPER IDENTIFICATION OF FISH THEY CATCH. OUR GOAL IS TO REDUCE ADDITIONAL MORTALITY OF BULL TROUT AS A RESULT OF RECREATIONAL ANGLERS MISTAKENLY HARVESTING BULL TROUT THAT HAVE BEEN MISIDENTIFIED AS A DIFFERENT SPECIES OF FISH. TO DO THIS WE WILL PRINT ALUMINUM SIGNS THAT SHOW SPECIES PRESENT IN DIFFERENT WATERBODIES THEN POST THE SIGNS AT POPULAR ANGLING ACCESS POINTS. THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT WITH THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, IDAHO POWER COMPANY, AND THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE. THE FUNDING ASSOCIATED WITH OUR GRANT THAT WE RECEIVED FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IS FOR THE PURCHASE OF SIGNS AND ASSOCIATED HARDWARE. THE PROJECT WILL HELP PROMOTE BULL TROUT CONSERVATION AND PROMOTE PUBLIC AWARENESS OF THE NEED TO PROTECT THIS IMPORTANT SPECIES.

ISLAND CONSERVATION, AND ITS PARTNERS AT THE VIRGIN ISLANDS DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND NATURAL RESOURCES, NORTH CAROLINA ZOO, AND GREENSBORO SCIENCE CENTER ARE PROPOSING TO ESTABLISH A NEW POPULATION OF THE ENDANGERED VIRGIN ISLANDS TREE BOA THROUGH THE ERADICATION OF INVASIVE RATS FROM SAVANA ISLAND, U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS. THE VI BOA POPULATION IS LIMITED TO AS FEW AS 1,500 INDIVIDUALS AND RESTRICTED TO SEVEN WIDELY DISPERSED SITES IN PUERTO RICO AND THE U.S. AND BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS, MANY OF WHICH ARE THREATENED BY DAMAGING INVASIVE SPECIES (E.G., RODENTS, CATS) AND SEA LEVEL RISE. WITH THE HELP AND SUPPORT OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND OTHER EXPERTS, THE PARTNERSHIP IDENTIFIED THAT ESTABLISHING A NEW POPULATION OF VI BOAS ON SAVANA ISLAND IS A CRITICAL ACTION FOR CONSERVING THIS THREATENED SPECIES. BY ERADICATING RATS, THE HABITAT ON SAVANA WILL BE MADE SUITABLE TO ESTABLISH A BRAND-NEW POPULATION OF BOAS AND PAVE THE WAY FOR OTHER VI BOA INTRODUCTIONS IN THE REGION. TWO VI BOA POPULATIONS WERE ESTABLISHED ON OFFSHORE CAYS IN THE 1990S AFTER THE SUCCESSFUL ERADICATION OF RATS AND HUNDREDS OF SUCCESSFUL RAT ERADICATIONS HAVE BEEN SAFELY CONDUCTED ACROSS THE GLOBE. THIS PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH AN ADDITIONAL VI BOA POPULATION WHERE THREATS FROM INVASIVE MAMMALS ARE NOT PRESENT AND WHERE SEA LEVEL RISE WILL HAVE MINIMAL IMPACT ON THE HABITAT OR THE BOA. WE AIM TO COMPLETE THE MOST COST-EFFECTIVE RAT ERADICATION STRATEGY WITH THE GREATEST LIKELIHOOD OF SUCCESS BY CONDUCTING AN AERIAL BROADCAST OF A SPECIALIZED RODENT BAIT ACROSS THE ISLAND. IN PARALLEL, WE WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS TO PUT IN PLACE COMPREHENSIVE AND PRACTICAL BIOSECURITY MEASURES FOR PREVENTION, SURVEILLANCE, AND RESPONSE TO RAT INCURSIONS AND NEW INVASIVE THREATS SO THAT OUR EFFORTS AND VALUABLE CONSERVATION FUNDING WILL BE PROTECTED IN THE FUTURE. TWELVE MONTHS AFTER THE ERADICATION, A TEAM WILL RETURN TO SAVANA TO INITIATE THE CONFIRMATION PHASE TO DETERMINE THE SUCCESS OF THE ERADICATION. USING A SUITE OF DETECTION TOOLS SUCH AS CAMERA TRAPS, ULTRASONIC RECORDERS, AND TRACKING TUNNELS, THE TEAM WILL COLLECT SCIENCE-BASED DATA TO CONFIRM THE PROJECT WAS SUCCESSFUL IN ERADICATING RATS. ONCE THE ISLAND IS CONFIRMED FREE OF RATS, WE WILL COLLABORATE WITH PARTNERS TO CREATE A WORKPLAN FOR TRANSLOCATING THE VI BOA POPULATION FROM EXISTING POPULATIONS IN THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS AND FROM A CAPTIVE FACILITY TO SAVANA ISLAND THROUGH AN IN-PERSON WORKSHOP. AS A PROJECT OUTCOME, PARTNERS WILL ESTABLISH THE LARGEST PROTECTED, THREAT-FREE REFUGE FOR THE VI BOA, HELPING THE SPECIES RECOVERY, ENHANCING ESSENTIAL HABITAT, AND CREATING A PATHWAY TO ESTABLISH ADDITIONAL VI BOA POPULATIONS WITHIN PUERTO RICO (E.G., CULEBRITA AND LUIS PEA) AND THE U.S. VIRGIN ISLANDS.

THE KEAUHOU BIRD CONSERVATION CENTER WAS ESTABLISHED TO HELP PREVENT IMMINENT EXTINCTION ANDRECOVER WILD POPULATIONS OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS USING CONSERVATION BREEDINGAND REINTRODUCTION TECHNIQUES. THE LARGER CONSERVATION BREEDING AND REINTRODUCTION EFFORT HASSUCCESSFULLY RAISED AND RELEASED 842 INDIVIDUALS FROM 16 DIFFERENT HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRD SPECIESINTO THE WILD SINCE 1993, AND HAS MADE SIGNIFICANT CAPITAL INVESTMENTS AT THE PERMANENT FACILITY.FURTHERMORE, THE FACILITY CONDUCTS COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT WITH THE GOAL OF INSPIRING ANDCONNECTING RESIDENTS TO RETURN THEIR COMMUNITIES WHERE THEY CAN SERVE AS MORE KNOWLEDGEABLEAND MOTIVATED AMBASSADORS FOR HAWAIIAN BIRD CONSERVATION AND THEIR NATURAL HERITAGE. HOWEVER,TO CONTINUE CARRYING OUT ESSENTIAL CONSERVATION BREEDING AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENTOPPORTUNITIES, INFRASTRUCTURE REPAIRS, RENOVATIONS, AND IMPROVEMENTS ARE NECESSARY BECAUSE THEINFRASTRUCTURE IS AGING AND IN NEED OF SIGNIFICANT REPAIR. THE HAWAIIAN BIRD CONSERVATION BREEDINGAND REINTRODUCTION EFFORT IS CONDUCTED AS PART OF THE FOREST BIRD CONSERVATION BREEDINGPARTNERSHIP  A HIGHLY COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE, U.S.FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCESDIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE.

KLAMATH BIRD OBSERVATORY (KBO), AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY (ABC), AND ECOSTUDIES INSTITUTE (ESI), WILL CONDUCT AN EXTENSIVE DATA ANALYSIS OF HABITAT USE AND DEMOGRAPHY, COMBINING THREE DATASETS COLLECTED OVER THE LAST SEVEN YEARS AT MULTIPLE SITES IN WESTERN OREGON AND WASHINGTON, TO EVALUATE FACTORS LIMITING POPULATIONS OF THE FEDERAL CANDIDATE OREGON VESPER SPARROW. THE PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE APPROXIMATELY  650,000 FROM OVER 15 DIFFERENT FUNDING PARTNERS, AND PROVIDE THE USFWS WITH CRITICAL INFORMATION NECESSARY TO MAKE A SOUND LISTING DECISION FOR OREGON VESPER SPARROW. THE OUTCOMES WILL ALSO PROVIDE THE FOUNDATION AND THE DIRECTION FOR THE NEXT PHASE OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THREATS AND INITIATE RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR POPULATIONS OF THIS IMPERILED BIRD.

THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR THE LOCAL POPULATION OF ESA-LISTED HOOD RIVER BULL TROUT, WHICH RESIDE UPSTREAM OF CLEAR BRANCH DAM, USING UNDERWATER VIDEO WEIR TECHNOLOGY. NO UPSTREAM PASSAGE FACILITIES EXIST AT CLEAR BRANCH DAM, THE IMPOUNDMENT THAT FORMS LAURANCE LAKE, AND DOWNSTREAM PASSAGE EVENTS ARE LIMITED TO SURFACE SPILL EVENTS. FOR THIS REASON, THE POPULATION OF BULL TROUT UPSTREAM OF CLEAR BRANCH DAM ARE MOSTLY GEOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED. TO PROVIDE UPDATED ESTIMATES OF BULL TROUT SPAWNER ESCAPEMENT AND TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE TIMING OF RESERVOIR USE, THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE VIDEO WEIR MONITORING AND IMPLEMENT TEMPERATURE MONITORING IN LAURANCE LAKE TRIBUTARIES, CLEAR BRANCH AND PINNACLE CREEK. VIDEO WEIR MONITORING HAS BEEN COMPLETED DURING 2021-2022 FIELD SEASONS AND THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE VIDEO WEIR MONITORING THROUGH THE 2023-2026 FIELD SEASONS. IN ADDITION TO SPAWNER ABUNDANCE, VIDEO WEIR MONITORING WILL PROVIDE MULTI-YEAR CALIBRATION FOR ANNUAL SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS WHICH HAVE BEEN COMPLETED ANNUALLY OVER A 17-YEAR TIME SERIES. TEMPERATURE LOGGER DEPLOYMENT AND FLOW MONITORING IN LAURANCE LAKE TRIBUTARIES WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION REGARDING TRIBUTARY TEMPERATURE PROFILES AND INFLOWS INTO THE LAURANCE LAKE. OVERALL, INFORMATION COLLECTED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BETTER INFORM MANAGERS ABOUT THE STATUS OF THIS IMPERILED POPULATION.

THE FLORIDA GRASSHOPPER SPARROW (FGSP), LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 1986 (51 FR 27492), IS CONSIDERED ONE OF NORTH AMERICA S MOST IMPERILED BIRDS. FGSPS TYPICALLY OCCUR IN FLORIDA DRY PRAIRIE, YET ALSO ARE FOUND IN PASTURES ON WORKING RANCHES. LESS THAN 20  OF FLORIDA S NATURAL DRY PRAIRIE REMAINS, WITH THE LARGEST, INTACT NATIVE DRY PRAIRIES ALREADY PROTECTED. WORKING RANGELANDS MAY PROVIDE THE BEST OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF FGSP POPULATIONS AND ACHIEVE DELISTING RECOVERY CRITERION 1. HOWEVER, THIS STRATEGY NECESSITATES UNDERSTANDING FGSP DEMOGRAPHY AND NEST SUCCESS ON RANGELANDS. ARCHBOLD WILL MONITOR FGSPS, FIND AND PROTECT NESTS, AND ASSESS HABITAT AT DELUCA PRESERVE, A WORKING CATTLE RANCH, TO BETTER UNDERSTAND DEMOGRAPHY OF FGSPS ON RANGELANDS.THE DELUCA PRESERVE WAS A PRIVATELY HELD CATTLE RANCH (DESTINY RANCH), AND IN 2020, THE DELUCA FAMILY PLACED A CONSERVATION EASEMENT ON THE PROPERTY AND DONATED THE LAND TO THE UNIVERSITY OF FLORIDA. SINCE 2017, ARCHBOLD, WITH SUPPORT FROM THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, US DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE, AND THE FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF FLORIDA, HAS MONITORED AND MANAGED THE DELUCA FGSP POPULATION, PROTECTED NESTS, COMPLETED HABITAT ASSESSMENTS FOR FGSPS, PROVIDED HABITAT MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE SERVICE, AND COORDINATED THESE ACTIONS THROUGH THE FLORIDA GRASSHOPPER SPARROW WORKING GROUP.HERE WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE THESE ACTIONS TO: (I) BETTER UNDERSTAND THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN MANAGEMENT, FGSP HABITAT, AND DEMOGRAPHY. ALL OUR PROJECT OBJECTIVES ALIGN WITH THE RECOVERY ACTIONS DESCRIBED IN THE FGSP STRATEGIC VISION (SERVICE 2019).OBJECTIVES1.POPULATION   DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORINGA.CONDUCT POINT-COUNT SURVEYS IN OCCUPIED PASTURES IN APRIL, MAY, JUNE, AND JULY (ACTIONS 6, 8, 16).B.CONDUCT TRANSECT SURVEYS IN PASTURES NOT KNOWN TO BE OCCUPIED ONCE PER BREEDING SEASON (ACTIONS 6, 8, 16).C.BAND ALL FGSPS AT DELUCA, INCLUDING NESTLINGS (ACTIONS 6, 8, 16).2.NEST PROTECTIONA.LOCATE AND FENCE ALL FGSP NESTS (ACTIONS 3, 8).B.LIFT FGSP NESTS AT RISK OF FLOODING (ACTION 4).C.TREAT RED IMPORTED FIRE ANT MOUNDS NEAR FGSP NESTS (ACTION 5).3.HABITAT QUALITY ASSESSMENTSA.ASSESS HABITAT AT ALL TRANSECT AND POINT COUNT SURVEY LOCATIONS ANNUALLY (ACTION 16).4.STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENTA.COORDINATE, VIA THE FGSP WORKING GROUP, WITH PARTNERS AND AGENCY STAFF (ACTION 19).DELIVERABLES1.TECHNICAL REPORT SUMMARIZING POPULATION, DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING, AND NEST PROTECTION ACTIVITIES AND OUTCOMES, AND HABITAT ASSESSMENTS.2.WEEKLY ATTENDANCE AT THE FGSP WORKING GROUP MEETINGS DURING THE BREEDING SEASON AND PRESENTATIONS SUMMARIZING RESULTS AT THE ANNUAL MEETING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT AND RESTORE NATIVE FORESTS, BIODIVERSITY, AND ENDANGERED SPECIES BY CONTROLLING INVASIVE SPECIES, PREDATORS, AND PESTS THAT THREATEN NATIVE SPECIES THAT ARE INTEGRAL TO THOSE ECOSYSTEMS. THE FUNDING AND SUPPORT PROVIDED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO EXPAND IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN PRIORITY SITES THAT MAXIMIZE BENEFITS TO THE LARGEST NUMBER OF THE MOST CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES. FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE DEPLOYMENT AND ESTABLISHMENT OF THREAT CONTROL EQUIPMENT TO PROVIDE EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF MAJOR PREDATORS AND PESTS OF NATIVE SPECIES. RATS AND OTHER PREDATORS HAVE BEEN WELL DOCUMENTED TO BE THE MOST PROLIFIC DESTROYERS OF ISLAND ECOSYSTEMS THROUGHOUT OCEANIA. IN ADDITION TO RATS, MONGOOSE, FERAL CATS, SLUGS, PREDATORY SNAILS, AND ASSOCIATED THREATS WILL BE ADDRESSED IN STRATEGIC LOCALES WHERE LIMITED AND TARGETED CONTROL WILL HAVE THE MOST IMPACT.

TO EXPAND THE CURRENT EXTENT OF FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) POPULATIONS AND LOCATE NEW POPULATIONS, BUMBLE BEE SURVEYS ARE PERFORMED IN U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE REGIONS 3 AND 5. SURVEYS OCCUR THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES WATERSHED IN THREE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES IN NEW YORK, OHIO, AND WISCONSIN (FOX RIVER  WI , OTTAWA  OH , AND MONTEZUMA  NY ), WETLAND MANAGEMENT DISTRICTS AND STATE GAME AREAS IN MICHIGAN, TWO COUNTIES (COOK AND LAKE) IN ILLINOIS, AND 5 COUNTIES (ALLEN, ELKHART, LAGRANGE, NOBLE, AND STEUBEN) IN INDIANA. SURVEYS GENERALLY FOLLOW USFWS SURVEY PROTOCOLS FOR THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) VERSION 2.2, RAPID SURVEY PROTOCOL TO EXPEDITE SAMPLING AND COVER AS MUCH AREA AS POSSIBLE AND ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE UNTIL 2025. INFORMATION REGARDING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE, BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITIES, AND FLOWER USE IS RELATIVELY LACKING THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE GREAT LAKES WATERSHED. DETAILED DATA ASSOCIATED WITH BEE SPECIES RICHNESS, ABUNDANCE, AND HABITAT USE PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SUPPORT FOR GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVES AND U.S. FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICES OVERALL CONSERVATION GOALS IN THE WATERSHED.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING LONG-TERM REINTRODUCTIONS EFFORT FOR THE CAROLINA MADTOM CURRENTLY BEING PERFORMED UNDER A GRANT WITH NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION ENDING 12 31 2024, TO PROMOTE POPULATION GROWTH WITHIN TWO WATERSHEDS (IN THE TAR AND NEUSE RIVER DRAINAGES IN NORTH CAROLINA) AND HELP TO ACHIEVE RECOVERY GOALS OF THIS IMPERILED SPECIES. BASED ON CFI S 35  YEARS OF EXPERIENCE WITH NATIVE FRESHWATER NON-GAME FISH RESTORATION PROJECTS, YEARS (OF DECADES) OF REINTRODUCTIONS ARE NECESSARY TO ESTABLISH SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS OF RARE, THREATENED, OR ENDANGERED FISH SPECIES. USFWS FUNDS WILL BE USED BEGINNING 01 01 2025 TO EXTEND THIS PROJECT.CFI ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE PROPAGATION OF POPULATIONS OF CAROLINA MADTOM IN COOPERATION WITH FWS PARTNERS. JUVENILES WILL BE RELEASED IN OCTOBER NOVEMBER AT APPROPRIATE SITES DETERMINED BY THE USFWS AND NCWRC.THE PRIMARY DELIVERABLES ARE YOUNG, HEALTHY, VIE MARKED CAROLINA MADTOMS THAT WILL BE RELEASED INTO THEIR NATIVE HABITATS. CFI ALSO WILL PROVIDE ANNUAL PROGRESS REPORTS AND A FINAL REPORT TO THE RALEIGH FIELD OFFICE. USFWS AND NCWRC STAFF WILL CONTRIBUTE TIME AND TRAVEL TO PARTICIPATE IN BROODSTOCK COLLECTION AND RELEASE OF PROGENY. IF NEEDED, THE NCWRC MAY PROVIDE ADDITIONAL SUPPORT VIA HATCHERY SPACE, CARE, AND MAINTENANCE OF BROODSTOCK OR PROGENY AT THE MARION CONSERVATION AQUACULTURE CENTER (MCAC) IN MARION, NC, IN PREPARATION FOR RELEASE. THE MCAC SUCCESSFULLY OVERWINTERED JUVENILES OF PREVIOUS COHORTS TO RELIEVE SPACE CONSTRAINTS AT CFI DUE TO HIGHLYSUCCESSFUL YEARS OF PRODUCING MORE CAROLINA MADTOMS THAN ANTICIPATED. CAROLINA MADTOM RECOVERY GOALS WOULD BE ADDRESSED BY THIS WORK.

RECENT EXTREMELY LOW WILD POPULATION SIZES OF THE ENDANGERED POWESHIEK SKIPPERLING HAVE CONTRASTED WITH SUCCESSES IN ZOO-BASED MANAGED BREEDING EFFORTS. THESE EX SITU BREEDING AND REARING EFFORTS HAVE PRODUCED MORE POWESHIEK SKIPPERLINGS IN HUMAN CARE THAN EVER BEFORE, AND ARE NOW SERVING AS A VITAL INSURANCE POPULATION AND SOURCE FOR FUTURE TRANSLOCATIONS. THIS NECESSITATES ADDITIONAL REARING AND MONITORING EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES UPGRADES AT THE MINNESOTA ZOO. TO SAFELY ACCOMMODATE THE ADDITIONAL POWESHIEK SKIPPERLING INDIVIDUALS, THE MINNESOTA ZOO MUST KEEP THEM QUARANTINED AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE FROM CONCURRENT LARGE REARING AND BREEDING OPERATIONS WITH THE FEDERALLY THREATENED DAKOTA SKIPPER. WE REQUIRE EQUIPMENT AND SUPPLIES FOR SEPARATE HUSBANDRY OPERATIONS, NEW LABORATORY-GRADE HIBERNATION FREEZER GROWTH CHAMBERS FOR DIAPAUSE AND SEASONAL TRANSITIONS, AN EXPANDED MICROCLIMATE MONITORING SYSTEM, AND AS WELL AS MATERIALS TO UPGRADE AND OR RE-PURPOSE EXISTING FACILITIES INTO DEDICATED REARING AND BREEDING SPACES.

FORESTED WATERSHEDS PROVIDE HAWAII WITH DRINKING WATER, CULTURAL RESOURCES, AND ARE HOME TO UNIQUE PLANTS AND WILDLIFE FOUND NOWHERE ELSE IN THE WORLD. PROTECTION IS NEEDED TO SAFEGUARD THESE INVALUABLE RESOURCES IN THE FACE OF THREATS SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES AND CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE FORESTS HAVE SIGNIFICANT ECONOMIC VALUE BECAUSE THEY REDUCE EROSION AND FLOODING, AS WELL AS CAPTURE FRESH WATER. PROTECTING THESE FORESTS IS THE TOP PRIORITY ACTION FOR STORING CARBON ON NATURAL AND WORKING LANDS ACCORDING TO THE HAWAII STATE GREENHOUSE GAS SEQUESTRATION TASK FORCE. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO LIKELY RESULT IN THE RECOVERY OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED PLANTS AND ANIMALS.THE STATE, WITH THE HELP OF PARTNERS, HAS CREATED COMPREHENSIVE WATERSHED MANAGEMENT PLANS TO PROTECT THESE FORESTS. THIS EAST MAUI PROJECT WILL REMOVE HIGH-PRIORITY INVASIVE PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES, PROVIDING DIRECT BENEFITS TO OVER 17,000 ACRES OF HIGH VALUE WATERSHED FORESTS.

AS A RECOVERY PROGRAM PARTNER, THE OREGON ZOO OPERATES THE SECOND-LARGEST OF FOUR CALIFORNIA CONDOR BREEDING FACILITIES IN THE WORLD, AND PLAYS A VITAL ROLE IN PREVENTING THE EXTINCTION OF THIS CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES.THE CONDOR RESTORATION RESILIENCY PROJECT WILL INVEST  2 MILLION IN CONGRESSIONALLY DIRECTED FUNDING TOWARDS IMPROVEMENTS TO THE OREGON ZOO S JONSSON CENTER FOR WILDLIFE CONSERVATION. THIS PROJECT WILL ENSURE THAT CONDOR BREEDING EFFORTS AT THE CENTER CAN CONTINUE SAFELY AND UNINTERRUPTED BY THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AS WELL AS PROTECT THE FUTURE GROWTH OF THE PROGRAM.THE FUNDING COULD SUPPORT ANY TO ALL OF THE FOLLOWING PROJECTS: INSTALLATION OF EMERGENCY POWER GENERATOR, ROAD IMPROVEMENTS AND CULVERT REPLACEMENT TO REDUCE FLOODING, ADDITION OF CONDOR DESENSITIZATION PENS, ADDITION OF VISUAL BARRIERS ALONG ACCESS ROADS AND UPGRADED WATER PIPING FROM THE WELL TO BUILDINGS.THROUGH THIS RESILIENCY EFFORT, THE OREGON ZOO WILL CONTINUE TO MAKE A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE SURVIVAL OF THIS SPECIES, ADVANCING THE COLLABORATIVE RECOVERY PROGRAM TOWARD ITS GOALS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE RECOVERY OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (RPBB) BY EXPLORING THE PESTICIDE RISK IN DIFFERENT HABITATS ACROSS SOUTHERN MICHIGAN, OHIO, AND INDIANA. WE WILL DO THIS BY MEASURING PESTICIDE RESIDUES ON COLLECTIONS OF A SURROGATE SPECIES, THE COMMON EASTERN BUMBLE BEE, WHICH OCCUPIES A SIMILAR RANGE AS THE RPBB TO ASSESS THE RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN LANDSCAPE COMPOSITION, PESTICIDE EXPOSURE, AND BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY HEALTH. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED BY DETERMINING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN PESTICIDE EXPOSURE (USING A RISK QUOTIENT APPROACH) AND SURROUNDING HABITAT CONTEXT. WE WILL ALSO DETERMINE THE SPATIAL EXTENT AT WHICH NATURAL LANDSCAPES BUFFER AGAINST PESTICIDE EXPOSURE. WE WILL ALSO DETERMINE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN LANDSCAPE LEVEL PESTICIDE EXPOSURE AND THE BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY STRUCTURE (I.E. BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY HEALTH.COLLECTIONS OF BUMBLE BEE SAMPLES FOR PESTICIDE ANALYSES WILL BE MADE AT 40 SITES HISTORICALLY CURRENTLY OCCUPIED BY RPBB WITHIN CONSERVATION UNIT 3. SITES WILL BE SELECTED TO MAXIMIZE VARIABILITY IN LANDSCAPE HETEROGENEITY IN ORDER TO MEET OUR OBJECTIVES. WE WILL VISIT EACH SITE TWICE DURING 2023 TO COLLECT BEE SAMPLES TO BE PROCESSED FOR ANALYSIS OF THEIR PESTICIDE RESIDUES. WE WILL WORK WITH AGENCY PARTNERS TO IDENTIFY SAMPLING LOCATIONS, WHICH WILL LIKELY INCLUDE BOTH HISTORICALLY AND CURRENTLY OCCUPIED RPBB HABITATS IN THE THREE STATES MENTIONED ABOVE. WE WILL WORK DIRECTLY WITH LANDOWNERS TO GAIN APPROVALS FOR COLLECTIONS. BEES WILL BE COLLECTED, CHILLED, IDENTIFIED, AND THEN AGGREGATED INTO SAMPLES FOR PESTICIDE ANALYSIS. THESE SAMPLES WILL BE EXTRACTED USING APPROPRIATE SOLVENTS, AND THEN SUBJECTED TO CHEMICAL ANALYSIS TO DETERMINE THE IDENTITY AND CONCENTRATIONS OF PESTICIDES IN THE SAMPLES. DATA WILL BE CLEANED AND ANALYZED TO COMPARE DATA ACROSS LANDSCAPES COMPOSITION AND TO COMPARE DIFFERENT TYPES OF HABITATS. WE EXPECT THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A VIEW OF THE RELATIVE PESTICIDE RISK OF DIFFERENT LOCATION TYPES TO AID IN PRIORITIZING CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF DECLINING BUMBLE BEE SPECIES. IT WILL ALSO BE VALUABLE IN THE EVENT THAT FUTURE PROGRAMS FOR REINTRODUCTION OF RPBB ARE DEVELOPED IN MICHIGAN OR ELSEWHERE IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION.THIS PROJECT WILL DELIVER NEW INFORMATION ON THE TYPES OF PESTICIDES AND THEIR CONCENTRATIONS ON BUMBLE BEES IN DIFFERENT HABITAT TYPES. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE USFWS IN ANNUAL REPORTS, ALONG WITH THE ANALYSIS OF RESIDUES IN RELATION TO HABITAT TYPES.WE EXPECT THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW FOR IDENTIFICATION OF CHARACTERISTICS OF AREAS WITH LOWER PESTICIDE RISK, AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR FUTURE TARGET AREAS TO CONSIDER FOR RELEASES. IN THE LONG RUN, WE HOPE THESE DATA WILL HELP TO INFORM SPATIAL DATABASES THAT CAN INTEGRATE HABITAT SUITABILITY FOR FORAGING, NESTING, AND LOWER PESTICIDE RISK.

IN THIS PROJECT, THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE (NPT) WILL IMPLEMENT PRIORITIES OF THE NORTHEASTERN OREGON SOUTHEASTERN WASHINGTON BULL TROUT MONITORING STRATEGY WITH A FOCUS ON CONTINUING LONG-TERM MONITORING VIA SPAWNING GROUND SURVEYS (REDD COUNTS) IN PRIORITY STREAMS AND FILLING KNOWLEDGE GAPS ON DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF BULL TROUT AND BROOK TROUT, ESPECIALLY IN BASINS WHERE HYBRIDIZATION IS A PRIMARY THREAT. THE NPT WILL COORDINATE WITH PARTNER AGENCIES (US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE, US FOREST SERVICE, AND OTHERS) TO IMPLEMENT THIS PROJECT AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE COLLECTIVE RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR BULL TROUT.

THE PURPOSE IF THIS AWARD IS TO SUPPORT GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER RECOVERY AT THE CAT ISLAND CHAIN IN LOWER GREENBAY. AGL WILL COORDINATE EFFORTS BY USFWS, WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WDNR), UNIVERSITY OFWISCONSIN-GREEN BAY (UWGB), AND NORTHEAST WISCONSIN AUDUBON (NEWI AUDUBON) TO ENSURE PIPL ARE MONITORED DAILY.AGL WISCONSIN CONSERVATION MANAGER TOM PRESTBY WILL OVERSEE MANAGE ASPECTS OF MONITORING INCLUDING TRAINING,SCHEDULING, QUALITY DATA COLLECTION AND COMMUNICATION, AND NOTIFYING USFWS OF URGENT DEVELOPMENTS IMMEDIATELY.USFWS IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SURVEYING TWO DAYS PER WEEK, WDNR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SURVEYING ONE DAY PER WEEK, AND AGLWILL COORDINATE AMONGST AGL, UWGB, AND NEWI AUDUBON MONITORS TO COVER THE REMAINING FOUR DAYS PER WEEK. TOMPRESTBY WILL WORK WITH USFWS BIOLOGIST JADE ARNESON TO ENSURE THAT QUALITY DATA ARE BEING COLLECTED VIA THE NESTSTORY PLATFORM. JADE ARNESON WILL COMMUNICATE DATA TO THE USFWS PIPL CONSERVATION TEAM.

TRACKING THE STATUS AND PROGRESS OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES RECOVERY EFFORTS REQUIRES INFORMATION ON THE SPECIES DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND POPULATION TRENDS. THE STREAKED HORNED LARK (SHLA) IS A FEDERALLY-THREATENED SUBSPECIES THAT OCCURS IN EARLY-SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT, INCLUDING AGRICULTURAL LANDS, IN WASHINGTON AND OREGON. PEARSON ET AL. (2016) DEVELOPED A STANDARDIZED MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR USE AT OCCUPIED SITES WITH WELL-DEFINED BOUNDARIES AND TO WHICH ACCESS IS ALLOWED (E.G., AIRFIELDS, PRAIRIES, COLUMBIA RIVER DEPOSITION ISLANDS). HOWEVER, A MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR SHLAS ON PRIVATE LANDS IN AGRICULTURAL HABITATS OF THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY, OR, WHERE   50  OF THE SHLAS RANGE-WIDE POPULATION LIKELY BREEDS, IS LACKING. ACCORDINGLY, THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR SHLAS IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY IS IDENTIFIED AS A CRITICAL NEED IN THE SPECIES DRAFT RECOVERY PLAN AND IS THE #1 RANKED PRIORITY IN THE 2021 SHLA ACTION PLAN. IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE OUTLINE A MULTI-PHASED PROPOSAL THAT DEVELOPS A ROAD-BASED SURVEY PROTOCOL FOR SHLAS IN THIS REGION. RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO RECOMMEND A FULL-SCALE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR MONITORING SHLA IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY CAPABLE OF ESTIMATING POPULATION SIZE AND TRACKING POPULATION TRENDS. IN COMBINATION WITH THE PEARSON ET AL. (2016) PROTOCOL, IT WILL BE POSSIBLE TO ESTIMATE RANGE-WIDE POPULATION ABUNDANCE AND TRENDS. THIS INFORMATION WOULD YIELD A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF SHLA POPULATION DYNAMICS, WHICH IS NECESSARY TO SUPPORT RECOVERY AND CONSERVATION OF THE SUBSPECIES.

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE PRIMARY ISSUE PREVENTING RECOVERY OF THE ENDANGERED CALIFORNIA CONDOR - LEAD TOXICOSIS RESULTING FROM INGESTION OF CARRION TAINTED WITH LEAD AMMUNITION. PERVASIVE THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES RANGE, IT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MORE THAN HALF OF ALL KNOWN CONDOR MORTALITY. A SELF-SUSTAINING, WILD POPULATION IS NOT THOUGHT TO BE ACHIEVABLE WHILE INGESTION OF LEAD AMMUNITION IS COMMON. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT CALIFORNIA CONDOR RECOVERY VIA INCREASED POPULATION SUSTAINABILITY VIA THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: (1) INCREASED OUTREACH TO PROMOTE USE OF NONLEAD AMMUNITION IN THE NORTHERN CALIFORNIA CONDOR RESTORATION PROGRAM (NCCRP) MANAGEMENT AREA, MANAGED BY THE YUROK TRIBE, IN COORDINATION WITH VENTANA WILDLIFE SOCIETY AND THE PINNACLES NATIONAL PARK  (2) INVESTMENT IN INFRASTRUCTURE TO IDENTIFY AND TREAT LEAD-POISONED CONDORS IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA AND CONTRIBUTE INFORMATION TO RECOVERY COORDINATION AND IMPROVEMENT  AND (3) INCREASE CAPACITY ACROSS NORTHERN CALIFORNIA TO RESPOND TO AND TREAT LEAD TOXICOSIS IN FREE-FLYING CONDORS.THE PROJECT WILL BE CONDUCTED WITHIN THE NCCRP IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA, WITH CONDOR MANAGEMENT BEING CENTERED AT THE NCCRP RELEASE AND MANAGEMENT FACILITY IN REDWOOD NATIONAL PARKS WITHIN YUROK ANCESTRAL TERRITORY IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT IS PROPOSED TO BE ACTIVE FROM FEBRUARY 24, 2023 THROUGH MARCH 31, 2024.

THIS PROJECT IS A SURVEY FOR BUMBLE BEES (BOMBUS SPP.), INCLUDING THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED BOMBUS AFFINIS (RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE), IN THE GREAT LAKES WATERSHEDS OF PENNSYLVANIA. THE SURVEY WILL TARGET THE LAKE ERIE WATERSHED IN ERIE AND CRAWFORD COUNTIES (512 SQ. MI.) AND THE UPPER GENESEE RIVER WATERSHED IN POTTER COUNTY (99 SQ. MI.). THESE WATERSHEDS ARE WITHIN THE HISTORIC RANGE OF B. AFFINIS, BUT THAT SPECIES HAS NOT BEEN SEEN IN PENNSYLVANIA IN RECENT YEARS. EIGHTEEN SPECIES OF BUMBLE BEE OCCUR IN PENNSYLVANIA, INCLUDING SPECIES OF GREATEST CONSERVATION NEED. OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND CONSERVATION STATUS OF BUMBLE BEES IN PENNSYLVANIA IS HAMPERED BY A LACK OF SURVEYS FOCUSED ON THIS GROUP. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE DATA GAP BY COMPLETING 20 30 SURVEYS IN THE GREAT LAKES WATERSHEDS IN PENNSYLVANIA. DISCOVERY OF A DISJUNCT POPULATION OF B. AFFINIS WOULD BE IMPORTANT FOR THE RECOVERY OF THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND WOULD REPRESENT A POTENTIAL RESERVOIR OF GENETIC DIVERSITY. SUCH A POPULATION WOULD BE A HIGH PRIORITY FOR MANAGEMENT OR RESTORATION EFFORTS.

THE MISSISSIPPI SANDHILL CRANE IS AN ENDANGERED NON MIGRATORY SUBSPECIES FOUND IN THE WILD ON AND NEAR THE MISSISSIPPI SANDHILL CRANE NWR. HISTORICALLY SOME AREAS OF MSCNWR HAVE HAD MORE SUCCESS NESTING AND FLEDGING CRANE CHICKS THAN OTHER AREAS. GIS ANALYSIS WILL BE USED TO INVESTIGATE DIFFERENCES IN HABITAT BETWEEN THE MORE AND LESS SUCCESSFUL AREAS, WHICH MAY ACCOUNT FOR THE DIFFERENTIAL NESTING AND FLEDGING SUCCESS. THIS INFORMATION CAN BE USED TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS, RESULTING IN INCREASED RECRUITMENT AND PROGRESS TO MEETING KEY SPECIES RECOVERY GOALS.

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE PRIMARY ISSUE PREVENTING RECOVERY OF THE ENDANGERED CALIFORNIA CONDOR LEAD TOXICOSISRESULTING FROM INGESTION OF CARRION TAINTED WITH LEAD AMMUNITION. PERVASIVE THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES  RANGE, IT ISRESPONSIBLE FOR HALF OF ALL KNOWN CONDOR MORTALITY. A SELF SUSTAINING, WILD POPULATION IS NOT THOUGHT TO BEACHIEVABLE WHILE INGESTION OF LEAD AMMUNITION IS COMMON. OVER THE PAST THREE DECADES, THE CALIFORNIA CONDORRECOVERY PROGRAM HAS FOCUSED FIELD EFFORTS, RESEARCH, AND RESOURCES TOWARD IDENTIFYING, UNDERSTANDING, ANDCOMBATING THE THREATS POSED TO CONDORS FROM LEAD. THIS PROJECT IS A JOINT PROPOSAL WITH BENEFITS EXPECTED ACROSSTHE NORTHERN, CENTRAL, AND SOUTHERN CONDOR MANAGEMENT AREAS AND POTENTIALLY THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE RANGE. IT WILLADDRESS THE PRIMARY THREAT OF LEAD CONTAMINATION THROUGH OUTREACH CONDUCTED BY VENTANA WILDLIFE SOCIETYSPECIALISTS TO SPORTING GROUPS, HUNTERS, RANCHERS, AND OTHERS. AN ADDITIONAL PART TIME OUTREACH SPECIALIST WILLBE ADDED TO THE VWS TEAM. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT VWS S CAPACITY TO DISTRIBUTE FREE NON LEAD AMMUNITIONTHROUGHOUT CA, AND INCREASE CAPACITY IN CENTRAL CA, FURTHER REDUCING THE USE OF LEAD AMMUNITION. THROUGH THESEEFFORTS WE ADDRESS A PRIMARY OBJECTIVE IN THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE CALIFORNIA CONDOR (USFWS 1996).

THE CYPRESS CHAPTER, INC. OF THE IZAAK WALTON LEAGUE OF AMERICA WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A WORK PLAN OF VOLUNTEER CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES AND WORKSHOPS IN SUPPORT OF SOUTH FLORIDA FEDERAL TRUST RESOURCES PRIMARILY ON PUBLIC LAND WITH POTENTIAL FOR PRIVATE LAND ACTIVITIES AS WELL. THE WORK PLAN WILL IDENTIFY NEEDS OF THE SITES, DESCRIBE THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF PROJECTS, THE ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF ANY PARTNERS INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT, PROJECT SCHEDULE, PROJECT OUTCOMES AND PERFORMANCE MEASURES.

THIS PROJECT WILL PERFORM SURVEILLANCE OF THE BASELINE WILD TYPE CQ MOSQUITO POPULATION IN MUTUALLY AGREED UPON AREAS WITHIN KAUAI AND BEGIN NECESSARY PREPARATIONS (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO PERMITTING, COMMUNITY OUTREACH, EQUIPMENT IMPORTATION AND TRAININGS, EVALUATION OF AERIAL RELEASE METHOD(S), AND MRR STUDIES) FOR A POTENTIAL FUTURE PHASE 2 THAT INVOLVE RELEASES OF IIT CQ MALES TO SUPPRESS THE POPULATION OF WILD TYPE CQ MOSQUITOES IN TREATED AREAS ON KAUAI. THE WORK SUBCONTRACTED THRU THIS PROPOSAL WILL BE USED BY THE STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LANDS AND NATURAL RESOURCES, THE FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, AND THE NATURE CONSERVANCY, AND OTHER BIRDS NOT MOSQUITOES PARTNERS TO ADVANCE IMPLEMENTATION OF A WOLBACHIA INSECT INCOMPATIBLE TECHNIQUE MOSQUITO SUPPRESSION CAMPAIGN ON KAUAI ISLAND TO ADDRESS CONTINUED FOREST BIRD LOSS. TNC AND THE SUBCONTRACTOR WILL WORK WITH USFWS AND CONSERVATION PARTNERS ON UNDERSTANDING THE DATA AND APPLYING IT TOWARDS IIT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS.

THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TWOFOLD  (1) CREATE A NEW SPATIALLY EXPLICIT MODEL OF HABITATS IN THE STATE OF FLORIDA THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF THE ENDANGERED FLORIDA PANTHER, AND (2) INCORPORATE MODEL RESULTS INTO VERSION 2.0 OF THE USFWS FLORIDA PANTHER SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT.  VERSION 1.0 OF THE PANTHER SSA, RELEASED TO THE PUBLIC IN OCTOBER 2021, INCLUDED BASE MODELS OF POTENTIALLY SUITABLE PANTHER HABITATS IN FLORIDA THAT WERE FURTHER REFINED THROUGH A SERIES OF GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM (GIS) ANALYSES TO IDENTIFY REGIONS OF FLORIDA WITH THE POTENTIAL TO SUPPORT VIABLE POPULATIONS OR SUBPOPULATIONS OF PANTHERS IN THE FUTURE.  THE BASE HABITAT MODEL USED IN THE PANTHER SSA HAS BEEN CRITICIZED FOR BEING BUILT FROM GIS DATA LAYERS THAT ARE OUT OF DATE.  MOREOVER, AN ANONYMOUS THIRD PARTY PEER REVIEW OF THE PANTHER SSA HAS FOUND THAT THE METHODOLOGY USED TO CREATE THE BASE HABITAT MODELS WAS POORLY DOCUMENTED, AND, THEREFORE, THAT MODELING EFFORT WAS NEITHER TRANSPARENT NOR REPRODUCIBLE.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL CORRECT THESE DEFICIENCIES BY PRODUCING AN UPDATED PANTHER HABITAT MODEL THAT IS BASED ON THE MOST RECENT PUBLICLY AVAILABLE LAND USE AND LAND COVER DATA LAYERS FOR FLORIDA.  THE MODELING METHODOLOGY WILL BE FULLY DESCRIBED TO ENSURE TRANSPARENCY AND FUTURE REPRODUCIBILITY.  THE HABITAT MODEL WILL BE BASED ON THE MOST RECENT STATEWIDE FLORIDA COOPERATIVE LAND COVER GIS DATABASE (I.E., NOVEMBER 2021 AS OF THIS WRITING) AVAILABLE FROM THE FLORIDA FISH AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION COMMISSION (FFWCC) WEB SITE.  A BRIEF SUMMARY OF MODEL STEPS IS AS FOLLOWS   (1) ISOLATE FOREST COVER, THE PRIMARY HABITAT OF PANTHERS, FROM THE DATABASE  (2) ADD TO FOREST COVER PREFERRED OPEN COVER TYPES WITHIN A SPECIFIED DISTANCE FROM FOREST COVER BASED ON OBSERVATIONS OF PANTHER MOVEMENTS  (3) REGION GROUP AREAS IDENTIFIED IN STEPS 1 AND 2 TO CREATE INDIVIDUAL HABITAT PATCHES AND CALCULATE THE SIZE OF EACH PATCH  (4) SEGREGATE PATCH SIZES INTO CATEGORIES OF LIKELIHOOD TO SUPPORT PANTHERS  (5) IDENTIFY SMALL PATCHES THAT FALL WITHIN THE FLORIDA WILDLIFE CORRIDOR DATABASE THAT MAY FUNCTION AS LANDSCAPE LINKAGES TO ACCOMMODATE PANTHER MOVEMENTS AMONG LARGER PATCHES  AND (6) CONSOLIDATE THE PRODUCTS OF THESE STEPS INTO A FINAL STATEWIDE PANTHER HABITAT MODEL.  THE HABITAT MODEL WILL BE USED TO ASSESS THE LIKELIHOOD OF FUTURE HABITAT LOSS TO GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT AND SEA LEVEL RISE.  THESE RESULTS WILL BE USED TO CREATE FIGURES, TABLES, AND TEXT TO UPDATE THE HABITAT SUITABILITY SECTIONS FOR VERSION 2.0 OF THE PANTHER SSA.

DEGRADED WATER QUALITY CAN BE HARMFUL TO FRESHWATER MUSSELS. A 2014 STUDY INVESTIGATED WHETHER THE CONTRACTION IN DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL DISTRIBUTION THAT OCCURRED BETWEEN 2002 AND 2012 WITHIN BROWNS BRANCH, WHICH IS AN AGRICULTURAL WATERSHED, WAS ASSOCIATED WITH WATER QUALITY. ONE SITE IN NANJEMOY CREEK WAS ALSO SAMPLED, WHICH IS IN A FORESTED WATERSHED WHERE DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL DISTRIBUTION EXHIBITED NO CHANGE OVER THE SAME TIME. TOTAL AMMONIA NITROGEN (TAN) WAS THE ONLY ANALYTE CONSISTENT WITH THE HYPOTHESIS THAT CONCENTRATIONS OF POTENTIALLY TOXIC ANALYTES WERE SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER IN BOTH SURFACE AND POREWATER WHERE CONTRACTION IN DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL OCCURRED IN BROWNS BRANCH.IN 2022, WE BEGAN SAMPLING SURFACE AND POREWATER AT THE SAME SITES ALONG WITH ADDITIONAL SITES IN EACH STREAM TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE RELATION BETWEEN TAN AND MUSSEL DISTRIBUTION. IN 2023, WE PROPOSE TO COLLECT ADDITIONAL WATER SAMPLES TO ASSESS INTER ANNUAL DIFFERENCES. IN 2024, WATER SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED FROM THREE BRIDGES BRANCH AND OR MCINTOSH RUN, WHERE MUSSEL SURVEYS WILL HAVE BEEN RECENTLY COMPLETED AND TAN IN SURFACE WATER IS HIGHER THAN NANJEMOY CREEK. ABOUT 130 COMBINED SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED OVER TWO YEARS. THIS INFORMATION MAY BE USEFUL TO UNDERSTAND POPULATION CONTRACTION RECENTLY FOUND IN MCINTOSH RUN, INFORM NON POINT SOURCE POLLUTION MANAGEMENT IN THREE BRIDGES BRANCH, AND EVALUATE LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PRACTICES IN THE BROWNS BRANCH WATERSHED. FIELD AND ANALYTICAL WORK WILL OCCUR FROM JANUARY 2023 DECEMBER 2024.RECOVERY OBJECTIVES UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT FOR DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL INCLUDE DOCUMENTING VIABLE POPULATIONS OVER AN EXTENDED PERIOD OF TIME TO DEMONSTRATE STABILITY IN ABUNDANCE AND RECRUITMENT. THIS SPECIES EXISTS IN FIVE SMALL STREAMS IN MARYLAND  THE NANJEMOY CREEK POPULATION IS THE LARGEST AND EXISTS IN A MINIMALLY DISTURBED WATERSHED. THE POPULATION IN THE BROWNS BRANCH WATERSHED APPEARS TO BE IN DECLINE, BUT COULD BE RECOVERED BY PROPOSED LANDSCAPE RESTORATION AND POPULATION AUGMENTATION. AN UNDERSTANDING OF DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL DEMOGRAPHICS IS NEEDED TO MANAGE OR RESTORE THEIR POPULATIONS. THIS REQUIRES REPEATED SAMPLING (CAPTURE MARK RECAPTURE) FROM WITHIN HABITAT OR POPULATION OF INTEREST. WE PREVIOUSLY USED A ROBUST SAMPLING DESIGN AT FOUR SITES IN EACH STREAM TO ESTIMATE DETECTION PROBABILITY AND APPARENT SURVIVAL OF PIT TAGGED DWARF WEDGEMUSSEL BY MONITORING WITH A SUBMERSIBLE PIT TAG READER DURING FOUR SECONDARY MONITORING EVENTS IN TWO PRIMARY SAMPLING PERIODS (FALL AND SPRING) AFTER MARKING. A VISUAL SURVEY WAS DONE IN THE SUMMER PRIOR TO STARTING MONITORING AND AFTER THE SPRING PERIOD TO MEASURE MUSSEL GROWTH AND TAG ANY UNMARKED MUSSELS.WE RECOVERED A MAJORITY OF THE PIT TAGGED MUSSELS IN THE FALL, BUT RECOVERED LESS MUSSELS THE FOLLOWING SPRING, POSSIBLY DUE TO A COMBINATION OF TAG LOSS, IMMIGRATION, AND MORTALITY. WE RECAPTURED A LOW PERCENTAGE OF TAGGED MUSSELS IN VISUAL SURVEYS AT ALL SITES. THIS SAMPLING PRODUCED A DATASET WITH ENOUGH OBSERVATIONS TO ESTIMATE INTRA ANNUAL SURVIVAL AND DETECTION PROBABILITY BECAUSE REPEATED PIT TAG BASED MONITORING RECOVERED A HIGH PERCENTAGE OF MARKED MUSSELS. HOWEVER, THIS CAME AT THE EXPENSE OF THE EFFORT NEEDED TO RECAPTURE MUSSELS. A CHANGE IN THE SAMPLING DESIGN IS WARRANTED TO COLLECT THIS DATA. IN 2023, WE PROPOSE USING REPEATED VISUAL AT TWO OF FOUR MONITORING SITES IN EACH STREAM TO IMPROVE RECAPTURE RATES TO BETTER QUANTIFY GROWTH RATES AND ESTIMATE POPULATION SIZE. AFTER THE VISUAL SURVEY, WE WILL USE THE PIT TAG READER TO ATTEMPT TO RECAPTURE UNDETECTED MUSSELS. A SINGLE VISUAL SURVEY IN THE SUMMER WILL TAKE PLACE AT THE OTHER TWO SITES IN EACH STREAM. BY CONTINUING THIS STUDY, WE WILL OBTAIN 1) A THIRD YEAR OF DATA ON POPULATION SIZE AND GROWTH IN NANJEMOY CREEK 2) A SECOND YEAR OF DEMOGRAPHIC DATA FOR BROWNS BRANCH PRIOR TO IMPLEMENTING LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PRACTICES. FIELD AND ANALYTICAL WORK WILL OCCUR FROM APRIL 2023 DECEMBER 2024.

HAWAII S NATIVE PLANTS ARE THE FOUNDATION OF FLOURISHING ECOSYSTEMS WHICH PROTECT OUR WATERSHEDS AND PROVIDE HABITAT FOR COUNTLESS OTHER ORGANISMS SUCH AS BIRDS, BATS, SNAILS, AND INSECTS. THEY PROTECT OUR OCEANS FROM RUNOFF AND OUR NEIGHBORHOODS FROM DANGEROUS FLOODING. NATIVE PLANTS ALSO HAVE A FUNDAMENTAL ROLE IN HAWAIIAN CULTURE. RARE PLANT NURSERIES PROVIDE THE THOUSANDS OF PLANTS NEEDED FOR RESTORING NATURAL AREAS. UPGRADES TO THESE NURSERIES ARE CRITICALLY NEEDED. THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE S  DOFAW  RARE PLANT PROGRAM OPERATES STATEWIDE TO CONSERVE AND PROTECT ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES. DOFAW STAFF AND OUR PARTNERS SCOUR NATURAL AREAS TO LOCATE REMNANT POPULATIONS OF RARE NATIVE PLANTS. ONCE FOUND, FENCES AND OTHER THREAT CONTROL IS INSTALLED TO PROTECT THE SITE. POPULATIONS OF RARE PLANTS CAN BE SLOW TO RECOVER ON THEIR OWN, SO COLLECTIONS OF SEEDS OR CLONES ARE TAKEN TO THE NEAREST RARE PLANT FACILITY OR SEED BANK. THESE FACILITIES ARE TRIAGE CENTERS FOR HAWAII S RAREST PLANTS, ENSURING THAT ANYTHING SALVAGED FROM THE WILD CAN SURVIVE UNDER BETTER CONDITIONS IN A NURSERY. ONCE RESCUED, PLANTS ARE REPLICATED AND PLANTED INTO PROTECTED HABITAT TO RESUME THEIR IMPORTANT ROLES IN NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS. THIS IS HOW EXTINCTION IS PREVENTED. IN THE LAST DECADE, BOTANISTS HAVE MADE COLLECTIONS FROM NEARLY ALL OF THE RAREST SPECIES. HOWEVER, NURSERY FACILITIES STATEWIDE ARE STILL OPERATING ON SMALL BUDGETS WITH MINIMAL STAFF USING MANUAL LABOR TO WATER AND MANAGE PESTS. AUTOMATING IRRIGATION SYSTEMS AND UPDATING EQUIPMENT WOULD GREATLY INCREASE PRODUCTIVITY AND EFFICIENCY AT EACH OF THESE FACILITIES. IN ADDITION, INSTALLING BACK-UP POWER AND WATER SUPPLIES, AS WELL AS HARDENING STRUCTURES NEEDS TO BE DONE BEFORE DISASTERS STRIKE THESE NURSERIES. WITH INCREASED SUPPORT FOR INFRASTRUCTURE UPGRADES AND BETTER STAFFING AT OUR NURSERIES, WE WILL BE ABLE TO MAXIMIZE FEDERAL FUNDING FOR THESE EFFORTS AND PRESERVE THESE PLANTS FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. WITHOUT IT, WE RISK LOSING MORE OF OUR NATIVE PLANTS TO EXTINCTION.

THE FOCUS WILL BE TO 1  CONDUCT SURVEYS AND HABITAT RESTORATION AT KNOWN AND POTENTIAL BOG TURTLE SITES AND 2  CONDUCT SURVEYS  STANDARDIZED MONITORING AND EDNA SAMPLE COLLECTION  AND HABITAT RESTORATION AT KNOWN AND POTENTIAL WOOD TURTLE SITES.THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO CONDUCT MORE SURVEYS AND HABITAT RESTORATION FOR BOTH SPECIES.

HAY S GROUNDWATER AMPHIPOD  STYGOBROMUS HAYI  IS A GLOBALLY RARE  G1  AND FEDERALLY ENDANGERED FRESHWATER CRANGONICTID CRUSTACEAN RESTRICTED TO FEDERAL LANDS WITHIN WASHINGTON, D.C.. DETECTION RECORDS ARE PRIMARILY FROM INTERMITTENT SPRINGS IN ROCK CREEK PARK, WITH ADDITIONAL RECORDS FROM THE NATIONAL ZOOLOGICAL PARK  TYPE LOCALITY . THIS DATA IS THE RESULT OF GROUNDWATER FAUNA SURVEYS CONDUCTED SPORADICALLY OVER A PERIOD OF DECADES, INITIALLY CONDUCTED BY THE COLLECTION, PRESERVATION, AND LABORATORY IDENTIFICATION OF AMPHIPODS AT POINTS OF GROUNDWATER EMERGENCE. IN 2021, EDNA SURVEYS WERE CONDUCTED WHICH RESULTED IN CONFIRMATION OF TWO SITES THAT WERE CONSIDERED  UNKNOWN  OR  PROBABLE  AND A DISCOVERY OF A NEW SITE.OBJECTIVES-THE FOCUS OF THIS STUDY WILL BE TO  1  UPDATE THE CURRENT STATUS OF ALL DOCUMENTED S. HAYI SPRINGEMERGENCE SITES IN WASHINGTON D.C. BY HAND COLLECTION, 2  SAMPLE ADDITIONAL SPRINGS WHERE EDNA DETECTED THE SPECIES  AND 3  OBTAIN GENETIC MATERIAL OF S. HAYI TO MAKE FUTURE EDNA ANALYSIS MORE ROBUST.THE FOCUS OF THIS STUDY WILL BE TO  1  UPDATE THE CURRENT STATUS OF ALL DOCUMENTED S. HAYI SPRINGEMERGENCE SITES IN WASHINGTON D.C. BY HAND COLLECTION, 2  SAMPLE ADDITIONAL SPRINGS WHERE EDNADETECTED THE SPECIES  AND 3  OBTAIN GENETIC MATERIAL OF S. HAYI TO MAKE FUTURE EDNA ANALYSIS MOREROBUST.COLLECTED SPECIMENS WILL BE IDENTIFIED BY DCRDNH AND ANY S. HAYI ANDS. KENKI WILL BE SENT TO THE USFWS S LAMAR FISH HEALTH CENTER FOR GENETIC ANALYSIS.

THE SANTA ANA SUCKER (CATASTOMUS SANTAANAE, HEREAFTER SUCKER) IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES FOUND IN THE SANTA ANA WATERSHED, THE SANTA CLARA RIVER, AND THE UPPER REGIONS OF THE LOS ANGELES AND SAN GABRIEL RIVERS. THREATS TO THE SUCKER IN ITS CURRENT RANGE INCLUDE HABITAT LOSS DUE TO MODIFICATION AND FRAGMENTATION, WATER QUALITY DEGRADATION, INTRODUCTION OF NONNATIVE SPECIES, AND LARGE-SCALE WATER REMOVAL FOR MUNICIPAL PURPOSES. THESE THREATS ARE DRIVEN BY THE ONGOING URBANIZATION AND HUMAN POPULATION GROWTH IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. CLIMATE CHANGE AND NON-ENVIRONMENTAL FLOWSHAVE MODIFIED THE HYDROLOGY OF THE URBAN SANTA ANA RIVER SINCE SANTA ANA SUCKER LIFE HISTORY WAS FIRST STUDIED. THIS HAS LEFT A KNOWLEDGE GAP ABOUT BASIC SANTA ANA SUCKER BIOLOGY NEEDED TO CONSERVE REMAINING POPULATIONS OF THE SPECIES.WHILE MONITORING OF SUCKER HAS IMPROVED IN RECENT YEARS, THERE ARE STILL MANY GAPS IN OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SUCKER BIOLOGY AND LIFE HISTORY, PARTICULARLY WITH RESPECT TO EARLY LIFE STAGES THAT ARE LIKELY HIGHLY SENSITIVE TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS. INDEED, ONLY ONE STUDY HAS EXAMINED THE EGG SURVIVAL AND LARVAL DEVELOPMENT OF SUCKER (GREENFIELD ET AL. 1970). OUR PROPOSED WORK WILL IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF SUCKER EGG AND LARVAL MORTALITY AND DEVELOPMENT UNDER THE RANGE OF TEMPERATURES FOUND IN THEIR EXTANT URBANIZED HABITAT IN THE SANTA ANA RIVER IN SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTIES. THIS WILL PROVIDE BADLY NEEDED INFORMATION TO RESEARCHERS AND MANAGERS ABOUT THE EXISTING (OR HOW CHANGES TO THE) THERMAL REGIME IN THE SANTA ANA RIVER MAY IMPACT SUCKER POPULATION VIABILITY.

THE PACIFIC POCKET MOUSE (PEROGNATHUS LONGIMEMBRIS PACIFICUS  PPM) IS AN ENDANGERED SPECIES, NATIVE TO THE COASTAL REGIONS OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. THERE ARE ONLY THREE TINY POPULATIONS REMAINING, WHICH ARE GENETICALLY AND GEOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED BY URBANIZATION. THE MAIN RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE SPECIES CALL FOR PRESERVING EXISTING POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT, AND FOR CREATING NEW POPULATIONS IN UNOCCUPIED HABITAT. CURRENTLY THERE ARE NO SITES WITHIN THE SPECIES HISTORIC RANGE THAT CONTAIN ENOUGH SUITABLE HABITAT (E.G., YOUNG COASTAL SAGE SCRUB OR DUNES WITH LOW NON-NATIVE GRASS COVER) TO SUPPORT A NEW POPULATION. IN ADDITION, THE THREE EXTANT POPULATIONS ARE TOO SMALL TO BE USED AS A SOURCE OF INDIVIDUALS FOR CREATING NEW POPULATIONS. THEREFORE IN 2012 A CONSERVATION BREEDING PROGRAM WAS INITIATED BASED ON THE FEEDBACK AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN COUNTY, STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS AND OTHER PARTNERS, RESEARCHERS, AND COMMUNITIES THATPARTICIPATE IN PPM RECOVERY. DESPITE PROGRAM SUCCESSES IN PRODUCING PPM IN CAPTIVITY AND FOUNDING A NEW POPULATION IN THE LAGUNA COAST WILDERNESS PARK, MAJOR HURDLES REMAIN FOR THE SPECIES. WE DO NOT YET KNOW THE OPTIMAL WAY TO RESTORE AND MANAGE RELEASE SITES TO ENCOURAGE PPM POPULATION ESTABLISHMENT. ALSO, GENETIC DIVERSITY IN THE REMAINING WILD POPULATIONS IS DECLINING, AND REINTRODUCTION METHODS NEED TO BE OPTIMIZED BEFORE NEW POPULATIONS WILL BE SELF-SUFFICIENT. WITH THIS PROPOSAL, WE AIM TO SUPPORT THE BREEDING AND REINTRODUCTION PROCESS FOR PPM, SAFEGUARD REMAINING GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND OUTLINE A PATH FOR THE BREAKTHROUGHS IN HABITAT RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT IN A HUMAN-DOMINATED LANDSCAPE WHICH WILL BE CRITICAL FOR PPM POPULATION CREATION, LONG-TERM SURVIVAL, AND RESILIENCY. SPECIFICALLY, WE (SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE) HAVE THREE MAIN AIMS WHICH WE WILL PURSUE IN CLOSE COLLABORATION AND CONSULTATION WITH MANY PARTNERS, INCLUDING UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, ORANGE COUNTY PARKS AND THE SAN DIEGO NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM. FIRST, USING RESEARCH TO FILL INFORMATION GAPS ON THE SPECIES NATURAL HISTORY, WE WILL CREATE A ROADMAP FOR PRODUCING LARGE NUMBERS OF BEHAVIORALLY FIT AND GENETICALLY REPRESENTATIVE PPM FOR REINTRODUCTIONS. WE WILL OPTIMIZE CONSERVATION BREEDING TO ENCOMPASS GREATER GENETIC DIVERSITY, ADDING 10 WILD PPM TO THE BREEDING PROGRAM, AND USING CUTTING EDGE HUSBANDRY, ASSISTED REPRODUCTIVE TECHNOLOGY, GENETIC MONITORING AND ENDOCRINE TECHNIQUES. SECOND, WE WILL IMPROVE OUR METHODS FOR PREPARING PPM FOR REINTRODUCTION, AND FOR RESTORING AND MANAGING SELECTED RELEASE SITES SO THAT THE TWO NEW RELEASED POPULATIONS WE PLAN TO INITIATE (EACH WITH UP TO 50 FOUNDER MICE) WILL HAVE THE BEST CHANCE OF ESTABLISHING AND PERSISTING. SHORT-TERM, SUMMER SURVIVAL FOLLOWING PREVIOUS REINTRODUCTIONS HAS BEEN HIGH DUE TO POST-RELEASE SUPPORT, SUCH AS SUPPLEMENTAL FEEDING AND PROTECTION FROM PREDATORS. BY OPTIMIZING HOW WE BEHAVIORALLY TRAIN PPM FOR THE CHALLENGES OF THE WILD, WHICH WILL HELP THEM SURVIVE WINTER, WE HOPE TO SEE THE RELEASED POPULATION BOOM. FINALLY, WE NEED TO IMPROVE LONGER TERMMANAGEMENT OF RELEASE SITES, WHICH WE WILL ONLY UNDERSTAND VIA MONITORING BOTH PPM AND THE SURROUNDING HABITAT. FOR INSTANCE, WE ARE HEAVILY RELIANT ON HUMAN MANAGEMENT OF RELEASE SITES, TO REDUCE PREDATION, AND OFFER SUPPLEMENTAL FOOD. WE WILL NEED TO LEARN HOW TO STEP BACK FROM THESE SUPPORTS TO HELP PPM BECOME INDEPENDENT AND CREATE RESILIENT NEW POPULATIONS. TOGETHER THESE THREE AIMS WILL HELP ACHIEVE THE CONSERVATION AND BREEDING PROGRAM GOAL OF CREATING THREE NEW POPULATIONS FROM ANIMALS PRODUCED IN CAPTIVITY. FUNDING THIS PROPOSAL WILL HELP RESTORE BIODIVERSITY FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS TO ENJOY, PROMOTE RESILIENCE OF THIS UNIQUEECOSYSTEM, WHICH IS HOME TO MANY CALIFORNIA NATIVE SPECIES, AND REDUCE FIRE RISK IN HIGHLY POPULATED COASTAL LANDSCAPES.

WHILE PREVIOUS RESEARCH ESTIMATES THAT THE ENDANGERED PUAIOHI HAS A STABLE POPULATION OF ABOUT 500 BIRDS, RECENT OBSERVATIONS IN THE FIELD SUGGEST THAT AT SOME SITES IT IS RAPIDLY DECLINING. POPULATION VIABILITY MODELS SUGGEST THAT THE SPECIES COULD FACE INCREASED EXTINCTION RISK IF FACTORS SUCH AS PREDATION ARE NOT MITIGATED. CURRENTLY RATS ARE SUPPRESSED IN TWO LANDSCAPE-LEVEL MANAGEMENT UNITS IN THE REMAINING PUAIOHI RANGE WITH GOODNATURE A24 RAT TRAPS. THESE EFFORTS HAVE REDUCED RAT ABUNDANCE, BUT PERHAPS NOT TO A LEVEL THAT DEMONSTRATES AN EFFECT ON NATIVE BIRDS. IN FACT, OVER THE PAST 2 YEARS BANDING AND NESTLING SURVIVAL DATA HAVE NOT INDICATED BIOLOGICALLY DIFFERENT ESTIMATES BETWEEN TRAPPED AND UNTRAPPED LOCATIONS. FUTHERMORE, OTHER FACTORS, SUCH AS DISEASE, MAY IMPACT PUAIOHI SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTION. WE PROPOSE TO MONITOR POPULATIONS OF PUAIOHI AND OTHER NATIVE FOREST BIRDS ON STREAMS WITHIN AND OUTSIDE RAT TRAPPING GRIDS FOR ONE YEAR DURING THE BREEDING SEASON USING AN OCCUPANCY ANALYSIS FRAMEWORK. WE WILL COMPARE THESE DATA TO OCCUPANCY SURVEYS CONDUCTED ON THESE SAME STREAMS IN 2012 AND 2018 TO 1) EXAMINE TEMPORAL TRENDS IN PUAIOHI OCCUPANCY AND 2) ASSESS IMPACTS OF RODENT CONTROL ON PUAIOHI OCCUPANCY, SHOULD WE ACHIEVE SUFFICIENT STATISTICAL POWER. WE HOPE TO LEVERAGE OTHER FUNDS TO ALSO COLLECT DATA WITH SONG METERS, ASSESS RODENT ABUNDANCE, AND MONITOR NEST SURVIVAL ON AT LEAST TWO OF THESE STREAMS TO GAIN A BETTER PICTURE OF PUAIOHI POPULATION TRENDS AND IMPACTS OF THREATS, SUCH AS RODENT PREDATION, ON THIS SPECIES. THIS STUDY IS A CRITICAL NEXT STEP TO INFORM RAT CONTROL AND OTHER MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO PROTECT THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES FROM EXTINCTION.

THE PROPERTIES SURROUNDING HAGG LAKE, LOCATED SOUTHWEST OF PORTLAND, OREGON IN THE SALEM WEST RECOVERY ZONE, ARE HOME TO RARE WILLAMETTE VALLEY PRAIRIE AND OAK HABITAT AND HOST POPULATIONS OF TWO FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES: FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY (FBB, ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI  THREATENED) AND KINCAID S LUPINE (LUPINUS OREGANUS, THREATENED). THIS PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE ON THE PRAIRIE AND OAK HABITATS ADJACENT TO HAGG LAKE OWNED BY BUREAU OF RECLAMATION (BOR). PROJECT FUNDS ARE PROVIDED THROUGH AN INTERAGENCY AGREEMENT WITH BOR. THE OVERALL GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO, WITH THE COLLABORATION OF THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OREGON FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE (USFWS OFWO), EXPAND AND IMPROVE FBB AND KINCAID S LUPINE HABITAT AND ULTIMATELY INCREASE POPULATION SIZES OF BOTH SPECIES. PROPOSED WORK ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE  MONITORING OF FBB POPULATIONS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO TRACK SPECIES RECOVERY AND DOCUMENT RESULTS OF CURRENT AND ONGOING HABITAT RESTORATION, CONDUCTING REVEGETATION WITH NATIVE SPECIES TO REACH RECOVERY PLAN HABITAT QUALITY BENCHMARKS FOR FBB AND KINCAID S LUPINE AND TO ENHANCE THE VALUE OF THE SITE FOR RECREATION AND ENJOYMENT BY THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, PERFORM HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS THAT REDUCE COVER OF NON-NATIVE AND INVASIVE NATIVE SPECIES AND PREPARE THE SITE FOR NATIVE SPECIES REVEGETATION IMPLEMENTATION.

FOR OVER A DECADE SAN JUAN ISLAND NATIONAL HISTORICAL PARK, NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) HAS BEEN RAISING ISLANDMARBLE BUTTERFLIES IN A CAPTIVE PROPAGATION FACILITY IN SUPPORT OF CONSERVATION STRATEGIES DEVELOPED WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND OTHER PARTNERS. IN FISCAL YEAR (FY) 2024, THE NPS WILL PIVOT PRIORITIESAND FOCUS ON RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF IMB HABITAT IN SUPPORT OF THE USFWS RECOVERY PLAN (RP), RECOVERYIMPLEMENTATION PLAN (RIP), AND THE NPS VEGETATION AND ISLAND MARBLE BUTTERFLY RECOVERY. THE NPS WILL NO LONGERHAVE THE RESOURCES OR STAFF NECESSARY TO MAINTAIN THE CAPTIVE PROPAGATION PROGRAM. IF THIS PROPOSAL IS FUNDED,ON SACRED GROUND (OSG) WILL UNDERTAKE ALL PERMITTING, STAFFING, EQUIPMENT MAINTENANCE, PROPAGATION, ANDRESPONSIBILITY FOR INDIVIDUAL ISLAND MARBLE BUTTERFLIES BROUGHT INTO THE CAPTIVE PROPAGATION FACILITY IN 2024.

THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE GENETIC DIVERSITY, POPULATION-LEVEL GENE FLOW AND SOIL REQUIREMENTS OF WHITE BLUFFS BLADDER POD (PHYSARIA DOUGLASII SSP. TUPLASHENSIS). WE WILL EVALUATE KEY POPULATION GENETIC STATISTICS TO UNDERSTAND GENETIC DIVERSITY OF THE NATIVE POPULATION, THE RISK OF INBREEDING DEPRESSION AND THE HYBRIDIZATION RISK WITH NEARBY POPULATIONS OF P. D. SPP. DOUGLASII. THIS INFORMATION WILL HELP DIRECT MANAGEMENT PRIORITIES AND WILL IMPROVE SUCCESS OF FUTURE INTRODUCTION EFFORTS. WE WILL ALSO EVALUATE HOW SOILS ENVIRONMENT EFFECTS PLANT GROWTH AND VIGOR TO DETERMINE WHETHER THIS SPECIES IS AN EDAPHIC SPECIALIST. THIS INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO DEVELOP AN EFFECTIVE INTRODUCTION PLAN FOR RECOVERY OF WHITE BLUFFS BLADDERPOD.

THE ENDANGERED WHOOPING CRANE IS ONE OF THE RAREST AND MOST THREATENED BIRD SPECIES IN NORTH AMERICA. SINCE 2001, THE INTERNATIONAL CRANE FOUNDATION (ICF) HAS BEEN A LEADER IN REINTRODUCING WHOOPING CRANES IN THE EASTERN U.S. THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH THE WHOOPING CRANE REINTRODUCTION TEAM, WE ARE BREEDING AND RAISING WHOOPING CRANES AT ICF AND RELEASING THEM ON WETLAND WILDLIFE REFUGES PRIMARILY IN WISCONSIN AND LOUISIANA. PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE BREEDING, REARING, AND RELEASING WHOOPING CRANES, WHILE MAXIMIZING GENETIC DIVERSITY, PRODUCTIVITY, AND SURVIVAL. ANOTHER GOAL INCLUDES MAKING SURE CRANES ARE PROTECTED ON THEIR NESTING, MIGRATORY, AND WINTERING GROUNDS BY ENGAGING CITIZENS AND COMMUNITY GROUPS TO PROMOTE ACTIONS AND POLICIES THAT DECREASE MORTALITY FROM HABITAT LOSS, ILLEGAL SHOOTINGS, AND POWER LINE COLLISIONS. OBJECTIVES FOR THE PROJECT INCLUDE CAPTIVE BREEDING AND REARING OF CHICKS, PROVIDING SPECIALIZED VETERINARY CARE, UNDERTAKING TARGETED RESEARCH AND MONITORING OF REINTRODUCED CRANES, AND FOCUSED OUTREACH IN LOCATIONS WHERE REINTRODUCED CRANES EXIST AIMED AT REDUCING INCIDENTAL LOSSES AND BUILDING SUPPORT FOR WHOOPING CRANE CONSERVATION EFFORTS. ICF WILL BREED CRANES FROM OUR CAREFULLY MANAGED CAPTIVE FLOCK AND REAR CHICKS FOR DIRECT RELEASE INTO THE WILD. WE WILL MAINTAIN HEALTHY ADULT CAPTIVE CRANE PAIRS AT THE ICF FACILITY, AND REARING CHICKS TO FLEDGLING AGE. WE WILL ADVANCE CRANE REINTRODUCTION SCIENCE THROUGH STUDIES OF NESTING SUCCESS, HABITAT USE, AND CHICK REARING METHODS. ALL OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES DESCRIBED HEREIN WILL BE UNDERTAKEN TO ADDRESS HIGH PRIORITY RECOVERY ACTIONS IN THE AREAS OF INCREASING WHOOPING CRANE POPULATION NUMBERS, MAINTAINING CAPTIVE POPULATIONS, MANAGING GENETIC DIVERSITY, ASSISTING WITH THE ESTABLISHMENT OF ADDITIONAL WILD POPULATIONS, AND EXPANDING CRANE EDUCATION PROGRAMS.

THE MOBILE RIVER BASIN DRAINS MORE THAN 32,000 SQUARE MILES IN ALABAMA, EQUATING TO APPROXIMATELY 63  OF THE TOTAL LAND AREA. THE TOMBIGBEE AND ALABAMA RIVERS CONVERGE TO FORM THE MOBILE RIVER ABOUT 50 MILES NORTHEAST OF MOBILE. THE ALABAMA RIVER IS ONE OF THE MOST BIODIVERSE ECOSYSTEMS IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES. MANY SPECIES THAT ARE SUPPORTED BY THESE RICH WATERS ARE MIGRATORY, EITHER FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO UPSTREAM INTO THE ALABAMA RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIES OR LOCALLY MIGRANT WITHIN THE RIVER AND TRIBUTARIES. THE CAHABA RIVER BOASTS THE MOST AQUATIC BIODIVERSITY IN THE ALABAMA RIVER SYSTEM AND WAS THE HISTORIC ENDPOINT FOR MANY OF THESE MIGRATORY FISH SPECIES ON THEIR JOURNEYS TO FULFILL THEIR LIFE HISTORY REQUIREMENTS.SINCE CONSTRUCTION OF CLAIBORNE AND MILLERS FERRY LOCKS AND DAMS ON THE LOWER ALABAMA RIVER, A HISTORIC AND ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT MIGRATORY CORRIDOR WAS CLOSED. FOR THOUSANDS OF YEARS AQUATIC ORGANISMS MOVED FREELY FROM THE GULF OF MEXICO INTO THE ALABAMA RIVER AND INTO THE CAHABA RIVER. SEVERAL SPECIES RELIED ON THIS CORRIDOR FOR COMPLETION OF LIFE HISTORY REQUIREMENTS (I.E., FISH AND FRESHWATER MUSSELS). SINCE DAM CONSTRUCTION FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS HAVE TRIED TO SLOW AND MITIGATE SPECIES DECLINE VIA CONSERVATION LOCKING. RECENT STUDIES BY AUBURN UNIVERSITY HAVE YIELDED THAT THESE EFFORTS HAVE NOT BEEN SUCCESSFUL. IN RESPONSE TO SPECIES DECLINE AND RECOGNITION OF CRITICAL TIMELINES FOR SPECIES SURVIVAL, THE NATURE CONSERVANCY OF ALABAMA (TNC) ENTERED INTO AN AGREEMENT WITH THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (USACE) TO COMPLETE A FEASIBILITY STUDY FOR FISH PASSAGE AT CLAIBORNE AND MILLERS FERRY LOCKS AND DAMS ON THE ALABAMA RIVER. IMPLEMENTATION OF FISH PASSAGE AT THESE STRUCTURES WOULD YIELD ECOLOGICAL RECONNECTION OF 236 MILES OF THE ALABAMA RIVER AND 152 MILES OF THE CAHABA RIVER. WITH 388 MILES OF RECONNECTED MIGRATORY CORRIDOR AND GIVEN THE MONUMENTAL AQUATIC BIODIVERSITY OF THIS SYSTEM, THIS WILL BE THE MOST ECOLOGICALLY SIGNIFICANT RIVER RESTORATION IN NORTH AMERICA.TWENTY-SIX ALTERNATIVES HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED BY THE PROJECT DEVELOPMENT TEAM. THROUGHOUT THE PROCESS THESE ALTERNATIVES WERE NARROWED DOWN TO 5 POTENTIAL FISH PASSAGE SCENARIOS. ECOLOGICAL AND ECONOMIC MODELING WAS THEN COMPLETED TO YIELD THE TENTATIVELY SELECTED PLAN (TSP), WHICH IS A NATURAL BYPASS CHANNEL AT EACH DAM STRUCTURE. THE TSP IS THE STARTING POINT FOR TRUE ALIGNMENT OF THE BYPASS CHANNELS AND ENGINEERING FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE. PUBLIC COMMENTS HAVE BEEN COLLECTED AND RESPONDED TO BY USACE. TNC AND USACE ARE IN THE PROCESS OF FINALIZING ALIGNMENTS FOR THE BYPASS CHANNELS AND WORKING WITH PRIVATE LANDOWNERS TO MITIGATE AND OR LESSEN IMPACTS TO PRIVATE PROPERTY. THE FEASIBILITY STUDY WILL BE COMPLETED NOVEMBER 2024 AND THE IMPLEMENTATION PHASE WILL BEGIN. TNC IS WORKING WITH GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS, STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO ALIGN FUNDING MECHANISMS FOR IMPLEMENTATION.ALTHOUGH THIS SUSTAINABLE RIVERS PROGRAM (SRP) GRANT IS NOT PART OF NOR IS IT USED AS MATCHING FUNDS FOR THE FEASIBILITY STUDY, THE SPECIES ASSESSMENTS AT 8 SITES WITHIN THE AFFECTED AREA WILL GREATLY BENEFIT FUTURE PLANNING AS USACE AND TNC MOVE INTO THE IMPLEMENTATION PLANNING PHASE. ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT (ADEM), GEOLOGICAL SURVEY OF ALABAMA (GSA), TNC AND USACE WILL EMPLOY BENTHIC TRAWLING, BOAT ELECTROFISHING, AND SHORELINE SEINING AT EACH SITE FOR A CURRENT SPECIES ASSESSMENT. THESE DATA WILL BE USED TO ADVISE FUTURE WATER PLANNING AND POTENTIALLY WATER CONTROL MANUAL EDITS TO COINCIDE WITH CONSTRUCTION OF NATURAL BYPASS CHANNELS AT EACH SITE. TNC AND USACE AGREE THAT CHANGES WILL NEED TO BE MADE TO REFLECT FLOW NEEDS AND OPERATIONS AT THE BYPASS CHANNELS. THIS IS THE FIRST YEAR OF A 2-YEAR STUDY AND THERE IS FUTURE INTEREST BY TNC AND USACE TO USE SRP FUNDING TO AID USACE WITH COMPLETION OF WATER CONTROL MANUAL UPDATES.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COMPLETE THE DEVELOPMENT OF GENOMIC-BASED TECHNOLOGY TO INCREASE THE SPEED AND EFFICIENCY OF SELECTING WHITE PINE BLISTER RUST (WPBR) RESISTANT AND CLIMATE ADAPTED WHITEBARK PINE SEED SOURCES THAT CAN BE USED TO CONSERVE AND RESTORE POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT ITS NATURAL RANGE IN THE US AND CANADA. THE MODERN GENOMIC TECHNOLOGY IS NOT MEANT TO TOTALLY REPLACE CONVENTIONAL PHENOTYPE-BASED APPROACHES, BUT RATHER TO SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE, BY SEVERAL ORDERS OF MAGNITUDE, THE AMOUNT OF MATERIAL THAT CAN BE SCREENED PER UNIT TIME AND COST. THERE IS AN URGENT NEED TO HAVE A LARGE SUPPLY OF GENETICALLY DIVERSE, WHITE PINE BLISTER RUST RESISTANT AND CLIMATE ADAPTED SEED SOURCES FOR RESTORATION, YET THE CONVENTIONAL APPROACHES SIMPLY CANNOT IDENTIFY THESE SOURCES IN THE CRITICALLY SHORT TIME FRAME WHEN THEY ARE NEEDED. AN INDIRECT CONSEQUENCE OF THIS LIMITED NUMBER OF APPROPRIATE SEED SOURCES IS THAT RESTORATION PLANTATIONS MIGHT BE ESTABLISHED WITH TOO LITTLE GENETIC DIVERSITY LEADING TO LOSS OF FUTURE ADAPTIVE DIVERSITY AND POPULATION INBREEDING.DEVELOPMENT OF APPLIED GENOMIC TECHNOLOGY PROCEEDS IN THREE PHASES:PHASE 1, SEQUENCE THE WHITEBARK PINE GENOME.PHASE 2, CONDUCT GENOME WIDE ASSOCIATION STUDIES (GWAS) AND GENOTYPE BY ENVIRONMENT STUDIES (GEA) TO IDENTIFY GENETIC MARKERS THAT CAN BE USED IN HIGH-THROUGHPUT SCREENINGPHASE 3, TRAIN FOREST RESOURCE SCIENTISTS AND MANAGERS IN THE USE OF THIS TECHNOLOGY.PHASE 1 WAS INITIATED IN 2020 AND WILL BE COMPLETED IN 2023. THIS APPLICATION REQUESTS FUNDING FOR PHASE 2 AND PHASE 3 WHICH WILL BEGIN IN LATE 2023 AND BE COMPLETED BY LATE 2025

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE USFWS WITH AN UPDATED DRAFT RECOVERY PLAN IN 1 YEAR AND A FINAL AMARGOSA NITERWORT RECOVERY PLAN UPDATE WITHIN 2.5 YEARS OF THE PROJECT S INITIATION. UPDATES WILL INCLUDE REVISING THE PLAN S RECOVERY STRATEGY, DELISTING CRITERIA, THREATS TO BE AMELIORATED, AND RECOVERY ACTIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL REMOVE THE AQUATIC INVASIVE PLANT AZOLLA FILICULOIDES (AZOLLA) FROM A LARGE CALIFORNIA RED LEGGED FROG (RANA DRAYTONII) BREEDING POND ON MENDOCINO REDWOOD COMPANY (MRC) PROPERTY IN MENDOCINO COUNTY, CA. IF FUNDED, MRC WILL HIRE A CONTRACTOR TO OPERATE AN EXCAVATOR TO REMOVE AZOLLA FROM THE POND. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CLEAR OUT ENOUGH AZOLLA FROM THE POND SO THAT CALIFORNIA RED-LEGGED FROGS BEGIN TO USE THE POND AGAIN FOR BREEDING. THIS WILL INCREASE REPRODUCTION POTENTIAL FOR THE SPECIES, WHILE ALSO PROVIDING HABITAT FOR FORAGING AND SHELTERING, ALL OF WHICH WILL AID IN THE CONSERVATION OF THE SPECIES. THE PROJECT SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSES MULTIPLE RECOVERY PLAN OBJECTIVES  INCLUDING PROTECTING KNOWN POPULATIONS (IN THIS CASE WE WOULD BE WORKING TO RESTORE A KNOWN POPULATION), AND PROTECTING KNOWN HABITAT (AGAIN, IN THIS CASE RESTORING KNOWN HABITAT).ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW US TO REPORT TO THE LARGER AMPHIBIAN COMMUNITY ON POSSIBLE PHYSICAL SOLUTIONS FOR CONTROLLING AZOLLA, WHICH COULD BE USED TOWARDS ACCOMPLISHING ANOTHER RECOVERY PLAN OBJECTIVE FOCUSED ON CREATING AND IMPLEMENTING MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR THE SPECIES.

THE ANCESTRAL HOME OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED PAHRUMP POOLFISH (EMPETRICHTHYS LATOS) WAS LOCATED AT MANSE SPRING IN PAHRUMP, NEVADA BUT WAS LOST DUE TO EXCESSIVE PUMPING OF GROUNDWATER FOR AGRICULTURE IN THE MID-1970S. SINCE THEN, THE SPECIES HAS BEEN MANAGED EXCLUSIVELY AT REFUGIA SITES REPRESENTING ENTIRELY DIFFERENT CONDITIONS THAN THOSE AT THEIR ANCESTRAL HOME. THE PAHRUMP POOLFISH RECOVERY PLAN REQUIRES THE CREATION AND LONG-TERM STABILITY OF A MINIMUM OF THREE POPULATIONS TO INCREASE POPULATION RESILIENCY, DOWNGRADE, AND EVENTUALLY DELIST THE SPECIES.THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS MULTI-AGENCY CONSERVATION PROJECT IS TO RECREATE AN APPROXIMATELY 100-METER DESERT SPRING REFUGIUM FOR THE PAHRUMP POOLFISH IN THE SOUTH FORK OF THE HISTORIC LAS VEGAS CREEK AT THE SPRINGS PRESERVE (PRESERVE) IN LAS VEGAS, NEVADA. LIKE MANSE SPRING, THE CREEK RAN DRY PRIOR TO 1962 BECAUSE OF GROUNDWATER PUMPING. IT WAS NOT UNTIL 1984 THAT SCIENTISTS REALIZED THAT THE CREEK HAD BEEN HOME TO THE ENDEMIC, BUT NOW EXTINCT, LAS VEGAS DACE (RHINICHTHYS DEACONI). TO PROMOTE THE RECOVERY OF PAHRUMP POOLFISH, THE LAS VEGAS VALLEY WATER DISTRICT AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) ENTERED INTO A 15-YEAR PAHRUMP POOLFISH SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENT THAT ALLOWS FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF REFUGIA AT THE PRESERVE TO INCREASE SPECIES REDUNDANCY AND REPRESENTATION. ONCE THE REFUGIUM HAS BEEN DESIGNED AND BUILT, THE PRESERVE WILL WORK WITH THE SERVICE AND THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE (NDOW) TO MONITOR THE POPULATION.

THE KAWAIIKI REGION OF KAUAI HOLDS THE LAST KNOWN WILD INDIVIDUALS OF TWO RARE FERN SPECIES: ASPLENIUM DIELMANNII AND ASPLENIUM DIELLACINIATUM, BOTH ENDANGERED AND ONCE FEARED EXTINCT UNTIL THEIR REDISCOVERY IN THIS AREA TWO-DECADES PRIOR. THEY FACE NUMEROUS THREATS TO THEIR CONTINUED EXISTENCE, INCLUDING DEGRADATION OF HABITAT AND COMPETITION FROM NON-NATIVE PLANT SPECIES, BUT MOST PRESSINGLY DIRECT HERBIVORY FROM BLACK-TAILED DEER AND FERAL GOATS, AND UPROOTING AND TRAMPLING BY FERAL PIGS. THE MAJORITY OF THESE WILD PLANTS WERE PROTECTED THROUGH TWO FISH AND WILDLIFE-FUNDED UNGULATE EXCLUSION FENCES (KNOWN AS MANNII AND ERECTA, RESPECTIVELY), ABOUT ONE ACRE EACH, CONSTRUCTED IN 2012 BY THE KAUAI PLANT EXTINCTION PREVENTION PROGRAM (KPEPP) AND THE KOKEE RESOURCE CONSERVATION PROGRAM (KRCP). HOWEVER, A THIRD POPULATION OF MORPHOLOGICALLY DISTINCT ASPLENIUM FERNS IN THE SAME DIELLIA ALLIANCE WAS DISCOVERED NEARBY AND NEVER RECEIVED PROTECTION FROM FENCING. THIS GROUP WAS ALWAYS CONSIDERED DISTINCT, HAVING ONCE BEEN REFERRED TO AS A SEPARATE SPECIES (DIELLIA KNUDSENII) COLLECTED BY THE FAMED VALDEMAR KNUDSEN A CENTURY PRIOR. THEY HAVE BEEN OFFICIALLY MERGED BY FERN TAXONOMISTS INTO A VARIABLE SPECIES CONCEPT OF ASPLENIUM DIELLACINIATUM (SEE LORENCE ET AL., 2013), BUT HAVE BEEN CONSIDERED SEPARATE BY SOME LOCAL BOTANISTS AND FERN EXPERTS (AGURAIUJA, PERS. COMM). NOW FACING THE CONTINUED RAVAGES OF FERAL PIGS AND WILD DEER THAT ARE RAMPANT IN THE AREA, THIS UNFENCED POPULATION IS BARELY HANGING ON. WE PROPOSE SEVERAL ACTIONS IN THE AREA TO AID IN THE CONSERVATION OF THESE AND OTHER RARE PLANT SPECIES. FIRSTLY, STAFF FROM KPEPP, IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE KAUAI DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE (DOFAW), PART OF THE HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES, WILL CONSTRUCT A SMALL FENCE, ROUGHLY 250 FEET IN TOTAL PERIMETER LENGTH, TO PROTECT THE MAJORITY OF SURVIVING PLANTS OF THIS INTERMEDIATE FORM OF A. DIELLACINIATUM ON KAWAIIKI RIDGE. SECONDLY, THE TWO EXISTING ONE-ACRE EXCLOSURES WILL RECEIVE RENEWED WEEDING THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP WITH KRCP, WITH BOTH MANNII AND ERECTA EXCLOSURES EACH BEING WEEDED FOR ONE FULL WEEK. LASTLY, KPEPP AND DOFAW STAFF WILL SURVEY THE SURROUNDING AREA TO ASSESS THE FEASIBILITY OF CONSTRUCTING A LARGER EXCLOSURE THAT WOULD INCLUDE THE EXISTING ERECTA EXCLOSURE AND MUCH OF THE NORTH SLOPE OF THE UPPER KAWAIIKI VALLEY. THIS AREA IS HOME TO NUMEROUS RARE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES AND WOULD PROVIDE MUCH-NEEDED HABITAT FOR OUTPLANTING A SUITE OF RARE PLANT SPECIES THAT OCCUR IN THE BROADER REGION FOR WHICH WE HAVE NO PROTECTED AREA TO RESTORE THEM BEYOND THE ONE-ACRE MANNII AND ERECTA EXCLOSURES.

THE PUERTO RICAN PARROT (AMAZONA VITTATA) IS A CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES ENDEMIC TO PUERTO RICO. DUE TO HIGH MORTALITY AND LOW REPRODUCTION RATES, THE PUERTO RICAN PARROT POPULATIONS HAVE NOT RECOVERED NATURALLY AND ARE IN A LOCAL RECOVERY PROGRAM TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND SIZES OF WILD POPULATIONS. A MAJOR CAUSE OF MORTALITY FOR PARROTS THAT ARE RELEASED FROM CAPTIVITY IS PREDATION BY THE RED-TAILED HAWK (BUTEO JAMAICENSIS), A WIDESPREAD TOP PREDATOR FOUND ACROSS PUERTO RICO. TO INCREASE POPULATIONS, IT IS IMPORTANT TO REDUCE MORTALITY FROM PREDATION, ESPECIALLY WHEN ESTABLISHING A NEW POPULATION WITHOUT A CORE WILD PARROT POPULATION. IN THE MARICAO COMMONWEALTH FOREST, THERE ARE CURRENTLY 29 WILD PUERTO RICAN PARROTS, WITH EIGHT ACTIVE NESTS AND FOUR HATCHLINGS. HOWEVER, THE RECOVERY POTENTIAL OF THIS POPULATION IS REDUCED DUE TO HEAVY PREDATION BY RED-TAILED HAWKS. IN ORDER TO INCREASE RECOVERY POTENTIAL OF THIS POPULATION, THE USFWS PROPOSES TO INCREASE EFFORTS TO CONTROL PREDATION BY RED-TAILED HAWKS FROM DECEMBER TO FEBRUARY AND MAY TO JULY, THE TWO PERIODS OF TIME DURING THE YEAR WHEN PREDATION BY THIS HAWK IS MORE ACTIVE IN MARICAO. NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION PROTECTORES DE CUENCAS INC. PROPOSES TO SUPPORT THE USFWS IN THESE EFFORTS DURING A TWO-YEAR PERIOD BY SUBCONTRACTING TWO STUDENT INTERNS TO IMPLEMENT CONTROL EFFORTS ON THE RED-TAILED HAWK IN THE MARICAO COMMONWEALTH FOREST.

CONSERVATION FISHERIES, INC. (CFI) PROPOSES TO DEVELOP CAPTIVE PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS AND PRODUCE INDIVIDUALS OF PEARL DARTER (PERCINA AURORA) TO SUPPORT U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) DRAFT RECOVERY GOALS FOR THIS THREATENED FISH SPECIES.DURING THIS EFFORT, CFI WILL: DEVELOP AND DOCUMENT CAPTIVE PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS FOR THE THREATENED PEARL DARTER. COORDINATE WITH PRIVATE JOHN ALLEN NATIONAL FISHERY HATCHERY BIOLOGISTS ON DEVELOPING AND REFINING THESE PROTOCOLS. PROVIDE CAPTIVELY PROPAGATED INDIVIDUALS TO USFWS AND MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE, FISHERIES, AND PARKS (MDWFP) FOR REINTRODUCTION PURPOSES. PROVIDE A FINAL REPORT OF ALL ACTIVITIES CONDUCTED UNDER THIS GRANT.DEVELOPMENT OF THESE PROTOCOLS IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE DRAFT PEARL DARTER RECOVERY PLAN AND WILL AID USFWS AND MDWFP IN THEIR EFFORTS TO CONSERVE AND RECOVER POPULATIONS OF THIS THREATENED SPECIES.

IDAHO FISH AND GAME (IDFG) IS COMMITTED TO CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY OF BULL TROUT IN THE STATE AS PART OF THEIR LONG-TERM FISHERIES MANAGEMENT STRATEGY (IDFG 2019). IDFG HAS PARTNERED WITH USFWS ON DEVELOPMENT OF THE BULL TROUT SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT, COLLABORATION THROUGH WORK GROUPS, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO PROMOTE THE SPECIES IN IDAHO. THIS PROJECT CONTINUES THOSE EFFORTS AND IDENTIFIES PROGRAMMATIC PLANNING, RESTORATION ACTIONS, AND RESEARCH NEEDS TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND PRIORITIZE ACTIONS WHICH DOCUMENT STATUS, ADDRESS CONSERVATION NEEDS, AND WORK TOWARD RECOVERY OF BULL TROUT IN IDAHO. THE PROJECT ALSO COORDINATES FUTURE CONSERVATION PLAN DEVELOPMENT, RESEARCH AND MONITORING NEEDS, HABITAT RESTORATION, AND THREATS REDUCTION PROJECTS TO BENEFIT SPECIES DESCRIPTION, STATUS AND TREND, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF MANAGEMENT TOOLS FOR HIGH PRIORITY NATIVE FISHES OF IDAHO.

THE BIG MEADOWS COMPLEX IS LOCATED IN THE MARBLE MOUNTAINS, WEST OF FORT JONES AND GREENVIEW, CA.  IT IS CHARACTERIZED BY WET MOUNTAIN MEADOWS WITH SMALL AND DISPERSED ASPEN STANDS.  THE MEADOWS CONTAIN ABUNDANT FLORAL RESOURCES IN PROXIMITY TO SEEPS, PRIMARY HABITAT COMPONENTS FOR THE ENDANGERED FRANKLINS BUMBLE BEE.  THE BIG MEADOWS COMPLEX CONTAINS ONE OF ONLY A FEW HISTORICAL OBSERVATIONS OF THE SPECIES IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA. THE BIG MEADOWS COMPLEX ALSO CONTAINS THE HEADWATERS OF SHACKLEFORD CREEK, ONE THE MOST PRODUCTIVE CREEKS IN THE SCOTT RIVER VALLEY FOR THE THREATENED SOUTHERN OREGON NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST COHO SALMON.  OVER TIME MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDING CATTLE GRAZING AND FIRE SUPPRESSION HAVE DEGRADED HABITAT AND THE FUNCTION OF THE BIG MEADOWS COMPLEX.  TO RESTORE THE MEADOW COMPLEX THIS PROJECT WILL CONSTRUCT 25 ACRES OF WILDLIFE FRIENDLY FENCE TO EXCLUDE CATTLE FROM THE WET MEADOWS AND ASPEN STANDS, REMOVE ENCROACHING CONIFERS FROM FIVE ACRES OF WET MEADOW AND ASPEN HABITAT, MANUALLY REMOVE NON-NATIVE INVASIVE SPECIES, AND USE LOW TECH PROCESS-BASED TECHNIQUES INCLUDING WOOD LOADING TO RESTORE HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION.  BY RESTORING NATIVE FLORAL COMMUNITIES AND WET MEADOW HABITATS THE HYDROLOGY OF THE WET MEADOW COMPLEX, THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS THREATS AND IDENTIFIED RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR FRANKLINS BUMBLE BEE AND  SOUTHERN OREGON NORTHERN CALIFORNIA COAST COHO SALMON.

THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE AND SURVEY MARITIME CHAPARRAL HABITAT SUITABLE FOR YADONS PIPERIA (PIPERIA YADONII). THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO CONDUCT SEED INTRODUCTION EXPERIMENTS. PROJECT PERSONNEL WILL NEED EXPERIENCE IN IDENTIFYING YADONS PIPERIA, ITS HABITAT, AND BE KNOWLEDGEABLE OF ITS DEMOGRAPHICS WITHIN THE AREA UNDER CONSIDERATION AS WELL AS THE MOST RECENT AVAILABLE LITERATURE SUPPORTING THE IDEA OF SEED INTRODUCTION. CONDUCT SURVEYS, RESTORE, AND INTRODUCE SEED WITHIN MARITIME CHAPARRAL HABITAT, USING METHODS PREVIOUSLY USED IN MONTEREY PINE FOREST HABITAT. ALL WORK IS FOCUSED ON RECOVERING YADONS PIPERIA.

THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE SAN BERNARDINO KANGAROO RAT (DIPODOMYS MERRIAMI PARVUS, SBKR), IS LIMITED TO THREE EXTANTISOLATED POPULATIONS FOUND IN SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTIES. THE SAN JACINTO POPULATION HAS BEENDOCUMENTED TO HAVE EXTREMELY LOW EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE AND GENETIC DIVERSITY. A TRANSLOCATION OF SBKR INTOSAN JACINTO OCCURRED IN 2020 TO DETERMINE THE EFFICACY OF THIS CONSERVATION METHOD TO FACILITATE RECOVERY ANDMITIGATE FOR LOSSES ASSOCIATED WITH DEVELOPMENT. TRANSLOCATION SUCCESS IS EVALUATED IN STAGES AND CAN TAKE YEARSTO MOVE FROM SETTLEMENT AND SURVIVAL TO REPRODUCTION, POPULATION GROWTH AND POPULATION REGULATION. SHORT-TERMSUCCESS OF THE 2020 TRANSLOCATION WAS HIGH. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ASSESS LONG-TERM SUCCESS OF THISCONSERVATION ACTION THROUGH MONITORING FOR AN ADDITIONAL 2.5 YEARS (THROUGH YEAR 5 POST-RELEASE) AND PROVIDESUPPORT TO THE NEWLY CREATED POPULATION THROUGH ANNUAL HABITAT EVALUATIONS OF THE RECEIVER SITE AND SEEDSUPPLEMENTATION. IF DEEMED NECESSARY BASED ON POPULATION SIZE, THE RELOCATED POPULATION WILL BE SUPPORTED WITHSUPPLEMENTAL INDIVIDUALS. MOREOVER, GENETIC SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED AND BANKED TO MONITOR THE GENETICS OF THERELEASED POPULATION. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO RANGE-WIDE LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT ANDRECOVERY OF SBKR.

KAUAIS ENDEMIC HONEYCREEPERS ARE CRASHING DUE TO INCREASED PREVALENCE OF AVIAN MALARIA AND ITS MOSQUITO VECTOR,CULEX QUINQUEFASCIATUS, DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE. THE ENDANGERED AKIKIKI AND AKEKEE ARE OF SPECIAL CONCERN. THEMOST PROMISING STRATEGY FOR MANAGING AVIAN MALARIA IS MOSQUITO POPULATION SUPPRESSION VIA THE INCOMPATIBLE INSECTTECHNIQUE (IIT). THE FIRST TRIAL 3000-ACRE (12.2 SQ KM) IIT DEPLOYMENT ON KAUAI IS TARGETED FOR FALL 2024 WITHBI-WEEKLY RELEASES OF INCOMPATIBLE MALE MOSQUITOES FOR SIX MONTHS. HERE WE PROPOSE TO CHARACTERIZE MOSQUITOPOPULATION DISTRIBUTIONS DURING THE SIX MONTHS OF RELEASES AT THE TREATMENT SITE (MOHIHI UPPER KAWAIKOI) AND ASMALLER, ECOLOGICALLY SIMILAR REFERENCE SITE (LOWER KAWAIKOI) TO ASSESS IMPACT AND REFINE RELEASE STRATEGIES. WEWILL MONITOR MALE AND FEMALE MOSQUITO ABUNDANCE AT BOTH SITES WEEKLY FOR SIX MONTHS DURING RELEASES USING BGTRAPS AND EGG HATCH RATES USING OVIPOTS. MOSQUITO SPECIMENS WILL BE SCREENED WITH PCR FOR AVIAN MALARIA BYNORTHERN ARIZONA UNIVERSITY. WEEKLY, WE WILL RUN  100 TRAP SITES IN A GRID THAT COVERS THE 12.2 SQ KM TREATMENTAND  50 TRAP SITES IN A GRID THAT COVERS THE 6.1 SQ KM CONTROL AREA. VECTOR POPULATION DATA WILL BE USED TOINFORM MODELS OF THE NUMBERS OF INCOMPATIBLE MALE MOSQUITOES NEEDED TO OVER-FLOOD WILD MALES AND LIMITREPRODUCTION. POST-RELEASE, WE WILL ASSESS ABUNDANCE OF FEMALE MOSQUITOES IN THE TREATMENT SITE VS. THE CONTROLSITE TO QUANTIFY VECTOR POPULATION REDUCTION AND ALSO PREVALENCE OF MALARIA IN BOTH SITES. WE WILL ALSO ESTIMATEDISPERSAL DISTANCES AND SURVIVAL OF RELEASED MALES.

THE WYOMING TOAD (ANAXYRUS BAXTERI), ONE OF THE MOST ENDANGERED AMPHIBIANS IN NORTH AMERICA, RAPIDLY DECLINED IN THE 1970S DUE TO UNKNOWN CAUSES. THIS NARROW-RANGE ENDEMIC WAS LISTED UNDER THE ESA IN 1984). IN THE EARLY 1990S, MANAGERS COLLECTED THE REMAINING INDIVIDUALS TO ESTABLISH A CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAM. THE PURPOSE OF THE REQUESTED FUNDING IS TO SUPPORT CAPTIVE EFFORTS AT RED BUTTES WYOMING TOAD FACILITY. THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING (UW) WILL SUPPLY WET-LAB FACILITIES TO HOUSE A CAPTIVE BREEDING COLONY OF TOADS AT THE RED BUTTE ENVIRONMENTAL LABORATORY. UW WILL MAINTAIN THE LAB INFRASTRUCTURE AND WILL HELP IN HIRING SEASONAL TECHNICIANS TO SUPPORT THE CAPTIVE BREEDING AND SUBSEQUENT RELEASE MONITORING OF TOADS IN THE WILD.
