WE PROPOSE TO COLLECT SEED OF THREE ENDANGERED SPECIES THAT HAVE RECOMMENDATIONS IN RECOVERY PLANS AND OR 5-YEAR REVIEWS TO ESTABLISH EX SITU SEED COLLECTIONS AT CENTER FOR PLANT CONSERVATION APPROVED SEED BANKS. WE HAVE IDENTIFIED MONTEREY GILIA (GILIA TENUIFLORA SSP. TENUIFLORA  ENDANGERED, VFWO PROMOTING RECOVERY SPECIES), SCOTTS VALLEY SPINEFLOWER (CHORIZANTHE ROBUSTA VAR. HARTWEGII  ENDANGERED), AND ROBUST SPINEFLOWER (CHORIZANTHE ROBUSTA VAR. ROBUSTA  ENDANGERED) AS SPECIES IN NEED OF ESTABLISHING CONSERVATION SEED BANKS OR ESTABLISHING NEW ACCESSIONS FROM UNIQUE POPULATIONS TO INCREASE REDUNDANCY AND REPRESENTATION IN EX SITU SEED BANKS. THE NEW ACCESSIONS WILL BE HOUSED AT THE CALIFORNIA BOTANIC GARDEN WHICH IS AN INSTITUTION WITH THE LARGEST CONSERVATION SEED BANK OF CALIFORNIA FLORA SPECIALIZING IN EVALUATING AND MAINTAINING CONSERVATION SEED BANKS.

THE WA ON BIRDS IN THE KUMULIPO BEGINS WITH THE PHRASE  LAU PAHIWA. LAU OR MANY, AND VARIED, AND PAHIWA MEANING DARK, OR TO DARKEN, SUCH AS FLOCKS OF BIRDS DARKENING THE SKY, IS THE VISION KUPUNA HAD WHEN VOCALIZING THIS PHRASE. THIS PROJECT IS A TRAINING MODULE ESPECIALLY CREATED FOR THE RESEARCHERS AND SCIENTISTS CONNECTED TO THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE, WHOSE RESPONSIBILITY IS THE FLOURISHING OF OUR NATIVE BIRDS. ALTHOUGH KUPUNA EMPLOYED BIRD PRACTITIONERS, WE CURRENTLY DO NOT EXPERIENCE THESE KIND OF EXPERTS DUE TO THE FACT THAT THE EXPERTISE OF BIRD CATCHING  HENCE, BIRD OBSERVING HAS NOT BEEN A PRACTICE AND IS NOT A VIABLE NECESSITY PRESENTLY IN HAWAIIAN CULTURE. THEREFORE, THE REAL BIRD PRACTITIONERS ARE THOSE WHO OBSERVE, RESEARCH, AND DOCUMENT THEIR STUDIES FOR CONSERVATION AND RESTORATION PURPOSES FOR THE PURPOSE OF HALTING THE EXTINCTION OF EXISTING NATIVE BIRDS. THIS PROJECT WILL INSTILL ANCESTRAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE OF OUR RELATIONSHIP TO OUR NATURAL WORLD THROUGH MELE (DATA-FILLED ANCESTRAL TEXT), KA AO (DATA-INSPIRED MYTHOLOGY), AND CEREMONY AND THE INTERPRETATION OF THESE TRADITIONS THROUGH THE LENS OF THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY OF BIRD CONSERVATIONISTS.  THIS INFORMATION WILL BE RESEARCHED AND THEN COMMUNICATED TO CURRENT DAY BIRD PRACTITIONERS TO CONNECT THAT BIOCULTURAL CONSIDERATIONS INTO PRACTICE.

BULL TROUT (SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS) ARE LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. ACROSS THE NATIVE RANGE OF BULL TROUT THERE IS CONCERN AS THEIR HABITAT REQUIREMENTS ARE DEGRADED. AS LOWER ELEVATION WATER BODIES WARM DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE BULL TROUT POPULATIONS WILL INCREASINGLY BECOME ISOLATED. BULL TROUT RESIDING IN SMALL SUB-ALPINE LAKES REPRESENT A UNIQUE LIFE HISTORY FORM THAT IS IMPORTANT TO STUDY CONSIDERING FUTURE HABITAT CHANGES. BECAUSE THESE LAKE COHORTS HAVE BEEN DISCONNECTED FROM ADJACENT POPULATIONS FOR A LONG TIME THEY COULD BE GENETICALLY DIVERGENT. OUR PRELIMINARY INVESTIGATION OF BULL TROUT FROM FISH LAKE IN THE NORTH FORK CLEARWATER RIVER DRAINAGE SHOWS THIS TO BE THE CASE. IN ADDITION, THE EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE OF FISH LAKE BULL TROUT IS SMALL, YET THEY HAVE PERSISTED THERE A LONG TIME. THE PURPOSE OF THIS STUDY IS TO IDENTIFY OTHER ISOLATED LAKE POPULATIONS OF BULL TROUT IN IDAHO TO FORM A COLLECTIVE COMPARISON OF GENETIC DIVERSITY. IN ADDITION, THIS STUDY WOULD PROVIDE THE BASIS FOR INVESTIGATING THE MECHANISM FOR HOW THESE POPULATIONS HAVE PERSISTED. LASTLY, THE REPRODUCTIVE BEHAVIOR OF THESE NON-MIGRATORY BULL TROUT WILL BE INVESTIGATED TO UNDERSTAND THEIR SPAWNING BIOLOGY. THIS RESEARCH PROPOSAL WILL PROVIDE IMPORTANT NEW INFORMATION ON THE EVOLUTION OF BULL TROUT GENETIC DIVERSITY, MINIMUM BULL TROUT POPULATION SIZE, AND CONTRIBUTE TO THE BIOLOGY OF BULL TROUT LIFE HISTORY. THESE FEATURES ARE PROMINENT IN SEVERAL ACTION ITEMS FOR MAINTAINING AND INCREASING THIS THREATENED FISH SPECIES ACROSS ITS NATIVE RANGE.

THE RED KNOT (CALIDRIS CANUTUS) WAS RECENTLY FEDERALLY LISTED AND UTILIZES SC INTERTIDAL HABITATS DURING ITS ANNUAL MIGRATIONS. AS WITH MANY SHOREBIRDS, THIS SPECIES HAS EXHIBITED POPULATION DECLINES IN RECENT YEARS, AND THIS IS BELIEVED TO RESULT FROM IMPACTS TO MIGRATORY HABITATS, WHICH PROVIDE ESSENTIAL NUTRITION FOR THEIR LONG MIGRATION. RECENT COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH BETWEEN THE SC DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS ESTABLISHED LINKAGES BETWEEN BENTHIC PREY ABUNDANCE AND FORAGING ACTIVITY ALONG SC BEACHES. HOWEVER, MOST OF THESE PROJECTS FOCUSED ON DETERMINING IMPACTS FROM SHORELINE MODIFICATION, RATHER THAN QUANTIFYING HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT SEEKS TO APPLY NEW GENETIC TOOLS AND REANALYZE THESE DATASETS TO IDENTIFY A SUITE OF PREY NEEDS AND OPTIMAL FORAGING HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL WORK WITH A STAKEHOLDER GROUP TO DEVELOP A HABITAT ASSESSMENT TOOL FOR THESE SPECIES. THIS WILL BE INVALUABLE TO THOSE TASKED WITH PROTECTING ENDANGERED SPECIES AND PERMITTING COASTAL IMPACTS AS WELL AS RESOURCE MANAGERS FACED WITH MANAGING BEACHES AND INTERTIDAL HABITATS IN THE FACE OF SEA LEVEL RISE, INCREASING COASTAL DEVELOPMENT AND SHORELINE MODIFICATIONS, AND DECLINING SHOREBIRD POPULATIONS. THIS PROJECT ALIGNS WITH MULTIPLE PROGRAM PRIORITIES OUTLINED IN THE NFWF BUSINESS PLAN (2018), TARGETED RECOVERY UNITS, AND STRATEGIES OUTLINED IN THE DRAFT RUFA RED KNOT RECOVERY PLAN (USFWS 2021).

THIS STUDY WILL GATHER INFORMATION ABOUT THE NUMBERS AND GENETIC AND DEMOGRAPHIC TRENDS OF SIERRA NEVADA RED FOX IN ITS SONORA PASS CORE AREA AND IN AREAS PERIPHERAL TO THE SONORA PASS CORE AREA, INCLUDING THE EL DORADO AND HUMBOLDT-TOIYABE NATIONAL FORESTS. THE KNOWN POPULATION OF THE FOX IS SMALL, OCCURS AT HIGH ELEVATION AND IS DIFFICULT TO DETECT. FUNDS WOULD BE USED TO IMPLEMENT NON-INVASIVE GENETIC SURVEYS AND DNA ANALYSIS METHODS TO TRACK KNOWN INDIVIDUALS AND ADD NEW INDIVIDUALS WHEN POSSIBLE. SURVEYS BEGAN IN 2010 AND HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED ANNUALLY THROUGH 2022. THIS TASK CONTINUES THOSE SURVEYS.

KINCAID S LUPINE (LUPINUS OREGANUS), A FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES, WAS ONCE ABUNDANT THROUGH OREGON S WILLAMETTE VALLEY AND ADJACENT AREAS OF DOUGLAS COUNTY, OREGON, TO THE SOUTH, AND WESTERN WASHINGTON, TO THE NORTH. TODAY, THE VAST MAJORITY OF KINCAID S LUPINE IS RESTRICTED TO THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY, WITH ONLY A FEW POPULATIONS REMAINING IN DOUGLAS COUNTY AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON. TO DATE, RECOVERY EFFORTS HAVE PRIMARILY FOCUSED ON REINTRODUCING AND OR AUGMENTING KINCAID S LUPINE POPULATIONS IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY, RESTORING ASSOCIATED PRAIRIE HABITAT, PRODUCING KINCAID S LUPINE PLANT MATERIALS AND MONITORING KINCAID S LUPINE AND PRAIRIE HABITAT. THIS PROJECT SUBSTANTIALLY EXPANDS THE SCOPE OF PREVIOUS KINCAID S LUPINE RECOVERY EFFORTS BY INITIATING NEW RESTORATION EFFORTS IN DOUGLAS COUNTY AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON, WHICH REPRESENT THE SOUTHERN AND NORTHERN EXTENT OF THE SPECIES  RANGE AND ARE CRITICAL FOR ADVANCING RANGE-WIDE RECOVERY GOALS. IT PROVIDES FUNDING FOR MONITORING KINCAID S LUPINE POPULATIONS AND HABITAT QUALITY AND EXTENDS THE PRODUCTION OF KINCAID S LUPINE SEED AMPLIFICATION FIELDS FOR THREE YEARS. SEED PRODUCED WILL SUPPORT RECOVERY EFFORTS ACROSS THE SPECIES  RANGE.IN ADDITION TO FURTHERING RECOVERY OF KINCAID S LUPINE, THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY BENEFITS OTHER RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES, AND THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY (ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI), A SPECIES ENDEMIC TO THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY WHICH RELIES ON KINCAID S LUPINE AS ITS HOST PLANT.THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT RESTORATION ACTIONS NECESSARY TO MEET RECOVERY CRITERIA FOR KINCAID S LUPINE IN TWO RECOVERY ZONES: DOUGLAS COUNTY AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON. WE PROPOSE ENHANCING PRAIRIE HABITAT AT 13 SITES (EIGHT IN DOUGLAS COUNTY AND FIVE IN SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON) BY MANAGING TO ACHIEVE AT LEAST 50  NATIVE SPECIES COVER, HAVING AT LEAST 10 NATIVE SPECIES PRESENT (ONE OF WHICH WILL BE A BUNCHGRASS), MAINTAINING LESS THAN 15  WOODY COVER, AND HAVING NO MORE THAN 5  COVER OF SELECTED HIGH PRIORITY NONNATIVE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, WE PROPOSE TO INTRODUCE OR AUGMENT KINCAID S LUPINE AT THESE SITES WITH THE GOAL THAT EACH ZONE WILL EXCEED THE MINIMUM TARGETS SET IN THE RECOVERY PLAN. THIS WILL INCREASE THE RESILIENCY OF EXISTING POPULATIONS, INCREASE REDUNDANCY BY ESTABLISHING NEW POPULATIONS, AND ENHANCE REPRESENTATION BY INCREASING THE SPECIES  RANGE, THEREBY INCREASING ITS ADAPTIVE CAPACITY.TO MEET PROJECT OBJECTIVES, ACTIVE RESTORATION, MONITORING AND PLANT MATERIALS PRODUCTION WILL BE USED. RESTORATION PLANS WILL BE DEVELOPED FOR EACH SITE AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS SUCH AS MOWING, FELLING TREES, HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS, SOLARIZATION, AND PLANTING KINCAID S LUPINE AND NATIVE SPECIES WILL BE COMPLETED. MONITORING WILL OCCUR AT ALL PROJECT SITES AND INCLUDE SURVEY METHODOLOGIES APPROVED BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. PLANT MATERIAL PRODUCTION INCLUDES MAINTAINING KINCAID S LUPINE SEED AMPLIFICATION FIELDS WHILE THEY ARE EXPECTED TO BE AT PEAK PRODUCTION AND GROWING 26,300 KINCAID S LUPINE PLUGS FOR PLANTING AT RESTORED SITES.WITHOUT DIRECT INTERVENTION, KINCAID S LUPINE PROSPECTS FOR RECOVERY, AND THOSE OF ITS OBLIGATE BUTTERFLY SPECIES, ARE POOR. MOST REMAINING POPULATIONS ARE SMALL AND ISOLATED. FURTHER, NATURAL RECRUITMENT IS LOW DUE TO COMPETITION WITH INVASIVE SPECIES, ALTERED DISTURBANCE REGIMES, AND POSSIBLE GENETIC ISSUES. HOWEVER, THE PRESENCE OF A WIDE ARRAY OF PARTNERS WORKING TO PROTECT AND RESTORE NATIVE PRAIRIE HABITAT, ALONG WITH THE PENDING AVAILABILITY OF LARGER QUANTITIES OF KINCAID S LUPINE SEED TO AUGMENT EXISTING OR ESTABLISH NEW POPULATIONS, PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR THIS SPECIES TO BE SUCCESSFULLY RECOVERED. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, A NETWORK OF PARTNERS WILL COLLABORATIVELY WORK TOGETHER TO PROMOTE THE LASTING RECOVERY OF THIS SPECIES THROUGHOUT ITS HISTORICAL RANGE. EFFORTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE SPECIES  RESILIENCY, REPRESENTATION, AND REDUNDANCY.

SINCE 2008, THE INSTITUTE FOR APPLIED ECOLOGY (IAE) HAS BEEN WORKING WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) TO STRATEGICALLY COLLECT AND PRODUCE GENETICALLY DIVERSE SEED FOR THE FIVE T E PLANT SPECIES ADDRESSED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE PRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON (RECOVERY PLAN, USFWS 2010) AS WELL AS SEVERAL SPECIES IDENTIFIED BY EXPERTS AS KEY NECTAR RESOURCE PLANTS FOR FENDERS BLUE AND TAYLORS CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLIES, LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 2013. THE PRODUCTION OF NATIVE SEED IS OFTEN A LONG-TERM EFFORT, WITH SOME SPECIES TAKING UP TO FIVE YEARS TO PRODUCE THEIR FIRST HARVEST. IN ADDITION, CURRENT SEED PRODUCTION FIELDS ARE SUCCESSFUL BUT ARE TOO SMALL TO MEET THE CURRENT AND ANTICIPATED DEMAND. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE CURRENT PRODUCTION TO PROVIDE FBB HOST AND NECTAR SPECIES IN SUFFICIENT QUANTITIES TO MEET THE DOWNLISTING AND DELISTING CRITERIA FOR FBB AND OTHER WILLAMETTE VALLEY LISTED SPECIES.

LAGUNA MOUNTAINS SKIPPER (LMS) IS A SMALL BROWN AND WHITE CHECKERED BUTTERFLY THAT HISTORICALLY WAS ONLY FOUND IN THE LAGUNA AND PALOMAR MOUNTAINS OF SAN DIEGO COUNTY. IT HAS NOT BEEN LOCATED ON LAGUNA MOUNTAIN SINCE THE 1990S. AS PART OF A STRATEGY TO REINTRODUCE LAGUNA MOUNTAINS SKIPPER TO ITS HISTORICAL RANGE, THE CHEROSKE MEADOW AREA WAS IDENTIFIED AS THE PREFERRED LOCATION TO RELEASE LAGUNA MOUNTAINS SKIPPERS TRANSLOCATED FROM PALOMAR MOUNTAIN AND CAPTIVE-REARED PUPAE FROM ADULTS COLLECTED AT MENDENHALL VALLEY WERE RELEASED THERE IN 2021 AND MONITORED THROUGH THE 2022 FLIGHT SEASON(S). FOR THIS PROJECT, ADDITIONAL FEMALES WILL BE COLLECTED FROM MENDENHALL VALLEY TO OBTAIN EGGS THAT WILL BE CAPTIVE REARED BY THE SAN DIEGO ZOO TO AN APPROPRIATE ENDPOINT FOR RELEASE (LARVAE OR PUPAE). THESE INDIVIDUALS WILL THEN BE RELEASED AT CHEROSKE MEADOW DURING 2024. FOR FULL DETAILS ON THE OVERALL REINTRODUCTION PLAN AND THE RELEASE PLAN FOR CHEROSKE MEADOW, SEE THE ASSOCIATED APPROVED PLANS. UWG PROPOSES TO PROVIDE GENERAL PROJECT COORDINATION AND REPORTING AND TO HIRE OSBORNE BIOLOGICAL CONSULTING TO UNDERTAKE SURVEYS AND COLLECT THE WILD LMS FEMALES.

AMBYSTOMA MACRODACTYLUM CROCEUM (SANTA CRUZ LONG-TOED SALAMANDER  HEREAFTER SCLTS) IS A SALAMANDER LOCAL TO COASTAL CALIFORNIA, AND HAS A RANGE LIMITED TO SOUTHERN SANTA CRUZ AND NORTHERN MONTEREY COUNTIES. THIS SUBSPECIES IS CURRENTLY FEDERALLY ENDANGERED, STATE FULLY PROTECTED AND HAS ONE OF THE SMALLEST RANGES OF ANY ENDANGERED SPECIES. THE SINGLE LARGEST FACTOR CONTRIBUTING TO THE ENDANGERED STATUS IS THE DESTRUCTION OF HABITAT, RESULTING IN HIGHLY FRAGMENTED POPULATIONS WITHIN THE SPECIES RANGE. OVER THE PAST TWO DECADES, SEVERAL RECOVERY ACTIVITIES HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED IN SANTA CRUZ COUNTY, STABILIZING AND BOLSTERING THE SANTA CRUZ COUNTY POPULATIONS. HOWEVER, OVER THE SAME TIMEFRAME, POPULATIONS IN MONTEREY COUNTY HAVE STEADILY DECREASED AND POPULATION EXTINCTIONS CONTINUE TO OCCUR. CURRENTLY, THERE ARE ONLY FIVE KNOWN FUNCTIONAL BREEDING SITES LEFT WITHIN MONTEREY COUNTY. AS MONTEREY COUNTY POPULATIONS CONTINUE TO DECLINE, LOW GENETIC DIVERSITY AND INBREEDING HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS MAJOR THREATS TO SCLTS POPULATIONS. POPULATIONS WITH LOW GENETIC DIVERSITY, MEANING THEY POSSESS FEWER UNIQUE ALLELES FOR EACH GENE, CANNOT RESPOND TO CHANGING ENVIRONMENTS. THEY CANNOT ENDURE STOCHASTIC EVENTS, LIKE DROUGHTS AND WILDFIRES, AND THEY ARE EXTREMELY VULNERABLE TO LOCAL EXTINCTIONS. THESE THREATS WILL BE INTENSIFIED BY CLIMATE CHANGE AND ARE ESPECIALLY DANGEROUS TO SPECIES WITH SMALL RANGES LIKE SCLTS, SO WE WILL NEED INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO RECOVER THE SPECIES. WE PROPOSE A NEW PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, SANTA CRUZ AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO ADDRESS THESE CONCERNS. WE WILL CONTINUE AND BUILD UPON A RECENT CAPTIVE BREEDING EFFORT THAT WILL CROSS LOW GENETIC DIVERSITY MONTEREY COUNTY POPULATIONS WITH HIGHER DIVERSITY SANTA CRUZ COUNTY POPULATIONS. AFTER, WE WILL RELEASE LARVAE TO STRUGGLING MONTEREY COUNTY POPULATIONS. IMPORTANTLY, WE WILL QUANTIFY THE GENETIC COMPOSITION FOR THE SCLTS POPULATIONS AND USE GENETIC ANALYSIS TO TRACK THE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS OF OUR RELEASED ANIMALS. WE CAN MEASURE IMPACTS OF ADDED GENETIC DIVERSITY ON POPULATION HEALTH AND RANK POTENTIAL BREEDING LOCATIONS AND HABITATS. FROM THIS INFORMATION, WE CAN CREATE A GUIDE TO MANAGE THE SPECIES AND RANK PRIORITY SITES FOR FUTURE RELEASES. THIS NOVEL APPROACH WILL BECOME A PROACTIVE CONSERVATION METHOD AND CONTRIBUTE TO POPULATION VIABILITY. THE CONTINUED RELEASES OF GENETICALLY DIVERSE LARVAE WILL BOLSTER SPECIES NUMBERS, RESULTING IN STABLE POPULATIONS AND INCREASED RESILIENCY AGAINST CLIMATE CHANGE. IN ADDITION, THE RELEASES OF GENETICALLY CROSSED LARVAE WILL PROVIDE THE CRUCIAL BENEFITS OF INCREASED GENETIC REPRESENTATION AND RESILIENCY FROM HIGHER GENETIC DIVERSITY. LASTLY, A CAPTIVE BREEDING AND REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM WILL PRODUCE LARVAE THAT WILL ACT AS FOUNDERS FOR NEW BREEDING SITES TO INCREASE REDUNDANCY. BY INCREASING RESILIENCY, REPRESENTATION, AND REDUNDANCY, WE WILL ADDRESS OUR MAIN GOALS TO PERPETUATE SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS AND ENSURE EXISTING PONDS REMAIN FUNCTIONAL BREEDING SITES. BY THE END OF THIS PROJECT, INFORMATION ON CAPTIVE BREEDING, SUCCESS OF RELEASING LARVAE WITH DIFFERENT LEVELS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND A LIST OF PRIORITY RELEASE SITES WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO ASSIST IN SCLTS RECOVERY PLANNING AND ACTIONS. BASED ON OUR GENETIC ANALYSES AND HABITAT RANKINGS, THESE FUTURE ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE CREATING OR STOCKING NEW PONDS, CREATING NEW GENETIC CROSSES, AND PLANNING FUTURE RELEASE SITES.

A SURVEY OF GENETIC DIVERSITY OF HUDSONIA MONTANA IN 2020 AND 2021, SEED AND STEM CUTTINGS WERE SAMPLED FROM FIVE SUBPOPULATIONS OF THE CRITICALLY IMPERILED (G1) HUDSONIA MONTANA IN LINVILLE GORGE WILDERNESS, ITSELF A SECAS BLUEPRINT AREA OF HIGHEST CONSERVATION PRIORITY. DATA AND SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM SUBPOPULATIONS INCLUDED PHENOLOGY ASSESSMENT OF POPULATIONS, FOLLOWED BY SEED COLLECTION AND NON-LETHAL STEM CUTTINGS. SEED VIABILITY WAS TESTED, GERMINATION AND PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS WERE DEVELOPED, AND PLANTS WERE GROWN OUT IN THE ATLANTA BOTANICAL GARDENS CONSERVATION GREENHOUSE.  A GENETIC SURVEY OF HUDSONIA MONTANA IS NEEDED TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS WITH RESPECT TO DISTINCT GENETICS, IF THEY EXIST, AMONG POPULATIONS OF HUDSONIA MONTANA. HUDSONIA MONTANA HAS A PUBLISHED CHROMOSOME COUNT OF 2N   20 (LOVE 1985). THE SPECIES PLOIDY IS UNCHARACTERIZED, ALTHOUGH THE THREE REPORTS ON THIS GENUS SHOW NO EVIDENCE OF POLYPLOIDY. WE PROPOSE TO USE MICROSATELLITE MARKERS TO SURVEY GENETIC DIVERSITY METRICS WITHIN AND AMONG EOS. THE STARTING HYPOTHESIS IS THAT THE TABLEROCK AND FLAT LEDGE POPULATIONS OF HUDSONIA MONTANA NUTT. (CISTACEAE  MOUNTAIN GOLDENHEATHER) ARE GENETICALLY DISTINCT. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT LEAF DNA SAMPLING ACROSS ITS RANGE AND DETERMINE THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF HUDSONIA MONTANA TO INFORM NEEDED SAFEGUARDING AND IN SITU REINTRODUCTION AND AUGMENTATION ACTIONS.

THYSANOCARPUS CONCHULIFERUS GREENE IS A DIMINUTIVE ANNUAL HERB IN THE MUSTARD FAMILY, OR BRASSICACEAE. KNOWN AS THE SANTA CRUZ ISLAND FRINGEPOD, THE SPECIES WAS THOUGHT TO BE LIMITED TO 15 CALIFORNIA NATURAL DIVERSITY DATABASE (CNDDB) ELEMENT OCCURRENCES (EOS) ON SANTA CRUZ ISLAND. DUE TO ITS RARITY, THE SPECIES WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, AND HAS BEEN GIVEN THE RARE PLANT RANKING OF 1B.2 BY THE CALIFORNIA NATIVE PLANT SOCIETY. IN 2008, SPECIMENS IDENTIFIED AS T. CONCHULIFERUS WERE COLLECTED BY BURGESS ET AL. ON THE MAINLAND NEAR SANDSTONE PEAK IN THE WESTERN SANTA MONICA MOUNTAINS (SMM). SINCE THAT TIME, ADDITIONAL POPULATIONS NEAR SANDSTONE PEAK HAVE BEEN VOUCHERED, AS WELL AS NEW POPULATIONS FROM TWO OTHER REGIONS IN THE SMM. THESE MAINLAND SPECIMENS ATTRIBUTED TO T. CONCHULIFERUS CALL INTO QUESTION BOTH THE CIRCUMSCRIPTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF THIS RARE SPECIES.WE WILL CONDUCT A PHYLOGENOMIC STUDY OF THYSANOCARPUS, WITH THE OBJECTIVES OF 1) ESTIMATING A GENUS-LEVEL PHYLOGENY, 2) EVALUATING THE CIRCUMSCRIPTION OF T. CONCHULIFERUS, AND 3) ASSESSING THE PHYLOGENETIC PLACEMENT OF SAMPLES OF PUTATIVE T. CONCHULIFERUS FROM THE SMM. DNA SEQUENCE DATA WILL BE GATHERED USING THE REDUCED REPRESENTATION APPROACH DDRADSEQ. APPROXIMATELY 30 SAMPLES WILL BE GATHERED ON SANTA CRUZ ISLAND, 30 FROM THE SMM, AND AN ADDITIONAL 30 FROM THROUGHOUT THE GENUS.

WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT AT-SEA SURVEYS IN CONSERVATION ZONE 3 (COLUMBIA RIVER TO COOS BAY, OREGON) IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PROTOCOL AND SURVEY DESIGN DESCRIBED IN RAPHAEL ET AL. (2007). THESE DATA WILL BE USED TO OBTAIN AN ABUNDANCE ESTIMATE FOR 2024 AND, IN CONCERT WITH ALL PRIOR SURVEYS, WILL BE USED TO DESCRIBE THE OVERALL POPULATION TREND WITHIN ZONE 3 AND OVER THE ENTIRE NWFP AREA. THIS SUBSTANTIALLY MEETS THE OBJECTIVES OF NWFP MARBLED MURRELET MONITORING IN THIS REGION.FINAL PRODUCTSPROVISION OF MARBLED MURRELET DATA IN THE PRESCRIBED FORMAT FOR ABUNDANCE MONITORING, PROVISION OF ALL OTHER SEABIRD AND MARINE MAMMAL DATA, AND AN ANNUAL REPORT DETAILING SURVEY EFFORT, DISTRIBUTION OF MURRELETS, AND DETECTIONS OF FLEDGLING MURRELETS AT SEA.

THE SIHEK RECOVERY PROGRAM IS A GLOBAL COLLABORATIVE OF CONSERVATIONISTS DEDICATED TO RECOVERING ONE OF GUAMS MOST ICONIC NATIVE SPECIES. THE SIHEK (GUAM KINGFISHER, TODIRAMPHUS CINNAMOMINUS) WAS DRIVEN TO EXTINCTION IN THE WILD BY 1988 DUE TO PREDATION BY INVASIVE BROWN TREESNAKES (BOIGA IRREGULARIS). TWENTY-NINE OF THE LAST WILD SIHEK WERE BROUGHT INTO ZOOS TO START A CONSERVATION BREEDING PROGRAM. TODAY, THIS POPULATION INCLUDES 137 ADULT SIHEK IN 25 FACILITIES AROUND THE US MAINLAND AND ONE FACILITY ON GUAM. HOWEVER, THE SPECIES IS ONCE AGAIN AT RISK DUE TO THE EFFECTS OF SMALL POPULATION SIZE AND INBREEDING. RECENT ANALYSES SUGGEST IT WILL DECLINE TO EXTINCTION UNLESS THE GLOBAL POPULATION CAN BE SUBSTANTIALLY INCREASED, BUT ZOOS ARE NEARING CAPACITY, AND IT WILL NOT BE POSSIBLE TO RELEASE SIHEK TO GUAM UNTIL SNAKES ARE CONTROLLED. OUR PROJECT AIMS TO AVERT THE PREDICTED DECLINE TO EXTINCTION BY (1) EXPANDING THE CONSERVATION BREEDING PROGRAM ON GUAM AND (2) ESTABLISHING THE FIRST WILD SIHEK POPULATION IN 35 YEARS BY INTRODUCING THE SPECIES TO PALMYRA ATOLL. WE WILL RAISE SIHEK AT A QUARANTINED REARING FACILITY IN HAWAII AND TRANSPORT A SUBSET OF BIRDS TO A FACILITY AT GUAM DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE DIVISION OF AQUATIC   WILDLIFE RESOURCES. THE MAJORITY OF SIHEK RAISED IN HAWAII (UP TO 27 INDIVIDUALS OVER A THREE-YEAR PERIOD) WILL BE RELEASED TO PALMYRA ATOLL. WE WILL MONITOR AND PROVIDE SUPPORTIVE MANAGEMENT TO THE POPULATION FOR FIVE YEARS AND USE THE DATA WE COLLECT TO CONTINUOUSLY EVALUATE AND ADJUST OUR MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO MAXIMIZE THE POPULATIONS CHANCE OF SUCCESS. COMBINED, OUR EFFORTS ON GUAM AND PALMYRA HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO EXPAND THE GLOBAL SIHEK POPULATION BY APPROXIMATELY 53 . AT THE SAME TIME, ESTABLISHING A POPULATION ON PALMYRA ATOLL WILL ENABLE US TO PRODUCE SIHEK THAT ARE ADAPTED TO LIFE IN THE WILD AND DEVELOP EFFECTIVE RELEASE METHODS THAT CAN ONE DAY BE USED TO REINTRODUCE SIHEK TO GUAM.

THE CALIFORNIA RED-LEGGED FROG (CRLF) IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED AMPHIBIAN THAT IS EXPERIENCINGPOPULATION DECLINES THROUGHOUT MUCH OF ITS RANGE (USFWS 2002). WHEN COMPARED WITH HISTORICAL RECORDS, THE MODERN DISTRIBUTION OF CRLF SHOWS NUMEROUS LOCAL EXTIRPATIONS IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AND MANY EXTANT POPULATIONS THAT ARE COMPLETELY ISOLATED FROM ONE ANOTHER (THOMSON, WRIGHT, AND SHAFFER 2016). IN ADDITION TO THIS RECENT PHYSICAL ISOLATION, CRLF POPULATION DIFFERENTIATION HAS PRESUMABLY ALSO BEEN SHAPED BY THE LOW RAINFALL AND THE XERIC LANDSCAPE OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA THAT HAVE ALWAYS CHARACTERIZED THE REGION. THIS COMBINATION OF HISTORICAL AND ANTHROPOGENIC EFFECTS HAS RENDERED MANY SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA POPULATIONS OF CRLF GENETICALLY DISTINCT AND EXPRESSING STRONG EVIDENCE OF DECREASED GENETIC VARIATION (RICHMOND ET AL. 2013). ONE SUCH ISOLATED POPULATION, EAST LAS VIRGENES (ELV), LOS ANGELES COUNTY, SHOWS A NEAR TWOFOLD DECREASE IN GENETIC VARIATION AND A 2.5-FOLD INCREASE IN RELATEDNESS AMONG INDIVIDUALS WITHIN THE POPULATION WHEN COMPARED TO LARGER, MORE INTACT POPULATIONS (RICHMOND ET AL. 2013). REINTRODUCTION PROGRAMS BY WILDLIFE MANAGERS INTRODUCING CRLF FROM THE SMALL REMAINING EAST LAS VIRGENES POPULATION TO NEARBY EXTIRPATED STREAM SITES HAVE RE-ESTABLISHED FROGS, AND SEVERAL OF THESE POPULATIONS ARE NOW SUCCESSFULLY BREEDING ON THEIR OWN (DR. KATY DELANEY, UNPUBLISHED DATA). ALTHOUGH CLEARLY SUCCESSFUL AT THE IMMEDIATE DEMOGRAPHIC LEVEL, MANAGERS OF THE CRLF DO NOT CURRENTLY HAVE THE DATA NECESSARY TO ESTIMATE THE EXTENT TO WHICH THE ELV SOURCE POPULATION MAY HARBOR RELATIVELY HIGH LEVELS OF DELETERIOUS GENETIC VARIANTS BECAUSE OF INBREEDING, OR HOW SUCH HARMFUL VARIATION MAY AFFECT POPULATION FITNESS IN THE NEAR FUTURE. FURTHER, LITTLE EFFORT HAS BEEN MADE TO ASSESS THE EXTENT TO WHICH SOURCING INDIVIDUALS FROM OTHER, NEARBY POPULATIONS MIGHT BE USED TO INCREASE THE EVOLUTIONARY POTENTIAL OF LOCAL CRLF POPULATIONS RATHER THAN USING A SINGLE SOURCE FROM ELV. WE PROPOSE TO SEQUENCE THE ENTIRE GENOMES OF NINE INDIVIDUAL CRLFS FROM MULTIPLE LOCAL REGIONS TO PROVIDE THE DATA NEEDED TO ANSWER THESE QUESTIONS.

CRITICALLYENDANGEREDHAWAIIANFORESTBIRDSHAVEDECLINEDSUCHTHATINTENSIVECONSERVATIONBREEDINGPROVIDESTHEONLYREALISTICHOPETOPREVENTIMMINENTEXTINCTIONFORTHEEVENTUALRECOVERYINTHEWILD.THEKEAUHOUANDMAUIBIRDCONSERVATIONCENTERSINHAWAIIAREOPERATEDBYTHESANDIEGOZOOWILDLIFEALLIANCE,ASPARTOFTHEFORESTBIRDCONSERVATIONBREEDINGPARTNERSHIPWITHTHEU.S.FISHANDWILDLIFESERVICEANDSTATEOFHAWAIIDEPARTMENTOFLANDANDNATURALRESOURCESDIVISIONOFFORESTRYANDWILDLIFE.THISPROGRAMCOLLABORATESTOPREVENTEXTINCTIONS,ANDTORE-ESTABLISHORSUPPLEMENTWILDPOPULATIONSOFENDEMICFORESTBIRDSOFHAWAII,USINGHUSBANDRY,AVICULTURE,CONSERVATIONBREEDING,ANDREINTRODUCTIONTECHNIQUES.SINCE1993,THISEFFORTHASREAREDOVER1150OFFSPRINGFROM16DIFFERENTENDEMICHAWAIIANBIRDSPECIESANDRELEASEDOVER840BIRDSINTOTHEWILD,ANDHASMADESIGNIFICANTCAPITALINVESTMENTSATTHETWOPERMANENTFACILITIES.FURTHERMORE,THISPROGRAMBEENRECOGNIZEDBYTHEASSOCIATIONOFZOOS ANDAQUARIUMSNORTHAMERICANCONSERVATIONAWARD,ASWELLASTHEU.S.FISHANDWILDLIFESERVICESRECOVERYCHAMPIONSAWARDINBOTH2018AND2019.PRIORTOTHEESTABLISHMENTOFTHISCONSERVATIONBREEDINGANDREINTRODUCTIONPROGRAM,NOINSTITUTIONORENTITYHASDEMONSTRATEDTHEABILITYTOCAREFORANDBREEDENDANGEREDHAWAIIANBIRDSATAHIGHLEVELUNDERHUMANCARE.

QUANTIFYING POPULATION STRUCTURE AND ADAPTIVE GENOMIC VARIATION WITHIN ENDANGERED SPECIES IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF MODERN CONSERVATION INITIATIVES. OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL APPLY CONSERVATION GENOMICS TO THE ENDANGERED QUINO CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY, EUPHYDRYAS EDITHA QUINO. PREVIOUS GENETIC WORK ON E. E. QUINO RELIED ON AMPLIFIED FRAGMENT LENGTH POLYMORPHISMS (AFLPS) AND MICROSATELLITES, WHICH HAVE VERY LIMITED POWER FOR RESOLVING FINESCALE POPULATION STRUCTURE THAT HAS EVOLVED SINCE ANTHROPOGENICALLY DRIVEN POPULATION DECLINES STARTED IN THE 1980S. FURTHERMORE, THESE DATA CANNOT BE USED TO RESOLVE LOCAL ADAPTATION TO ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS, IDENTIFY HOST PLANT-ASSOCIATED DIVERGENCES THAT ARE OFTEN LOCALIZED IN BUTTERFLY GENOMES, OR USED TO ESTIMATE EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZES. BECAUSE OF THESE KNOWLEDGE GAPS, PAST AND ONGOING TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS (ATTEMPTING TO BOTH RE-ESTABLISH EXTIRPATED POPULATIONS AND AUGMENT DECLINING POPULATIONS) HAVE NOT TAKEN GENETIC DIVERSITY OR LOCAL ADAPTATION OF SOURCE POPULATIONS INTO CONSIDERATION. ADDRESSING THESE KNOWLEDGE GAPS WILL REQUIRE EQUAL PARTS LANDSCAPE GENOMICS, TO RESOLVE PATTERNS OF POPULATION STRUCTURE, HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, AND LOCAL ADAPTATION, AND FORWARD-IN-TIME LANDSCAPE AND ENVIRONMENTAL MODELLING, TO DETERMINE THE FATE OF PREFERRED HABITAT FOR E. E. QUINO. INFORMATION GENERATED BY OUR PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL ENSURE THAT TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS FOCUS ON SOURCE POPULATIONS THAT ARE MOST VIABLE, BOTH IN TERMS OF THEIR ECOLOGY AND GENOMIC COMPOSITION. FURTHERMORE, RESULTING GENOMIC DATA WILL ENABLE US TO ESTIMATE EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZES OF ALL POPULATION CLUSTERS IDENTIFIED. ADDITIONAL WORK FUNDED BY THE CALIFORNIA CONSERVATION GENOMICS PROJECT (CCGP) WILL ADDRESS LANDSCAPE GENOMICS AND PHYLOGEOGRAPHY OF E. EDITHA ACROSS CALIFORNIA, HELPING RESOLVE THE EVOLUTIONARY DISTINCTIVENESS OF E. E. QUINO AND CONTEXTUALIZE ONGOING CONSERVATION EFFORTS. WE HAVE MOST OF OUR REQUIRED SPECIMENS IN-HAND (N   65), AND REQUIRE FUNDING TO COVER A SUBSET OF OUR FIELD WORK AND WHOLE-GENOME SEQUENCING COSTS.

THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT WAS SIGNED ON DECEMBER 28, 1973. IT EMPHASIZED THAT MANY OF OUR NATIONS NATIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS WERE IN DANGER OF BECOMING EXTINCT AND PROVIDED PROTECTION FOR ECOSYSTEMS, CONSERVATION OF ENDANGERED AND THREATENED SPECIES, AND THE ENFORCEMENT OF ALL TREATIES RELATED TO WILDLIFE PRESERVATION. THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT HAS BEEN HIGHLY EFFECTIVE AND CREDITED WITH SAVING 99  OF LISTED SPECIES FROM EXTINCTION. IN 2023 THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT WILL TURN 50. TO CELEBRATE THE SUCCESSES TO DATE AND RECOGNIZE THE WORK STILL TO BE DONE THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WOULD LIKE TO PARTNER WITH AN ORGANIZATION TO COORDINATE CELEBRATORY ACTIVITIES AND EVENTS THAT WILL INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF AND SUPPORT FOR THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT.ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY, ESTABLISHED IN 2006 THROUGH THE EFFORTS OF THE SENATE, INCLUDING FORMER SENATOR JOE BIDEN, IS ONE ASPECT OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT CELEBRATION AND PREPARATION. ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY PROVIDES PUBLIC EDUCATION ON THE IMPORTANCE OF ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION. IT IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO SHED LIGHT ON THE BIODIVERSITY CRISIS, RAISE AWARENESS FOR THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, GARNER SUPPORT FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION, ESPECIALLY WITH YOUNGER GENERATIONS, AND PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS TO ENGAGE IN ENDANGERED SPECIES CONSERVATION EFFORTS. ACTIVITIES THE ACTIVITIES FOR THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATION WILL INCLUDE THE CONTINUATION OF A STEERING COMMITTEE TO ORCHESTRATE COORDINATION OF CELEBRATORY ACTIVITIES ACROSS NONPROFIT, INSTITUTIONAL, AND AGENCY PARTNERS, MAINTENANCE OF A WEBPAGE FOR THE ANNIVERSARY, AN ART GALLERY, AN ENGAGEMENT CALENDAR, CAREER PANELS, AND AN ESSAY CONTEST. THE ACTIVITIES FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY 2023 WILL INCLUDE COORDINATION AND ENGAGEMENT OF NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, INSTITUTIONS, SCHOOLS, PARKS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS, A CHALK ART EVENT, A MEDIA CAMPAIGN, EDUCATIONAL EVENTS, AND A WEBSITE. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE DELIVERABLES FOR THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY AND ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY CELEBRATIONS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING.REGULAR MONTHLY MEETINGS OF THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY STEERING COMMITTEE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY COMMITTEE. UP-TO-DATE WEBSITE WITH ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY EVENTS AND ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY EVENTS, RESOURCES. IMPLEMENTATION OF A STUDENT COLLABORATIVE ART GALLERY, CONSERVATION CAREER PANELS, ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY ESSAY CONTEST, ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY ESSAY CONTEST, CHALK ART EVENT FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY. CREATION OF AN EDUCATIONAL ENGAGEMENT CALENDAR. COORDINATION AND COMPLETION OF ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY NEWS STORIES AND SOCIAL MEDIA POSTINGS, EDUCATIONAL EVENTS ACROSS THE UNITED STATES.THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES FOR THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY AND ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY CELEBRATIONS INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING:1. PARTICIPATION OF 20 OR MORE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS IN THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT 50TH ANNIVERSARY STEERING COMMITTEE2. ENGAGEMENT OF 50 CLASSROOMS IN THE COLLABORATIVE ENDANGERED SPECIES ARTWORK SHARED IN A NATIONAL GALLERY3. ENGAGEMENT OF 150 K-12 AND COLLEGE STUDENTS IN LEARNING ABOUT CONSERVATION CAREER OPPORTUNITIES AND RESOURCES4. ENGAGEMENT OF 100 K-12 STUDENTS IN A NATIONWIDE 50TH-ANNIVERSARY ESSAY CONTEST5. PARTICIPATION OF 300 OR MORE NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, GOVERNMENT AGENCIES, INSTITUTIONS, SCHOOLS, PARKS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPS IN ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY 20236. ENGAGEMENT OF 100 YOUTH AND ADULTS IN A NATIONWIDE ENDANGERED SPECIES CHALK ART EVENT7. OUTREACH TO 10 MILLION PEOPLE WITH NEWS STORIES, SOCIAL MEDIA POSTS, AND OTHER PUBLIC MESSAGING ABOUT ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY AND THE IMPORTANCE OF BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION8. EDUCATION OF U.S. RESIDENTS ABOUT THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES VIA 50 ENDANGERED SPECIES DAY EVENTS AROUND THE COUNTRY

THE SEED CONSERVATION LABORATORY AT LYON ARBORETUM AIMS TO SECURE FUNDING FOR A 3-YEAR PROJECT SEEKING A KUPU INTERN TO ENHANCE THE LAB S SEED RESEARCH AND BANKING EFFORTS. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT INTENDS TO SUPPORT INCREASED COLLECTIONS OF NATIVE PLANTS FROM HAWAI I S NATIONAL PARKS. THIS INITIATIVE WILL BE EXECUTED THROUGH A COLLABORATIVE PARTNERSHIP INVOLVING THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, THE STATE OF HAWAI I S DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE, AND THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAI I PLANT EXTINCTION PREVENTION PROGRAM. THE INTERN S ROLE WILL BE PIVOTAL IN ACCOMPLISHING THE FOLLOWING PROJECT GOALS: 1) IDENTIFYING STORAGE, DORMANCY, AND GERMINATION PROTOCOLS FOR NATIVE PLANTS BY WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE SEED CONSERVATION LAB S TEAM TO RESEARCH AND DEVELOP OPTIMAL METHODS FOR NATIVE PLANTS FOUND WITHIN THE NATIONAL PARKS. THUS, ENSURING THE LONG-TERM VIABILITY AND PRESERVATION OF THESE NATIVE SPECIES AND INFORMING FUTURE RESTORATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS. 2) SUPPLYING PLANTS AND SEEDS FOR RESTORATION  CONTRIBUTING TO THE CONSERVATION OF HAWAI I S NATIVE PLANT SPECIES BY COLLECTING, PROPAGATION, AND DISTRIBUTING PLANTS AND SEEDS WITHIN THE NATIONAL PARKS. THEREBY ENHANCING ECOSYSTEM RESILIENCE, AND HELPING MAINTAIN THE UNIQUE BIODIVERSITY OF THESE CRITICAL HABITATS. 3) INCREASING THE BACKUP, LONG-TERM SEED COLLECTIONS HELD WITHIN THE SEED CONSERVATION LAB. THESE COLLECTIONS WILL SERVE AS A SAFEGUARD AGAINST THREATS TO NATIVE PLANT POPULATIONS, SUCH AS HABITAT LOSS, CLIMATE CHANGE, OR INVASIVE SPECIES. BY PRESERVING SEEDS IN A CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT, THE PROJECT AIMS TO ENSURE THE SURVIVAL AND AVAILABILITY OF THESE NATIVE SPECIES FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS, AND 4) GROWING PARTNERSHIPS AMONG COORDINATING PROGRAMS. THE KUPU INTERN S INVOLVEMENT IN THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE VALUABLE, HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE IN SEED RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION, AND CONTRIBUTE SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND RESTORATION OF HAWAI I S NATIVE PLANT SPECIES.

WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT SURVEYS FOR YADON S PIPERIA TO DETERMINE AREAL EXTENT, ABUNDANCE, AND CURRENT THREATS AT OCCURRENCES WITHIN DEL MONTE FOREST CONSERVANCY AND PEBBLE BEACH COMPANY LAND, AS WELL AS AT POINT LOBOS RANCH. TASK 1: EVALUATE LONG-TERM POPULATION ESTABLISHMENT FROM SEED. WE WILL RECENSUS 44 PLOTS SEEDED WITH YADONS PIPERIA IN 2006 AND 2007, TO COUNT THE NUMBER OF VEGETATIVE PLANTS IN WINTER ( MARCH) AND THEN REVISIT THE PLOTS IN THE SUMMER (AUGUST) TO COUNT THE NUMBER OF PLANTS THAT REPRODUCE. THE SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR TWO YEARS (E.G. 2024 AND 2025) AS YADONS PIPERIA VEGETATIVE ABUNDANCE AND FLOWERING ARE HIGHLY INFLUENCED BY ANNUAL PRECIPITATION. REFERENCE SITES WITHIN DEL MONTE FOREST CONSERVANCY WILL ALSO BE QUALITATIVELY EVALUATED FOR COMPARISON.TASK 2: MAP AND CHARACTERIZE THE POPULATION OF YADONS PIPERIA WITHIN POINT LOBOS RANCH. WE WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A STUDY TO MAP AND CHARACTERIZE THE DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT OF YADONS PIPERIA WITHIN POINT LOBOS RANCH. THE STUDY WILL BE CONDUCTED IN A SINGLE YEAR OF AT LEAST NORMAL WINTER RAINFALL WHICH IS SUFFICIENT TO PROMOTE ABOVEGROUND EMERGENCE.

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE VIABILITY OF SANTA CRUZ CYPRESS SEED HELD IN PARTIALLY OPENED CONES THROUGH TWO APPROACHES:1. QUANTIFYING THE AMOUNT OF SEEDS PER OPENED CONE, WHICH CAN BE COMBINED WITH A SEPARATE ASSESSMENT OF THE NUMBER OF OPEN CONES LEFT ON TREES, TO QUANTIFY THE AMOUNT OF SEED HELD IN THE AERIAL SEED BANK 2. ANALYZING GERMINABILITY AND VIABILITY TO CALCULATE THE PERCENTAGE OF SEED THAT GERMINATES IN THE LAB, AND THE PERCENTAGE OF SEED THAT DOES NOT GERMINATE BUT THAT IS VIABLE (I.E., DORMANT).THESE MEASUREMENTS WILL BE COMBINED WITH DATA COLLECTED AS PART OF A SEPARATE STUDY ON SANTA CRUZ CYPRESS, TO ESTIMATE THE AMOUNT OF SEED THAT IS HELD IN TREES THAT COULD CONTRIBUTE TO SEEDLING ESTABLISHMENT THREE YEARS (PLUS) POST FIRE. THE SEPARATE STUDY, WHICH IS BEING FUNDED BY SECTION 6 FUNDS (FAIN F22AP000087-00), IS EXAMINING THE EFFECTS OF THE CZU LIGHTNING COMPLEX FIRE ON THE AREAL EXTENT AND POPULATION ABUNDANCE OF SANTA CRUZ CYPRESS POST FIRE.

WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A STUDY OF THE POINT LOBOS POPULATION OF GOWEN CYPRESS TO ASSESS THE THREATS TO PERSISTENCE IN ORDER TO INFORM MANAGEMENT.  SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL SAMPLE THE POPULATION TO CHARACTERIZE ITS ABUNDANCE, STAGE DISTRIBUTION, RECRUITMENT, AND THREATS.  SAMPLING WILL BE CONDUCTED IN PERMANENTLY MONUMENTED AND GEOREFERENCED PLOTS, WHICH CAN BE MONITORED IN THE FUTURE TO ASSESS POPULATION CHANGES. TASK 1: ASSESS THE POINT LOBOS RANCH GOWEN CYPRESS POPULATION: IN THIS TASK, WE WILL CONDUCT AN INITIAL ASSESSMENT OF THE POPULATION TO DESIGN THE MONITORING STUDY. THE TASK INCLUDES WORK TO PREPARE FOR AND CONDUCT THE QUALITATIVE ASSESSMENT WHICH WILL GENERALLY EVALUATE THE STAND DISTRIBUTION, ASSESS THE STAND STRUCTURE, AND EVALUATE CONDITIONS THAT CAN BE QUANTIFIED DURING MONITORING. TASK 2: SAMPLE THE POPULATION AND CHARACTERIZE THREATS: WE WILL USE SAMPLE PLOTS TO ASSESS STAND DENSITY, STAGE STRUCTURE, AND RECRUITMENT, AND TO EVALUATE THREATS INCLUDING VEGETATION MANAGEMENT, EXOTIC PLANTS, AND SENESCENCE RISK. PLOTS WILL BE LOCATED RANDOMLY WITHIN THE STAND, SO THAT THE PLOT DATA WILL REPRESENT THE POPULATIONS. WITHIN EACH PLOT, DATA WILL BE COLLECTED ON THE AGE SIZE STRUCTURE USING STAGE CLASSES (E.G. SEEDLINGS, JUVENILES, AND ADULTS OF VARIOUS CLASSES BASED ON DIAMETER AT BREAST HEIGHT). THREATS WILL BE CATEGORIZED FOR EACH PLOT. PLOTS WILL BE PERMANENTLY MONUMENTED AND GEOREFERENCED, ALLOWING FUTURE MONITORING.

THE NORTHERN IDAHO GROUND SQUIRREL (UROCITELLUS BRUNNEUS  NIDGS) IS A FEDERALLY LISTED THREATENED SPECIES. THE RECOVERY PLAN, PUBLISHED IN 2003, ESTABLISHED CRITERIA FOR ASSESSING HOW THE SPECIES WAS MOVING TOWARD RECOVERY AND EVENTUAL DELISTING. THOSE CRITERIA INCLUDED GOALS FOR NIDGS ABUNDANCE AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION ON THE LANDSCAPE. ANNUAL POPULATION MONITORING SURVEYS HAVE SHOWN THAT SEVERAL METRICS OF ABUNDANCE AND TREND HAVE BEEN ON AN UPWARD TRAJECTORY SINCE 2011 AND ARE SUBSTANTIALLY HIGHER THAN WHEN THE RECOVERY PLAN WAS PUBLISHED IN 2003. HOWEVER, NO POPULATION METRIC IDENTIFIED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN HAS BEEN ACHIEVED. NIDGS STILL OCCURS MOST FREQUENTLY IN SMALL POPULATIONS THAT ARE GEOGRAPHICALLY AND GENETICALLY SEPARATED FROM ONE ANOTHER. WELL-DEFINED, REPEATABLE SURVEYS ARE NEEDED TO TRACK IF, AND TO WHAT EXTENT, THE NIDGS POPULATION IS MOVING TOWARD RECOVERY. WITHOUT SUCH DATA, RECOVERY CRITERIA CANNOT BE MEASURED, AND IT BECOMES MORE DIFFICULT TO DIRECT MEANINGFUL CONSERVATION ACTIONS WHERE THEY WILL HAVE THE MOST BENEFIT. THIS PROJECT CONTINUES FUNDING FOR 2 YEARS FOR AN IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (IDFG) EMPLOYEE TO SERVE AS PROJECT COORDINATOR TO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT OF NIDGS RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION, INCLUDING SURVEYS TO OBTAIN CURRENT INFORMATION ON NIDGS ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION USING A PROVEN SURVEY DESIGN, ANALYSIS OF RESULTS TO ASSESS POPULATION TRAJECTORY, DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION TO OTHER PARTNERS IN RECOVERY TO INFORM THEIR EFFORTS TO IMPROVE HABITAT, EVALUATION OF NIDGS RESPONSE TO HABITAT TREATMENTS, AND DEVELOPMENT OF CONSERVATION ACTIONS ON PRIVATE LAND. CHANGES IN DISTRIBUTION DETECTED ON SURVEYS WILL INFLUENCE MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AND LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL AID IN DEVELOPING APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES AND, ULTIMATELY, RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES. ANTICIPATED PRODUCTS INCLUDE (1) ANNUAL STATISTICAL SUMMARIES AND FINAL REPORTS OF SURVEY DATA, INCLUDING ESTIMATES OF NIDGS ABUNDANCE, POPULATION TREND, AND SPATIAL DISTRIBUTION  AND (2) UPDATED SPATIAL DATA LAYERS OF NIDGS OCCURRENCE THAT WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO RECOVERY PARTNERS.

THE PROJECT WILL PREVENT THE EXTINCTION OF OVER 150 OF HAWAII S FEDERALLY LISTED PLANT SPECIES. OBJECTIVE 1 IS TO PROTECT IN SITU POPULATIONS OF AT LEAST 45 SPECIES BY CONTROLLING THREATS IDENTIFIED IN RECOVERY PLANS. THREATS INCLUDE INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH AS UNGULATES, RODENTS, INVERTEBRATES, MOLLUSKS, AND PLANTS AND PRIORITY WILL BE FOR SPECIES WITHOUT ANY PROTECTED SITES. OBJECTIVE 2 IS TO CONDUCT SURVEYS AND OR PROPAGULE COLLECTIONS OF AT LEAST 75 LISTED SPECIES. THE HIGHEST PRIORITY FOR COLLECTIONS ARE SPECIES WITHOUT ANY EX SITU COLLECTIONS (SPECIES-LEVEL COLLECTIONS) AND THE SECOND PRIORITY TO UNDER-REPRESENTED SPECIES (SITE-SPECIFIC COLLECTIONS). OBJECTIVE 3 IS TO CREATE NEW OR SUPPLEMENT RESTORATION SITES OF AT LEAST 30 SPECIES BY OUTPLANTING IN COLLABORATION WITH CONSERVATION AND LANDOWNER PARTNERS. THIS FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE INCREASING COST OF ONGOING OPERATIONS ON KAUAI, OAHU, MOLOKAI, MAUI, LANAI, AND HAWAII ISLAND AND EXPAND PEPP BY HIRING ADDITIONAL FIELD TECHNICIANS AND OR ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANCE TO HELP WITH GRANT ADMINISTRATION AND LOGISTICS. EXPENSES WILL INCLUDE STAFF SALARY, SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT FOR FIELD OPERATIONS, TRAINING, INTER-ISLAND TRANSPORT OF PLANTS AND PROPAGULES, AND HELICOPTER CONTRACTS TO ENABLE WORK IN REMOTE FIELD SITES. IF INCREMENTAL FUNDING IS AVAILABLE, THOSE FUNDS WILL SUPPORT THE INCREASING COST OF SUPPLIES FOR CONDUCTING ADDITIONAL THREAT CONTROL AND THE PURCHASE OF A 4X4 TRUCK TO REPLACE AGED EQUIPMENT IN YEARS 2 AND 4. ALL PROPOSED ACTIVITIES ARE PRIORITY 1 OR 2 RECOVERY ACTIONS DESCRIBED IN USFWS RECOVERY PLANS, OR ARE IDENTICAL ACTIONS APPLIED TO SPECIES WITHOUT RECOVERY PLANS INCLUDING SURVEYS, MONITORING, THREAT CONTROL, PROPAGULE COLLECTION, AND OUTPLANTING TO INCREASE RESILIENCE, REPRESENTATION, AND REDUNDANCY FOR RECOVERY THROUGHOUT HAWAII.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC SAFETY BY REDUCING HUMAN-POLAR BEAR INTERACTIONS THAT COULD POTENTIALLY RESULT IN INJURY OR DEATH TO HUMANS AND POLAR BEARS IN ALASKA. THIS WORK WILL HELP CONSERVE POLAR BEARS BY REDUCING CONFLICTS BETWEEN POLAR BEARS AND HUMANS THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF A POLAR BEAR DETERRENCE PROGRAM (POLAR BEAR PATROLS) IN THE NORTH SLOPE COMMUNITIES OF UTQIAGVIK (FORMERLY BARROW), KAKTOVIK, NUIQSUT (CROSS ISLAND), POINT HOPE, POINT LAY AND WAINWRIGHT.  THIS INVOLVES HIRING AND TRAINING VILLAGE RESIDENTS TO BE RESPONSIBLE FOR EARLY DETECTION OF POLAR BEARS, CONDUCTING VEHICLE-BASED PATROLS, HAZING (DETERRING) BEARS AS APPROPRIATE, ENCOURAGING ATTRACTANTS MANAGEMENT, AND REPORTING ON PATROL ACTIVITIES.

THE FRAGRANT PRICKLY-APPLE (HARRISIA FRAGRANS) WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 1985 (AS CEREUS ERIOPHORUS VAR. FRAGRANS). THE MOST RECENT 5-YEAR REVIEW (SERVICE 2021) RECOMMENDED A CHANGE IN ENTITY FOR THE SPECIES BY COMBINING IT WITH SIMPSONS PRICKLY-APPLE (HARRISIA SIMPSONII) BASED ON RECENT TAXONOMIC WORK. DUE TO A LACK OF PERCEIVED MORPHOLOGICAL DISTINCTION, THE CACTI WERE COMBINED AS ONE SPECIES BUT UNCERTAINTY REMAINS IF THEY SHOULD BE TREATED AS ONE SPECIES OR TWO SEPARATE SPECIES. THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO CONDUCT ROBUST GENETIC ANALYSES TO DEFINITIVELY DETERMINE IF H. FRAGRANS AND H. SIMPSONII ARE THE SAME SPECIES AND WHAT THEIR RELATIONSHIP IS TO THE OTHER FLORIDA AND CARIBBEAN SPECIES. TWO GENETIC ANALYSES WILL BE PERFORMED, ONE UTILIZING 10 NUCLEAR MICROSATELLITE LOCI FROM 80 SAMPLES OF H. FRAGRANS AND H. SIMPSONII AND THE OTHER SEQUENCING 353 SINGLE-COPY NUCLEAR LOCI ACROSS 50 SAMPLES COVERING ALL SPECIES OF HARRISIA INCLUDING 25 SAMPLES FROM ACROSS ITS RANGE IN FLORIDA.

THE KENTUCKY NATURAL LANDS TRUST PROPOSES PROJECTS IN FEDERAL FISCAL YEAR 2023 THAT WILL FURTHER BENEFIT FOREST AND LISTED BAT CONSERVATION AT FORT KNOX AS WELL AS THROUGHOUT THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY. THE PROJECTS WILL BE UNDERTAKEN ON FORT KNOX, KENTUCKY AND THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE RECOVERY PROGRAM, ADMINISTERED BY THE KENTUCKY FIELD OFFICE THROUGHOUT KENTUCKY. FORT KNOX, LOCATED IN NORTH- CENTRAL KENTUCKY, IS THE HOME OF THE ARMY CADET COMMAND, ARMY HUMAN RESOURCES COMMAND, ARMY RECRUITING COMMAND. FORT KNOX IS 109,000 ACRES IN SIZE AND PROVIDES HIGH-QUALITY, REALISTIC TRAINING LANDS FOR THE ARMY, AIR FORCE, NAVY, MARINE CORPS, NATIONAL GUARD, COAST GUARD, RESERVE FORCES, AND MILITARY UNITS OF OTHER NATIONS.IN COOPERATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE RESOURCES, FORT KNOX HAS DEVELOPED AN INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PLAN THAT GUIDES THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES PROGRAM ON THE INSTALLATION. THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OUTLINED HELP TO ENSURE THE CONSERVATION OF FORT KNOX S NATURAL RESOURCES, WHILE PROVIDING HIGH-QUALITY TRAINING LANDS TO SUPPORT THE MILITARY MISSION. THE PLAN OUTLINES SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES ON THE INSTALLATION, INCLUDING MONITORING FOR THE NORTHERN LONG-EARED BAT (MYOTIS SEPTENTRIONALIS) AND THE INDIANA BAT (MYOTIS SODALIS).THE COMMONWEALTH OF KENTUCKY HAS HISTORICALLY HAD A RICH FAUNAL DIVERSITY THAT HAS BEEN, TO VARYING DEGREES, IMPACTED BY DEVELOPMENT (HABITAT LOSS), HABITAT CONVERSION AND DISEASE (WHITE NOSE SYNDROME). THE KENTUCKY FIELD OFFICE AND ITS CONSERVATION PARTNERS CONTINUE TO PRIORITIZE THE IDENTIFICATION, RESTORATION (WHEN NEEDED), AND PROTECTION OF HABITATS WHERE FEDERALLY LISTED (E.G., INDIANA, GRAY, NORTHERN LONG-EARED, AND VIRGINIA BIG-EARED BATS) AND AT-RISK (E.G., LITTLE BROWN AND TRICOLORED BATS) SHELTER (ROOST), FEED (FORAGE), AND TRAVEL. FOR EXAMPLE, AN UNDERSTANDING OF THESE BAT SPECIES MIGRATORY ROUTES, ROOST TREES, AND MATERNITY COLONY LOCATIONS IN KENTUCKY IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE FIELD OFFICE AND ITS PARTNERS TO UNDERTAKE NECESSARY RECOVERY ACTIONS, AS WELL AS MINIMIZE ADVERSE EFFECTS THAT MAY RESULT FROM CERTAIN FOREST PRACTICES, ENERGY DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS, AND OTHER POTENTIAL IMPACTS TO THE SPECIES FORAGING GROUNDS AND ROOST TREES.  PROJECTS WILL BE UNDERTAKEN IN FIELD OFFICE PRIORITY AREAS THROUGHOUT THE COMMONWEALTH TO DIRECTLY BENEFIT CONSERVATION OF THESE SPECIES AND THE HABITATS THEY DEPEND ON THROUGH TARGETED RESEARCH TO BETTER UNDERSTAND ASPECTS OF THESE SPECIES LIFE HISTORY, TO SUPPORT IMPROVING SPECIES PRESENCE DETERMINATIONS, AND OR TO RESTORE AND PROTECT KEY HABITATS WHERE THE SPECIES PERSISTS.

OVER THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT, POLLINATOR HABITAT WILL BE RESTORED TO THE PROJECT AREA CLEARING THE SITE OF SOD GRASS, SEEDING A NATIVE POLLINATOR SEED MIX, AND PLANTING EARLY FLOWERING NATIVE SHRUBS. SEEDED AND PLANTED SPECIES WILL PROVIDE NESTING MATERIALS, OVERWINTERING AREAS, AND FOOD RESOURCES FOR NATIVE POLLINATORS. PRINCIPAL OBJECTIVES INCLUDE CLEARING SOD GRASS TO PREPARE AREAS FOR SEEDING AND PLANTING, SEED THE AREAS WITH A NATIVE POLLINATOR SEED MIX, AND PLANT NATIVE SHRUBS TO PROVIDE EARLY SEASON NECTAR AND POLLEN.

IN 2015, THE MALHEUR SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT (SWCD) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) INITIATED THE 30-YEAR PROGRAMMATIC CANDIDATE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT WITH ASSURANCES (CCAA) FOR GREATER SAGE-GROUSE IN MALHEUR COUNTY TO MAINTAIN IMPROVE SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT WHILE PRESERVING THE ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY AND RANCHING CULTURE IN OREGON. THE PROGRAMMATIC SAGE-GROUSE CCAAS ARE DESIGNED TO DIRECTLY ADDRESS THESE PRIMARY THREATS TO SAGEBRUSH ENVIRONMENTS (WILDFIRE, JUNIPER ENCROACHMENT, AND INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES), AS WELL AS OTHER SAGE-GROUSE SPECIFIC THREATS (E.G. WNV, FENCE COLLISION) OVER THE LONG-TERM (30 YEARS). COMPLETED SSPS SERVE AS RANCH MANAGEMENT PLANS TO GUIDE CONSERVATION WORK ON LOCAL PROPERTIES TO SPECIFICALLY ADDRESS THE PRIMARY ECOLOGICAL THREATS TO OREGON S RANGELANDS.

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL CONTINUE THE HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL EFFORT TO REAR AND RELEASE AGA OR MARIANA CROWS (CORVUS KUBARYI) ON THE ISLAND OF ROTA TO AUGMENT THE LAST EXTANT POPULATION OF THIS CRITICALLY ENDANGERED CORVID. FOLLOWING EXTIRPATION ON GUAM AND  90  DECLINE ON ROTA, THE POPULATION NOW STANDS AT APPROXIMATELY 55 BREEDING PAIRS AND IS HIGHLY VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION. NATURAL POPULATION RECRUITMENT HAS BEEN MINIMAL DUE TO LOW REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND POOR JUVENILE SURVIVAL, MUCH OF WHICH HAS BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO AN UNIDENTIFIED INFLAMMATORY SYNDROME. IN RESPONSE TO THIS THREAT, THE ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF SAN DIEGO D B A  SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE (SDZWA) INITIATED A REAR-AND-RELEASE PROGRAM IN 2016. IN THE FIRST 5 YEARS, THE PROGRAM HAS ACHIEVED HATCH AND REARING RATES EXCEEDING 95  AND HAS RELEASED 4 COHORTS WITH HIGH POST- RELEASE SURVIVAL WHO, AS OF 2022, ARE SUCCESSFULLY BREEDING WITH WILD AGA. WE PLAN TO CONTINUE AND IMPROVE ARTIFICIAL INCUBATION AND HAND REARING, NATIVE FORAGING AND PRE-RELEASE ANTIPREDATOR TRAINING, SAMPLING TO MONITOR FOR DISEASE IN HAND- REARED BIRDS, AND INVESTIGATION OF FACTORS LEADING TO NESTING FAILURE OF WILD AND CAPTIVE-REARED BIRDS USING NEST MONITORING CAMERAS.

USFWS RENO FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE STAFF WILL NOT HAVE WORKLOAD CAPACITY TO COMPLETE FULL SURVEYS AT THREE POPULATIONS OF CARSON WANDERING SKIPPER. TAHOE INSTITUTE FOR NATURAL SCIENCE HAS QUALIFIED STAFF TO SUPPORT SURVEY EFFORTS. GIVEN LARGE DECLINE IN NUMBERS AT TWO OF THE THREE POPULATIONS IN 2022, COMPREHENSIVE SURVEYS ARE NEEDED IN 2023. THIS WOULD PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR 8 OF THE 18 SURVEY DAYS.

THE MIGRATORY WESTERN MONARCH BUTTERFLY (DANAUS PLEXIPPUS PLEXIPPUS) IS INCREASINGLY AT RISK OF EXTINCTION, REQUIRING LANDSCAPE-SCALE INTERVENTION FOCUSED ON THE MOST VULNERABLE PERIODS OF ITS ANNUAL LIFE CYCLE TO HELP CONSERVE ITS POPULATIONS AND PRESERVE ITS UNIQUE MIGRATION. SPECIFICALLY, ONE OF THE GREATEST LIMITING FACTORS TO MIGRATING WESTERN MONARCH BUTTERFLIES LIKELY OCCURS DURING THE OVERWINTERING AND EARLY BREEDING STAGES OF THE SPECIES LIFE CYCLE. MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION CENTERED ON THE EARLY BREEDING ZONE IS THUS CONSIDERED A KEY PRIORITY, AND IN RESPONSE TO THIS NEED, A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT IS UNDERWAY TO ADVANCE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEEDS IN CALIFORNIA, WITH THE GOALS OF:1. IDENTIFYING AREAS WHERE EARLY SEASON MILKWEEDS ARE GROWING ON THE LANDSCAPE, INCLUDING SEED COLLECTION FOR PLANT MATERIALS AND LEAF COLLECTION FOR PESTICIDE SAMPLING.2. DETERMINING WESTERN MONARCHS USAGE OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEEDS AT KNOWN, NATIVE STANDS.3. EVALUATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF EXISTING PLANTINGS AT EARLY SEASON MILKWEED SITES, AND4. CONDUCTING NEW PLANTINGS OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEED TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL EARLY SPRING LARVAL AND ADULT HABITAT RESOURCES TO WESTERN MONARCHS AND DETERMINE THE COMPONENTS OF RESTORATION THAT WILL INCREASE THEIR POPULATIONS PERFORMANCE (I.E., THIS PROPOSAL).THIS PROJECT ENCOMPASSES THE FOURTH PRIORITY ACTION, WHERE NEW PLANTINGS OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEED WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL EARLY SPRING HABITAT FOR BOTH MIGRATING AND BREEDING WESTERN MONARCHS AS THEY NAVIGATE FROM THEIR OVERWINTERING SITES TO INTERIOR AND SUMMER BREEDING HABITATS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO AID IN DETERMINING KEY COMPONENTS OF MILKWEED RESTORATION THAT MAY INCREASE SPECIES POPULATIONS PERFORMANCE, ESPECIALLY AS LAND MANAGERS AND THEIR PARTNERS CONSIDER SCALING UP RESTORATION EFFORTS ACROSS THE CENTRAL COAST OF CALIFORNIA. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO INFORM BROAD-SCALE IMPLEMENTATION EFFORTS WITH RESPECT TO IRRIGATION, HERBIVORY PROTECTION, PLANTING ARRANGEMENTS, AND OTHER RELATED VARIABLES TO ENHANCE THE FEASIBILITY AND VIABILITY OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEED RESTORATION WORK. IMPORTANTLY, WITH A SUCCESSFUL RESTORATION PROJECT, FUTURE SEED WILL BECOME AVAILABLE FROM THE STUDY SITES TO PROVIDE SEED MATERIAL FOR OTHER RESTORATION EFFORTS. SOME OF WHICH ARE EXTREMELY LIMITED IN SUPPLY. ULTIMATELY, LESSONS LEARNED FROM THIS EFFORT WILL AID IN SCALING UP EARLY SEASON MILKWEED RESTORATION ENDEAVORS STATEWIDE.

LARGE-SCALE CONVERSION AND FRAGMENTATION OF NATIVE SHRUB-STEPPE HABITATS PLAYED A PRIMARY ROLE IN THE LONG-TERM DECLINE OF THE COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT (CPBR- BRACHYLAGUS IDAHOENSIS)DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT. THE RESULTING SMALL AND ISOLATED SUB-POPULATIONS WERE UNABLE TO WITHSTAND ADDITIONAL STRESSORS, INCLUDING PREDATION, DISEASE, LOSS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND INBREEDING, ULTIMATELY LEADING TO ASSUMED EXTIRPATION FROM ITS RANGE IN WASHINGTON. FOLLOWING A SUCCESSFUL CAPTIVE BREEDING AND GENETIC RESCUE EFFORTS, REINTRODUCTIONS BEGAN IN 2011 AND CONTINUE TODAY. SEMI-WILD BREEDING ENCLOSURES ARE MAINTAINED FOR PRODUCTION OF JUVENILES (KITS) WHICH ARE CAPTURED AND RELEASED ONTO ACCLIMATION SITES IN DESIGNATED REINTRODUCTION AREAS IN THE WILD. THIS APPROACH HAS BEEN SUCCESSFUL IN ESTABLISHING TWO POPULATIONS AND REMAINS THE BASIS FOR CURRENT RECOVERY EFFORTS AS OUTLINED WITHIN THE FEDERAL RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT.

MITCHELL S SATYR BUTTERFLY, NEONYMPHA MITCHELLII MITCHELLII, IS A CRITICALLY ENDANGERED BUTTERFLY THAT IS THREATENED BY CLIMATE CHANGE. THE ONLY EXTANT NORTHERN POPULATIONS ARE IN MICHIGAN AND HAVE DECLINED PRECIPITOUSLY IN THE PAST TWO DECADES. IN CONTRAST, SOUTHERN POPULATIONS IN MISSISSIPPI AND ALABAMA APPEAR STABLE. THE EXISTENCE OF BOTH NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN POPULATIONS OFFERS UNRIVALED POTENTIAL FOR ASSISTED GENE FLOW FROM WARM-ADAPTED SOUTHERN POPULATIONS INTO MICHIGAN POPULATIONS FACING WARMING TEMPERATURES AND LONGER GROWING SEASONS. HOWEVER, BEFORE ASSISTED MIGRATION FROM SOUTHERN POPULATIONS IS IMPLEMENTED, IT IS IMPORTANT TO EVALUATE POTENTIAL RISKS INCLUDING FROM THE PARASITIC BACTERIA WOLBACHIA, WHICH IS THE PURPOSE OF THIS WORK. IN THIS PROJECT WE WILL SEQUENCE AND IDENTIFY STRAINS OF WOLBACHIA PRESENT THROUGHOUT THE RANGE OF THE MITCHELLS SATYR BUTTERFLY. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO COVER LABORATORY COSTS FOR EXTRACTION AND SEQUENCING OF DNA, AS WELL AS PERSONNEL SALARY TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT OF A COMPUTATIONAL PIPELINE TO ISOLATE WOLBACHIA DNA FROM BUTTERFLY DNA. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH MSB GENOMIC SEQUENCING TO CHOOSE POPULATIONS FOR EXPERIMENTAL OUTCROSSING BETWEEN NORTHERN RECIPIENT AND SOUTHERN DONOR INDIVIDUALS EX-SITU. ULTIMATELY, THIS WORK WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION CRITICAL TO INFORMING FUTURE CONSERVATION ACTIONS IN MITCHELLS SATYR BUTTERFLY.

LONGLEAF ALLIANCE WILL RE-ESTABLISH NATIVE GROUND COVER FOR APPROXIMATELY 82 ACRES AT TYNDALL AFB. LLA WILL COORDINATE SEEDLING PURCHASE AND DELIVERY TO TYNDALL AFB, WILL PROVIDE SITE PLANNING AND FINAL MAPS TO THE TYNDALL AFB FORESTER, BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OBTAINING AND MAINTAINING NECESSARY LICENSES, CERTIFICATIONS AND PERMITS, AND MUST COMPLY WITH APPLICABLE FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL LAWS, CODES, AND REGULATIONS IN CONNECTION WITH THE ACTIVITIES AS NEEDED.

THE ONLY DOCUMENTED POPULATION OF ERIOGONUM CODIUM IS IN SLOW DECLINE WITH LITTLE TO NO CONFIRMED REPRODUCTION IN RECENT YEARS. THE SPECIES FACES A RISK OF EXTINCTION IF ALTERNATIVE POPULATIONS ARE NOT ESTABLISHED. PROPERTY CURRENTLY OWNED BY THE COWICHE CANYON CONSERVANCY (CCC) ON COWICHE MOUNTAIN IN COWICHE, WASHINGTON PROVIDES A PROMISING ESTABLISHMENT SITE FOR AN ALTERNATIVE POPULATION. WE ARE REQUESTING FUNDING TO PLANT 200 SEEDLINGS IN THE FALL OF 2022, TO MAINTAIN AND WATER SEEDLINGS IN SUMMER OF 2023, AND TO MONITOR THE 200 SEEDLINGS PLANTED IN 2022 IN ADDITION TO 323 SEEDLINGS PLANTED IN 2020 2021 FOR 3 YEARS. THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE SIGNIFICANT VOLUNTEER CONTRIBUTIONS AND WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF E. CODIUM THROUGH THE ESTABLISHMENT OF NEW SEEDLINGS, DATA COLLECTION TO INFORM FUTURE PLANTING EFFORTS, AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION ON RARE PLANT CONSERVATION.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, NEW JERSEY FIELD OFFICE AND THE CONSERVE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY ARE ENTERING INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOR TASKS RELATED TO THE CONSERVATION OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES OCCURRING ON BEACHES IN OCEAN, ATLANTIC, AND CAPE MAY COUNTIES, NEW JERSEY. FUNDING FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS PROVIDED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, PHILADELPHIA DISTRICT STEMMING FROM A FEDERALLY FUNDED BEACH NOURISHMENT PROGRAM THAT COVERS MOST OF THE MUNICIPAL BEACHES IN THESE THREE COUNTIES. THE MAJOR TASKS COVERED BY THIS AGREEMENT ARE BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANNING, PROTECTIVE FENCING, AND COORDINATION WITH LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS. DELIVERABLE  1 IS A SUMMARY OF PROGRESS ON 5 TO 7 BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANS, INCLUDING COMPLETION OR SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS ON AT LEAST 3 PLANS. DELIVERABLE  2 INCLUDES RAW DATA FOR LOCATIONS OF A LISTED PLANT (SEABEACH AMARANTH) AND A COMPANION REPORT DETAILING THE MUNICIPAL COORDINATION AND TEMPORARY FENCING EFFORTS CARRIED OUT TO PROTECT THESE PLANTS FROM DAMAGE BY PEDESTRIANS, VEHICLES, ANDMECHANICAL BEACH RAKES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANNING IS MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING COMMUNICATION AND COOPERATION BETWEEN LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS AND STATE FEDERAL NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES REGARDING THE CONSERVATION OF LISTED BEACH SPECIES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM PROTECTIVE FENCING IS LONG-TERM INCREASES IN THE NUMBERS OF SEABEACH AMARANTH AND EXPANSION OF ITS GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION IN NEW JERSEY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE AMERICAN PUBLIC (FROM ADVANCING RECOVERY OF LISTED SPECIES), LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS (FROM IMPROVED COMMUNICATION COORDINATION), THE STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCY (FROM INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS), AND THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (FROM SATISFACTION OF LEGAL OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT).

WE EXPECT MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEED (ASCLEPIAS SPP.) HABITAT THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA TO BE CRITICAL FOR IMPROVING POPULATION NUMBERS AND DECREASING EXTINCTION RISK OF THE WESTERN MONARCH (DANAUS PLEXIPPUS). HOWEVER, WE KNOW LITTLE ABOUT THE CURRENT DISTRIBUTION OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEEDS THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES EARLY BREEDING ZONE. IN AN EFFORT TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF EARLY SEASON MILKWEED, STAFF AT THE SANTA BARBARA BOTANIC GARDEN (SBBG) WILL CONDUCT FIELD SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY AREAS WHERE A. CALIFORNICA AND OTHER EARLY SEASON SPECIES OF MILKWEED (A. VESTITA, A. ERIOCARPA, AND A. EROSA) ARE GROWING WITHIN THE LOS PADRES NATIONAL FOREST (LPNF). WE WILL ALSO INITIATE EARLY SEASON MILKWEED CONSERVATION SEED COLLECTIONS FOR BANKING AND BULKING TO SUPPORT FUTURE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES. LASTLY, SBBG WILL COLLECT EARLY SEASON MILKWEED LEAF MATERIAL FOR PESTICIDE SAMPLING.

THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES RECOVERY GOALS FOR THE MITCHELL S SATYR (MS), A FEDERALLY ENDANGERED BUTTERFLY SPECIES THAT OCCURS IN SOUTHERN MICHIGAN. EFFORTS TO EVALUATE AND RECOVER THE MS BUTTERFLY WILL INCLUDE SURVEYS OF EXTANT POPULATIONS AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT IN MICHIGAN. PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE SPATIAL AND SUMMARY DATA OF MS POPULATIONS AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT WORK CONDUCTED WITH FOUR PARTICIPATING PARTNERS IN SOUTHERN MICHIGAN. SURVEYS AND POPULATION MONITORING WILL BE CONTINUED TO INFORM THE BEST TIME FOR EGG COLLECTION FOR PROPAGATION EFFORTS AND TO PROVIDE THE US FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE WITH POPULATION TREND ESTIMATES. HABITAT MANAGEMENT WILL OCCUR ON MS OCCUPIED SITES WHERE HABITAT MANAGEMENT IS IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY BY A SITE CONSERVATION PLAN AND OR THE MS WORKING GROUP

PIPING PLOVERS INHABITING DISTURBANCE-DEPENDENT ENVIRONMENTS ARE MORE VULNERABLE TO HABITAT LOSS AND REQUIRE MORE HABITAT THAN SPECIES IN STABLE ENVIRONMENTS BECAUSE DISTURBANCES AND SUCCESSIONAL PROCESSES CREATE CONSTANT TURNOVER IN HABITAT. THEREFORE, PIPING PLOVERS MUST BE MANAGED AS A METAPOPULATION, IN WHICH A SET NUMBER OF HABITAT PATCHES FORM A RESERVE.  IDENTIFYING PATCHES THAT OPTIMIZE THRESHOLDS FOR METAPOPULATION VIABILITY IS REQUIRED FOR SUCCESSFUL CONSERVATION IN SUCH SYSTEMS. BAND RE-SIGHTINGS INDICATE THAT THE NY-NJ SUBPOPULATION OFFERS A BRIDGE BETWEEN THE NE AND SOUTHERN RECOVERY UNITS (RU), AND THEREFORE IS NECESSARY FOR MAINTAINING RESILIENCY AND REDUNDANCY ACROSS THE RANGE. WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A SPATIALLY EXPLICIT POPULATION VIABILITY ANALYSIS WITHIN THE NY-NJ RU TO DETERMINE POPULATION SIZE, DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, AND HABITAT AMOUNTS AND CONFIGURATIONS NECESSARY FOR VIABILITY AND RECOVERY, INCLUDING UNDER SCENARIOS OF A CHANGING COASTAL STORM REGIME AND SEA-LEVEL RISE. INFORMATION DERIVED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE TARGETS FOR ACHIEVING THE RU CONSERVATION GOALS, AND FOR ENSURING A RANGE WIDE METAPOPULATION ROBUST TO STOCHASTIC EVENTS DESPITE DECLINING HABITAT. OUR RESULTS WILL PROVIDE ACTIONABLE SCIENCE THAT IMPROVES REDUNDANCY, RESILIENCY, AND REPRESENTATION WITHIN THE GREATER ATLANTIC COAST PIPING PLOVER POPULATION.

THE SHARE THE BEACH PROGRAM IS A PUBLIC OUTREACH CAMPAIGN AIMED AT INCREASING PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL BEACH ECOSYSTEMS, AND COMMUNITY SUPPORT FOR THE PROTECTION OF NATIVE WILDLIFE, INCLUDING THE THREATENED WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER (PLOVER). FRIENDS OF THE DUNES WILL WORK TOGETHER WITH THE WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER RECOVERY UNIT 2 OUTREACH SUBCOMMITTEE TO TRAIN, HIRE, AND SUPERVISE SHARE THE BEACH DOCENTS. SHARE THE BEACH DOCENTS WILL CONDUCT EDUCATION AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH FOR PLOVERS ON SELECTED BEACHES IN HUMBOLDT COUNTY, CALIFORNIA ON WEEKENDS AND HIGH VISITOR USE TIMES DURING THE 2023 AND 2024 PLOVER BREEDING SEASON.THE CRUMB CLEAN CAMPAIGN WAS ORIGINALLY DEVELOPED TO HELP PROTECT THE FEDERALLY THREATENED MARBLED MURRELET. DURING THE ORIGINAL DEVELOPMENT, MULTIPLE INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS WERE CREATED TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT HUMAN BEHAVIORS THAT ATTRACT MURRELET PREDATORS AND WHAT VISITORS COULD DO TO PROTECT THE BIRDS. CALIFORNIA STATE PARKS IS INITIATING THE REDESIGN OF THE ORIGINAL CRUMB CLEAN CAMPAIGN EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS. REDESIGNED VERSIONS WILL INFORM THE PUBLIC ABOUT HOW THEY CAN HELP PROTECT PLOVERS BY REDUCING HUMAN-INFLUENCED CORVID (E.G., RAVENS AND CROWS) ATTRACTANTS. ONCE DRAFT MATERIALS ARE PRODUCED, FRIENDS OF THE DUNES WILL CONDUCT A SOCIAL SURVEY TO GET PUBLIC FEEDBACK TO ASSESS MESSAGING EFFECTIVENESS.

LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (ONCORHYNCHUS CLARKII HENSHAWI, LCT) ARE FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973. NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE(NDOW) LCT MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ARE DIRECTED TO ACHIEVE OBJECTIVES IDENTIFIED IN THE 2019 UPDATED GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOR THE CONSERVATION OF LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT (2019 UGOS). TO MEET THESE RECOVERY OBJECTIVES NDOW BIOLOGISTS RELY HEAVILY ON SEASONAL EMPLOYEES TO COMPLETE FIELDWORK, VARIOUS UNIVERSITY LABORATORIES TO COMPLETE GENETIC ANALYSES, AND THE ROCKY MOUNTAIN RESEARCH STATION NATIONAL GENOMICS CENTER (RMRS-NGC) TO ANALYZE EDNA SAMPLES. NDOW STAFF ALSO RELIES ON THE ASSISTANCE OF PART-TIME CONTRACTUAL EMPLOYEES TO COORDINATE REGULAR INTERAGENCY MEETING MANAGEMENT AND ORGANIZING ISSUES EFFECTING LCT RANGE WIDE. IN RECENT YEARS IT HAS BECOME APPARENT THE EXTENT OF NON-NATIVE FISH AND HYBRIDIZATION WITHIN THE MARY-S RIVER LCT POPULATION IS HIGHER THAN BELIEVED AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS THESE THREATS ARE URGENTLY NEEDED. THE CURRENT GRANTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE NDOW FISHERIES DIVISION ARE NOT SUFFICIENT TO COVER THE COSTS OF THESE ESSENTIAL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS.

SINCE 1990, INSTITUTE FOR NATURAL RESOURCES, USFWS, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, US FOREST SERVICE, US ARMY CORPS ENGINEERS, OREGON PARKS AND RECREATION DEPARTMENT, AND OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE HAVE PARTNERED TO MANAGE AND MONITOR FEDERALLY THREATENED SNOWY PLOVERS ALONG THE OREGON COAST. DURING THIS TIME, INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT AND AGENCY COLLABORATION HAS RESULTED IN POPULATION GROWTH  THE OREGON COASTAL POPULATION CURRENTLY MEETS RECOVERY GOALS ESTABLISHED IN THE USFWS 2007 RECOVERY PLAN. ALTHOUGH THE OREGON POPULATION IS ESTIMATED AT OVER 600 BREEDING ADULTS, THIS IS STILL A SMALL, CONSERVATION-RELIANT POPULATION. OUR GOAL IS TO HELP COOPERATING LAND MANAGEMENT AGENCIES ENSURE THAT THEIR EFFORTS ARE EFFECTIVE AT MAINTAINING THE OREGON COAST PLOVER POPULATION AT RECOVERY LEVELS BY MONITORING PLOVER ABUNDANCE, DISTRIBUTION, AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS. MONITORING DOCUMENTS EFFECTIVENESS OF MANAGEMENT AND PROGRESS TOWARDS RECOVERY, ENSURES PROMPT IDENTIFICATION OF NEW PROBLEMS, IS ESSENTIAL TO SUCCESSFUL IMPLEMENTATION OF EXISTING PREDATOR, HABITAT AND RECREATION MANAGEMENT EFFORTS, AND IS REQUIRED BY THE RECOVERY PLAN PRIOR TO AND AFTER DELISTING. MONITORING IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AFTER DELISTING. FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO CONDUCT BREEDING WINDOW SURVEYS, LOCATE AND MONITOR NESTS, AND BAND BROODS TO CLOSELY DOCUMENT POPULATION SIZE, PRODUCTIVITY, SURVIVAL, AND TO IDENTIFY FACTORS LIMITING POPULATION GROWTH.

THIS PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE AND ADD TO THE VERNAL POOL HABITAT MAPPING AND ASSESSMENT COMPLETED UNDER USFWS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT F22AC00949-00 BY USING THAT GIS MAP TO DESIGN RECOVERY SPECIES SURVEYS AND GUIDE TARGETED FIELD WORK. WE WILL COMPILE EXISTING OCCURRENCE DATA ON THREE ESA SPECIES, VERNAL POOL FAIRY SHRIMP (BRANCHINECTA LYNCHI, BRLY), COOKS DESERT PARSLEY (LOMATIUM COOKII, LOCO), AND LARGE-FLOWERED WOOLLY MEADOWFOAM (LIMNANTHES PUMILA SSP. GRANDIFLORA, LIPUGR), AND CONDUCT NEW FIELD SURVEYS TO STRATEGICALLY FILL GAPS IN THE DATA COVERAGE. RESULTING SPECIES LOCATION DATA WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO THE HABITAT MAP TO INFORM USFWS DECISIONS ON NEW CONSERVATION AREAS AND ALLOW FOR FUTURE HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELING. THIS WORK WILL BUILD A KNOWLEDGE FOUNDATION OF SPECIES LOCATIONS, STATUS, AND RANGE, AND THE CONDITION AND SUITABILITY OF REMAINING HABITAT AS AN ESSENTIAL BASELINE TO GUIDE SPECIES RECOVERY PLANS AND ACTIONS. A WRITTEN REPORT WILL DOCUMENT DATA COMPILATION METHODS, SOURCES, AND RESULTS, NEW SURVEY DESIGN, FIELD EFFORT, DATA SUMMARY RELATIVE TO HABITAT VARIABLES, AND ACCOMPANYING MAPS. SPATIAL DATA WILL BE PROVIDED AS NEW GIS FEATURE CLASSES AND AS UPDATES TO THE VERNAL POOL HABITAT GEODATABASE FROM PRIOR VERNAL POOL HABITAT MAPPING.

PIPING PLOVERS WERE LOCALLY EXTIRPATED FROM LAKE ONTARIO IN 1984, WITH THE LAST PAIR OF THIS FEDERALLY-ENDANGERED SPECIES OCCURRING IN NEW YORK. IN 2015, A SINGLE PAIR NESTED IN JEFFERSON COUNTY. DUE TO COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION EFFORTS OF SUNY ESF WITH MULTIPLE STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES AND NGOS, THE POPULATION REACHED 3 PAIRS IN THE REGION IN 2023. WE PROPOSE TO COORDINATE CONTINUED CONSERVATION EFFORTS, INCLUDING NESTING PAIR MONITORING AND BANDING, FENCING, NEST ENCLOSURES, PREDATOR MANAGEMENT, HABITAT RESTORATION, AND WORKING WITH THE BASIN-WIDE CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIP TO SHARE DATA AND PUBLISH SCIENTIFIC PAPERS IN SUPPORT OF MANAGEMENT.

AFTER EXTENSIVE FEDERAL REVIEW, SPALDINGS CATCHFLY (SILENE SPALDINGII), A HERBACEOUS PERENNIAL WILDFLOWER NATIVE TO GRASSLAND PRAIRIES OF THE INLAND PACIFIC NORTHWEST, WAS FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN OCTOBER 2001. THIS SPECIES WAS ALSO OREGON STATE-LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 1995. IF NO ACTION WERE TAKEN, THE CONTINUED DECLINE OF PLANT POPULATIONS IN THE REGION WAS EXPECTED.IN 2007, USDI FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE (THE SERVICE) COMPLETED THE FINAL SPALDINGS CATCHFLY RECOVERY PLAN (THE RECOVERY PLAN), WHICH IS THE SOLE TARGET SPECIES OF THIS PROJECT. THE GOAL OF THE RECOVERY PLAN IS TO RECOVER THE SPECIES TO THE POINT OF DE-LISTING. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES TO MEET THIS GOAL ARE TO 1) REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THE THREATS TO THE SPECIES, AND 2) PROTECT AND MAINTAIN MULTIPLE REPRODUCING, SELF-SUSTAINING POPULATIONS DISTRIBUTED ACROSS EACH OF THE FIVE DISTINCT PHYSIOGRAPHIC REGIONS WHERE THE PLANT RESIDES, SUFFICIENT TO ENSURE THE SPECIES LONG-TERM PERSISTENCE.THE RECOVERY PLANS FIVE PHYSIOGRAPHIC REGIONS ARE DIVIDED INTO KEY CONSERVATION AREAS (KCAS) WITH UNIQUE AREA MONITORING POPULATION TRENDS AND HABITAT CONDITIONS. EACH KCA IS DEFINED BY SEVERAL FACTORS, INCLUDING A MINIMUM PLANT THRESHOLD AND QUALITY HABITAT TO SUSTAIN CATCHFLY POPULATIONS. THE WALLOWA LAKE AREA IS ONE OF THE KCAS WITHIN THE BLUE MOUNTAIN BASINS PHYSIOGRAPHIC REGION AS DESCRIBED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN. THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT INCLUDE THE CONTINUED MONITORING OF SPALDINGS CATCHFLY POPULATIONS ON BOTH PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS IN THE WALLOWA LAKE KCA. THIS MONITORING WILL INCLUDE DEMOGRAPHIC CENSUS MONITORING AND SUBSAMPLE MONITORING. MONITORING TO EVALUATE EXTANT POPULATIONS IN KCAS IS IDENTIFIED AS AN IMPORTANT RECOVERY TASK IN THE RECOVERY PLAN.AT THIS PROJECTS CONCEPTION IN 2010, A LARGE PLANT POPULATION WAS DEFINED AS A MINIMUM OF 500 PLANTS. HOWEVER, EVEN WITH TOTAL CENSUS MONITORING (COUNTING EVERY KNOWN PLANT ON THE SITE), THE KNOWN POPULATION AT THE WALLOWA LAKE KCA WAS FEWER THAN 500 PLANTS. WITH AN UNDERSTANDING THAT HABITAT WITHIN THE WALLOWA VALLEY IS HIGHLY DISSECTED BY URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL LANDS, PARTNERS BEGAN CONSIDERING MONITORING ON PRIVATE LANDS TO CAPTURE MORE DATA ON SPALDINGS CATCHFLY PLANTS IN THE WALLOWA LAKE KCA. AS OF 2019, SURVEYS HAVE BEEN CONDUCTED ON APPROXIMATELY 1,600 ACRES OF PRIVATE LANDS. THROUGH THE PRIVATE LAND SURVEYS, PREVIOUSLY UNDOCUMENTED SPALDINGS CATCHFLY PLANTS WERE IDENTIFIED. THESE SURVEYS BROUGHT THE TOTAL POPULATION IN THE AREA TO OVER 1,400, WELL OVER THE 500-PLANT THRESHOLD FOR A LARGE POPULATION.THE PROPOSED MONITORING OF SPALDINGS CATCHFLY AT WALLOWA LAKE HAS RESULTED IN THE COLLECTION OF VALUABLE CENSUS, TREND AND DEMOGRAPHIC DATA THAT AIDS IN THE MANAGEMENT AND RECOVERY OF THIS SPECIES FOR THE WALLOWA LAKE KCA WITHIN THE BLUE MOUNTAIN BASINS. AFTER BEING COMPILED AND ORGANIZED, THE DATA WILL BE ARCHIVED AND INTEGRATED INTO DATABASES FROM OTHER CO-MANAGER MAND E ACTIVITIES, MAKING THE DATA ACCESSIBLE BOTH LOCALLY AND REGIONALLY.THIS PROJECT IS PART OF A LARGER, ONGOING SPALDINGS CATCHFLY MONITORING EFFORT THAT IS OCCURRING IN MONTANA, WASHINGTON, OREGON, AND IDAHO. A SPALDINGS CATCHFLY TECHNICAL WORKING GROUP (WITH MEMBERS FROM THESE FOUR STATES AND MULTIPLE ORGANIZATIONS) MEETS ANNUALLY TO DISCUSS RECOVERY ACTIONS INCLUDING A CONSISTENT RANGE-WIDE MONITORING APPROACH FOR THIS SPECIES. THE TEAM HAS NOT ESTABLISHED A SPECIFIC MONITORING APPROACH BECAUSE THE RECOVERY AREA IS TOO DIVERSE. HOWEVER, IT HAS DECIDED UPON SPECIFIC INFORMATION THAT EACH KCA MUST ANNUALLY COLLECT.DATA COLLECTED BY THIS PROJECT WILL BE COMPATIBLE WITH PAST SPALDINGS CATCHFLY POPULATION TREND AND HABITAT DATA PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED IN THE WALLOWA LAKE KCA. OUR DATA, WHEN COMBINED WITH OTHER DATA IN THE BLUE MOUNTAIN BASINS AND ELSEWHERE IN THE RECOVERY AREA, WILL BECOME MORE POWERFUL AND INFORMATIVE FOR SPALDINGS CATCHFLY TECHNICAL WORKING GROUP MANAGERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING IS TO EXPAND THE CAPACITY OF THE RENO FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OFFICE TO ALLOW TROUT UNLIMITED TO ACCOMPLISH THE NECESSARY WORK TO BE ACCOMPLISHED IN A TIMELY MANNER. ONGOING EFFORTS TO COLLECT AND CATALOG GENETIC SAMPLES FROM ACROSS THE RANGE OF LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (LCT) ARE NEEDED TO DEVELOP A GENETICS MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK TO AID IN RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES. THIS FUNDING ALLOWS TROUT UNLIMITED (TU) TO MANAGE FIELD CREWS THAT WILL COLLECT THE DATA AND ASSIST WITH THE FORTHCOMING GENETICS MANAGEMENT FRAMEWORK DEVELOPMENT. IN ADDITION, TU WILL ALSO ASSIST WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN INTERAGENCY LCT RECOVERY WEBSITE, LEAD TWO RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION TEAMS (RITS  INDEPENDENCE AND CARSON), SERVE AS AN ADVISORY MEMBER OF THE HUMBOLDT, QUINN, REESE, WALKER, INDEPENDENCE, CARSON, SUMMIT, AND WILLOW-WHITEHORSE RITS, MANAGE RECOVERY EFFORTS AT INDEPENDENCE LAKE, PARTICIPATE IN VARIOUS INTERAGENCY WORKING GROUPS SUCH AS THE COORDINATING COMMITTEE (CC), ROGER (RESULTS ORIENTED GRAZING FOR ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE), THE CONSERVATION EFFORTS DATABASE TEAM, THE HABITAT CORE TEAM, THE DEMOGRAPHICS SUB-TEAM, THE COMMUNICATIONS TEAM, AND THE GENETICS TEAM  ALL ASSEMBLED FOR THE PURPOSE OF LCT RECOVERY.AS A RESULT OF THIS WORK, TU WILL ASSIST STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS IN COLLECTING THE REQUIRED GENETIC SAMPLES IN TIME TO DEVELOP THE GENETICS MANAGEMENT PLAN. WE WILL ALSO BE ABLE TO ASSIST WITH EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATING INTERAGENCY AND RANGEWIDE PRIORITIES THROUGHOUT THE VARIOUS GROUPS TASKED WITH LCT RECOVERY, THEREBY INCREASING EFFICIENCY OF RECOVERY BY ELIMINATING THE BARRIERS TO COMMUNICATION CREATED BY STATE AND FEDERAL JURISDICTIONAL BOUNDARIES. IN ADDITION, THIS FUNDING WILL ALSO PROVIDE THE CAPACITY TO CREATE AND MANAGE AN INTERAGENCY LCT WEBSITE TO EFFECTIVELY COMMUNICATE THE RECOVERY STRATEGY TO INTERESTED PARTIES AND ENGAGE THOSE PARTIES IN LCT RECOVERY EFFORTS. BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE THE INTERESTED PUBLIC, US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT, US FOREST SERVICE, NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES, AND THE MULTITUDE OF HUMAN AND NATURAL RESOURCES THAT BENEFIT FROM LCT RECOVERY EFFORTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THE WORK IS TO EXECUTE NATURAL RESOURCE PROJECTS IN SUPPORT OF EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE (AFB), ROBINS AFB, AND THE AIR FORCE CIVIL ENGINEER CENTER. TEXAS A M NATURAL RESOURCES INSTITUTE (TAMU-NRI) WILL PROVIDE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE INSTALLATION SUPPORT SERVICES AS STATED IN THE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (CA). TAMUNRIS WORK FOCUSES ON THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES THROUGH INTERDISCIPLINARY AND APPLIED RESEARCH, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER, POLICY AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES, STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT, AND INCLUDES: (1) TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EDUCATION TO FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL AND RESEARCH AGENCIES, AND THEIR POTENTIAL PARTNERS. (2) DEVELOPING PROGRAMS OF RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND EDUCATION THAT INVOLVES THE BIOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, SOCIAL SCIENCES NEEDED TO ADDRESS RESOURCE ISSUES AND INTERDISCIPLINARY PROBLEM-SOLVING AT MULTIPLE SCALES AND IN AN ECOSYSTEM CONTEXT AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND NATIONAL LEVEL. (3) WORKING IN COLLABORATION AMONG FEDERAL AGENCIES AND UNIVERSITIES AND THEIR RELATED PARTNER INSTITUTIONS.  TAMU-NRI WILL PERFORM ACTIVITIES INCLUDING RESEARCH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND EDUCATION TO FEDERAL LAND MANAGEMENT, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND RESEARCH AGENCIES AND THEIR PARTNERS. CAPABILITIES INCLUDES BIOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, SOCIAL, CULTURAL, AND ENGINEERING DISCIPLINES NEEDED TO ADDRESS NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ISSUES AT MULTIPLE SCALES AND IN AN ECOSYSTEM CONTEXT. THE OUTCOME OF THESE ACTIVITIES WILL ENSURE COMPLIANCE WITH THE SIKES ACT (16 USC 670A), ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA), DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE INSTRUCTION 4715.03, NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION PROGRAM, DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE DIRECTIVE 4700.4, NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PROGRAM, DOD REGULATIONS AND INSTRUCTIONS, EXECUTIVE ORDERS (EOS), DOD INSTALLATION INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PLANS (INRMPS), AND USFWS TAMU-NRI CA IN SUPPORT OF ENDANGERED OR THREATENED SPECIES, FLORA, FAUNA, AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON FEDERAL LANDS. BENEFICIARIES OF THIS WORK INCLUDE MULTIPLE FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL AGENCIES BY PROVIDING SUPPORT FOR THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT NATURAL RESOURCES ON FEDERAL LANDS. NO SUB-RECIPIENT ACTIVITIES ARE ANTICIPATED.  FUTURE FUNDING IS EXPECTED AND OTHER SOUTHEASTERN INSTALLATIONS WILL BE SUPPORTED AS REQUESTED WHEN FUNDS BECOME AVAILABLE.

MARYS RIVER WATERSHED COUNCIL (MRWC) WILL CONTINUE TO ASSIST IN ACHIEVING VIABLE POPULATIONS OF FENDERS BLUE BUTTERFLY (ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI) AND TAYLORS CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY (EUPHYDRYAS EDITHA TAYLORI) IN THE CORVALLIS, OREGON RECOVERY ZONE. OUR GOAL IS TO SUPPORT AND EXPAND POPULATIONS OF HOST AND NECTAR PLANT SPECIES AND TO REDUCE HABITAT ISOLATION AND FRAGMENTATION BY LINKING CONSERVATION LANDS THROUGH VOLUNTARY PRIVATE LANDOWNER CONSERVATION.  MRWC BEGAN WORKING ON PRAIRIE RECOVERY MORE EXTENSIVELY IN THE WREN AREA IN 2011. SINCE THAT TIME, KINCAID S LUPINE COVER IN WREN HAS BEEN EXPANDED TO OVER 40  ABOVE THE ESTIMATED 2,391M SURVEYED BETWEEN 2006 AND 2011 IN THE BENTON COUNTY HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN.1 NECTAR HAS INCREASED OVER 12 YEARS, WITH 72,406 TOTAL BULBS, PLUGS, AND BARE ROOTS HAVING BEEN PLANTED. NOTWITHSTANDING THIS SUCCESS, INVASIVE CONTROL IS AN ONGOING ENDEAVOR ON PRAIRIE SITES, AND ENCROACHMENT FROM WEEDS AND THE CONTINUED NEED FOR EXPANDING SUITABLE HABITAT NECESSITATES CONTINUING AND EXPANDED WORK. MRWC PROPOSES IN THE SCOPE OF THIS PROJECT TO SHORE UP EXISTING KINCAIDS LUPINE AND NECTAR PLANTING SITES THROUGH WEED CONTROL AND EXPANDED PLANTING.  IN ADDITION, WE INTEND TO WORK WITH THE USFWS PARTNERS PROGRAM TO INCREASE CONNECTIVITY ON FOUR SITES, REMOVING CONIFER AND DENSE ENGLISH HAWTHORN STAND BARRIERS, WORKING ON PROPERTIES WITH LANDOWNERS ALREADY ENGAGED IN RECOVERY PROGRAM EFFORTS. FOLLOWING ON THE SUCCESS OF IMPROVING HABITATS AND CONNECTIVITY ON EXISTING RESTORATION SITES, MRWC WILL LOOK FOR OPPORTUNITIES TO EXPAND THE NUMBER OF LANDOWNERS AND SITES ENGAGED IN THE WREN NECTAR NETWORK. SAFE HARBOR AGREEMENTS WILL BE PURSUED AND DEVELOPED FOR LANDOWNERS, AND MRWC WILL ALSO PROVIDE LANDOWNER LIAISON FOR USFWS PARTNERS AGREEMENT DEVELOPMENT, PRAIRIE SURVEY AND RESEARCH PROJECTS.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOR SEASONAL MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DNR) EMPLOYEES TO MONITOR INDIVIDUALS OF THE ENDANGERED GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER (CHARADRIUS MELODUS) IN MICHIGAN STATE PARKS DURING THE NESTING SEASON. THE EMPLOYEES WILL MONITOR THE ACTIVITY OF ADULT AND YOUNG PIPING PLOVERS, ASSIST WITH INSTALLING AND REMOVING FENCING AND NEST EXCLOSURES AS NEEDED, AND PROTECT THE PLOVERS BY EDUCATING PARK VISITORS ABOUT THESE BIRDS. THIS PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO INCREASE THE CHANCE OF SURVIVAL AND BREEDING SUCCESS OF PIPING PLOVERS AT THE PARKS.

THE SOUTHERN MOUNTAIN CARIBOU DPS IS DECLINING PRIMARILY DUE TO TIMBER HARVEST THAT ALTERS HABITAT TO FAVOR PRIMARY PREY SPECIES (DEER, ELK, AND MOOSE), THEREBY INCREASING CARIBOU SUSCEPTIBILITY TO PREDATION. GIVEN SMALL SUBPOPULATION SIZES AND DECLINING TRENDS, RECOVERY ACTIONS BEYOND HABITAT PROTECTIONS ALONE ARE NECESSARY TO ADVERT EXTIRPATION. IN RECENT YEARS, MULTIPLE RECOVERY ACTIONS HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED FOR THE CENTRAL SELKIRK SUBPOPULATION, INCLUDING SUBSTANTIAL HABITAT PROTECTIONS, RECREATION AND PREDATOR MANAGEMENT, AND NOW MATERNAL PENNING. THE MATERNITY PEN PROJECT IS THE HERD S BEST CHANCE TO ACHIEVE POPULATION GROWTH THROUGH IMPROVING CALF SURVIVAL.THE KALISPEL TRIBE (TRIBE) HAS BEEN ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN SOUTHERN AND CENTRAL MOUNTAIN CARIBOU RECOVERY EFFORTS AND HAVE SUCCESSFULLY EXECUTED INTERNATIONAL CONTRACTS WITH THE ARROW LAKES CARIBOU SOCIETY AND ITS CONTRACTORS. WE ARE PREPARED TO RECEIVE SERVICE FUNDING AND EFFICIENTLY DELIVER IT TO OUR CANADIAN PARTNERS TO MEET OUR SHARED CARIBOU RECOVERY GOALS.

THE CARDWELL HILL AREA, LOCATED IN BENTON COUNTY, OREGON, IS HOME TO ONE OF THE LAST TWO REMAINING OREGON POPULATIONS OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY (EUPHYDRYAS EDITHA TAYLORI, TCB, MAP 1). DUE TO HABITAT LOSS, DEGRADATION AND FRAGMENTATION, THESE TWO IMPERILED TCB POPULATIONS HAVE DECLINED DRASTICALLY. NECTAR AND HOST PLANT AVAILABILITY ARE CRITICAL COMPONENTS TO SUITABLE HABITAT FOR TCB. WITHIN THE CARDWELL HILL PROJECT AREA, LOSS OF HABITAT CONNECTIVITY, INVASIVE WEEDS, AND WOODY PLANT ENCROACHMENT ARE THE MAIN FACTORS NEGATIVELY AFFECTING BUTTERFLY HABITAT. U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) RECOVERY FUNDS WOULD SUPPORT IMPROVING CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN AND ENHANCE BUTTERFLY HABITAT IN THREE PRIVATELY OWNED TCB OCCUPIED MEADOWS AT THE CARDWELL HILL PROJECT AREA (MAP 2). PROPOSED HABITAT ENHANCEMENT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INVASIVE WEED TREATMENTS, REDUCTION OF SHRUB TREE ENCROACHMENT, AND NATIVE AND BUTTERFLY RESOURCE PLANT COMMUNITY AUGMENTATION. MORE SPECIFICALLY, TREATMENTS WOULD INCLUDE SPOT AND BROADCAST SPRAY HERBICIDE APPLICATIONS, MOWING, CHAINSAW WORK TO REMOVE TREES AND LIMBS, AND PLANTING AND SEEDING WITH UPLAND PRAIRIE SPECIES INCLUDING TCB NECTAR AND HOST PLANTS. PARTNERS FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE USFWS PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE PROGRAM (PFW), BONNEVILLE POWER ADMINISTRATION (BPA), AND PRIVATE LAND OWNERS.

KINCAID S LUPINE (LUPINUS OREGANUS) IS LISTED AS THREATENED BY THE USFWS. THIS PROJECT WILL SURVEY KINCAID S LUPINE POPULATIONS AND ASSOCIATED PRAIRIE HABITAT AND ASSESS PROGRESS TOWARDS RECOVERY GOALS, USING THE SAME PROTOCOLS USED FOR THE PREVIOUS RANGE WIDE ASSESSMENT CONDUCTED 2014 2016. WE WILL CONDUCT SURVEYS AT THE ISABELLE SITE AND THE FIVE WILLOW CREEK SITES IN THE EUGENE WEST RECOVERY ZONE. WE WILL ALSO COORDINATE SURVEY EFFORTS CONDUCTED BY IAE AND PROJECT PARTNERS AT OTHER SITES TO START BUILDING A RANGE WIDE ASSESSMENT OF KINCAID S LUPINE THAT WILL CONTINUE IN 2024. FINALLY, WE WILL INCORPORATE ALL RESULTS INTO THE USFWS TAND E GEODATABASE. THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE PRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON IDENTIFIES THE NEED TO MONITOR POPULATION ABUNDANCE, HABITAT QUALITY, AND EVALUATE POPULATION TRENDS AT SITES ACROSS THE HISTORIC RANGE OF KINCAID S LUPINE. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY ADDRESS THIS STATED NEED.

SINCE 2008, THE INSTITUTE FOR APPLIED ECOLOGY (IAE) HAS BEEN WORKING WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) TO STRATEGICALLY COLLECT AND PRODUCE GENETICALLY DIVERSE SEED FOR THE FIVE TAND E PLANT SPECIES ADDRESSED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE PRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SOUTHWESTERN WASHINGTON (RECOVERY PLAN, USFWS 2010) AS WELL AS SEVERAL SPECIES IDENTIFIED BY EXPERTS AS KEY NECTAR RESOURCE PLANTS FOR FENDER S BLUE AND TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLIES, LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 2013. THE PRODUCTION OF NATIVE SEED IS OFTEN A LONG TERM EFFORT, WITH SOME SPECIES TAKING UP TO FIVE YEARS TO PRODUCE THEIR FIRST HARVEST. IN ADDITION, CURRENT SEED PRODUCTION FIELDS ARE SUCCESSFUL BUT ARE TOO SMALL TO MEET THE CURRENT AND ANTICIPATED DEMAND. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, WE PROPOSE TO CONTINUE CURRENT PRODUCTION TO PROVIDE FBB HOST AND NECTAR SPECIES IN SUFFICIENT QUANTITIES TO MEET THE DOWNLISTING AND DELISTING CRITERIA FOR FBB AND OTHER WILLAMETTE VALLEY LISTED SPECIES.
