THIS PROJECT BENEFITS MULTIPLE AT RISK SPECIES IN THE PRAIRIES OF WESTERN OREGON INCLUDING TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT (ENDANGERED), WILLAMETTE DAISY (ENDANGERED) AND BRADSHAW S LOMATIUM (DELISTED 2021). PROPOSED ACTIONS FOR TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT, INCLUDING HABITAT MANAGEMENT, ENHANCEMENT AND MONITORING ARE THOSE RECOMMENDED IN THE DRAFT USFWS RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE SPECIES, THE ROADMAP CREATED BY USFWS TO GUIDE THE WORK NEEDED TO REMOVE SPECIES FROM THE ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST. PROPOSED ACTIONS FOR WILLAMETTE DAISY, THREAT REDUCTION AND POPULATION INTRODUCTION AUGMENTATION ARE THOSE RECOMMENDED IN THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR PRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SW WASHINGTON. ACTIONS FOR BRADSHAW S LOMATIUM ARE INCLUDE THE REQUIRED POST DELISTING MONITORING, TO CONFIRM AND TRACK THE SPECIES STATUS AFTER ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT PROTECTIONS HAVE BEEN REMOVED, AND TO ALSO PROMOTE SOUND MANAGEMENT OF THE SPECIES OVER TIME. PRIMARY FACTORS THAT PUT ALL THESE SPECIES AT RISK AND IN NEED OF PROTECTION ARE HABITAT LOSS AND REDUCTION IN HABITAT QUALITY CAUSED BY INVASIVE WEEDS AND WOODY SHRUBS THAT SPREAD AGGRESSIVELY INTO THE SPECIES  HABITATS. PROPOSED ACTIONS INCLUDE INTRODUCTIONS OF BUTTERFLIES AND WILLAMETTE DAISY, HABITAT MANAGEMENT TO CONTROL SHRUBS AND WEEDS, SEEDING NATIVE SPECIES, ALL ON PERMANENTLY PROTECTED AND MANAGED CONSERVATION SITES.

CAS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED IN ONE WETLAND BASIN THAT SPANS PORTIONS OF HURLBURT, EAFB, AND THE CITY OF FORT WALTON BEACH. INITIAL LITERATURE REVIEWS INDICATED CONTROL METHODS SUCH AS HAND REMOVAL, TRAPPING, AND HERBICIDE MAY BE EFFECTIVE. HURLBURT FIELD ATTEMPTED CONTROL EFFORTS BY HAND COLLECTING EGG MASSES WITHIN THE INHABITED WETLAND AREA IN ORDER TO GAIN SOME DISTRIBUTIONAL KNOWLEDGE AND ESTIMATE POPULATION SIZE AND RECOLONIZATION RATES FOR THE SPECIES. HAND REMOVAL IS LABOR INTENSIVE, AND EFFECTIVENESS REMAINS UNCLEAR. SEVERAL TRAP DESIGNS WERE TESTED FOR EFFECTIVENESS, BUT TRAPPING IS ALSO LABOR INTENSIVE, AND EFFECTIVENESS REMAINS UNCLEAR. TAMU NRI WILL PROVIDE HURLBURT FIELD WITH SIKES ACT AND INRMP SUPPORT VIA, CHANNELED APPLE SNAIL SUPPORT AND CONTROL AT HURLBURT FIELD, FLORIDA, ANALYSIS, INVASIVE SPECIES ASSESSMENT, TECHNICAL EXPERTISE, CONTROL, AND REPORTS.

PRESENCE-ABSENCE SURVEYS FOR THE RARE ENDEMIC SIUSLAW HAIRY-NECKED TIGER BEETLE (CICINDELA HIRTICOLLIS SIUSLAWENSIS  SHNTB) WILL BE CONDUCTED THROUGHOUT ITS HISTORIC RANGE TO DETERMINE THE SPECIES CURRENT RANGE AND POPULATION STATUS. SURVEYS WILL BE DONE IN LATE SPRING THROUGH LATE SUMMER IN 2023 AND 2024  WE WORK WITH USFWS, LANDOWNERS, AND SITE MANAGERS AT ALL SITES AS NEEDED TO OBTAIN ACCESS. ALL SITES IN OR AND WA WHERE SHNTB WAS FOUND IN THE PAST 15 YEARSWILL BE REVISITED, AND SURVEYS WILL BE EXTENDED TO ANY POTENTIALLY SUITABLE HABITATS WITHIN 1 MILE OF EXTANT POPULATIONS. ADDITIONAL SITES WITH SUITABLE HABITAT FROM CENTRAL WA THROUGH SOUTHERN OR WILL ALSO BE IDENTIFIED AND SURVEYED. SURVEYS IN NORTHERN CA (DEL NORTE AND HUMBOLDT COUNTY) WILL BE SELECTED BASED ON EXAMINING MAPS, CONSULTING WITH LOCAL NATURAL RESOURCE STAFF, AND SURVEYORS PRIOR KNOWLEDGE OF POTENTIAL HABITAT IN THE AREAS. SURVEYS FOR ADULT BEETLES, LARVAL BURROWS, AND ADULT SHELTERS WILL BE CONDUCTED AND VOUCHERS (PHOTOS AND A LIMITED NUMBER OF SPECIMENS) WILL BE COLLECTED. ALL SITES WILL BE MAPPED AND SYMBOLIZED FOR PRESENCE ABSENCE AND ABUNDANCE CLASSES OF SHNTB (ABSENT, SPARSE, COMMON, ABUNDANT), AND PRESENCE OF CONGENERICS WILL BE NOTED. THESE SURVEYS WILL ENABLE IDENTIFICATION OF NEW EXTANT SHNTB POPULATIONS  ASSESS WHETHER KNOWN POPULATIONS IN OR AND WA PERSISTED ACROSS THE 15 YEARS IN WHICH THEY WERE FOUND AND WHETHER THE HABITAT AT THESE SITES HAS CHANGED  AND INFORM CURRENT AND FUTURE CONSERVATION EFFORTS TO PRESERVE THIS WEST COAST ENDEMIC BEETLE.

PROJECT IMPLEMENTS REQUIREMENTS OF THE EGLIN AFB, TYNDALL AFB, AND OTHER USAF INSTALLATIONS WITHIN THE SOUTHEAST S INSTALLATION NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN (INRMP)  AIR FORCE FUNDING IS PROVIDED THROUGHOUT THE YEAR FOR UNIQUE PROJECTS THROUGHOUT THE BASES. THIS AMENDMENT CONTINUES FUNDING NR PROJECTS AT THE BASES TO INCLUDE HABITAT MANAGEMENT   IMPROVEMENT FOR TAND E SPECIES RECOVERY, WETLAND IMPROVEMENT MONITORING AND OTHER ASSOCIATED ACTIVITIES.

THE GOAL OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO ENSURE THAT US FISH AND WILDLIFE (FWS) STAFF HAVE ACCESS TO ACCURATE AND UP TO  DATE INFORMATION CHARACTERIZING RESIDENT SPECIES AND HABITATS WITHIN THE AIR FORCE INSTALLATIONS OF FLORIDA. THIS  INFORMATION IS NEEDED TO ENSURE THAT THESE LANDS CAN BE MANAGED TO MEET STEWARDSHIP REQUIREMENTS WHILE SUPPORTING  MILITARY TRAINING. THE FLORIDA NATURAL AREAS INVENTORY (FNAI) IS FLORIDA S STATE HERITAGE PROGRAM AND PART OF  FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY. FNAI CONDUCTS A WIDE VARIETY OF ECOLOGICAL INVENTORY, MONITORING, MAPPING, AND APPLIED  RESEARCH THROUGHOUT FLORIDA AND IS WELL QUALIFIED TO ASSIST THE SERVICE IN FILLING ECOLOGICAL INFORMATION GAPS.  UNDER THIS AGREEMENT FWS AND FNAI WILL COOPERATOR ON ECOLOGICAL MONITORING EFFORTS INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO  RARE SPECIES INVENTORY AND MONITORING, INVASIVE SPECIES MAPPING, AND NATURAL COMMUNITY MAPPING.

AT RISK AND LISTED AQUATIC SPECIES, ESPECIALLY FRESHWATER MUSSELS, SUCH AS RABBITSFOOT (T), PURPLE LILLIPUT (ARS), AND WESTERN FANSHELL (ARS)  FISH, SUCH AS OZARK SHINER (ARS), AND LONGNOSE DARTER (ARS)  AND AMPHIBIANS, SUCH AS OKLAHOMA SALAMANDER (ARS), REQUIRES HIGH QUALITY FLOWING WATER FREE OF EXCESSIVE SEDIMENT, AND NUTRIENTS. THIS RESTORATION FOR RECOVERY STRATEGY (RRS) FOCUSES EFFORTS WITHIN THE BEAVER LAKE PRIORITY WATERSHED, WORKING WITH PARTNERS BEAVER WATERSHED ALLIANCE (BWA), ARKANSAS GAME AND FISH COMMISSION (AGFC), PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE, PRIVATE LANDOWNERS AND OTHERS TO REDUCE OR ELIMINATE THREATS TO THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES AND IMPROVE INSTREAM, RIPARIAN, AND ASSOCIATED HABITATS IN THE WAR EAGLE CREEK SUB WATERSHEDS WHICH CONTAIN ALL PRIORITY SPECIES LISTED ABOVE. WAR EAGLE CREEK CONTAINS A WIDE DIVERSITY OF AQUATIC SPECIES (INCLUDING FEDERALLY LISTED AND AT RISK) AND WAR EAGLE WATERSHED IS THE LARGEST WATERSHED FEEDING INTO BEAVER LAKE, A REGIONAL SOURCE WATER DRINKING SUPPLY FOR OVER FIVE HUNDRED AND FIFTY THOUSAND ARKANSAS RESIDENTS (1 IN 5 ARKANSANS). STRATEGY COMPONENTS WILL INCLUDE ASSESSMENT, DESIGN DEVELOPMENT, REMOVAL OF A DERELICT DAM AND TWO DEGRADED LOW WATER CROSSINGS TO ALLOW FOR AQUATIC SPECIES PASSAGE, AND RECONNECTION OF THE FLOODPLAIN TO WAR EAGLE CREEK THROUGH RIPARIAN AND STREAM RESTORATION. OVER TWO HUNDRED MILES OF STREAMS WILL BE RECONNECTED THROUGH THE REMOVAL OF INSTREAM STRUCTURES, AND WATER QUALITY WILL IMPROVE THROUGH STABILIZATION OF THE SEGMENT OF CREEK AND STREAMBANKS. THESE IMPROVEMENTS ARE THE MOST EFFECTIVE AND FEASIBLE SUITE OF RECOVERY ACTIONS TO PROMOTE SPECIES SURVIVAL AND RECOVERY AND PROJECT PARTNERS ARE WORKING IN COLLABORATION TO LEVERAGE RESOURCES AND MEET PROJECT GOALS.

RECIPIENT WILL MAINTAIN A FACILITY FOR THE ENDANGERED POWESHIEK SKIPPERLING (OARISMA POWESHIEK) BUTTERFLY AT THE JOHN BALL ZOO (GRAND RAPIDS, MICHIGAN). THESE CAPTIVE REARING EFFORTS HAVE BECOME CENTRAL TO POWESHIEK SKIPPERLING RECOVERY EFFORTS. WE WILL CONTINUE TO MANAGE THE CAPTIVE BREEDING POPULATION, COLLECT EGGS, REAR CATERPILLARS, AND PROVIDE APPROPRIATE HUSBANDRY FOR ALL LIFE STAGES OF POWESHIEK SKIPPERLING. WE WILL OVERSEE THE RAPID EXPANSION OF THE EX SITU PROGRAM, FROM 32 BUTTERFLIES IN 2021 TO NOW OVER 850 CATERPILLARS IN 2023, AND LIKELY MORE THIS COMING YEAR. THE CAPTIVE POPULATION WILL ALLOW FLEXIBILITY FOR HOW POWESHIEK SKIPPERLING POPULATIONS ARE MANAGED AND RESTORED MOVING FORWARD.

COOPERATIVE RECOVERY OF TWO CRITICALLY ENDANGERED GALLIFORMESTHIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO PREVENT EXTINCTION OF THE MASKED BOBWHITE QUAIL (MBQ) AND ATTWATER SPRAIRIE CHICKEN (APC) WITHIN THE U.S. AND MAXIMIZE THEIR RECOVERY BY ACCOMPLISHING THE FOLLOWINGACTIONS IDENTIFIED IN BOTH SPECIES  RECOVERY PLANS  1) PREVENT EXTINCTION AND REVERSAL OF RECENTPROGRAM ADVANCEMENTS THROUGH SUPPORT AND ENHANCEMENT OF CAPTIVE AND BIOSECURE POPULATIONS OFMBQ AND APC AT THE GEORGE MIKSCH SUTTON AVIAN RESEARCH CENTER (SUTTON CENTER) AND, 2)SUPPORT EXPANDED BREEDING, REARING AND GENETIC MANAGEMENT OF MBQ AND APC. CAPTIVE BREEDINGIS THE SOLE SOURCE OF BIRDS FOR RE ESTABLISHING VIABLE POPULATIONS OF BOTH SPECIES IN THE WILD, AND THESUTTON CENTER IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAM FOR BOTH SPECIES. THIS FUNDINGWILL ENABLE THE SUTTON CENTER TO PRODUCE VIGOROUS, HEALTHY CHICKS (2,000 MBQ  100 200 APC)ANNUALLY FOR RELEASE INTO WILD HABITATS. CONTINUED SUPPORT IS CRITICAL TO MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING RECOVERY SUCCESSES, WHICH THE USFWS HAS PERSEVERED 30 YEARS TO ACHIEVE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REINVIGORATE AND EXPAND MAINE AUDUBON S  PETS FOR PLOVERS  OUTREACH PROGRAM TO FACILITATE RECOVERY OF THE FEDERALLY THREATENED PIPING PLOVER. THIS PROGRAM WAS STARTED IN 2017 AS A SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO ENCOURAGE PET OWNERS IN MAINE TO SHOW SOLIDARITY AND COMMITMENT TO PIPING PLOVER CONSERVATION, BUT LIMITED STAFFING AND RESOURCES PRECLUDED THE PROGRAM FROM ACHIEVING THE DESIRED SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE AND VISIBILITY ONLINE. POSITIVE FEEDBACK FROM PET OWNERS ABOUT THE PROGRAM HAS BEEN DEMONSTRATED THROUGH INTERACTIONS IN THE FIELD, HOWEVER THERE IS A NEED TO REVIVE OUTREACH AND MARKETING MATERIALS TO SUSTAIN PUBLIC SUPPORT. ALTHOUGH MAINE AUDUBON HAS A BUDGET FOR PIPING PLOVER CONSERVATION, THE GROWING POPULATION OF PIPING PLOVERS IN THE STATE HAS REQUIRED THAT THE LIMITED EXISTING FUNDING BE PRIMARILY ALLOTTED TO FIELD MONITORING AT THE EXPENSE OF OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS. ALTHOUGH PIPING PLOVER NUMBERS IN MAINE ARE THE HIGHEST THEY VE BEEN SINCE MONITORING BEGAN IN 1981, THEIR POPULATION STATUS REMAINS PRECARIOUS, AND THEY CONTINUE TO NEED INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT. ONE OF THE MAJOR THREATS TO PIPING PLOVERS IN MAINE COMES FROM UNLEASHED DOGS AND OUTDOOR CATS, WHICH BOTH CAN CAUSE PLOVER MORTALITY AND NESTING DISRUPTIONS. SEVERAL IMPORTANT NESTING BEACHES ALLOW UNLEASHED DOGS, WHILE OTHERS HAVE LEASH RULES THAT THEY STRUGGLE TO ENFORCE. MAINE AUDUBON STAFF HAVE FOUND THAT THE BEST WAY TO CHANGE THESE BEHAVIORS IS THROUGH THE COMMUNITY ITSELF, AND THAT GIVING A STRONGER VOICE TO PET OWNERS THAT ARE COMMITTED TO CONSERVATION HELPS FOSTER A CULTURE OF PLOVER FRIENDLY BEHAVIORS. THE PETS FOR PLOVERS PROGRAM WILL HELP SHIFT THE NARRATIVE AWAY FROM NEGATIVE INTERACTIONS BETWEEN PET OWNERS AND PIPING PLOVERS AND DEMONSTRATE THAT PET OWNERSHIP AND BIRD CONSERVATION ARE NOT MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE. WE WILL CREATE A WEBSITE, INCREASE OUR PETS4PLOVERS SOCIAL MEDIA PRESENCE, AND DEVELOP ADDITIONAL SWAG TO CONNECT WITH PET OWNERS. BY DOING THIS WORK AND ENGAGING WITH DOG AND CAT OWNERS THROUGH VET OFFICES, PET STORES, AND ONLINE WE WILL SHIFT THE NEGATIVE NARRATIVE AND EXPAND EDUCATIONAL EFFORTS.

GENETIC STUDIES TO IMPROVE OUR KNOWLEDGE OF RARE PLANT SPECIES AND THE VEGETATION STRUCTURE OF IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEMS AT THE AVON PARK AIR FORCE RANGESUBPROJECT 1. STUDIES ON THE RARE PLANTS OF AVON PARK AIR FORCE RANGE  WE WILL COLLECT GENETIC SAMPLES AND HERBARIUM SPECIMENS, ANALYZE BOTH THE RARE SPECIES AND THEIR CLOSE RELATIVES GENETICALLY TO UNDERSTAND SPECIES LIMITS AND GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND GENERATE MANUSCRIPTS THAT WILL INCREASE OUR KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE GLOBALLY RARE PLANT SPECIES ON APAFR. THE SAMPLES AND MANUSCRIPTS WILL SERVE AS BASELINE DATA ON THESE IMPORTANT RARE PLANT SPECIES AT THE APAFR, WHICH WILL BE USED FOR EVALUATING THE EFFECTS OF COMMON EVENTS SUCH AS FREQUENT AIR TO GROUND TRAINING MISSIONS, WILDFIRES, AND THE EFFECTS OF RANGE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND CLIMATE FACTORS ON THE NATIVE FLORA.SUBPROJECT 2. UNDERSTANDING VEGETATION STRUCTURE IN THE FLORIDA DRY PRAIRIE ECOSYSTEM AT APAFR TO CHARACTERIZE ATTRIBUTES OF FLORIDA GRASSHOPPER SPARROW HABITAT. THE WILL PROJECT WILL CLARIFY THE VEGETATION STRUCTURE OF THE FLORIDA DRY PRAIRIE ECOSYSTEM AND HOW IT RESPONDS TO FIRE. THIS KNOWLEDGE WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON HOW TO MANAGE THIS HABITAT, WHICH WILL HELP ENSURE THE LONG TERM VIABILITY AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS FOR THE FLORIDA GRASSHOPPER SPARROW.SUBPROJECT 3. CLONALITY AND HYBRIDIZATION BETWEEN THE FEDERALLY THREATENED CLITORIA FRAGRANS AND WITH CLITORIA MARIANA  THE GOAL OF THIS PART OF THE PROJECT IS TO INTEGRATE THE MORPHOMETRIC AND GENETIC DATA INTO A COMBINED MANUSCRIPT AND SUBMIT IT FOR PUBLICATION IN A PEER REVIEWED JOURNAL. A PEER REVIEWED PUBLICATION WOULD HAVE POTENTIAL TO INFLUENCE A CHANGE TO LISTING OF CLITORIA FRAGRANS.

RECOVERY OF ENDANGERED SPECIES OFTEN COMES WITH THE GOAL OR MAINTAINING OR INCREASING THEIR NUMBERS. IT IS DIFFICULT TO MONITOR VERY SMALL ORGANISMS BEING HELD IN REFUGIA. HOWEVER, TAGS HAVE BECOME SMALLER OVER TIME ALLOWING NEW WAYS TO MARK SMALL ORGANISMS. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS STUDY IS TO SEE IF A NEW TAG TYPE CAN BE USED TO TAG RIFFLE BEETLES AND AN ENDANGERED AMPHIPOD. EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED TO SEE IF THE TAGS HOLD AND IF THE TAGS AFFECT SURVIVAL.

UNDERSTANDING HOW AND WHAT TRIGGERS REPRODUCTION, AND VIABLE DEVELOPMENT IS FUNDAMENTAL TO THE FUTURE BREEDING AND PROPAGATION OBJECTIVES WITHIN THE EDWARDS AQUIFER AUTHORITIES (EAA) HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN. EXOGENOUS ENVIRONMENTAL CUES (E.G., CIRCADIAN RHYTHM, CHANGE IN SEASONAL TEMPERATURE, ETC.) ARE PERCEIVED BY AN ORGANISM S SENSORY ORGANS (EYES  PHOTOTRANSDUCTION  OLFACTORY BULB  CHEMOSENSORY  SKIN  TEMPERATURE), AND ARE PART OF OF THE INITIAL SIGNALING THAT INDICATES THE IDEAL REPRODUCTION PERIODS. WE PROPOSE TO COMBINE A NOVEL MICROCT SCANNING APPROACH (DICECT) WITH RNA SEQUENCING TO BOTH MAP THE DEVELOPMENT OF SENSORY SYSTEMS AND CREATE DE NOVO TRANSCRIPTOMES FOR ENDANGERED SPECIES OF SALAMANDERS. THIS WILL ALLOW US TO TRACK AND MEASURE SENSORY ORGANS, AND ESTABLISH A TRANSCRIPTOME FOR COMPARATIVE GENE EXPRESSION WORK. WITH A TRANSCRIPTOME IN HAND WE PROPOSE TO ESTABLISH A BASELINE UNDERSTANDING OF THE MOLECULAR UNDERPINNINGS RESPONSIBLE FOR GRAVIDITY (FEMALES) AND SPERMATOGENESIS (MALES), AND TO ESTABLISH A DEVELOPMENTAL SERIES OUTLINING PROPER DEVELOPMENT OF EACH SPECIES. THIS STUDY FITS WELL WITH THE OBJECTIVES OF THE SAN MARCOS SPRINGS AND RIVER ECOSYSTEM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. SPECIFICALLY, THE OFF SITE REFUGIA S ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES OBJECTIVES TO  DETERMINE LIFE HISTORY CHARACTERISTICS (LIFE SPAN, TOLERANCE TO WATER QUALITY CHANGES, REPRODUCTION, FOOD RESOURCES)AND MINIMIZE IMPACTS.  (EDWARDS AQUIFER RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION PROGRAM 6.4.4.3, 2012

TO PROVIDE CRITICAL CONSERVATION GENETIC INFORMATION FOR THE CAPTIVE PROPAGATION OF PECK S CAVE AMPHIPODS, STYGOBROMUS PECKI, THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE POPULATION GENOMICS DATA TO QUANTIFY GENETIC VARIATION FROM WILD S. PECKI ACROSS THEIR RANGE AND IN THE  REFUGE  POPULATION. GENOTYPIC DATA FROM ACROSS THE GENOME WILL BE USED TO INFORM COLLECTING AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AND ESTIMATE EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZES FOR WILD POPULATIONS. SIMULATIONS BASED ON THESE DATA WILL BE USED TO PREDICT THE MAINTENANCE OF GENETIC VARIATION IN THE REFUGE POPULATION.

THE COMAL SPRINGS DRYOPID BEETLE, STYGOPARNUS COMALENSIS (BARR AND SPANGLER, 1992) IS A TROGLOBITIC BEETLE IN THE FAMILY DRYOPIDAE (COLEOPTERA) KNOWN PRIMARILY FROM COMAL SPRINGS, COMAL COUNTY, TEXAS, USA, BUT HAS ALSO BEEN COLLECTED FROM SEVERAL SPRINGS IN HAYS COUNTY, TEXAS (GIBSON ET AL., 2008). THIS SPECIES IS PROTECTED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND HAS 22 HA OF DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT (USFWS, 1997, 2013). LIKE MANY OTHER SPECIES IN THE EDWARDS AQUIFER, S. COMALENSIS FACES NUMEROUS THREATS TO THEIR ECOSYSTEM, ESPECIALLY, OVER PUMPING OF WATER, POLLUTION, AND COMPETITION FROM THE INTRODUCTION OF EXOTIC SPECIES (BOWLES AND ARSUFFI 1993). HAVING FUNCTIONAL REFUGES THAT CONTAIN SELF PROPAGATING CAPTIVE POPULATIONS OF S. COMALENSIS IS A GOAL OF THE EDWARDS AQUIFER HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN (EAHCP) AND A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THIS SPECIES HABITAT AND LIFE HISTORIES IS ESSENTIAL FOR MEETING THAT GOAL.THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE HABITAT NEEDS AND GROWTH OF THE COMAL SPRINGS DRYOPID BEETLE (STYGOPARNUS COMALENSIS).EXPLICIT OBJECTIVES 1.HAVE MORE DEFINITIVE ESTIMATES OF LARVAL GROWTH2.DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT THE BEST AQUARIA FOR MAINTAINING ALL LIFE STAGESANOTHER MAJOR COMPONENT, BUT NOT A DIRECT OBJECTIVE, WILL BE TO EXPAND THE COLLECTION RANGE.EXPECTED BENEFIT TO THE REFUGIAGAIN A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF THE LIFE HISTORY NEEDS OF STYGOPARNUS COMALENSIS AND HELP DETERMINE A HOUSING CAPABLE OF MAINTAINING STANDING STOCK OF A CAPTIVE SELF PROPAGATING COLONY FOR REFUGE PURPOSES.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION TO SUPPORT DECISIONS FOR FUTURE MITIGATION AND ENSURE ON THE GROUND ACTIVITIES AND MITIGATION ARE PROMOTING NATIVE PLANT POPULATIONS AND PROTECTING THEIR HABITAT. ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE DRAFTING AND PERFORMING FIELD SURVEYS FOR THE TARGETED PLANT SPECIES, WRITING A REPORT ON THE SURVEY RESULTS, AND WORKING WITH OTHER AGENCIES AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO PLAN MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO PROMOTE THE CONSERVATION OF THE TARGETED SPECIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE DIETS OF PALLID STURGEON  SCAPHIRHYNCHUS ALBUS  IN THE MISSOURI RIVER ABOVE FORT PECK RESERVOIR USING STABLE ISOTOPES  I.E., LONGER-TERM INTEGRATION OF FOOD HABITS  AND REAL-TIME GUT CONTENTS  I.E., SHORT-TERM INTEGRATION OF FOOD HABITS . DIET DATA WILL BE EVALUATED BY YEAR-CLASS  AGE , SIZE  LENGTH, WEIGHT , RIVER LOCATION  LONGITUDINALLY , SEASONS, AND WITH HISTORICAL DATA FROM GERRITY ET AL.  2006 . THESE DATA WILL BE PAIRED WITH CONTEMPORARY AND HISTORICAL  GRISAK 1996  CATCH-PER-UNIT EFFORT DATA FOR SICKLEFIN CHUB  MACRHYBOPSIS MEEKI  AND STURGEON CHUB  MACRHYBOPSIS GELIDA . THE INFORMATION FROM THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO THE CONTEMPORARY IMPORTANCE OF SICKLEFIN CHUB AND STURGEON CHUB IN THE DIETS OF PALLID STURGEON AND WHETHER THE CONCLUSIONS DETERMINED BY GERRITY  2006  ARE STILL RELEVANT FOR THIS REACH OF THE MISSOURI RIVER. THESE RESULTS WILL ALSO BE COMPARED TO DIET DATA FOR PALLID STURGEON SAMPLED BELOW FORT PECK RESERVOIR  SEE DUTTON 2018  TO MAKE LARGER INFERENCES ABOUT PALLID STURGEON FEEDING ECOLOGY. FURTHERMORE, THESE DATA WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ON THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN DIET AND VARIABILITY IN GROWTH. THAT IS, ARE SLOW GROWING PALLID STURGEON WITHIN A YEAR-CLASS PRIMARILY FEEDING ON MACROINVERTEBRATES  CONVERSELY, ARE FAST GROWING PALLID STURGEON WITHIN A YEAR-CLASS PRIMARILY FEEDING ON FISH  THE NEED FOR THIS INFORMATION IS TIMELY GIVEN THE PROPOSED LISTING OF SICKLEFIN CHUB AND STURGEON CHUB AND THE CONTINUED QUESTIONS SURROUNDING VARIATION IN GROWTH AND CARRYING CAPACITY OF HATCHERY-REARED PALLID STURGEON.

IN COOPERATION WITH THE USFWS THE FOREST PRESERVE DISTRICT OF DUPAGE COUNTY ARE PROPOSING TO MANAGE EPFO  PLATANTHERA LEUCOPHAEA  HABITAT AT THREE DUPAGE FOREST PRESERVES THAT ARE ALSO ILLINOIS NATURE PRESERVES.EPFO IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES FACING MANY RISKS PARTICULARLY IN DUPAGE COUNTY. FROM HABITAT LOSS, FRAGMENTATION, HABITAT DEGRADATION, HYDROLOGICAL CHANGE, CLIMATE CHANGE, ISLAND BIOGEOGRAPHY, LACK OF CONTROLLED BURNING SINCE EUROPEAN SETTLEMENT, WOODY AND HERBACEOUS INVASIVE SPECIES ENCROACHMENT, AND LIMITED CROSS POLLINATION OPPORTUNITIES   GENETIC DIVERSITY GREATLY THREATEN EPFO. THESE THREATS ARE AMPLIFIED IN DUPAGE COUNTY DUE TO EXTENSIVE DEVELOPMENT AND HUMAN PRESSURES.THE IMMEDIATE GRANT FUNDED NEED FOR EPFO IS SYSTEMIC CONTROL OF WOODY INVASIVE SPECIES CURRENTLY DEGRADING THE CORE HABITAT AND POTENTIAL HABITAT ALONG WITH BOLSTERING THE REMNANT COMMUNITIES TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR EPFO STABILIZATION AND EXPANSION.GRANT BENEFICIARIES ARE LOCAL ECOSYSTEMS CONTAINING EPFO AND THE  NEARLY ONE MILLION  RESIDENTS OF DUPAGE COUNTY.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  SERVICE  DRAFT RECOVERY PLAN FOR RUFA RED KNOT CALLS FOR PROTECTION OF ALL OF THE MOST IMPORTANT   TIER 1   WINTERING AND STOPOVER HABITAT AREAS FOR THE SPECIES. ENSURING THE EFFECTIVE PROTECTION OF EACH TIER 1 SITE FIRST REQUIRES THEIR IDENTIFICATION AND CHARACTERIZATION. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF THE RUFA RED KNOT POPULATION THROUGH THE IDENTIFICATION, MAPPING, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF TIER 1 WINTERING AND MIGRATION STOPOVER SITES ACROSS THE SPECIES  RANGE. THIS PURPOSE WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE FOLLOWING TASKS ACTIVITIES     1  DEVELOP A TEMPLATE FOR LOCAL PARTNERS TO PROPOSE SITES FOR TIER 1 STATUS   2  AS NEEDED, ASSIST LOCAL PARTNERS WITH THE PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION OF THE NECESSARY DOCUMENTATION   3  REVIEW SUBMITTED DOCUMENTATION TO ENSURE THAT EACH TIER 1 SITE MEETS THE CRITERIA LISTED IN THE FINAL RECOVERY PLAN, ONCE RELEASED   4  FOR EACH TIER 1 SITE, COMPLETE A DOCUMENTATION PACKAGE WITH A MAP, SUMMARY DESCRIPTION OF THE SITE, SUMMARY EVIDENCE FOR HOW IT MEETS THE TIER 1 CRITERIA, AND SUPPORTING CITATIONS DATA, AS WELL AS AN ESRI-COMPATIBLE GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEM  GIS  LAYER OF THE SITE BOUNDARY.

AS THE ONLY BREEDING FACILITY FOR ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS ON THE ISLAND OF MAUI, THE MAUI BIRD CONSERVATION  CENTER  MBCC  IS AN IMPORTANT RESOURCE FOR BOTH NATURAL AND HUMAN COMMUNITIES, PROVIDING A UNIQUE OPPORTUNITY TO  CONNECT THE COMMUNITY WITH THESE OTHERWISE DIFFICULT-TO-SEE SPECIES. TO INITIATE THIS COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT  PROGRAM WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY RECOVERING ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS, CONSTRUCTION, RENOVATION, AND ESTABLISHMENT OF  INFRASTRUCTURE AT THE MAUI BIRD CONSERVATION CENTER ARE NEEDED.  FUNDING IS ANTICIPATED TO BE USED FOR THE FOLLOWING ACTIVITIES. TWO ACCESSIBLE EDUCATION AVIARIES FOR ALALA AND  HAWAIIAN HONEYCREEPER WILL BE BUILT, WHICH WILL REQUIRE CUTTING AND CLEARING NON-NATIVE TREES. EDUCATION AVIARIES  WILL ALLOW THE COMMUNITY TO EASILY SEE, CONNECT WITH, AND LEARN ABOUT HAWAIIAN BIRDS. THESE EDUCATION AVIARIES  WILL BE LOCATED AWAY FROM EXISTING BREEDING AREAS TO AVOID DISTURBING BIRDS IN THE BREEDING PROGRAM. IN ADDITION,  ACTIVITIES ARE PLANNED TO INCLUDE  CUT AND CLEAR NON-NATIVE TREES TO CREATE SITES FOR THE COMMUNITY TO PLANT  NATIVE PLANTS AS PART OF SERVICE-LEARNING ACTIVITIES  INSTALL A PERIMETER FENCE AROUND THE PROPERTY TO PREVENT  INVASIVE DEER FROM BROWSING ON NATIVE PLANTS  REPLACE ROOF SHINGLES ON THE ENTRY ROOM BUILDING DUE TO ONGOING  LEAKING  RENOVATE AND REFURBISH THE ENTRY ROOM TO MAKE IT MORE WELCOMING, COMFORTABLE, AND BETTER SUITED FOR  ENGAGING EXPERIENCES FOR VISITING COMMUNITY MEMBERS  AND BUILD AN OUTDOOR COVERED AREA FOR VISITORS TO OBSERVE  AND CONNECT WITH THE ENVIRONMENT. ONCE THE INFRASTRUCTURE IS ESTABLISHED, THE MAUI BIRD CONSERVATION CENTER WILL  BE BETTER ABLE TO INVOLVE AND CONNECT LOCAL RESIDENTS WITH THE RESTORATION OF BOTH HAWAIIAN BIRDS AND FORESTS,  AND WILL BECOME AN INSPIRATION AND CATALYST FOR HAWAII RESIDENTS TO EMBRACE, PRESERVE, AND RESTORE  HAWAIIAN SPECIES ON THEIR ISLAND HOME.  OBJECTIVES   1  COMPLETE INFRASTRUCTURE RENOVATIONS AND CONSTRUCTION AT MBCC BY SEPTEMBER 30, 2025

RARE AND ENDANGERED SNAIL TREE-SNAIL SPECIES IN THE GENUS ACHATINELLA, ENDEMIC TO THE NORTHERN KOOLAU MOUNTAINS ON OAHU, AND RELATED SPECIES IN THE GENERA PARTULINA, PERDICELLA, AND NEWCOMBIA, FOUND ON THE ISLANDS OF MAUI NUI, HAVE EXPERIENCED DRASTIC RANGE REDUCTIONS AND POPULATIONS DECLINES DUE LARGELY TO INTRODUCED PREDATORS AND CLIMATE CHANGE. TO DATE THE MOST EFFECTIVE WAY TO CONSERVE TREE-SNAIL SPECIES IS TO REESTABLISH AND PROTECT EXISTING POPULATIONS IN THE WILD WITH PREDATOR-PROOF FENCING. HERE THE DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE PROPOSES TO CONSTRUCT PREDATOR-PROOF FENCES AT PRIORITY SITES ON OAHU AND ON THE ISLANDS OF MAUI NUI TO PROTECT RARE AND ENDANGERED SNAIL POPULATIONS.

THE PROPERTIES SURROUNDING HAGG LAKE, LOCATED SOUTHWEST OF PORTLAND, OREGON IN THE SALEM WEST RECOVERY ZONE, ARE HOME TO RARE WILLAMETTE VALLEY PRAIRIE AND OAK HABITAT AND HOST POPULATIONS OF TWO FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES  FENDER S BLUE BUTTERFLY  FBB, ICARICIA ICARIOIDES FENDERI  ENDANGERED  AND KINCAID S LUPINE  LUPINUS OREGANUS, THREATENED . THIS PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE ON THE PRAIRIE AND OAK HABITATS ADJACENT TO HAGG LAKE OWNED BY BUREAU OF RECLAMATION  BOR . PROJECT FUNDS ARE PROVIDED THROUGH AN INTERAGENCY AGREEMENT WITH BOR. THE OVERALL GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO, WITH THE COLLABORATION OF THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE OREGON FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE  USFWS OFWO , EXPAND AND IMPROVE FBB AND KINCAID S LUPINE HABITAT AND ULTIMATELY INCREASE POPULATION SIZES OF BOTH SPECIES. PROPOSED WORK ACTIONS WILL INCLUDE  MONITORING OF FBB POPULATIONS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION TO TRACK SPECIES RECOVERY AND DOCUMENT RESULTS OF CURRENT AND ONGOING HABITAT RESTORATION, CONDUCTING REVEGETATION WITH NATIVE SPECIES TO REACH RECOVERY PLAN HABITAT QUALITY BENCHMARKS FOR FBB AND KINCAID S LUPINE AND TO ENHANCE THE VALUE OF THE SITE FOR RECREATION AND ENJOYMENT BY THE LOCAL COMMUNITY, PERFORM HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIONS THAT REDUCE COVER OF NON-NATIVE AND INVASIVE NATIVE SPECIES AND PREPARE THE SITE FOR NATIVE SPECIES REVEGETATION IMPLEMENTATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM PROJECT IS TO REDUCE AND OR ELIMINATE THREATS TO SAGEBRUSH HABITATS AND RESTORE AND ENHANCE SAGEBRUSH HABITATS FOR SAGE GROUSE  TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL CHEMICAL AND MECHANICAL TREATMENTS WILL BE APPLIED TO THE SAGEBRUSH  THE APPLICATION OF REJUVRA HERBICIDE AND MASTICATION WILL BE THE PRESCRIBED TREATMENTS  REJUVRA WILL BE APPLIED BY BOTH ROTARY WING AND FIXED WING AIRCRAFT  APPROXIMATELY 3000 ACRES WILL BE TARGETED FOR THIS TREATMENT  MECHANICAL TREATMENT WILL BE APPLIED USING A MASTICATOR AND APPROXIMATELY 500 ACRES WILL BE TREATED  THE PLANNING OF DESIRABLE FORBS WILL THEN BE SPREAD THE TARGET BROOD REARING SAGE GROUSE  THIS PROJECT WILL BE MONITORED BY TRANSECTS AND PHOTO POINTS

THE VARRONIA RUPICOLA IS AN ENDEMIC LARGE SHRUB IN PUERTO RICO AND THE BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS  THERE ARE ONLY THREE KNOWN POPULATIONS IN THE WILD, ONE IS IN THE ISLAND OF ANEGADA  BRITISH VIRGIN ISLANDS , THE SECOND IN THE PUERTO RICO COMMONWEALTH RESERVE FOREST OF GUANICA AND THE THIRD IN THE VIEQUES NWR  THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES HAS BEEN LISTED AS A HIGH REGIONAL PRIORITY, SINCE IT IS IN A PROTECTED AREA, IT IS FOUND IN EXTREMELY LOW NUMBERS AND CAN BE POSITIVELY IMPACTED WITH SMALL AND LOWER COST FUNDED PROJECTS  IN THE VIEQUES NWR, THE SMALL POPULATION OF 16 WILD INDIVIDUALS IS SUPPLEMENTED BY A GROUP OF OVER 40 INDIVIDUALS THAT ARE BEING GROWN IN THE REFUGE GREENHOUSE, AS PART OF A PILOT PROGRAM  DUE TO HABITAT DAMAGE BY HURRICANES IRMA AND MARIA, IN 2017, THE SELECTED AREAS HAVE BEEN INVADED BY TWO ESTABLISHED INVASIVES FROM OTHER AREAS OF THE REFUGE, BUT THEY ARE NEW TO THE VARRONIA HABITAT  THE ACACIA  ACACIA FARNESIANA  AND TAM TAM  LEUCAENA LEUCOCEPHALA   TICATOVE PROPOSES TO AID IN THE RECOVERY OF VARRONIA RUPICOLA AT THE VIEQUES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE THROUGH INVASIVE PLANT AND FIRE THREAT REDUCTION WORK IN COOPERATION WITH THE USFWS

GUNNISON BASIN CHEATGRASS AND WET MEADOW IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT 2022PROJECT ABSTRACTTHIS PROJECT WILL ELEVATE THE LONG TERM EFFORTS OF THE CONSERVATION COMMUNITY OF THE GUNNISON BASIN OF COLORADO TO ENSURE THAT THE WESTERN STRONGHOLD OF NORTH AMERICA S SAGEBRUSH BIOME IS PROTECTED WITH STRATEGIC AND COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION ACTION  PROJECT FUNDING WILL SUPPORT STRATEGIC EFFORTS TO DELIVER TANGIBLE OUTCOMES OF WET MEADOW RESTORATION AND SAGEBRUSH RESTORATION WITHIN THE GUNNISON BASIN  THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO SIGNIFICANTLY BOLSTER THE ON GOING EFFORTS OF THE LOCAL CONSERVATION COMMUNITY BY SUPPORTING THE EXISTING WET MEADOW RESTORATION EFFORTS TO ENHANCE HABITAT FOR CRITICAL LIFE STAGES OF THE GUNNISON SAGE GROUSE  THE PROJECT IS HIGHLY COLLABORATIVE, ENGAGING FEDERAL, STATE, COUNTY, ACADEMIC, AND NON PROFIT PARTNERS TO TAKE DELIBERATE ACTION TO PROTECT, MAINTAIN, AND RESTORE GUNNISON BASIN S SAGEBRUSH HABITAT THROUGH WET MEADOW RESTORATION  COLLECTIVELY, THESE PARTNER DRIVEN EFFORTS WILL PROTECT, ENHANCE, AND RESTORE CRITICAL HABITAT FOR SAGEBRUSH OBLIGATE WILDLIFE WHILE SUPPORTING COMPATIBLE LAND USE LIKE LIVESTOCK GRAZING, RECREATION, AND ECOTOURISM WE WILL USE HIGH RESOLUTION, REMOTELY SENSED IMAGERY TO MAP THE OCCURRENCE OF CHEATGRASS WITHIN THE BASIN, AS WELL AS TO INFORM LOCATIONS FOR LONG TERM WET MEADOW PROJECTS AND GAIN CRUCIAL VISUAL DATA ON SAGEBRUSH, PERENNIAL GRASS BARE GROUND, AND CONIFER COVER AT HIGH SPATIAL RESOLUTION  FUNDING WILL EXPEDITE ON THE GROUND PROJECTS ON PRIVATE AND TRIBAL LANDS OVER THE NEXT THREE YEARS  IN DOING SO, THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE EFFORTS OF UPPER GUNNISON RIVER WATER CONSERVANCY  UGRWCD , COLORADO PARKS AND WILDLIFE  CPW , AND USFWS PARTNERS FOR FISH AND WILDLIFE  PFW  AND THEIR LEADERSHIP IN THE BASIN TO RESTORE WET MEADOW HABITAT  POST TREATMENT MONITORING OVER THREE YEARS WILL ALLOW IN DEPTH ANALYSIS OF PROJECT AND REPRODUCIBILITY IN OTHER LOCATIONS  PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL ENGAGE WESTERN COLORADO UNIVERSITY GRADUATE STUDENTS AND SUPPORT THEIR RESEARCH AND EFFORTS TO FURTHER STREAMLINE AND UPSCALE WET MEADOW RESTORATION  FURTHER, FUNDING WILL BE DEDICATED TO THE OUTREACH AND VOLUNTEER EFFORTS THAT GUNNISON BASIN PROUDLY AND SUCCESSFULLY CONDUCTS TO ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN BOTH THE WET MEADOW AND CHEATGRASS PROJECTS WITH NON PROFIT PARTNERS THROUGH LOW TECH STRUCTURE CONSTRUCTION AND CHEATGRASS PULLING THE FUNDING OF THIS PROJECT IS A PIVOTAL MOMENT FOR CONSERVATION IN THE GUNNISON BASIN AND WILL ALLOW USFWS TO FULLY ENGAGE WITH THE COMMUNITY AS A PARTNER  BEYOND THE DIRECT IMPACT AND CRUCIAL ACREAGE OF THESE RESTORATION EFFORTS, THIS PROJECT SYMBOLIZES USFWS  COMMITMENT TO SUPPORTING AND UPLIFTING OUR FEDERAL, TRIBAL, STATE, COUNTY, NON PROFIT, AND ACADEMIC PARTNERS IN GROUNDBREAKING WAYS TO SUPPORT THEIR DECADES OF EFFORTS TO PROTECT THIS ESSENTIAL SAGEBRUSH HABITAT

SANDY POINT NWR IS CRITICAL NESTING HABITAT FOR THREE FEDERALLY PROTECTED SEA TURTLE SPECIES, THE LEATHERBACK, GREEN AND HAWKSBILL SEA TURTLE  THE LEATHERBACK RECOVERY PROGRAM BEGAN ON SANDY POINT WITH MONITORING AND TAGGING EFFORTS IN 1977, LEADING TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE LONGEST CONTINOUSLY OPERATED LEATHERBACK RESEARCH AND RECOVERY PROGRAM  THIS LONG TERM RECOVERY EFFORT AND RESULTING DATA, AND RESEARCH ARE CRITICAL FOR SUPPORTING THE LEATHERBACK SEA TURTLE POPULATION RECOVERY BY PROVIDING INFORMATION ON LIFE HISTORY TRAITS SUCH AS SURVIVAL, RECRUITMENT, HATCH SUCCESS, AGE TO MATURITY AND LONGEVITY  THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE OCEAN FOUNDATION IN COLLABORATION WITH SANDY POINT NWR STAFF, WILL INCREASE EFFORTS FOR RECORDING HAWKSBILL SEA TURTLE NESTS AND DOCUMENT EMERGENCES WITH THE GOAL OF ESTABLISHING SANDY POINT NWR AS AN IMPORTANT INDEX NESTING BEACH FOR THIS SPECIES  EXTENDED DAY PATROLS, ASSESSING HATCH SUCCES, TRACKING PRODUCTIVITY ARE PART OF THE ACTIVITIES THAT WILL BE CONDUCTED FOR THIS SPECIES, IN ADDITION TO RECORDING BIOMETRIC DATA TO COMPILE NESTING HISTORY AND COLLECTING GENETIC SAMPLES TO DETERMINE IF GREEN AND HAWKSBILLS SEA TURTLES IN THE CARIBBEAN ARE UNIQUE POPULATIONS  THE CONTIUEATION OF ENDANGERED SEA TURTLE MANAGEMENT, MONITORING, AND RESEARCH ON THE REFUGE IS ESSENTIAL TO BOTH THE MISSION OF THE REFUGE AND RECOVERY OF SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS WORLD WIDE

CRAYFISH THAT ARE PRIMARY BURROWERS ARE NOTORIOUSLY DIFFICULT TO COLLECT SINCE INDIVIDUALS ARE SELDOM IN OPENWATER OR ON THE SURFACE  COMMONLY USED COLLECTION METHODS  E G , BURROW TRAPPING AND BURROW EXCAVATION  ARE NOTSPECIES SPECIFIC, ARE TIME CONSUMING, AND ARE NOT FEASIBLE WITHOUT LANDOWNER PERMISSIONS WHICH CAN BE HARD TOOBTAIN AS IT IS NECESSARY TO DIG HOLES  THIS HAS NUMEROUS NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON CONFIDENTLY ESTIMATING THECONSERVATION STATUS OF THESE ANIMALS BECAUSE ESTIMATIONS OF DISTRIBUTION, HABITAT USE, AND CURRENT AND FUTURERISKS ARE MUCH MORE UNCERTAIN  WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A WIDELY APPLICABLE EDNA BASED APPROACH USING BURROWCHIMNEYS  I E , SOIL SAMPLES  AND WATER IN BURROWS  I E , WATER SAMPLES  TO ESTIMATE DISTRIBUTION AND HABITAT USEIN BURROWING CRAYFISH  WE WILL VALIDATE THIS APPROACH USING THE PETITIONED JACKSON PRAIRIE CRAYFISH  PROCAMBARUSBARBIGER  EVALUATE ITS APPLICATION TO OTHER CRAYFISH SPECIES, INCLUDING THE PETITIONED PROCAMBARUS FITZGERALDIAND CREASERINUS DANIELAE  A SUCCESSFUL, WIDELY APPLICABLE, MINIMALLY INVASIVE SAMPLING PROTOCOL WILL ALLOW MUCHFASTER COLLECTION OF SAMPLES FOR PRIMARY BURROWING CRAYFISHES OVER GREATER SPATIAL EXTENTS PER UNIT OF EFFORT ANDGREATER LIKELIHOOD OF OBTAINING LANDOWNER PERMISSION  NO DIGGING NECESSARY   DISTRIBUTIONAL DATA WILL BE USED TOESTIMATE HABITAT USE AND POTENTIAL DISTRIBUTION OF THE TARGET SPECIES  PRODUCTS WILL BE USED IN THE SPECIESSTATUS ASSESSMENT FOR THE JACKSON PRAIRIE CRAYFISH  THIS PROJECT WOULD ALSO HELP TO FORM WHAT WE HOPE WILL BE ALONG TERM PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE MISSISSIPPI FIELD OFFICE AND JACKSON STATE UNIVERSITY  ONE OF THE LARGESTHISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES IN THE UNITED STATES , SUPPORTING MINORITY STUDENTS AND PROVIDINGTHEM WITH NUMEROUS OPPORTUNITIES TO WORK WITH SERVICE BIOLOGISTS AND EXPLORE CAREER OPPORTUNITIES

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO EXAMINE THE INTER AND OR INTRA POPULATION GENETIC VARIATION FOR T  PERSISTENS IN ORDER TO AID STATE FEDERAL AGENCIES AND PRIVATE LANDOWNERS IN SETTING GOALS FOR SAFEGUARDING AND MANAGEMENT EFFORTS  OVERALL, THIS PROJECT WILL ENABLE STAKEHOLDERS TO BETTER ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES THAT MAY AFFECT T  PERSISTENS RESILIENCE, REPRESENTATION AND REDUNDANCY IN THE LANDSCAPE

IN SAGITTARIA FASCICULATA, ESTIMATING POPULATION AND COLONY SIZE IS A PRIORITY 2 RECOVERY TASK  THE SPECIES ISKNOWN TO REPRODUCE BOTH SEXUALLY BY SEED AND ASEXUALLY BY CLONAL EXPANSION  THE IMPORTANCE OF CLONALITY WITHINAND AMONG POPULATIONS HAS NOT YET BEEN DOCUMENTED  BASELINE INFORMATION ON CLONAL STRUCTURE IS KEY TO DETERMININGTHE NUMBER OF GENETICALLY UNIQUE INDIVIDUALS PRESENT WITHIN AND AMONG COLONIES  ADDITIONALLY, GENETIC INFORMATIONWILL PROVIDE AN ASSESSMENT OF HOW CONNECTED COLONIES WITHIN POPULATIONS ARE, AS WELL AS HOW CONNECTED POPULATIONSARE TO EACH OTHER  FOR THIS WORK, I PROPOSE THE USE OF HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING OF MICROSATELLITE LOCI TOGENERATE HIGH RESOLUTION GENETIC PROFILES FOR APPROXIMATELY HALF OF THE EXTANT COLONIES  18  ACROSS ALL 11POPULATIONS

OF THE 17 SPECIES OF BUMBLE BEES THAT OCCUR ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST, SEVERAL HAVE EITHER BEEN FEDERALLY LISTED  RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE, BOMBUS AFFINIS , PETITIONED FOR LISTING  YELLOW BANDED BUMBLE BEE, B  TERRICOLA , AND OR HAVE POSITIVE 90 DAY FINDINGS  VARIABLE CUCKOO BUMBLE BEE, B  VARIABILIS, AND AMERICAN BUMBLE BEE, B  PENSYLVANICUS   OTHER SPECIES WITHIN THE PROJECT AREA ARE IN A THREATENED CATEGORY ON THE INTERNATIONAL UNION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURE  IUCN  RED LIST  SOUTHERN PLAINS BUMBLE BEE, B  FRATERNUS   ENDANGERED  AND YELLOW BUMBLE BEE, B  FERVIDUS   VULNERABLE   EVIDENCE SUGGESTS THAT OVERALL BUMBLE BEE POPULATION NUMBERS, DIVERSITY, AND ABUNDANCE HAVE DRAMATICALLY DECREASED OVER THE LAST SEVERAL DECADES  THE CAUSES OF THESE DECLINES ARE NOT FULLY UNDERSTOOD, BUT THE FOLLOWING LIKELY PLAY A ROLE  LOSS OR FRAGMENTATION OF HABITAT, PESTICIDE EXPOSURE, CLIMATE CHANGE, COMPETITION WITH HONEY BEES, LOW GENETIC DIVERSITY, AND PERHAPS MOST SIGNIFICANT OF ALL, THE INTRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION OF PATHOGENS THROUGH COMMERCIAL HONEY BEE AND BUMBLE BEE COLONIES USED FOR CROP POLLINATION  ALL OF THESE FACTORS LIKELY INTERACT, INCREASING BUMBLE BEE VULNERABILITY  ADDITIONALLY, CURRENT OCCURRENCE DATA FOR THESE SPECIES ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST HAS SUBSTANTIAL DEFICIENCIES, INCLUDING A LACK OF A COMPREHENSIVE, SYSTEMATIC, AND REPEATABLE SURVEYS TO TRACK BUMBLE BEES AT A REGIONAL SCALE  FUTURE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS  SSAS , LISTING DECISIONS, AND CONSERVATION PLANS ACTIONS WOULD GREATLY BENEFIT FROM AN ORGANIZED EFFORT TO UPDATE ELEMENT OCCURRENCE RECORDS  EORS

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTITLE  DEVELOPING A WILLAMETTE VALLEY SURVEY PROTOCOL TO MONITOR DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND POPULATION TRENDS OF THE FEDERALLY THREATENED STREAKED HORNED LARK ABSTRACT TRACKING THE STATUS AND PROGRESS OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES RECOVERY EFFORTS REQUIRES INFORMATION ON THE SPECIES  DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND POPULATION TRENDS  THE STREAKED HORNED LARK  SHLA  IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED SUBSPECIES THAT OCCURS IN EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT, INCLUDING AGRICULTURAL LANDS, IN WASHINGTON AND OREGON  PEARSON ET AL   2016  DEVELOPED A STANDARDIZED MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR USE AT OCCUPIED SITES WITH WELL DEFINED BOUNDARIES AND TO WHICH ACCESS IS ALLOWED  E G , AIRFIELDS, PRAIRIES, COLUMBIA RIVER DEPOSITION ISLANDS   HOWEVER, A MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR SHLAS ON PRIVATE LANDS IN AGRICULTURAL HABITATS OF THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY, OR, WHERE   50  OF THE SHLA S RANGE WIDE POPULATION LIKELY BREEDS, IS LACKING  ACCORDINGLY, THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MONITORING PROTOCOL FOR SHLAS IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY IS IDENTIFIED AS A CRITICAL NEED IN THE SPECIES  DRAFT RECOVERY PLAN AND IS THE  1 RANKED PRIORITY IN THE 2021 SHLA ACTION PLAN  IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE OUTLINE A MULTI PHASED PROPOSAL THAT DEVELOPS A ROAD BASED SURVEY PROTOCOL FOR SHLAS IN THIS REGION  RESULTS FROM THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO RECOMMEND A FULL SCALE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN FOR MONITORING SHLA IN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY CAPABLE OF ESTIMATING POPULATION SIZE AND TRACKING POPULATION TRENDS  IN COMBINATION WITH THE PEARSON ET AL   2016  PROTOCOL, IT WILL BE POSSIBLE TO ESTIMATE RANGE WIDE POPULATION ABUNDANCE AND TRENDS  THIS INFORMATION WOULD YIELD A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF SHLA POPULATION DYNAMICS, WHICH IS NECESSARY TO SUPPORT RECOVERY AND CONSERVATION OF THE SUBSPECIES

THE LONGNOSE DARTER  PERCINA NASUTA  IS A SPECIES ENDEMIC TO THE UPPER WHITE RIVER, LOWER ARKANSAS RIVER, AND THE ST  FRANCIS RIVER IN ARKANSAS, OKLAHOMA, AND MISSOURI  THE LONGNOSE DARTER IS A CANDIDATE FOR PROTECTION UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  HOWEVER, IT IS NOT CLEAR HOW MANY SPECIES COMPRISE THE POPULATIONS CURRENTLY DESIGNATED AS P  NASUTA  THIS PROJECT WILL EXPLORE SPECIES DIVERSITY OF POPULATIONS CURRENTLY DESIGNATED AS LONGNOSE DARTER AND SLENDERHEAD DARTER  P  PHOXOCEPHALA  THROUGH A COMBINATION OF PHYLOGENETIC ANALYSES OF DNA SEQUENCES GENERATED USING DDRAD AND ASSESSMENT OF DISPARITY IN MORPHOLOGICAL TRAITS LONG USED TO DISCOVER AND DESCRIBE SPECIES OF FISHES  THIS INFORMATION WILL GUIDE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THROUGH APPROPRIATE ASSESSMENT OF SPECIES DIVERSITY AND GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN AND AMONG THE SPECIES CURRENTLY MASQUERADING AS LONGNOSE DARTER

THE USFWS UTAH ECOLOGICAL SERVICES FIELD OFFICE IS COLLABORATING WITH THE UTAH DIVISION OF WILDLIFE RESOURCES  UDWR TO DISTRIBUTE FUNDING FROM THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW TO RESTORE AND CONSERVE STRATEGIC AREAS WITHIN THE SAGEBRUSH ECOSYSTEM  THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THIS FUNDING REQUEST IS TO SUPPORT UPLAND AND MESIC HABITAT RESTORATION IN UTAH BENEFITTING SAGEBRUSH AND SAGE GROUSE CONSERVATION  UDWR WILL DISTRIBUTE FUNDS TO TO PROJECTS THAT SUPPORT UPLAND AND MESIC HABITAT RESTORATION IN UTAH THAT SUPPORT SAGEBRUSH AND SAGE GROUSE CONSERVATION THROUGH UTAH S WATERSHED RESTORATION INITIATIVE

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO USE NEWLY AVAILABLE NANOPIN TELEMETRY TECHNOLOGY (LOTEK WIRELESS, INC.) TO TRACK THE NESTING LOCATIONS OF BUMBLE BEES, A TAXONOMIC GROUP THAT HAS SHOWN ALARMING DECLINES IN NORTH AMERICA AND ELSEWHERE. NANOTAGS HAVE BEEN ATTACHED SUCCESSFULLY TO TRACK MOVEMENTS OF INCREASINGLY SMALL ANIMALS LIKE SMALL SONGBIRDS AND DRAGONFLIES, BUT THIS WILL BE ONE OF THE FIRST ATTEMPTS TO USE THIS TECHNOLOGY ON BEES

THIS PROJECT WILL DELIVER A SECOND ITERATION OF A PRACTICUM FORMAT CONSERVATION BIOLOGY COURSE ON THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT WITH A FOCUS ON FIVE YEAR REVIEWS  THE COURSE WILL BE OFFERED AS A GRADUATE COURSE AT UGA, WITH REMOTE PARTICIPATION BY ADVANCED UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AT GEORGIA GWINNETT COLLEGE, A MINORITY SERVING INSTITUTION  THE CULMINATING PROJECT FOR EACH STUDENT WILL BE A DRAFT 5 YEAR REVIEW FOR A LISTED SPECIES, SUPPORTED BY A PRESENTATION SUMMARIZING THE REVIEW  WE WILL ALSO WORK WITH PARTNERS AT A PUERTO RICO UNIVERSITY TO TRAIN THEM TO DELIVER A SIMILAR COURSE

BUILDING ON THE WORK OF PROJECT PARTNERS WE SEEK FUNDING TO INFORM DESIGN OPPORTUNITIES FOR SEVEN MITIGATION LOCATIONS ON I-5 BETWEEN ASHLAND AND THE CALIFORNIA BORDER IN SOUTHWESTERN OREGON. THESE SITES WERE IDENTIFIED BY A COALITION OF AGENCIES AND ORGANIZATIONS AS POTENTIAL PASSAGE OPPORTUNITIES FOR WILDLIFE CROSSINGS ALONG THIS STRETCH OF I-5. FINAL PRODUCTS OF THIS PHASE OF WORK INCLUDE A PROJECT ALTERNATIVES REPORT AND PREFERRED MITIGATION ALTERNATIVES THAT COMPLY WITH LOCAL CONDITIONS AND ENGINEERING RESTRICTIONS.

AWARD PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF RUFA RED KNOTS (CALIDRIS CANUTUS RUFA) AND THEIR PREY DURING SPRING STOPOVER ALONG THE OCEAN INTERTIDAL ZONE OF WALLOPS ISLAND, WHICH INCLUDES THE WALLOPS ISLAND FLIGHT FACILITY, IN 2023. FUNDING IS SOUGHT FOR THE 2023 MIGRATION SEASON AND ASSOCIATED ANALYSES OF DATA FROM BOTH THE 2022 AND 2023 MIGRATION SEASONS. UNDERSTANDING RED KNOT DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE AND FORAGING ECOLOGY AT THIS STOPOVER WILL ASSIST FLYWAY-LEVEL MANAGEMENT PLANNING FOR THE RECOVERY OF THIS THREATENED SPECIES, AND PROJECT SPECIFIC ASSESSMENTS ON WALLOPS ISLAND AND ELSEWHERE IN VIRGINIA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED: WE WILL CONDUCT FIELD-BASED MONITORING OF RED KNOTS ALONG THE OCEAN INTERTIDAL ZONE OF WALLOPS ISLAND IN MAY 2023. WE WILL BEGIN LAB ANALYSES OF RED KNOT PREY FROM THE 2023 FIELD SEASON. WE WILL WRITE A REPORT SUMMARIZING OUR FINDINGS FROM FIELD SAMPLING AT WALLOPS ISLAND IN 2023, PLACING THE FINDINGS IN THE CONTEXT OF THE LONG-TERM MONITORING ACROSS THE VIRGINIA COAST RESERVE, AND MAKING ANY MANAGEMENT OR FURTHER MONITORING RECOMMENDATIONS. DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: A FINAL REPORT SUMMARIZING ACTIVITIES AS FOLLOWS: " THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF RED KNOTS AND THEIR PREY DURING SPRING MIGRATION ALONG WALLOPS ISLAND IN 2023. " FINDINGS FROM WALLOPS ISLAND 2023 CONTEXTUALIZED IN OUR LONG-TERM MONITORING DATASET OF RED KNOTS AND PREY IN VIRGINIA FROM 2006-2023. " RECOMMENDATIONS FOR CONTINUED MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF RED KNOTS AND THEIR PREY ON WALLOPS ISLAND AND IN VIRGINIA BASED ON THESE DATA. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES: FEDERAL, STATE AND NON-PROFIT MANAGEMENT ENTITIES WITH RESPONSIBILITIES FOR MANAGING THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY POPULATIONS OF THE RUFA RED KNOT. SUBRECIPIENT ACTIVITIES: NONE

THE PROJECT IS INTENDED TO BENEFIT WILDLIFE AND THEIR HABITAT AND PARTICULARLY SPECIES OF TRIBAL CULTURAL OR TRADITIONAL IMPORTANCE  WE ARE SEEKING FUNDING TO RELOCATE BEAVER INTO THE NORTHERN PORTION OF THE GIFFORD PINCHOT NATIONAL FOREST  BEAVER ARE CONSIDERED ECOSYSTEM ENGINEERS IN THAT THEY HAVE A PROFOUNDLY LARGE IMPACT ON THE ENVIRONMENT AROUND THEM  BEAVERS BUILD DAMS THAT IMPOUND WATER AND CREATE PONDS  THIS CONVERTS DRY LAND ADJACENT TO STREAMS INTO VALUABLE HABITAT FOR SALMON SPECIES, TURTLES, WATERFOWL, WADING BIRDS, AMPHIBIANS, AND BIG GAME SPECIES  BEAVERS CREATE HABITATS FOR ALL OF THESE VARIOUS SPECIES IN AN ENVIRONMENT WHERE THESE TYPES OF HABITATS ARE OFTEN LIMITING THE ABUNDANCE OF THESE PARTICULAR WILDLIFE POPULATIONS

HEALTHY NATIVE POLLINATOR COMMUNITIES CONTRIBUTE TO PRODUCTIVITY AND DIVERSITY IN BOTH NATURAL AND AGRICULTURAL ECOSYSTEMS. YET, MANY INSECT POLLINATOR SPECIES HAVE EXPERIENCED SIGNIFICANT REDUCTIONS IN POPULATION SIZES AND RANGE IN RECENT DECADES. IN NORTH AMERICA, BUMBLE BEE DECLINES APPEAR TO HAVE A SIGNAL OF RELATEDNESS, WITH MANY THREATENED SPECIES IN THE SAME SUBGENUS, WHICH INCLUDES THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE. THIS SUGGESTS THAT THIS GROUP HAS A SUSCEPTIBILITY TO FACTORS DETRIMENTAL TO BUMBLE BEE POPULATION HEALTH. BUMBLE BEE POPULATION HEALTH, FUTURE REINTRODUCTIONS AND MANAGEMENT OF THREATS ALL RELY ON KNOWLEDGE OF EXISTING STRESSORS, ECOLOGY, AND MEASURES OF POPULATION HEALTH, SUCH AS GENETIC DIVERSITY. THE PROPOSED WORK HAS TWO OBJECTIVES: 1) A COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF SUSCEPTIBILITY OF A REPRESENTATIVE OF THIS SPECIES TO PROPOSED DRIVERS OF DECLINE, AND 2) AN ASSESSMENT OF NON-DESTRUCTIVE SAMPLING FROM FECES TO ASSESS BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY HEALTH. FOR THE FIRST OBJECTIVE, USING LAB COLONIES OF SURROGATE SPECIES WITHIN BOMBUS SENSU STRICTO AND COMPARISON NON-THREATENED SPECIES WITHIN NATIVE BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITIES FROM OTHER SUBGENERA, A SERIES OF EXPERIMENTAL EXPOSURE STUDIES FOLLOWING ESTABLISHED PROTOCOLS WILL BE CARRIED OUT TO ASSESS SUSCEPTIBILITY TO PATHOGENS, POOR NUTRITION AND AGRI-CHEMICALS LINKED WITH DECLINES. IN ADDITION, COMBINATIONS OF THESE STRESSORS WILL BE ASSESSED FOR SYNERGISTIC DETRIMENTAL EFFECTS. WHERE PHENOTYPIC DIFFERENCES IN SUSCEPTIBILITY ARE UNCOVERED, A TARGETED MOLECULAR APPROACH WILL BE TAKEN TO UNCOVER UNDERLYING MECHANISMS.THE SECOND OBJECTIVE WILL BUILD ON PRELIMINARY DATA ON THE NON-DESTRUCTIVE SAMPLING OF FECES TO ASSESS PATHOGEN PRESENCE AND LOADS. THIS WILL BE EXPANDED TO ASSESS IF FECES CAN BE USED TO ACCURATELY DETECT OTHER COMMON AND DECLINE ASSOCIATED PATHOGENS, AND AN INDIVIDUAL BEE'S DIET AND GENETICS. VERIFICATION OF APPROACHES AND INFORMATION GAINED ON POTENTIAL DIFFERENTIAL SUSCEPTIBILITY AND ITS ROOT CAUSE WILL INFORM STRESSOR ASSESSMENTS AND REMEDIATION EFFORTS THAT ARE CRITICAL FOR NOT ONLY THE HEALTH OF THE EXISTING BUMBLE BEE POPULATIONS BUT ALSO FEASIBILITY OF POTENTIAL FUTURE REINTRODUCTIONS.

THE TEANAWAY RIVER AND CLE ELUM RIVER BULL TROUT IN THE YAKIMA BASIN HAVE BEEN FUNCTIONALLY EXTIRPATED. EIGHT OF THE 11 REGULARLY SURVEYED BULL TROUT SPAWNING STREAMS ARE AT LOW OR VERY LOW ABUNDANCE IN TERMS OF REDD COUNTS. TO AVOID FURTHER EXTIRPATIONS WITHIN THE YAKIMA BASIN BULL TROUT POPULATION ABUNDANCE NEEDS TO INCREASE AND BECOME MORE RESILIENT BY REOCCUPYING PREVIOUS AND NEW HABITATS. THE WDFW, MCFEG, YAKAMA NATION, BUREAU OF RECLAMATION, AND USFWS HAVE PARTNERED TOGETHER TO IMPLEMENT A BULL TROUT FRY AND JUVENILE RESCUE PROGRAM. WE HAVE SEEN SUCCESS IN THE REARING FACILITY ENVIRONMENT AND INDICATIONS THAT RELEASED FISH ARE PERSISTING IN THEIR NATAL STREAM. WE WANT TO USE THIS RESCUE TECHNIQUE TO ACQUIRE BULL TROUT FRY FROM STABLE POPULATIONS AND REINTRODUCE THEM INTO STREAMS WHERE THEY HAVE BEEN EXTIRPATED. OUR CURRENT CAPACITY ONLY ALLOWS FOR RESCUE FROM GOLD CREEK AND KACHESS RIVER AND THE NECESSARY MONITORING OF THOSE POPULATIONS WITH DEMOGRAPHIC SURVEYS AND PIT TAG DETECTORS. WE NEED TO EXPAND THE BULL TROUT RESCUE EFFORT TO HIGHER ABUNDANCE POPULATIONS THAT WILL MORE LIKELY BE ABLE TO SUSTAIN DONOR INDIVIDUALS TO A REINTRODUCTION EFFORT (I.E. SOUTH FORK TIETON RIVER, DEEP CREEK, AND INDIAN CREEK). THESE FRY WILL BE RAISED IN A REARING FACILITY AND REINTRODUCED INTO STREAMS THAT USED TO HAVE BULL TROUT AND WHERE THREATS THAT LEAD TO THEIR EXTIRPATION HAVE BEEN ADDRESSED. TO ENSURE THAT REMOVAL OF DONOR STOCK FROM THESE POPULATIONS DOES NOT DETRIMENTALLY IMPACT THEM, WE NEED TO MONITOR THE DONOR POPULATIONS BEYOND THE CURRENT REDD SURVEYS. WE NEED TO EXPAND THE DEMOGRAPHIC SURVEY MONITORING TO THESE DONOR STREAMS TO UNDERSTAND THE AGE 0 AND JUVENILE STREAM DWELLING LIFE HISTORY OF BULL TROUT TO DETERMINE IF POTENTIAL DONOR POPULATIONS CAN REMAIN STABLE AS A RESULT OF THE REMOVAL OF FRY. THE RESCUE EFFORT AND MONITORING DATA THAT WOULD BE OBTAINED BY THIS WORK IS ESSENTIAL TO IMMEDIATELY IMPLEMENT PRIORITY RECOVERY ACTIONS TO AID IN THE RECOVERY OF THE REMAINING BULL TROUT IN THE UPPER YAKIMA BASIN. IF WE DO NOT INCREASE CAPACITY TO RESCUE FRY FROM ABUNDANT POPULATIONS WE WILL HAVE NO DONOR STOCK AVAILABLE TO START A REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM. IF WE DO NOT MONITOR THE ABUNDANT POPULATIONS FOR IMPACTS TO THE RELATIVE ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THEIR FRY AND JUVENILES, WE RISK IRREPARABLE DAMAGE TO OUR STRONGEST BULL TROUT POPULATIONS. IF WE DO NOT TAKE THE ADDITIONAL ACTIONS DESCRIBED HERE, ONLY THE GOLD AND KACHESS POPULATIONS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE RESCUE, REARING, AND RELEASE EFFORTS. THE REMAINING POPULATIONS WILL CONTINUE TO DECLINE ESPECIALLY IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER ANTHROPOGENIC EFFECTS.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE REDWOOD PARKS CONSERVANCY (COOPERATOR), TOLOWA DUNES STATE PARK (TDSP - LANDOWNER), AND THE ARCATA FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE'S ECOLOGICAL SERVICES PROGRAM. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO HELP RECOVER THE FEDERALLY THREATENED OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (OSB) BY REMOVING INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, PRIMARILY EUROPEAN BEACHGRASS, AND PLANTING THE BUTTERFLY'S LARVAL HOST PLANT, VIOLA ADUNCA, NATIVE OSB NECTAR PLANTS, AND COMPANION PLANTS CONDUCIVE TO BUTTERFLY EGG-LAYING AND PROTECTION OF VIOLETS. THIS FUNDING WILL CONTINUE WORK ON THE 5 ACRE PROJECT NEAR TRANSECT 3 OF THE OSB SURVEY TRANSECTS ON TDSP LANDS. FUNDING WILL GO TOWARDS: 1) RETREATMENT OF 3 ACRES AND THE INITIAL TREATMENT OF 1 ACRE OF EUROPEAN BEACHGRASS, 2) REVEGETATION WITH NECTAR, VIOLETS, AND COMPANION PLANT SPECIES, AND 3) VEGETATION AND PHOTO MONITORING. PARK STAFF AND VOLUNTEERS WILL CONDUCT THE WORK. MAPPING AND PROJECT REPORTING WILL OCCUR ANNUALLY.

THIS PROJECT BENEFITS AN AT-RISK SPECIES IN THE PRAIRIES OF WESTERN OREGON BY SUPPORTING THE DE-LISTING(REMOVAL FROM THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST) OF NELSON'S CHECKERMALLOW (A THREATENED SPECIES). PROPOSED ACTIONS FOR NELSON'S CHECKERMALLOW ARE THOSE RECOMMENDED IN THE USFWS RECOVERY PLAN FORPRAIRIE SPECIES OF WESTERN OREGON AND SOUTHWEST WASHINGTON, THE ROADMAP CREATED BY USFWS TO GUIDETHE WORK NEEDED TO REMOVE SPECIES FROM THE ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST. PRIMARY FACTORS THAT PUT NELSON'SCHECKERMALLOW AT RISK AND IN NEED OF PROTECTION ARE HABITAT LOSS AND REDUCTION IN HABITAT QUALITY CAUSEDBY INVASIVE WEEDS AND WOODY SHRUBS THAT SPREAD AGGRESSIVELY INTO THE PLANTS' HABITATS. PROPOSED ACTIONSINCLUDE HABITAT MANAGEMENT TO CONTROL SHRUBS AND WEEDS, FOLLOWED BY SEEDING AND PLANTING MORENELSON'S CHECKERMALLOW, ACROSS FOUR LOCATIONS ON PERMANENTLY PROTECTED AND MANAGED CORVALLIS AREA CONSERVATION SITES. OVERALL, CREATING BETTER HABITAT AND BIGGER POPULATIONS AT FOUR SITES WILL HELP STABILIZE THIS SPECIES.

SUMMARY: THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH RECOVERY BY PROTECTING/MAINTAINING EXISTING POPULATIONS THROUGH HYBRID REMOVAL, EXPANDING EXISTING AND NEW POPULATIONS, SEED PRODUCTION TO ALLOW FOR CURRENT AUGMENTATION AND FUTURE EXPANSION, AND MONITORING OF POPULATIONSOBJECTIVES: 1. EXPAND AND SUPPORT EXISTING SEED PRODUCTION OF GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH TO ENABLE LARGE SCALE SEEDINGS.2. MAINTAIN EXISTING GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH POPULATIONS BY REMOVING HYBRID THREATS.3. EXPAND EXISTING POPULATIONS OF GOLDEN PAINTBRUSH AND ESTABLISH NEW POPULATIONS.   TASKS: ADD 6000 SQUARE FEET BED WITH THE REQUIRED LABOR-INTENSIVE WEEDING NEEDED FOR GROWING CASTILLEJA SPECIES AT SATELLITE FACILITY TO PREVENT HYBRIDIZATION POTENTIAL. PRODUCTION WILL BE EXPANDED IN 2022 AND NURTURED IN 2023 AS PLANTS ESTABLISH. USE SEED PRODUCED TO AUGMENT AND EXPAND MANAGED SITESMAINTENANCE ON THE EXISTING TWO BEDS (9500 SQUARE FEET TOTAL) THAT IS REGULARLY WEEDED AND MANAGED, ALLOWING FOR MAXIMUM PRODUCTION. MANUAL REMOVAL OF HYBRIDS WILL BE CONDUCTED EACH SUMMER DURING FLOWERING. SITES WILL BE SWEPT SEVERAL TIMES OVER THE GROWING SEASON TO HAND REMOVE POTENTIAL HYBRIDS. SEEDING WILL BE CONDUCTED IN THE FALL AFTER PRESCRIBED BURNING.

THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE SEQUOIA PARK ZOO FOUNDATION (COOPERATOR) AND THE ARCATA FISH AND WILDLIFE OFFICE'S ECOLOGICAL SERVICES PROGRAM. THE PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO HELP RECOVER THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED BEHRENS SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (BSB) BY AUGMENTING EXISTING POPULATIONS WITH CAPTIVELY-REARED LARVAE, PUPAE, AND ADULTS. THE ZOO WILL CARE FOR FERTILIZED ADULT BSB WHILE THEY LAY EGGS THROUGH THE END OF THEIR LIFE. THE ZOO WILL CARE FOR THE EGGS, LARVAE, PUPAE, AND ADULTS AS THEY MATURE. THE AUGMENTATION OF EXISTING POPULATIONS HELPS PREVENT EXTINCTION AND PROVIDES INCREASES TO NATURAL POPULATIONS WHICH HAVE BEEN DECREASING. THIS FUNDING WILL GO TOWARDS PERSONNEL AND TRAVEL NECESSARY TO CONDUCT THE CAPTIVE REARING AND RELEASES. ZOO STAFF WILL CONDUCT THE WORK. PROJECT REPORTING WILL OCCUR ANNUALLY.

THE ATLANTA BOTANICAL GARDEN WILL WORK WITH THE FWS AND OTHER SE PCA PARTNERS TO INCREASE CAPACITY FOR RARE PLANT RECOVERY. THIS INCLUDES THE CONTINUATION OF 4 PILOT PROJECTS AND THE INITIATION OF 6 NEW PROJECTS FOR SPECIES PRIORITIZED THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH REGIONAL LEADS IN 2021. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS RECOVERY ACTIONS AND TO ENHANCE THE SE PCA NETWORK WHILE LEVERAGING FINANCES AND RELATIONSHIPS ACROSS THE SOUTHEAST. FUNDING IS REQUESTED TO SUPPORT NEXT-STEP RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR VARRONIA RUPICOLA, PLATANTHERA INTEGRILABIA, RIBES ECHINELLUM, AND SCHWALBEA AMERICANA. PILOT PROJECT SUPPORT IS REQUESTED FOR OXYPOLIS CANBYI, LINUM ARENICOLA, HELIANTHUS SCHWEINITZII, EUPHORBIA TELEPHIOIDES, AND POLYGONELLA BASIRAMIA.
