SPALDINGS CATCHFLY RECOVERY DEPENDS ON THE CREATION AUGMENTATION OF LARGE POPULATIONS THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE.   THIS PROJECT WILL CONTINUE EFFORTS AT THE PARADISE RIDGEG ORMSEN BUTTE KEY CONSERVATION AREA (PARADISE KCA) IN THE PALOUSE GRASSLANDS PHYSIOGRACHIC REGION WHERE SIGNIFICANT STRIDES HAVE BEEN MADE TO ACHIEVE THE RECOVER GOAL OF ESTABLISHING OVER 500 INDIVIDUAL SPALDINGS CATCHFLY PLANTS.  BEST METHODS DEVELOPED BY THE LATAH SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT (LATCH SWCD) DURING PREVIOUS PLANTING AND MONITORING EFFORTS ARE BEING USED TO FULLY ESTABLISH A POPULATION AT THE PARADISE KCA AND FOR CREATING OR AUGMENTING OTHER POPULATIONS RANGEWIDE.  THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE FOLLOWING: 1.) MONITOR PLANTED/SEEDED LOCATIONS ANNUALLY, 2.) PLANT SPALDINGS CATCHFLY IN SUITABLE SITES TO ACHIEVE THE 500+ GOAL, 3.) CONTROL WEEDS AND RESEED WITH NATIVE SPECIES TO PREVENT WEED INVASIONS AND TO PROMOTE SUCCESSFUL SPALDINGS CATCHFLY ESTABLISHMENT, 4.) WRITE MONITORING REPORTS AND PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO SPALDINGS CATCHFLY RECOVERY PARTNERS IN THE REGION.

IN 2018, THE LONG-TIME RED WOLF SSP COORDINATOR AND STUDBOOK KEEPER RETIRED. SUBSEQUENTLY, THE AZA CANID AND HYENID TAXON ADVISORY GROUP (TAG) SELECTED A NEW SSP COORDINATOR, LOCATED WITH THE NORTH CAROLINA ZOO (NCZ), AND A NEW STUDBOOK KEEPER, LOCATED WITH PDZA. THE SSP COORDINATOR POSITION IS NEEDED TO OVERSEE A SCIENCE-BASED BREEDING PROGRAM FOR ALL RED WOLVES THAT ARE MANAGED IN THE POPULATION UNDER HUMAN CARE. THE SSP COORDINATOR WORKS COLLABORATIVELY WITH MORE THAN 40 INSTITUTION REPRESENTATIVES AND MANY AZA ORGANIZATIONS TO ASSURE THAT THE CAPTIVE POPULATION NOT ONLY REMAINS GENETICALLY DIVERSE, BUT IS ALSO LARGE ENOUGH TO SUPPORT THE USFWS RED WOLF RECOVERY PROGRAM. THE RED WOLF STUDBOOK KEEPER IS CHARGED WITH MAINTAINING AN ACCURATE RECORD OF THE CAPTIVE POPULATION, WHICH INCLUDES PROVIDING HISTORICAL GENETIC INFORMATION ON ALL WOLVES. ACCURATE STUDBOOK RECORDS ARE ESSENTIAL TO MANAGING THE CAPTIVE POPULATION AND FULFILLING THE GOAL OF LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY. BOTH POSITIONS ARE VITAL TO THE MANAGEMENT AND SUCCESS OF THE SSP AND ITS ABILITY TO MEET USFWS RECOVERY GOALS.

THE GOAL OF THE SAINT LOUIS ZOO'S PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO PROPAGATE THE OZARK HELLBENDER AND THE MISSOURI DISTINCT POPULATION SEGMENT (DPS) OF THE EASTERN HELLBENDERS AT THE ZOO TO AUGMENT DECLINING, WILD POPULATIONS. THIS PROJECT GOAL WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: 1) MODIFY/REPAIR TWO NEW INDOOR STREAMS FOR CONSERVATION-BREEDING, 2) ADDRESSING TEMPERATURE ISSUES COMPROMISING EQUIPMENT, AND 3) INCREASING STAFFING TO CARE FOR CAPTIVE HELLBENDERS.DELIVERABLE: THE ABOVE ACTIONS TO FACILITY THE PROPAGATION AND HEADSTARTING OF OZARK HELLBENDERS AND MO DPS EASTERN HELLBENDERS, WHICH IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF RECOVERING THE SPECIES.PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL TAKE PLACE FROM THE TIME THE FUNDING IS RECEIVED UNTIL MARCH 2025.

NORTH CAROLINA COASTAL LAND TRUST (NCCLT), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NORTH CAROLINA WILDLIFE RESOURCES COMMISSION (NCWRC), RESPECTFULLY REQUEST A GRANT OF $25,000 FROM THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE'S ENDANGERED SPECIESRECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION PROGRAM TO SUPPORT THE PERMANENT CONSERVATION OF APPROXIMATELY 260-ACRES OF LAND ALONG THE CAPE FEAR RIVER IN BLADEN COUNTY. THE 260-ACRE PROPERTY (CAPE FEAR/TCI TIMBER COMPANY TRACT) IS LOCATED NEAR THE TOWN OF EAST ARCADIA AND IS ACCESSED OFF U.S. HIGHWAY 87 IN BLADEN COUNTY. THE TCI TIMBER COMPANY TRACT IS PRESENTLY UNDEVELOPED AND IS OWNED BY TCI TIMBER COMPANY, LLC, A SUBSIDIARY OF CAMPBELL GLOBAL, LLC. NCCLTPROPOSES TO ACQUIRE THE 260-ACRE PROPERTY IN FEE TITLE AND THEN TRANSFER IT IN A SAME DAY CLOSING TO THE STATE OF NORTH CAROLINA TO BE MANAGED BY NCWRC AS PART OF THE WHITEHALL PLANTATION GAME LANDS WHICH IS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FOR HUNTING, FISHING, HIKING AND WILDLIFE OBSERVATION, OR AS A STATE CONSERVATION AREA. THE PROPERTY LIES WITHIN A LANDSCAPE OF OTHER CONSERVATION LANDS INCLUDING: (1) 2,900-ACRE WHITEHALL PLANTATION GAME LANDS (LOCATEDUPSTREAM OF THE PROPERTY IN BLADEN COUNTY); (2) A 546-ACRE CONSERVATION EASEMENT HELD BY NCCLT (LOCATED UPSTREAM OF THE PROPERTY IN BLADEN COUNTY); AND (3)THE 3,600-ACRE CAPE FEAR WETLANDS GAME LANDS (LOCATED DOWNSTREAM OF THE PROPERTY IN PENDER COUNTY). THE CAPE FEAR/TCI TIMBER COMPANY TRACT CONSISTS OF APPROXIMATELY 189 ACRES OFCYPRESS-GUM SWAMP AND BOTTOMLAND HARDWOOD WETLANDS ALONG AN ESTIMATED 1.1 MILES OF THE CAPE FEAR RIVER ALONG WITH 71 ACRES OF UPLANDS A MAJORITY OF WHICH IS IN MATURE HARDWOODS ALONG STEEP RAVINES. THE PROPERTY LIES WITHIN THE STEEP RUN SWAMP SIGNIFICANT NATURAL HERITAGE AREA IDENTIFIED BY THE NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL HERITAGE PROGRAM AS HAVING VERY HIGH ECOLOGICAL SIGNIFICANCE. PART OF THIS RANKING IS DUE TO THE FACT THAT THERE HAS BEEN ADOCUMENTED GREAT EGRET AND WOOD STORK COLONY ON THE PROPERTY AS WELL AS HAVING THE ONLY DOCUMENTED SWALLOW-TAILED KITE NEST IN THE STATE TO DATE. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO: (LL ENHANCE LOCAL WATER QUALITY THROUGH THE PROTECTION OF FORESTED WETLANDS AND ESTABLISHMENT OF PERMANENT RIPARIAN BUFFERS ALONG 1.1 MILES OF THE CAPE FEAR RIVER; (2) CONSERVE A PORTION OF A SIGNIFICANT NATURAL HERITAGE SITE; AND (3) PROTECT IMPORTANT HABITAT FOR A VARIETY OF RARE SPECIES INCLUDING THE FEDERALLY THREATENED WOOD STORK.

THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS 1 FTE WITH THE STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES AS A MOSQUITO CONTROL PROJECT SPECIALIST. THIS POSITION WILL ASSIST WITH THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF INCOMPATIBLE INSECT TECHNIQUE TOOL TO SUPPRESS NON-NATIVE MOSQUITO POPULATIONS THAT ARE THREATENING SEVERAL ENDANGERED FOREST BIRD SPECIES THROUGH THE SPREAD OF DISEASE. THIS POSITION WILL WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE NETWORK OF STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNER AGENCIES, UNIVERSITIES, AND PRIVATE COMPANIES TO SECURE FUNDING, HELP ATTAIN NECESSARY PERMITS, ASSIST WITH FEDERAL AND STATE REGULATORY COMPLIANCE, SUPPORT AND IMPLEMENT NECESSARY MONITORING RESEARCH TO EVALUATE EFFICACY OF THE TOOL, FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT OF DEPLOYMENT TECHNOLOGY, OBTAIN THE MOSQUITO PRODUCTS, SYNCH DOFAW LABORATORY PRODUCTION WITH RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT NEEDS, AND ASSIST AS NEEDED WITH ALL OTHER ACTIVITIES RELATING TO IMPLEMENTATION OF IIT ON THE LANDSCAPE. THIS FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE SUPPORTS THIS POSITION FOR 1.5YEARS.

BULL TROUT (SALVELINUS CONFLUENTUS) WERE EXTIRPATED FROM THE CLACKAMAS RIVER BASIN OVER 40 YEARS AGO. IN 2011, AN EFFORT TO REINTRODUCE BULL TROUT WAS INITIATED AS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS), THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW), AND PACIFIC GAS AND ELECTRIC (PGE). TRANSLOCATION EFFORTS CONTINUED FROM 2011-2016, AND MONITORING OF THE POPULATION HAS BEEN ONGOING SINCE. IF FUNDED, THIS PROJECT WILL ALLOW ODFW TO CONTINUE TO MONITOR BULL TROUT IN THE UPPER CLACKAMAS RIVER BASIN IN 2022 AND 2023, VIA CENSUS REDD SURVEYS IN KEY SPAWNING AREAS, EDNA SURVEYS, SNORKEL SURVEYS, AND TEMPERATURE MONITORING. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROPOSAL WILL FUND LAB-REARING TO COMPARE THE DEVELOPMENT FROM EGGS TO FRY IN THIS POPULATION WITH OTHER POPULATIONS IN OREGON. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PORTION OF THE PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE IF DEVELOPMENTAL ABNORMALITIES MAY BE CONTRIBUTING TO HIGHER MORTALITY IN EARLY LIFE STAGES IN THE CLACKAMAS BASIN. THE NEXT TWO YEARS COVER A CRITICAL PERIOD FOR THE EVALUATION OF THE REINTRODUCTION EFFORT. BASED ON PREVIOUS REDD COUNTS, A SIGNIFICANT INCREASE IN LOCAL-ORIGIN ADULTS IS PREDICTED TO OCCUR STARTING IN 2021. IF AN INCREASE IS OBSERVED, THIS WOULD INDICATE THAT THE POPULATION IS ON THE PATH TOWARDS BECOMING SELF-SUSTAINING; IN NOT, ADDITIONAL MANAGEMENT ACTIONS MAY BE NEEDED TO MEET REINTRODUCTION GOALS. THIS PROJECT COULD BE IMPLEMENTED IN FULL, OR A SUBSET OF THE PROPOSED WORK COULD BE COMPLETED FOR A PORTION OF THE TOTAL ESTIMATED COST.

A MODEL FOR PREDICTING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) OCCURRENCES IN THE  GREAT LAKES REGION BASED ON HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS, LAND COVER, ABIOTIC, AND OTHER  DESCRIPTIVE DATA IN AREAS OF POSITIVE AND NEGATIVE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE OCCURRENCE  IS PRODUCED TO ASSIST IN PRIORITIZING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) SURVEY  EFFORTS. MODEL PARAMETERS INCORPORATE RECOMMENDATIONS FROM U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE  SERVICE STAFF IN COLLABORATION WITH BUMBLE BEE EXPERTS. IN SUBSEQUENT YEARS, QUALIFIED  BIOLOGISTS TEST THE MODEL THROUGH SURVEY EFFORTS WHERE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE ARE NOT  KNOWN TO OCCUR BUT PREDICTED BY THE MODEL; AT LEAST 15 SITES ARE SURVEYED WITH LOW (5  SITES), MODERATE (5 SITES), OR HIGH (5 SITES) PROBABILITY OF OCCUPANCY. THE MODEL IS REFINED  AND RETESTED BASED ON SURVEY RESULTS. IN ALL CASES, FIELD SURVEYS FOLLOW USFWS SURVEY  PROTOCOLS FOR THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) VERSION 2.2, RAPID SURVEY  PROTOCOL TO EXPEDITE SAMPLING AND COVER AS MUCH AREA AS POSSIBLE. LIMITED OCCURRENCE  AND DISTRIBUTION INFORMATION OF RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES  REGION CREATES A CHALLENGE FOR LAND MANAGERS, BUT ONCE COMPOSED A PREDICTIVE MODEL  FOR RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE COULD SIGNIFICANTLY SUPPORT THE OVERALL CONSERVATION GOALS OF  THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE AND U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE.

RESTORATION EFFORTS SPECIFIC TO THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE  (BOMBUS AFFINIS) OCCUR THROUGHOUT THE GREAT LAKES REGION AT THE FEDERAL, STATE, LOCAL, AND  PRIVATE CITIZEN LEVELS. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES RESTORATION EFFORTS IN TWO WAYS, (1)  DEVELOPING A RESTORATION PLAN FOR THE GREAT LAKES REGION AND (2) EVALUATING EXISTING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE RESTORATIONS. TO ASSIST LAND MANAGERS AND PROPERTY OWNERS WITH  DEVELOPING AND MAINTAINING RESTORATIONS, A RESTORATION PLAN THAT PROVIDES VEGETATION  MANAGEMENT GUIDANCE, BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND OPTIMAL SIZE, STRUCTURE, AND  LOCATION(S) OF CURRENT AND FUTURE RESTORATIONS IS DEVELOPED. THE RESTORATION PLAN IS  CONSTRUCTED USING THE BEST AVAILABLE RESEARCH, HISTORIC AND CURRENT NATURAL HISTORY INFORMATION, AND SUGGESTIONS BY EXPERT BEE BIOLOGISTS. EVALUATION OF EXISTING RUSTY  PATCHED BUMBLE BEE HABITAT RESTORATIONS IS COMPLETED VIA FIELD SURVEYS IN RESTORATIONS  NEAR KNOWN POPULATIONS OF RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE IN INDIANA (NICHES [NORTHERN  INDIANA CITIZENS HELPING ECOSYSTEMS SURVIVE] LAND TRUST) AND WISCONSIN. FIELD SURVEYS  ASCERTAIN WHETHER RESTORATIONS ATTRACT RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEES FROM NEARBY KNOWN  POPULATIONS AND DETERMINE CURRENT MANAGEMENT PRACTICE EFFICACY. FIELD SURVEYS ARE  COMPLETED FOR RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE AND OTHER BEES OVER FOUR YEARS (2022-2025);  MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ARE EVALUATED EACH YEAR FOR EFFECTS ON BUMBLE BEES AND ANNUAL  RECOMMENDATIONS ARE MADE. SURVEYS GENERALLY FOLLOW FWS SURVEY PROTOCOLS FOR THE  RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) VERSION 2.2, RAPID SURVEY PROTOCOL TO  EXPEDITE SAMPLING AND COVER AS MUCH AREA AS POSSIBLE AND INCLUDE NON-LETHAL SURVEY  TECHNIQUES. BOTH THE RESTORATION PLAN AND EVALUATION OF RESTORATION MANAGEMENT EFFICACY  PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SUPPORT FOR THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE'S AND U.S. FISH &  WILDLIFE SERVICE'S OVERALL CONSERVATION GOALS IN THE REGION.

CATTLE WERE EXCLUDED FROM THE HART MOUNTAIN NATIONAL ANTELOPE REFUGE (HMNAR) IN 1991, MAKING IT ONE OF THE MOST EXPANSIVE WILDLIFE HABITATS IN THE ARID WEST FREE OF DOMESTIC LIVESTOCK. IN 1991 AND 1992, THE OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE CONDUCTED PHYSICAL STREAM HABITAT SURVEYS WHICH RECORDED DEGRADED STREAM CHANNELS, ERODING BANKS, AND LIMITED FISH COVER. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT QUANTITATIVE CENSUS INSTREAM HABITAT SURVEYS AND RIPARIAN TRANSECTS IN ROCK, GUANO, AND STOCKADE CREEKS; EVALUATE REDBAND TROUT ABUNDANCE IN ROCK CREEK VIA MARK-RECAPTURE; CONDUCT A FISH INVENTORY IN GUANO AND STOCKADE CREEKS. WE WILL NOTE OBSERVATIONS OF WILDLIFE, INCLUDING BEAVER, MUSSELS, AMPHIBIANS, AND FISH. WE WILL RETURN TO RANDOMLY-SELECTED POINTS TO RE-EVALUATE HABITAT AND WATER AVAILABILITY AND FISH ASSEMBLAGE AS THE FIELD SEASON ALLOWS. PAIRING RIPARIAN TRANSECTS AND STREAMSIDE VEGETATION COMPOSITION WITH SURVEYS OF WILLOW AND ASPEN RECRUITMENT AND AGE STRUCTURE WILL HELP DESCRIBE THE NATURAL RESTORATION OF RIPARIAN CONDITIONS AND STREAM CHANNEL INTEGRITY AND CHARACTERISTICS SINCE CATTLE WERE EXCLUDED. ALTHOUGH CHANGES TO RIPARIAN VEGETATION CAN BE RELATIVELY RAPID, STREAM MORPHOLOGY OFTEN CHANGES AT A SLOWER RATE; CONSEQUENTLY, CONDUCTING A REPEATED SURVEY AT THIS TIME WILL PROVIDE A MEANINGFUL EVALUATION OF PROGRESS IN RESTORATION AFTER 30 YEARS. OUR FINDINGS WILL BE SUMMARIZED IN REPORTS AND SHARED WITH PARTNERS.

BIOLOGISTS WILL CONDUCT HABITAT AND STRESSOR ASSESSMENTS (USING FWS RPBB ASSESSMENT GUIDANCE) AND  WORK WITH WI DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCE PROPERTY MANAGERS TO ACCOMPLISH SITE-SPECIFIC  HABITAT RESTORATION/ENHANCEMENT AND STRESSOR REMEDIATIONS. CURRENTLY ONLY 3 OF THE 9 KNOWN EXTANT  RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (RPBB) (BOMBUS AFFINIS) HIGH PRIORITY SITES WITHIN THE GREAT LAKES  WATERSHED HAVE HAD HABITAT ASSESSMENTS CONDUCTED. LEAVING 6 SITES STILL NEEDING HABITAT  ASSESSMENTS TO BE CONDUCTED. BIOLOGISTS WILL CONDUCT BUMBLE BEE SURVEYS ON STATE LAND WITHIN THE  GREAT LAKES BASIN. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED ACROSS EITHER ALL OR PART OF 11 OF WISCONSIN ECOLOGICAL  LANDSCAPES, INCLUDING NORTHERN, CENTRAL, AND SOUTHERN LAKE MICHIGAN COASTAL, NE 1/3 OF SOUTHEAST  GLACIAL PLAINS, NORTH 1/2 OF CENTRAL SAND HILLS, NORTHEAST SANDS, NORTH AND EAST PARTS OF NORTH  CENTRAL FOREST, SUPERIOR COASTAL PLAIN, NORTH 1/4 OF NORTHWEST SANDS AND NORTH 1/4 OF NORTHWEST  LOWLANDS. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED BETWEEN JUNE AND AUGUST FOLLOWING THE USFW SURVEY  PROTOCOLS FOR THE RPBB FOLLOWING PHOTOGRAPH ONLY SURVEYS PROTOCOLS OR POSSIBLY THE RAPID SURVEY  PROTOCOL - SURVEYING AREAS TO FIND NEW POPULATIONS. WE WILL GAIN FURTHER DATA ABOUT CURRENT BUMBLE  BEE DISTRIBUTIONS IN WI THROUGH THE WIDNR CITIZEN-BASED MONITORING (CBM) PROGRAM FOR WISCONSIN'S  BUMBLE BEES KNOWN AS THE BUMBLE BEE BRIGADE. LACK OF INFORMATION REMAINS A THREAT COMMON TO  THE CONSERVATION OF SGCN INVERTEBRATE GROUPS. CITIZEN-BASED MONITORING CAN BE USED TO COMBAT  THIS. THE WDNR'S BUMBLE BEE BRIGADE IS A SYSTEMATIC, LONG-TERM MONITORING SCHEME THAT WAS  DESIGNED TO MONITOR THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF BUMBLE BEES ACROSS THE STATE. ONE OF THE  GOALS OF THIS PROJECT IS TO KEEP THE CBM PROJECT FUNDED WITH PARTICIPANTS COLLECTING DATA ON BUMBLE  BEES, AS WELL AS PROVIDE OUTREACH AND TRAINING OF VOLUNTEERS TO ENGAGE IN LONG-TERM BUMBLE BEE  MONITORING.

AGL WILL COORDINATE EFFORTS BY USFWS, WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WDNR), UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN-GREEN BAY (UWGB), AND NORTHEAST WISCONSIN AUDUBON (NEWI AUDUBON) TO ENSURE PIPL ARE MONITORED DAILY. THIS ROLE WAS PREVIOUSLY CONDUCTED BY UWGB DURING 2017-2021 AND WILL BE COORDINATED BY AGL IN A RELATIVELY SIMILAR MANNER. AGL WISCONSIN CONSERVATION MANAGER TOM PRESTBY WILL OVERSEE/MANAGE ASPECTS OF MONITORING INCLUDING TRAINING, SCHEDULING, QUALITY DATA COLLECTION AND COMMUNICATION, AND NOTIFYING USFWS OF URGENT DEVELOPMENTS IMMEDIATELY. USFWS IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SURVEYING TWO DAYS PER WEEK, WDNR IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SURVEYING ONE DAY PER WEEK, AND AGL WILL COORDINATE AMONGST AGL, UWGB, AND NEWI AUDUBON MONITORS TO COVER THE REMAINING FOUR DAYS PER WEEK. TOM PRESTBY WILL WORK WITH USFWS BIOLOGIST JADE ARNESON TO ENSURE THAT QUALITY DATA ARE BEING COLLECTED VIA THE NEST STORY PLATFORM. JADE ARNESON WILL COMMUNICATE DATA TO THE USFWS PIPL CONSERVATION TEAM.

THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF BUMBLE BEE IDENTIFICATION WORKSHOPS AND A RUSTY  PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) FIELD SEASON KICK-OFF MEETING PROVIDE MUCH NEEDED  GUIDANCE AND STRUCTURE TO RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE RESEARCH AND REGULATORY SURVEY  EFFORTS. THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE FIELD KICK OFF MEETING IS AN ANNUAL ONE-DAY EVENT  (2022 - 2025) ATTENDED BY QUALIFIED SURVEYORS AND STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCY PERSONNEL.  THE MEETING FOCUSES ON SURVEY AND REPORTING REQUIREMENT CHANGES AND UPDATES, CLARIFIES  CRITERIA FOR HABITAT INTERPRETATIONS, AND DISSEMINATES REGIONALLY SPECIFIC RUSTY PATCHED  BUMBLE BEE INFORMATION. THE KICK-OFF MEETING ALSO INTRODUCES PREFERRED RUSTY PATCHED  BUMBLE BEE SURVEY AND DOCUMENTATION METHODS AND PROVIDES AN OPEN COMMUNICATION  FORUM WHERE PROFESSIONALS WORKING WITH THE SPECIES CAN ASK QUESTIONS AND PROMPT  DISCUSSIONS. BUMBLE BEE IDENTIFICATION WORKSHOPS COMPRISE 2.5-DAY EVENTS ADDRESSING  BUMBLE BEE IDENTIFICATION, NATURAL HISTORY, BIOLOGY, AND TAXONOMY. THREE BUMBLE BEE  IDENTIFICATION WORKSHOPS ARE CONDUCTED ANNUALLY (2022-2025) WITH UP TO 20 PARTICIPANTS  PER WORKSHOP. EACH EVENT COMPRISES ONE DAY OF BUMBLE BEE IDENTIFICATION INSTRUCTION  (LABORATORY SETTING), ONE DAY OF COLLECTING SPECIMENS AND ASSESSING BUMBLE BEE HABITAT  (FIELD SETTING), AND A HALF DAY FOCUSED ON SYNTHESIZING THE WORKSHOP AND ADDRESSING  OUTSTANDING BUMBLE BEE IDENTIFICATION OR HABITAT ASSESSMENT ISSUES AND QUESTIONS.  TRAINING FOR BUMBLE BEE IDENTIFICATION AND ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT GUIDANCE REGARDING  POLLINATORS IS RELATIVELY LACKING THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE GREAT LAKES WATERSHED, THUS A  RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE KICK OFF MEETING PRIOR TO AND BUMBLE BEE WORKSHOPS THROUGHOUT  THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE FIELD SEASON SIGNIFICANTLY SUPPORTS THE GREAT LAKES  RESTORATION INITIATIVE'S AND U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE'S OVERALL CONSERVATION OBJECTIVES  AND ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR IDENTIFICATION AND ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT COMPLIANCE  GUIDANCE PARTICULARLY REGARDING THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE.

TO EXPAND THE CURRENT EXTENT OF FEDERALLY ENDANGERED RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS  AFFINIS) POPULATIONS AND LOCATE NEW POPULATIONS, BUMBLE BEE SURVEYS ARE PERFORMED IN  U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE REGION 3 AND REGION 5. SURVEYS OCCUR THROUGHOUT THE  GREAT LAKES WATERSHED IN THREE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES IN NEW YORK, OHIO, AND  WISCONSIN (FOX RIVER [WI], OTTAWA [OH], AND MONTEZUMA [NY]), WETLAND MANAGEMENT  DISTRICTS AND STATE GAME AREAS IN MICHIGAN, TWO COUNTIES (COOK AND LAKE) IN ILLINOIS, AND  13 COUNTIES (ADAMS, ALLEN, DEKALB, ELKHART, KOSCIUSKO, LAKE, LAGRANGE, LAPORTE, NOBLE,  PORTER, ST. JOSEPH, STEUBEN, AND WELLS OR WHITLEY) IN INDIANA. SURVEYS GENERALLY FOLLOW  USFWS SURVEY PROTOCOLS FOR THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE (BOMBUS AFFINIS) VERSION  2.2, RAPID SURVEY PROTOCOL TO EXPEDITE SAMPLING AND COVER AS MUCH AREA AS POSSIBLE AND  ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE UNTIL 2025. INFORMATION REGARDING RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE,  BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITIES, AND FLOWER USE IS RELATIVELY LACKING THROUGHOUT MUCH OF THE  GREAT LAKES WATERSHED. DETAILED DATA ASSOCIATED WITH BEE SPECIES RICHNESS, ABUNDANCE,  AND HABITAT USE PROVIDE SIGNIFICANT SUPPORT FOR GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE'S AND  U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE'S OVERALL CONSERVATION GOALS IN THE WATERSHED.

APPLEGATE'S MILKVETCH (ASTRAGALUS APPLEGATEI) IS A CRITICALLY ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES AND IS ONE OF OREGON'S RAREST AND MOST ENDANGERED PLANTS. THE FEDERAL RECOVERY PLAN FOR A. APPLEGATEI CALLS FOR INCREASING OUR KNOWLEDGE OF CULTIVATION AND OUTPLANTING TECHNIQUES (TASK 3.2) AND ANNUAL DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING TO PROVIDE IMPORTANT INFORMATION ON POPULATION AGE STRUCTURE AND DYNAMICS (TASK 1.72). THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL SUPPORT TASK 1.72 IN THE RECOVERY PLAN TO CONDUCT ANNUAL DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING OF THIS IMPERILED SPECIES. IN THIS PROJECT, THE PI WILL COLLECT ADDITIONAL DEMOGRAPHIC DATA ON TRANSPLANTED INDIVIDUALS WITHIN ONE POPULATION AND NATURALLY OCCURRING NATIVE PLANTS (IE, EXTANT PLANTS) WITHIN FOUR POPULATIONS IN AND NEAR KLAMATH FALLS, OREGON. THIS ONE YEAR (2022) OF ADDITIONAL MONITORING WILL PROVIDE MORE INFORMATION ABOUT POPULATION FLUCTUATIONS RELATED TO WEATHER AND IMPORTANTLY, HELP US UNDERSTAND MORE ABOUT THE LIFESPAN AND ANNUAL MORTALITY OF ADULT MILKVETCH PLANTS. HOWEVER, ADDITIONAL YEARS OF MONITORING ARE RECOMMENDED TO ESTABLISH A TEN YEAR RECORD OF POPULATION DYNAMICS FOR THIS IMPERILED SPECIES.

THE FLORIDA SCRUB-JAY (FSJ), DECLARED FEDERALLY THREATENED IN 1987, IS A RAPIDLY-DECLINING SPECIES RESTRICTED TOISOLATED FRAGMENTS OF ITS NATIVE OAK SCRUB HABITAT. THE SPECIES FACES GENETIC RISKS ASSOCIATED WITH SMALLPOPULATION SIZE AND REDUCED CONNECTIVITY SUCH AS LOSS OF GENETIC VARIATION AND INBREEDING DEPRESSION. TO MITIGATETHESE PROBLEMS TWO IMPORTANT POPULATIONS WERE IDENTIFIED, LOCATED IN CONSERVED LANDS WITHIN FLORIDA'SSOUTHEASTERN ATLANTIC COAST TO TARGET FOR TRANSLOCATIONS. THESE ARE TARGETED BECAUSE OF HIGH RISK OF INBREEDINGDEPRESSION, BUT ALSO HIGH POTENTIAL FOR INCREASED POPULATION GROWTH. RESTORING THESE POPULATIONS IS CRUCIAL FORLONG-TERM VIABILITY AND PERSISTENCE OF THE SOUTHEASTERN COASTAL METAPOPULATION. IN 2019 AND 2020, EIGHT FSJS WERETRANSLOCATED FROM A LARGE CENTRAL POPULATION INTO ONE COASTAL POPULATION. THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE INTENSIVEDEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING OF BOTH COASTAL POPULATIONS AND STUDY THE CONSEQUENCES OF TRANSLOCATIONS. THE LONG-TERMGOAL IS TO STUDY THESE DYNAMICS OVER A PERIOD LONG ENOUGH TO TEST FOR GENETIC RESCUE. WHOLE GENOME SEQUENCINGDATA FROM ALL BREEDING INDIVIDUALS WILL BE COLLECTED TO TEST WHETHER INBREEDING LIMITS POPULATION GROWTH ANDWHETHER GENE FLOW CAN INCREASE POPULATION VIABILITY. OUTCOMES HAVE SIGNIFICANT VALUE TO THE RECOVERY OF THISSPECIES BY DOCUMENTING THE POTENTIAL FOR TRANSLOCATIONS AND GENETIC RESCUE TO INCREASE POPULATION GROWTH RATESAND FACILITATE NATURAL CONNECTIVITY. THIS WORK DIRECTLY ADDRESSES FOUR PRIORITY 1 AND ONE PRIORITY 3 RECOVERYACTIONS LISTED IN THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE FLORIDA SCRUB JAY.

PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY FOOTHILL YELLOW-LEGGED FROGS (RANA BOYLII) WERE RECENTLY FOUND TO BE WARRANTED FOR PROTECTED STATUS BY THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) IN SEVERAL ANALYSIS UNITS IN THE CALIFORNIA PORTION OF THE SPECIES' DISTRIBUTION. THE SPECIES IS SENSITIVE TO ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES, AND DESPITE THE REDUCED THREAT TO POPULATIONS IN THE NORTH COAST CLADE IN OREGON RELATIVE TO OTHER ANALYSIS UNITS, RESEARCHERS STILL SUSPECT THAT SIGNIFICANT LOCAL DECLINES HAVE OCCURRED (ESTIMATED AT 41%). ADDITIONAL INVENTORY WORK IS NEEDED TO DOCUMENT POPULATION STRONGHOLDS (CORE RANGE) THAT MAY BEST PROVIDE FOR LONG-TERM PERSISTENCE OF THE SPECIES. HERE, WE PROPOSE A STRATEGIC ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) INVENTORY OF FOOTHILL YELLOW-LEGGED FROGS IN OREGON TO BETTER DOCUMENT THE DISTRIBUTIONAL LIMITS OF CORE RANGE. FROG DETECTIONS IN PLACES WHERE HABITAT IS SUITABLE (YET NO ANIMALS HAVE BEEN DOCUMENTED TO-DATE) CAN HELP TO INCORPORATE MISSING HABITATS OR REGIONS INTO THE KNOWN CORE RANGE DISTRIBUTION. ADDITIONAL NO-DETECTION DATA AT HISTORICAL SITES WILL ASSIST MANAGERS WITH TRACKING EXTIRPATIONS AND IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL RESTORATION OR REINTRODUCTION SITES. ULTIMATELY, THIS INVENTORY WORK WILL PROVIDE FINE-SCALE RANGE DATA TO INFORM SPECIES CONSERVATION EFFORTS BY PROVIDING ACCURATE INFORMATION ABOUT CONTEMPORARY CORE HABITAT EXTENT.

THE SHORT-TAILED ALBATROSS (PHOEBASTRIA ALBATRUS, STAL) IS LISTED AS ENDANGERED THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE, INCLUDING THE UNITED STATES. THE STAL RECOVERY PLAN (USFWS 2008) AIMS TO RECLASSIFY ITS CONSERVATION STATUS OR TO REMOVE IT FROM THE ENDANGERED LIST. TO ACHIEVE THIS AIM, IMPORTANT RECOVERY ACTIONS WERE ESTABLISHED, INCLUDING THE CONTINUOUS MONITORING AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT ON TORISHIMA WHERE MOST INDIVIDUALS OF THIS SPECIES USE AS THE BREEDING SITE. MOST OF THE CRITERIA NECESSARY FOR RECLASSIFYING OR DELISTING ARE BASED ON THE NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS COUNTED IN NOVEMBER ON TORISHIMA. HOWEVER, THIS NEEDS TO BE FUNDED. THE AIM OF THE PROJECT IS TO COUNT THE NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS IN NOVEMBER AND DECEMBER 2022 TO PROVIDE THE BASIC DATA FOR RECONSIDERING THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF STAL. THE COUNTING SURVEY WILL NOT DISTURB THE BREEDING INDIVIDUALS BECAUSE THE OBSERVATIONS WILL BE CONDUCTED MORE THAN 100 METERS APART TO PREVENT THE INFLUENCE OF THE HUMAN PRESENCE.

RECOVER OF THE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY (SILVERSPOT) HINGES ON OUR ABILITY TO UNDERSTAND THE SPECIES' HABITAT MONITORING PROJECT HAVE RECENTLY BEEN FUNDED BY A RECOVERY CHALLENGE GRANT. THIS REQUEST IS FOR HOUSING FOR ROCK CREEK-BIG CREEK PRAIRIE HABITAT ON THE OREGON COASTLINE FROM JUNE 1ST THROUGH AUGUST 31ST, 2022.

INTERNATIONAL CRANE FOUNDATION (ICF) HAS BEEN A LEADER IN REINTRODUCING A SECOND, MIGRATORY POPULATION OF WHOOPING CRANES IN THE EASTERN U.S. THE GROWTH AND SECURITY OF THIS EASTERN POPULATION IS CRITICAL TO RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES AND ITS REMOVAL FROM THE ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST. PROJECT INCLUDES CAPTIVE BREEDING AND REARING OF WHOOPING CRANE CHICKS, SPECIALIZED VETERINARY CARE, AND TARGETED RESEARCH AND MONITORING OF REINTRODUCED CRANES. ICF WILL BREED CRANES FROM ITS CAREFULLY MANAGED CAPTIVE FLOCK AND REAR CHICKS FOR DIRECT RELEASE INTO THE WILD.ICF WILL MAINTAIN HEALTHY ADULT CAPTIVE CRANE PAIRS AT THE ITS FACILITY IN BARABOO, WISCONSIN AND REARING CHICKS TO FLEDGLING AGE. OUR GOAL IS TO MAINTAIN THE HEALTH OF THE BREEDING ADULTS AND REINTRODUCED CHICKS NEEDED FOR OPTIMAL PERFORMANCE THROUGH STATE-OF-THE ART PREVENTATIVE HEALTH CARE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS. ICFADVANCES CRANE REINTRODUCTION SCIENCE THROUGH STUDIES OF NESTING SUCCESS, HABITAT USE, AND CHICK REARING METHODS. RESEARCH FOCUSES ON THREE AREAS: UNDERSTANDING THE PATTERNS FOR SUCCESSFUL REPRODUCTION IN THE REINTRODUCED POPULATION AS THEY USE DIFFERENT AREAS OF WISCONSIN, STUDYING HABITATS USED BY THE CRANES IN BREEDING ANDWINTERING AREAS, AND INVESTIGATING HOW REARING METHODS IMPACT THE DEVELOPMENT OF WILD BEHAVIORS.

THE CHITTENANGO OVATE AMBER SNAIL ("COAS", NOVISUCCINEA CHITTENANGOENSIS) IS A SUCCINEID LAND SNAIL ENDEMIC TO ONE SMALL AREA NEAR A SINGLE WATERFALL IN NEW YORK STATE, WHICH IS LOCATED WITHIN THE LAKE ONTARIO GREAT LAKES WATERSHED. ALTHOUGH LIKELY HALF OF NORTH AMERICA'S LAND SNAIL SPECIES ARE EXTINCT OR ENDANGERED (LARGELY DUE TO HUMAN-MEDIATED HABITAT LOSS AND MODIFICATION), COAS IS UNDER PARTICULAR THREAT DUE TO ITS EXTREMELY NARROW GEOGRAPHIC RANGE, AND ITS SUSCEPTIBILITY TO SUDDEN DECLINE DUE TO STOCHASTIC EVENTS SUCH AS ROCK FALLS, AS HAS BEEN SHOWN IN THE PAST FEW DECADES. UNFORTUNATELY, THE SINGLE KNOWN POPULATION OF COAS HAS CONTINUED TO DECLINE IN RECENT YEARS, LEAVING IT PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO EXTIRPATION DUE TO ROCK FALLS OR OTHER FACTORS. IN ORDER TO PROVIDE A BACK UP POPULATION IN CASE THE WILD POPULATION DECLINES FURTHER, AS WELL AS TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL CAPTIVE-BRED SNAILS FOR POTENTIAL FUTURE TRANSLOCATION, A CAPTIVE BREEDING COLONY HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED AT SUNY-ESF IN SYRACUSE, NY. THIS LOCATION IS FERTILE FOR SUCH LAND SNAIL CONSERVATION PROJECTS DUE TO PI RUNDELL'S EXPERTISE AND EXPERIENCE IN THIS FIELD, THE FACILITIES AVAILABLE, AND THE ACADEMIC SETTING OF TALENTED STUDENTS FOCUSED PRIMARILY ON WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND GEARING THEIR CAREERS TOWARD PRESERVING SPECIES LIKE COAS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS AIMED AT THE CARE, MANAGEMENT, GROWTH, AND DEVELOPMENT OF THE CONSERVATION RESEARCH POTENTIAL OF THE COAS CAPTIVE COLONY, WHICH IS FACILITATED BY SKILLED TECHNICIANS AND STUDENTS. AS PART OF THE PROJECT WE ALSO AIM TO DISSEMINATE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT COAS AND UNDERSTUDIED INVERTEBRATE ANIMAL CONSERVATION THROUGH SPECIAL EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR THE PUBLIC, TRAINING OF VOLUNTEERS AND STUDENTS IN HANDS-ON CONSERVATION, AS WELL AS RESEARCH REPORTS AND PUBLICATIONS. WE ALSO COLLABORATE WITH SEVERAL PARTNERS, INCLUDING THE NY STATE DEPARTMENT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION, CHITTENANGO STATE PARK, AND THE ROSAMOND GIFFORD ZOO.

THE EXISTING BLACK-FOOTEDFERRET POPULATION SUFFERS FROM TWO THREATS: (1) LOW GENETIC DIVERSITY AND (2) SYLVATIC PLAGUE. GENETICRESCUE TO OVERCOME INBREEDING AND SUSCEPTIBILITY TO SYLVATIC PLAGUE WILL HELP ENSURE SUCCESSFUL RECOVERYOF THE BLACK-FOOTED FERRET. WE WILL DEMONSTRATE NEW METHODS FOR GENETIC RESCUE IN THE DOMESTIC FERRETMODEL. THIS IS IMPORTANT FOUNDATIONAL RESEARCH THAT CAN BE TRANSITIONED TO BLACK-FOOTED FERRETS TO HELPINCREASE REPRESENTATION, RESILIENCY AND REDUNDANCY FOR THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES. OUR HIGH-LEVEL GOAL IS TOENABLE BLACK-FOOTED FERRETS TO THRIVE IN THE WILD WITHOUT HUMAN INTERVENTION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ANALYZE A 43-YEAR RECORD OF SALT-MARSH BIRD'S BEAK DATA ALONG WITH ABIOTIC VARIABLES, IN ORDER TO DETERMINE WHAT VARIABLES INFLUENCE SALT MARSH BIRD'S BEAK INTER-ANNUAL VARIATION AT MUGU LAGOON. THIS PROJECT WILL ANSWER THE FOLLOWING QUESTIONS:1) HOW DOES TIDAL RANGE, PRECIPITATION, TEMPERATURE, OR OTHER ABIOTIC VARIABLES INFLUENCE INTER-ANNUAL BIRD'S BEAK SPATIAL EXTENT (AREA OCCUPIED) AT MUGU LAGOON?; AND2) IS THE INFLUENCE OF THOSE ABIOTIC VARIABLES DIFFERENT BETWEEN DIFFERENT AREAS OF THE BASE, AND DOES THIS DEPEND ON HYDROLOGY? THE DELIVERABLES ARE A WRITTEN SUMMARY OF FINDINGS THAT WILL ASSIST THE LAND MANAGER AND FWS IN RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR SALT-MARSH BIRD'S BEAK.
RECOVERY OF THE FEDERALLY THREATENED WHITE FRINGELESS ORCHID (PLATANTHERA INTEGRILABIA) ON THE DANIEL BOONE NATIONAL FOREST IN KENTUCKY

THE PEREGRINE FUND (TPF) HAS PARTNERED WITH U.S FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) SOUTHEAST REGION,  USFWS CARIBBEAN ECOLOGICAL SERVICES FIELD OFFICE AND PUERTO RICAN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL AND  ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES (DNER) TO RECOVER THE ENDEMIC AND ENDANGERED PUERTO RICAN SHARP-SHINNED  HAWK (ACCIPITER STRIATUS VENATOR - WETMORE 1914) IN THE COMMON WEALTH FORESTS OF THE CENTRAL  CORDILLERA. IN SEPTEMBER 2017 HURRICANE MARIA, A CATEGORY 5 STORM, DEVASTATED THE FORESTS AND REDUCED  THE HAWK POPULATION TO AROUND 20 INDIVIDUALS, AS DETERMINED FROM SURVEYS CONDUCTED DURING THE EARLY  2018 BREEDING SEASON. THE GOALS ARE TO RECOVER THE POPULATION TO PRE-HURRICANE MARIA STATUS OF AROUND 75  HAWKS BY INCREASING PRODUCTIVITY THROUGH: (1) CAPTIVE PROPAGATION METHODS, AND (2) MANAGING NESTING  ATTEMPTS FOR CONTROL OF THE NEST FLY (PHILORNIS SP.) INFESTATIONS. OBJECTIVE 1 INCREASES PRODUCTIVITY BY  PULLING COMPLETE CLUTCHES DURING EARLY INCUBATION (THIS MAKES PAIRS RE-NEST, DOUBLING THE NUMBER OF  NESTING ATTEMPTS) FROM FIRST NESTING ATTEMPTS, AND THEN ARTIFICIALLY INCUBATING, HATCHING, RAISING AND  RELEASING THE YOUNG BACK TO THE WILD BY HACKING. HACKING, A METHOD DEVELOPED BY THE PEREGRINE FUND TO  RELEASE YOUNG FROM A BOX WHERE THEY NATURALLY DEVELOP THEIR FLYING AND HUNTING SKILLS UNTIL DISPERSAL,  ENSURES THAT YOUNG SURVIVE TO DISPERSAL AGE AND INDEPENDENCE. OBJECTIVE 2 INCREASES PRODUCTIVITY OF FIRST  AND SECOND NESTING ATTEMPTS THAT WERE NOT USED FOR CAPTIVE PROPAGATION BY INCREASING NESTLING SURVIVAL TO  FLEDGING AGE. THESE OBJECTIVES AND ACTIONS CONDUCTED BY THE TPF ADDRESS SEVERAL OF THE USFWS PRIORITY  RECOVERY CRITERIA FOR RECOVERY TO THIS THREATENED HAWK IN PUERTO RICO
CHARACTERIZING GENES FOR GENETIC-BASED SIT IN THE AVIAN MALARIA VECTOR, CULEX QUINQUEFASCIATUS
OPTIMIZING REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS AND SURVIVAL FOR EASTERN BLACK RAILS IN COASTAL SOUTH CAROLINA THROUGH IMPOUNDMENT MANAGEMENT AND IRRIGATION
EXPANDING MEDICAL CARE CAPACITY FOR PREY-GO-NEESH IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES THE INSTALLATION OF FOREST RESOURCE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES HABITAT ASSESSMENT INVENTORY PLOTS AT EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE AT JACKSON GUARD  JG , FLORIDA. THE PURPOSE OF THE ASSESSMENT IS TO PROVIDE JG WITH VEGETATION LAND COVER INFORMATION NECESSARY TO MEET SITE SPECIFIC ANALYSIS NEEDS  AND TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ON FOREST COMPOSITION, FOREST HEALTH, AND STOCKING CONDITION FOR THE ASSESSMENT OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES HABITAT.

AWARD PURPOSE CYRTANDRA NANAWALEENSIS IS AN ENDANGERED PERENNIAL SHRUB OR SOMETIMES A SMALL TREE  THE SPECIES IS RAPIDLYDECLINING DUE TO THE IMPACTS OF FERAL PIGS, COMPETITION FROM NONNATIVE PLANTS, PREDATION OR HERBIVORY BY RATS ANDSLUGS, HYBRIDIZATION WITH OTHER CYRTANDRA SPECIES, VOLCANIC ACTIVITY, AND CLIMATE CHANGE  THIS PROJECT WILLINSTALL ONE LARGE FENCE AT WAO KELE O PUNA FOREST RESERVE IN PUNA ON THE ISLAND OF HAWAI'I  THE PROJECT AREA ISLOCATED ON THE SOUTHWEST BOUNDARY OF WAO KELE O PUNA ON PU'U HEIHEIAHULU IN A LOWLAND MESIC FOREST  THE PROPOSED17 ACRE FENCED EXCLOSURE WILL PROTECT A NEWLY DISCOVERED POPULATION OF CYRTANDRA NANAWALEENSIS  ONCE THE FENCE ISCOMPLETED, THE FENCE WILL REDUCE THE IMPACTS OF FERAL PIGS TO THIS POPULATION OF CYRTANDRA NANAWALEENSIS ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED THE PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE TO INSTALL ONE LARGE, FENCED UNIT  4006 LINEAR FEET  ENCLOSING APPROXIMATELY 17 ACRESOF LOWLAND MESIC FOREST  FENCE INSTALLATION WILL BE COMPLETED BY FOREST SOLUTIONS  FOREST SOLUTIONS STAFF WILLMONITOR THE COMPLETED FENCE MONTHLY AND CONDUCT REPAIRS AS NEEDED FOR TWO YEARS  FOREST SOLUTIONS STAFF WILLREMOVE UNGULATES FROM INSIDE THE FENCE USING TRAPS UPON FENCE COMPLETION  UNGULATE TRAPS WILL BE MONITOREDMONTHLY AT MINIMUM DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES THE PROJECT WILL INSTALL ONE LARGE, FENCED UNIT PROVIDING 17 ACRES OF LOWLAND MESIC FOREST FOR RESTORATION ANDTHE RECOVERY OF ENDANGERED PLANTS AND ANIMALS  ANNUAL REPORTS WILL INCLUDE PHOTOS, MAPS, SHAPEFILES, THE NUMBEROF UNGULATES REMOVED, AND MONITORING DATA OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES WITHIN THE PROTECTED AREA INTENDED BENEFICIARIES THE PROJECT WILL BENEFIT NATIVE HAWAIIANS, LOCAL COMMUNITIES, FEDERAL GOVERNMENT, STATE AGENCIES, ANDUNIVERSITIES

SEABEACH AMARANTH  AMARANTHUS PUMILUS  HAS EXPERIENCED A DRASTIC  98 5   DECLINE IN THE NUMBER OF INDIVIDUAL PLANTS FOUND RANGE WIDE SINCE THE EARLY 2000 S  LONG TERM COMMITMENT TO THE CONSERVATION OF THIS SPECIES HAVE SHOWN SUCCESS WITH REINTRODUCTION AND SEED STORAGE  TO ACHIEVE RECOVERY GOALS WE PROPOSE A TWO PHASED PROJECT TO CONDUCT POPULATION SURVEYS, GAIN UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL SEED DYNAMICS AND AMPLIFY SEED COLLECTIONS FOR LONG TERM STORAGE  PHASE I  AND BEGIN REINTRODUCTIONS INTO SUITABLE HABITAT ON PROTECTED BARRIER ISLANDS INVOLVING FEDERAL, STATE, AND NGO PARTNERS  PHASE II   SPECIFICALLY IN PHASE I WE WILL AMPLIFY EXISTING SMALL AND OR AGING SEED COLLECTIONS IN THE NC BOTANICAL GARDEN SEED BANK TO IMPROVE THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF SAFEGUARDED SEED MATERIAL FOR SIX  THREE PER PHASE  EXTIRPATED POPULATIONS  ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL SEARCH FOR NEW AND EXTIRPATED POPULATIONS ALONG THE NC COAST, PRIORITIZING HISTORICAL AND HIGH QUALITY HABITAT SITES  FINALLY WE WILL UTILIZE SEED BURIAL STUDIES TO UNDERSTAND THE POPULATION DYNAMICS OF SEEDS UNDER NATURAL CONDITIONS  THESE COMBINED ACTIONS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RESILIENCY AND REDUNDANCY OF SEABEACH AMARANTH TO PREVENT EXTINCTION

THE PEARL RIVER DRAINAGE IN MISSISSIPPI AND LOUISIANA IS INHABITED BY TWO ENDEMIC ANDIMPERILED MAP TURTLES  THE RINGED MAP TURTLE  THREATENED  GRAPTEMYS OCULIFERA  AND THE PEARLRIVER MAP TURTLE  PROPOSED THREATENED  G  PEARLENSIS   THE PEARL RIVER MAP TURTLE IS ONE OF THELEAST STUDIED FRESHWATER TURTLE SPECIES IN THE UNITED STATES, WITH MOST SURVEYS CONDUCTED ON THESYMPATRIC RINGED MAP TURTLE  THUS, LIMITED INFORMATION IS AVAILABLE ON THE SPECIFIC MICROHABITATVARIABLES THAT PEARL RIVER MAP TURTLES NEED FOR POPULATION VIABILITY  HABITAT SURVEYS HAVE ALSO NOTBEEN CONDUCTED FOR THE RINGED MAP TURTLE, WITH ASSUMPTIONS BEING MADE ABOUT THE INFLUENCE OFHABITAT ON THE DISTRIBUTIONS AND ABUNDANCES OF THESE TWO ENDEMIC SPECIES  OUR PROPOSED PROJECTWOULD USE SIDE SCAN SONAR TO QUANTIFY SUBMERGED MICROHABITAT AT MULTIPLE LONG TERM MARKRECAPTURELOCATIONS, AND AT SITES WITH REPEATED BASKING SURVEYS, FOR THE RINGED MAP TURTLE ANDPEARL RIVER MAP TURTLE  THIS PROJECT WOULD LEVERAGE MISSISSIPPI SECTION 6 FUNDING THAT HAS BEENTENTATIVELY AWARDED  SUMMER 2023  FOR ASSESSMENTS OF VISIBLE HABITAT STRUCTURE AT THE PREVIOUSLYMENTIONED SITES  THROUGH THESE HABITAT ASSESSMENTS AND THE CONSTRUCTION OF HABITAT SUITABILITY MODELS, WE WOULD BETTER INFORM THE DESIGNATION OF CRITICAL HABITAT FOR THE PEARL RIVER MAP TURTLE,ASSESS OPTIMAL AND SUBOPTIMAL HABITATS, AND DETERMINE THE IMPORTANCE OF HABITAT STRUCTURE ONPOPULATION ABUNDANCE FOR POTENTIAL FUTURE HABITAT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES

THE MIAMI BLUE BUTTERFLY IS CURRENTLY RESTRICTED TO ONLY A FEW SMALL REMAINING REMOTE ISLAND POPULATIONS WITHIN THE KEY WEST AND GREAT WHITE HERON NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES, MAKING IT ONE OF THE MOST CRITICALLY ENDANGERED INSECTS IN NORTH AMERICA  THE PROJECT SEEKS TO PREVENT EXTINCTION OF THE MIAMI BLUE BY ESTABLISHING NEW POPULATIONS OVER A MUCH LARGER GEOGRAPHIC RANGE IN SOUTH FLORIDA  THE APPLIED KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THIS PROJECT WILL SIGNIFICANTLY FURTHER THE DEVELOPMENT OF BEST PRACTICES FOR ORGANISM REINTRODUCTIONS THAT CAN BE BROADLY APPLIED TO THE GROWING LIST OF IMPERILED BUTTERFLIES IN FLORIDA AND ACROSS THE U S

IN 2010, 83 CRAYFISHES WERE PETITIONED FOR REVIEW UNDER THE ESA  21  OF ALL SPECIES PETITIONED BY CENTER FOR BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY , AND 24 SPECIES ARE CURRENTLY ON USFWS  FIVE YEAR WORKPLAN TO UNDERGO SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENTS  SSAS   STREAM NETWORKS BOUND FISH AND MUSSELS, BUT SEMI AQUATIC  BURROWING  CRAYFISHES ALSO POTENTIALLY DISPERSE OVERLAND OR THROUGH ARTIFICIALLY CREATED WETTED HABITATS SUCH AS ROAD SIDE DITCHES  THUS, IT IS UNCLEAR HOW TO DELINEATE POPULATION UNITS WHEN QUANTIFYING RESILIENCY AND REPRESENTATION WITHIN THE SSA FRAMEWORK, AND POTENTIAL DISPERSAL ROUTES NEEDED TO ASSESS AMONG POPULATION CONNECTIVITY  REDUNDANCY  ARE UNKNOWN FOR BURROWING CRAYFISHES  THEREFORE, WE WILL USE POPULATION GENETICS TO EVALUATE ALTERNATIVE DISPERSAL ROUTES  STREAM NETWORK, ROAD NETWORK, OVERLAND  CONNECTING POPULATIONS OF HOBBSEUS ORCONECTOIDES  OKTIBBEHA RIVULET CRAYFISH    A BURROWING CRAYFISH UNDERGOING AN SSA IN 2026  POPULATION GENETICS WILL FURTHER INFORM POPULATION RESILIENCY  POPULATION SIZE, GENETIC HETEROGENEITY  AND BOUNDARIES FOR DELINEATING POPULATIONS AND ECOLOGICAL SETTINGS  THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE A BLUEPRINT FOR STRUCTURING SSAS AN RECOVERY PLANS OF BURROWING CRAYFISHES, INCLUDING THE FOUR PETITIONED RIVULET CRAYFISHES

AMERICAN SHAD  ALOSA SAPIDISSIMA  AMS  UNDERTAKE ANNUAL SPRING SPAWNING MIGRATIONS FROM DOWNSTREAM COASTAL HABITATS INTO UPSTREAM FRESHWATER RIVER REACHES OF THE ALTAMAHA RIVER AND ITS TRIBUTARIES  ACCESS TO SOME HISTORICAL SPAWNING LOCATIONS PRESUMABLY IS BLOCKED BY MAN MADE DAMS AND IMPOUNDMENTS, AND HABITAT CONDITIONS DOWNSTREAM OF THESE DAMS PRESUMABLY ARE AFFECTED BY THE WAYS IN WHICH THE DAMS ARE OPERATED, FOR EXAMPLE HOW MUCH WATER IS RELEASED, HOW RAPIDLY RELEASE SCHEDULES CHANGE, AND THE TEMPORAL OVERLAP OF THESE CHANGES WITH THE AMS SPAWNING SEASON  EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THESE DAMS AND EVALUATION OF THEIR IMPACT TO AMS  AND OTHER MIGRATORY FISHES  HINGES ON A SOUND UNDERSTANDING OF THE TIMING AND LOCATIONS OF SPAWNING  THE PURPOSE OF THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS TO ESTIMATE THE TIMING OF AMS SPAWNING IN, AND COMPARE RELATIVE SPAWNING RATES BETWEEN, THE TWO LARGEST ALTAMAHA TRIBUTARIES  THE OCONEE AND OCMULGEE RIVERS  SPAWNING RATES WILL BE INDEXED USING EGG COUNTS, COLLECTED VIA A SERIES OF PELAGIC PLANKTON TOWS MADE APPROXIMATELY BIWEEKLY THROUGHOUT THE SPAWNING SEASON  JANUARY APRIL  AT EACH OF SEVERAL SITES DISTRIBUTED ALONG THE COURSE OF EACH TRIBUTARY  GEORGIA SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY S PRIMARY ROLES IN THIS PROJECT ARE TO COORDINATE AND CONDUCT THE MAJORITY OF THE FIELD WORK FOR THIS PROJECT, AND TO ASSIST WITH DATA ANALYSIS AND INTERPRETATION  EGG IDENTIFICATION AND QUANTIFICATION WILL PRIMARILY BE CONDUCTED BY NOAA PERSONNEL  THIS PROJECT SHOULD ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF AMS SPAWNING HABITAT AND PHENOLOGY IN THE ALTAMAHA SYSTEM, THEREBY INFORMING MANAGEMENT FOR THIS CULTURALLY AND ECONOMICALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES

PHEASANTS FOREVER  PF  IS PROPOSING TO ASSIST WITH IDENTIFICATION, COORDINATION, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PRIORITY ANNUAL GRASS REDUCTION PROJECTS IN SOUTHERN IDAHO  PROJECTS WILL IMPLEMENT ACTIONS THAT REDUCE OR ELIMINATE INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASS SPECIES  IAG  CHEATGRASS, MEDUSAHEAD, VENTENATA, ETC   AND OR SUPPORT THE RECOVERY OF DESIRABLE PERENNIAL VEGETATION

THE IDAHO FISH AND  WILDLIFE FOUNDATION  IFWF  IS PROPOSING TO COOPERATE WITH THE USFWS, IDAHO  DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND  GAME, IDAHO GOVERNOR S OFFICE OF SPECIES CONSERVATION, US FOREST SERVICE, AND  THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT TO ENHANCE RESTORE SAGEBRUSH STEPPE HABITATS WITHIN THE UPPER SNAKE  AREA WITHIN CLARK, BUTTE, JEFFERSON, FREMONT, MADISON, TETON, BONNEVILLE, AND BINGHAM COUNTIES, IDAHO   RESTORATION AND ENHANCEMENT OF UPLAND AND MESIC HABITATS ARE SPECIFICALLY NEEDED TO INCREASE THE  RESISTANCE AND RESILIENCE TO INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, WILDFIRES, AND OTHER NATURAL DISTURBANCES  THE UPPER  SNAKE RIVER LANDSCAPE CONTAINS SIGNIFICANT AMOUNTS OF CORE AND GROWTH OPPORTUNITY AREAS THAT HAVE  BEEN IDENTIFIED AS BEING CRITICALLY IMPORTANT FOR LONG TERM CONSERVATION OF THIS BIOME AND THE FLORA AND  FAUNA IT SUPPORTS  SAGE GROUSE AND A SUITE OF OTHER SAGEBRUSH STEPPE OBLIGATES RELY UPON BOTH OF THESE  HABITAT TYPES TO COMPLETE THEIR LIFE HISTORY STRATEGIES WITHIN THIS LANDSCAPE  LEVERAGING PARTNERSHIPS AND  ASSOCIATED INVESTMENTS TOWARDS CONSERVATION OF THIS LANDSCAPE IS SIGNIFICANT AT LOCAL, REGIONAL, AND  NATIONAL SCALES

THE MARBLED MURRELET  BRACHYRAMPHUS MARMORATUS  IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED SEABIRD THAT IS AN INDICATOR SPECIES TO ESTIMATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF RECOVERY ACTIONS UNDER THE NORTHWEST FOREST PLAN  NWFP   STANDARDIZED AT SEA SURVEYS HAVE BEEN CARRIED OUT TO MONITOR MURRELET POPULATION STATUS AND TRENDS WITHIN 5 CONSERVATION ZONES FROM PUGET SOUND TO SAN FRANCISCO FOR THE PAST 23 YEARS  CRESCENT COASTAL RESEARCH  CCR  HAS BEEN RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING ALL SURVEYS IN ZONE 3  COLUMBIA RIVER TO COOS BAY, OREGON , SINCE THE INCEPTION OF NWFP MONITORING IN 2000  IN CONSERVATION ZONE 4, FROM COOS BAY OREGON TO SHELTER COVE CALIFORNIA, CCR HAS CONTRIBUTED SURVEYS THROUGH 2009 AND SINCE 2010 HAS COMPLETED ALL ZONE 4 SURVEYS IN ADDITION TO ZONE 3 COVERAGE  IN THAT TIME, WE HAVE DEMONSTRATED FIELD AND DATA EXPERTISE, AND THE COMPETENCE AND COOPERATION REQUIRED TO COMPLETE THE MARBLED MURRELET EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING WORK ACCORDING TO THE NWFP PROTOCOL  HERE WE ARE APPLYING TO COMPLETE AT LEAST 20 MURRELET DENSITY SAMPLING SURVEYS IN THE CALIFORNIA PORTION OF CONSERVATION ZONE 4 DURING 2023  ANOTHER APPLICATION HAS BEEN MADE TO COMPLETE AT LEAST 10 SURVEYS IN THE OREGON PORTION OF ZONE 4

THE FLORIDA GRASSHOPPER SPARROW IS LISTED AS ENDANGERED UNDER THE U S  ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  THIS PROJECT AIMS TO DEVELOP AND APPLY GENETIC TOOLS TO AID IN THE RECOVERY AND ASSESSMENT OF THE STATUS OF THIS SONG SPARROW  THIS EFFORT WILL INCLUDE THE GENETIC FINGERPRINTING AND SEXING OF CAPTIVE BORN SPARROWS THAT ARE RELEASED INTO THE WILD AND THE GENETIC FINGERPRINTING OF UNKNOWN INDIVIDUALS SAMPLED FROM THE WILD  THESE DNA FINGERPRINTS WILL BE USED TO ESTIMATE RELATEDNESS AND OTHER DEMOGRAPHIC VARIABLES THAT WILL AID OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE STATUS OF THE POPULATION

THE OREGON DESERT LAND TRUST AND PARTNERS PROPOSE TO ASSESS, PROTECT, AND RESTORE STREAMS, SPRINGS, AND WET  MEADOWS IN OREGON S TROUT CREEK AND PUEBLO MOUNTAINS IN THE NORTHERN GREAT BASIN  THESE LANDS ARE PART OF THE  RICH HERITAGE OF THE NORTHERN PAIUTE PEOPLE, SUPPORT A LOCAL RANCHING COMMUNITY, AND ARE VALUED BY THE PUBLIC FOR  RECREATION   THE PUEBLO AND TROUT CREEK MOUNTAINS ARE HOME TO THE GREATER SAGE GROUSE, THE ALVORD CHUB, THE LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT  TROUT, AND OTHER SENSITIVE WILDLIFE SPECIES  IN THIS DESERT ENVIRONMENT, THE AREA S STREAMS, SPRINGS, AND WET  MEADOWS ARE IMPORTANT TO THE CONTINUING HEALTH OF THE WILD AND HUMAN COMMUNITIES, PARTICULARLY AS THE REGION S  CLIMATE CHANGES   WE VE IDENTIFIED CANDIDATE AREAS THROUGH REMOTE SENSING AND ARE NOW ASSESSING THEIR CONDITION AND FUNCTION  IN  THIS FIRST YEAR OF THE PROJECT, WE EXPECT TO CONTINUE ASSESSING AND PRIORITIZING WET AREAS  WE WILL ALSO COMPLETE   NO REGRETS  PROTECTION AND RESTORATION ACTIONS ON FEATURES OF RECOGNIZED IMPORTANCE  THESE ACTIONS COULD INCLUDE  FENCING WET MEADOWS, USING LOW TECH METHODS  FOR EXAMPLE,  BEAVER DAM ANALOGS  TO INITIATE STREAM RECOVERY, AND  REPAIRING OR RELOCATING LIVESTOCK WATER DEVELOPMENTS   CURRENT PROJECT PARTNERS INCLUDE THE NATURE CONSERVANCY AND LOCAL RANCHING FAMILIES  ONE OF OUR STATED PROJECT  GOALS IS TO SUPPORT LOCAL TRIBAL INTERESTS IN THE PROJECT AREA, WHETHER THAT IS CREATING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE  PRESENT OR PRESERVING OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE FUTURE

LANDSCAPE CONTROL OF MOSQUITOES IS ONE OF THE MOST URGENT CONSERVATION PROBLEMS IN HAWAII FOR HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRDS  MOSQUITOES AND THE DISEASES THEY SPREAD ARE DRIVING THE EXTINCTION OF NATIVE FOREST BIRDS IN HAWAII  A PARTNERSHIP OF FEDERAL, STATE AND NON GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS, INCLUDING THE AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY, ENTITLED  BIRDS NOT MOSQUITOES  IS COLLABORATING ON THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A WOLBACHIA INSECT INCOMPATIBILITY TECHNIQUE TO CONTROL MOSQUITO POPULATIONS IN KEY CONSERVATION AREAS  DEPLOYING THIS TOOL IN TIME TO SAVE IMPERILED BIRDS WILL ONLY BE SUCCESSFUL IF AN AERIAL DELIVERY CAPACITY IS DEVELOPED TO DISTRIBUTE THE IIT MOSQUITOES ON THE LANDSCAPE  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COLLABORATIVELY LEVERAGE THE ABOVE WORK AND EXPERTISE OF AMERICAN BIRD CONSERVANCY  ABC  TO DEVELOP AND TEST AN AERIAL DEPLOYMENT CAPACITY FOR LANDSCAPE SCALE DEPLOYMENT OF WOLBACHIA IIT IN HAWAII AT IDENTIFIED IMPLEMENTATION SITES  FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE WILL PROVIDE FOR THE PROJECT MANAGEMENT AND COORDINATION NEEDED TO WORK ON A STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURE TO IDENTIFY THE DELIVERY PLATFORM, REQUIRED PERMITTING, LOGISTICAL PLANNING AND STAFFING AND SUPPORT REQUIRED FOR THE AERIAL DELIVERY OF IIT MOSQUITOES ON FEDERAL STATE PRIVATE LANDS IN HAWAII

AS THE LARGEST NATIVE TERRESTRIAL MAMMAL ON THE CHANNEL ISLANDS, THE SANTA CATALINA ISLAND FOX  UROCYON LITTORALIS CATALINAE  IS SUSCEPTIBLE TO MANY RISKS INCLUDING NOVEL DISEASES AND PREDATORS  USFWS 2004   DUE TO A DISEASE OUTBREAK IN THE LATE 1990S THE POPULATION WAS REDUCED TO  100 INDIVIDUALS  AFTER YEARS OF RECOVERY EFFORTS, THIS FOX REMAINS A CONSERVATION RELIANT SPECIES  SPECIFICALLY, WITH OVER 1 MILLION VISITORS EVERY YEAR, THE RISK OF DISEASE SPREAD AND MORTALITY ASSOCIATED WITH VISITORS INCREASES ANNUALLY, AND IS THE ONLY FEDERALLY LISTED SUBSPECIES  SINCE 2005, THE CATALINA ISLAND CONSERVANCY HAS MANAGED AND RUN THE DAILY RECOVERY ACTIVITIES INTERNALLY INCLUDING ISLAND WIDE POPULATION ESTIMATE, VACCINATION PROGRAM, WEEKLY MONITORING OF RADIO COLLARED FOXES, AND PROVIDING VETERINARY TREATMENT TO FOXES INJURED IN THE WILD  FOLLOWING THE RECOMMENDATIONS FROM THE EPIDEMIC RESPONSE PLAN FOR CATALINA ISLAND FOXES  HUDGENS ET AL  2014 , THE CONSERVANCY ANNUALLY FITS 40 70 UNVACCINATED FOXES WITH COLLARS TO SERVE AS DISEASE SENTINELS  THE CONSERVANCY ALSO DEVELOPED NEW THREAT ABATEMENT STRATEGIES, CONDUCTED DISEASE PREVALENCE RESEARCH, CONDUCTED CDV AND RABIES VACCINE TITER PERSISTENCE RESEARCH, AND PROVIDED EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR ISLAND RESIDENTS AND VISITORS  THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE CATALINA ISLAND FOX TELEMETRY AND SENTINEL PROGRAM THAT IS SO CRUCIAL TO DETECTING POPULATION DECLINES AND DISEASE OUTBREAKS QUICKLY  FUNDING WILL BE USED TO PURCHASE VHF RADIO COLLARS AND HIRE A FOX TELEMETRY INTERN TO CONDUCT SURVEYS  THESE FREQUENT SURVEYS ARE NECESSARY TO ENSURE FOX MORTALITIES ARE DETECTED QUICKLY SO THAT NECROPSIES CAN BE USED TO DETERMINE CAUSE OF DEATH AND DISEASE PRESENCE  MORTALITY INFORMATION WILL ALSO CONTRIBUTE TO OUR UNDERSTANDING OF RISK OF EXTINCTION FOR THE CATALINA ISLAND FOX AS WELL AS ALLOW FOR RAPID RESPONSE IN THE CASE OF A DISEASE OUTBREAK

EASTERN INDIGO SNAKES  EIS , EASTERN DIAMONDBACK RATTLESNAKES  EDR , AND GOPHERTORTOISES  GT  ARE LISTED AND AT RISK TRUST SPECIES OF THE USFWS INTERIOR REGIONS 2 AND 4  THESE SPECIES ARE NATIVE RESIDENTS RELIANT UPON THE ECOSYSTEM NETWORK OF UPLAND SANDHILLS AND HARDWOOD FRESH WATERBOTTOMS IN SOUTHEASTERN GEORGIA, HABITATS THAT ARE INCREASINGLY IMPERILED  THE PROPOSED PROJECT EFFORTS FOCUS ON ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH AND MONITORING AND MULTI PARTNER CONSERVATION PLANNING FOR THE SPECIES AND THEIR HABITATS  OUR ACTIVITIES CONTRIBUTE SIGNIFICANTLY TO MEETING RECOVERY PLAN CRITERIA BY DEVELOPING PROOF OF CONCEPT DESIGNS FOR CONNECTING SPECIES ACROSS IMPACTED HABITATS, OR EXCLUDING THEM FROM TEMPORARY IMPACTS OCCURRING FROM INFRASTRUCTURE OPERATIONS, SUCH AS SOLAR, MINING AND TRANSPORTATION INDUSTRY  ADDITIONALLY, BASED ON A PROGRESSED UNDERSTANDING OF THESE SPECIES  MOVEMENT ECOLOGY AND USE OF IMPERILED LANDSCAPES, WE CAN GUIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SURVEY AND MONITORING TECHNIQUES  THROUGH THIS PROJECT, WE WILL ELEVATE CROSS COLLABORATOR COMMUNICATIONS WITH STATE AND PRIVATE LAND OWNERS, MANAGERS, AND INDUSTRIAL OPERATIONS TO ADVANCE OUR COLLECTIVE CONFIDENCE IN HOW WE STRUCTURE AND REPLICATE MULTI SPECIES IMPACT AVOIDANCE AND MINIMIZATION METHODS AND RESTORATION INITIATIVES TO PROVIDE A CONSERVATION NET BENEFIT FOR LISTED AND AT RISK SPECIES

PROJECT INCLUDES IMPROVING THE QUALITY AND INCREASING THE QUANTITY OF LONGLEAF PINE STANDS CRITICAL FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THE ENDANGERED RED COCKADED WOODPECKER  RCW  ON FORT JACKSON BY IMPLEMENTING PROFESSIONAL FOREST MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES  THE TECHNIQUES TO BE IMPLEMENTED INCLUDE THE USE OF CHEMICAL HERBICIDES AND MECHANICAL METHODS TO CONTROL UNDESIRABLE HARDWOOD TREE SPECIES, AND THE CONTROL OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES ON APPROXIMATELY 300 ACRES OF RCW FORAGING HABITAT  THE PROJECT ALSO INCLUDES THE RESTORATION OF LONGLEAF PINE ON APPROXIMATELY 100 ACRES WHERE OFF SITE PINE SPECIES HAVE BEEN REMOVED  RESTORATION METHODS INCLUDE CHEMICAL SITE PREPARATION AND PLANTING OF LONGLEAF PINE SEEDLINGS, RESULTING IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE RCW HABITAT AND SUSTAINABLE ARMY TRAINING LANDS

THE WASHINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY  WSU  BEAR RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND CONSERVATION CENTER IS A ONE OF A KIND FACILITY THAT AIMS TO PROVIDE INFORMATION AND UNDERSTANDING NECESSARY FOR THE CONSERVATION OF GRIZZLY BEARS AND OTHER BEARS AROUND THE WORLD  WSU DEVELOPED A CAPTIVE BEAR FACILITY IN COOPERATION WITH USFWS 36 YEARS AGO THAT HOLDS 10 TO 12 CAPTIVE GRIZZLY BEARS FOR RESEARCH PROJECTS INVOLVING ALL ASPECTS OF GRIZZLY BEAR BIOLOGY  THERE IS NO OTHER PLACE IN THE WORLD THAT HAS SUCH FACILITIES WHERE ONE CAN DO HIGH LEVEL SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH ON CAPTIVE GRIZZLY BEARS  THE FUNDING USFWS PROVIDES IN THIS GRANT HELPS SUPPORT THE CARE AND MAINTENANCE OF BEARS AT THE FACILITY AND IN DOING SO HELPS SUPPORT RESEARCH PROJECTS ACROSS THE NATION THAT UTILIZE THESE ANIMALS  USFWS HAS USED THE INFORMATION DEVELOPED AT WSU FOR MULTIPLE APPLICATIONS TO ADVANCE GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY  THE PRODUCTS COMING OUT OF THIS WORK HAVE ALLOWED USFWS AMONG MANY THINGS TO UNDERSTAND GRIZZLY BEAR FOOD HABITS, THE VALUE OF DIFFERENT FOODS IN THE OVERALL DIET AND THEREFORE HOW HABITAT MANAGEMENT AFFECTS POPULATION WELL BEING, AND GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN AND BETWEEN POPULATIONS  THE USFWS GRIZZLY BEAR RECOVERY OFFICE ALSO HAS USED THE CAPTIVE BEARS TO TRAIN OUR FIELD STAFF ABOUT ANESTHESIA AND FIELD TECHNIQUES FOR SAFELY HANDLING BEARS  THUS, THE WSU BEAR CENTER IS AN IMPORTANT, COOPERATIVE PART OF THE USFWS S EFFORT TO RECOVER GRIZZLY BEARS IN THE LOWER 48 STATES

THE OWYHEE WATERSHED COUNCIL (OWC) IS PROPOSING TO COOPERATE WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), NATURAL RESOURCES CONSERVATION SERVICE (NRCS), BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM), IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH & GAME (IDFG), IDAHO GOVERNOR'S OFFICE OF SPECIES CONSERVATION (OSC), IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF LANDS (IDL), PHEASANTS FOREVER (PF), AND INTERMOUNTAIN WEST JOINT VENTURE (IWJV) TO ENHANCE/RESTORE SAGE BRUSH STEPPE HABITAT THROUGH LANDSCAPE LEVEL JUNIPER REMOVAL TREATMENTS IN THE SOUTHERN IDAHO REGION TO INCLUDE OWYHEE AND CASSIA COUNTIES, IDAHO.

THE RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE  BOMBUS AFFINIS  HAS EXPERIENCED A DRAMATIC DECLINE AND IS  NEARLY ABSENT FROM 95  OF ITS NATIVE RANGE  IT IS CURRENTLY LISTED AS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED  THE  UPPER MIDWEST IS THE ONLY PART OF ITS RANGE WHERE THIS SPECIES IS STILL CONSISTENTLY RECORDED   MOST OF THE CURRENT OBSERVATIONS OF THIS BEE ARE IN URBAN AREAS OF MINNESOTA AND WISCONSIN   THIS HAS LED TO THE SPECULATION THAT THIS SPECIES MAY THRIVE IN URBAN LANDSCAPES  HOWEVER, THE  HIGHER NUMBER OF OBSERVATIONS IN URBAN AREAS MAY SIMPLY BE DUE TO GREATER SURVEYING EFFORT AS MORE BIOLOGISTS AND CITIZEN SCIENTISTS RESIDE IN CITIES  WE PROPOSE TO USE AN OCCUPANCY MODELING  APPROACH TO SAMPLE FOR RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEES IN NORTH AND EASTERN WISCONSIN  EACH YEAR  WE WILL SELECT 70 SITES ALONG A RURAL URBAN GRADIENT  140 SITES TOTAL  AND SAMPLE ALL SITES WITH AN  EQUAL AMOUNT OF EFFORT  AT EACH SITE, WE WILL WALK ALONG A 250 METER TRANSECT AND PHOTOGRAPH  RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEES VISITING FLOWERS  BASED ON OUR PREVIOUS RESEARCH, WE WILL SAMPLE  EACH SITE FIVE TIMES AS THIS FREQUENCY WILL GIVE US AN 80  PROBABILITY THAT WE WILL DETECT THIS  SPECIES IF IT IS PRESENT AT A SITE  THE FINDINGS OF THIS RESEARCH WILL HELP LAND MANAGERS, BIOLOGISTS,  AND POLICY MAKERS BETTER TARGET LOCATIONS FOR CONSERVATION OF THIS ENDANGERED SPECIES

PROJECT TITLE  UPPER WALLOWA RIVER RESTORATION PROJECTPROJECT ABSTRACT THE UPPER WALLOWA RIVER RESTORATION  UWRR  PROJECT AREA IS MANAGED FOR RECREATION WITH A MIX OF SMALL PROPERTY OWNERSHIP, AND WALLOWA LAKE STATE PARK   THE MOST SIGNIFICANT TOURIST ATTRACTION IN WALLOWA COUNTY  NATURAL FLOODPLAIN FUNCTION ALONG THE REACH HAS BEEN DEGRADED BY ENCROACHMENT AND DEVELOPMENT, THEREBY REDUCING SALMON AND AQUATIC HABITAT THE PROJECT WILL    ENHANCE AND RESTORE SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT FOR KOKANEE SALMON AND ESA LISTED BULL TROUT NOW AND POTENTIALLY SOCKEYE IN THE NEAR FUTURE   PROTECT PRIVATE AND PUBLIC PROPERTY FROM FLOODING   CREATE SIGNIFICANT OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUTREACH TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC  AND  SERVE AS A MODEL FOR FLOODPLAIN RESTORATION IN SEMI DEVELOPED AREAS THAT IS FEMA AND NOAA COMPLIANT

GAMBEL S WATERCRESS IS A CRITICALLY ENDANGERED, RHIZOMATOUS  ROOTS AT NODES  AQUATIC, PERENNIAL HERB IN THE BRASSICACEAE  MUSTARD FAMILY   GAMBEL S WATERCRESS IS IN A DIRE STATE, FACING A HIGH RISK OF EXTINCTION  THE SPECIES IS DECREASED TO A SINGLE DECLINING POPULATION ON VANDENBERG SPACE FORCE BASE  VSFB  THAT OCCUPIES A TOTAL AREA OF 0 024 HECTARE 0 06 ACRE  THE POPULATION ON VSFB HAS LOW RESILIENCY  CURRENT THREATS INCLUDE REDUCED HYDROLOGY AND HABITAT QUALITY WITHIN THE UNNAMED TRIBUTARY THAT SUPPORTS THE POPULATION  BECAUSE OF ITS CURRENT STATUS, THE SPECIES HAS ALARMINGLY LOW REDUNDANCY AND REPRESENTATION  INHERENT CHALLENGES WITH VSFB REQUIRES CREATION OF ADDITIONAL POPULATIONS OFF THE INSTALLATION TO PROVIDE BETTER MANAGEMENT AND TO PROMOTE THE SPECIES  RECOVERY AND CONSERVATION

THE INSTITUTE FOR APPLIED ECOLOGY  IAE  IS PARTNERING WITH THE USFWS, OREGON ZOO AND COFFEE CREEK CORRECTIONAL FACILITY  WILSONVILLE  TO CAPTIVE REAR TWO ENDANGERED AND THREATENED BUTTERFLIES   TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT  EUPHYDRYAS EDITHA TAYLORI  AND OREGON SILVERSPOT  SPEYERIA ZERENE HIPPOLYTA   BOTH BUTTERFLIES ARE BEING RAISED IN CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAMS TO AID IN THE SUCCESSFUL RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES THROUGH AUGMENTATION WOMEN WHO ARE INCARCERATED AT THE MINIMUM AND MEDIUM FACILITIES AT COFFEE CREEK GROW TWO PLANT SPECIES  PLANTAGO LANCEOLATA AND VIOLA ADUNCA, RESPECTIVELY  FOR FOOD FOR DEVELOPING BUTTERFLY LARVAE AND FOR OVIPOSITION PLANTS  LARVAE ARE THEN REARED IN BUTTERFLY LABS AT COFFEE CREEK, A BACKUP LAB, AND THE OREGON ZOO  ONCE LARVAE ARE CLOSE TO PUPATING, THE HUMAN REARED LARVAE ARE RELEASED BY THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE ON LANDS WITH APPROPRIATE HABITAT FOR THEIR SUPPORT AND RECOVERY TWO CREWS OF WOMEN AT COFFEE CREEK ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR GROWING THESE PLANTS  ADULTS IN CUSTODY AT THE MINIMUM FACILITY OF COFFEE CREEK RAISE AND HARVEST VIOLA ADUNCA LEAVES AS FOOD FOR THE OREGON SILVERSPOT BUTTERFLY LARVAE  WOMEN IN CUSTODY AT THE MEDIUM FACILITY RAISE PLANTAGO LANCEOLATA FOR TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY  ALTHOUGH CREW MEMBERS MAY HAVE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT RAISING PLANTS, IAE PROVIDES EDUCATION THROUGHOUT THE SEASON  TOPICS RANGE FROM ECOLOGY BIOLOGY OF THE BUTTERFLIES AND THEIR HABITATS, HORTICULTURE, INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT, TO PARTICULARS OF THE BOTANICAL KNOWLEDGE NEEDED TO UNDERSTAND THE WORK OF PRODUCING RELIABLE, HEALTHY PLANTS FOR LARVAE  AT THE END OF THE SEASON, CREW MEMBERS PARTICIPATE IN A  GRADUATION  OF SORTS   CERTIFICATES OF ACCOMPLISHMENT ARE PROVIDED DURING THE CELEBRATION  PLANT AND BUTTERFLY CREW MEMBERS SHARE STORIES OF THEIR EXPERIENCES IN CONNECTING TO NATURE THROUGH THESE PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT THE NEEDS OF SPECIES IN PERIL IAE BEGAN GROWING P  LANCEOLATA IN 2017 TO HELP IN THE CAPTIVE REARING OF TAYLOR S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLY  CREWS FROM COFFEE CREEK ARE NOW RAISING  5,000 PLANTS TO SUPPORT 6700 CATERPILLARS IN DIAPAUSE  SORT OF AN INSECT HIBERNATION    DUE TO WAKE UP THE FIRST WEEK OF MARCH EACH YEAR  WITH IAE S SUPPORT, ADULTS IN CUSTODY  AICS  BEGAN GROWING V  ADUNCA FOR CAPTIVE REARING AT THE OREGON ZOO IN 2013  CURRENTLY, WE ARE GROWING  9,000 VIOLETS TO SUPPORT THIS PROGRAM THE IRONY OF RAISING BUTTERFLIES IN CAPTIVITY THAT GO ON TO BE RELEASED IS NOT LOST ON INCARCERATED CREW MEMBERS, MANY OF WHOM WILL BE RELEASED IN A DIFFERENT CONTEXT  THIS PROGRAM, ONE OF A FEW THAT HELPS CONNECT ADULTS IN CUSTODY TO NATURE, PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS AND ABILITIES THAT MAY SERVE THEM UPON THEIR RELEASE  MANY EXPRESS GRATITUDE AT THE CHANCE TO GIVE BACK TO SOMETHING GREATER THAN THEMSELVES AND THAT ALSO PROVIDES THEM REWARDS GIVEN BY CONNECTING MORE DEEPLY TO NATURE

IN THE WESTERN US, MIGRATORY MONARCH BUTTERFLIES HAVE DECLINED IN ABUNDANCE  THE CURRENT POPULATION IS  5  OF THE ESTIMATED POPULATION SIZE OF WESTERN MONARCH BUTTERFLIES IN THE 1980 S  NATIONWIDE, MONARCH BUTTERFLIES ARE A CANDIDATE FOR LISTING UNDER THE US ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, WITH REGULAR REVIEWS OF THEIR STATUS  IN RESPONSE TO WIDESPREAD DECLINES, NUMEROUS AGENCIES AND NON GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS HAVE BEGUN TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR MONARCH BUTTERFLIES  ALTHOUGH THERE HAS BEEN EXTENSIVE PAST AND ONGOING RESEARCH ABOUT HOW TO RESTORE HABITAT IN THE SENSE OF ESTABLISHING APPROPRIATE PLANTS, THERE HAS BEEN LESS RESEARCH ABOUT IF AND HOW MONARCH BUTTERFLIES USE RESTORED HABITAT  THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR USE OF RESTORED HABITAT FOR BREEDING BY MONARCH BUTTERFLIES IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA  SPECIFICALLY, THE PROJECT WILL MONITOR MONARCH BUTTERFLY EGGS, CATERPILLARS, AND ADULTS AT THREE SITES THAT WERE PLANTED AS MONARCH BUTTERFLY HABITAT IN 2019, ALONG A NORTH SOUTH GRADIENT IN THE CENTRAL VALLEY  EACH SITE WILL BE MONITORED EVERY TWO WEEKS TO UNDERSTAND WHEN MONARCHS BREED AT EACH SITE  WE WILL ALSO TEST HABITAT USE WITHIN EACH SITE, FOR EXAMPLE, DO MONARCH BUTTERFLIES USE SUNNIER PLACES AT COOL TIMES OF YEAR, AND SHADIER PLACES AT WARM TIMES OF YEAR  THESE DATA WILL ALLOW US TO ASSESS THE CONTRIBUTION OF THESE RESTORATION SITES TO MONARCH BUTTERFLY RECOVERY, AND TO MAKE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVING FUTURE RESTORATION EFFORTS

UNTIL RECENTLY, THE AKIKIKI, A KAUAI ENDEMIC FOREST BIRD, WAS ESTIMATED TO NUMBER 500 BIRDS  HOWEVER IN THE LAST TWO YEARS IT HAS STEEPLY DECLINED DUE TO MOSQUITO BORNE DISEASE  IN 2021, WE FOUND ONLY 2 TERRITORIES  VS  36 TERRITORIES IN 2015  AT HALEHAHA  IN APRIL 2022, 3 ADULT AKIKIKI REMAIN AT THAT SITE AND MOSQUITO NUMBERS ARE INCREASING  EXPERTS BELIEVE THAT APPROXIMATELY 12 MORE AKIKIKI PAIRS LIKELY PERSIST IN DISJUNCT HABITAT PATCHES ALONG THE WAINIHA PALI, BUT RECENT MOSQUITO SURVEYS IN THOSE AREAS SHOW THAT MOSQUITOES ALSO ARE ENCROACHING INTO THOSE AREAS  LANDSCAPE SCALE MOSQUITO CONTROL WILL NOT BE IMPLEMENTED ON KAUAI UNTIL AT LEAST 2024  EXPERTS BELIEVE AKIKIKI COULD GO FUNCTIONALLY EXTINCT IN THE WILD BY 2023  I E ,   10 BREEDING FEMALES REMAINING  PAXTON ET AL  2022   THE CONSERVATION BREEDING POPULATION LARGELY CONSISTS OF 5 8 YEAR OLD INDIVIDUALS, MOST OF WHOM HAVE FAILED TO BREED, SO THESE BIRDS CANNOT BE CONSIDERED AN INSURANCE POLICY AGAINST EXTINCTION  TO PREVENT EXTINCTION OF AKIKIKI, WE MUST BRING AS MANY AS POSSIBLE OF THE REMAINING WILD AKIKIKI INTO CAPTIVITY  COLLECTION OF AKIKIKI WILL BE MOST SUCCESSFUL IN THE LATE WINTER AND SPRING, WHEN AKIKIKI ARE MOST TERRITORIAL AND RESPONSIVE TO PLAYBACK  PAST ATTEMPTS TO CATCH AKIKIKI AT OTHER TIMES OF YEAR HAVE NOT BEEN VERY FRUITFUL  WE REQUEST FUNDS FOR FIELD TEAMS TO LOCATE AND MONITOR AKIKIKI TERRITORIES AND NESTS THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE, COLLECT EGGS OR CHICKS FROM NESTS, THEN CAPTURE THE ADULTS AND ANY VOLANT YOUNG  EGGS, NON VOLANT CHICKS, AND ADULT BIRDS WILL BE TAKEN BY HELICOPTER TO A FACILITY ON KAUAI, WHERE THEY WILL BE HELD BRIEFLY BEFORE TRANSFER TO THEIR ULTIMATE HOME IN SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE FACILITIES ON MAUI OR HAWAII ISLANDS  THIS PROPOSAL ALSO REQUESTS FUNDING FOR THOSE FACILITIES AND STAFF, HELICOPTER, AND INTERISLAND AIRFARE

PREDATION BY INVASIVE AMERICAN BULLFROGS IS A MAJOR THREAT TO CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG CONSERVATION  THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG IS FEDERALLY LISTED AS THREATENED  IN THE PAST 22 YEARS, BULLFROG CONTROL HAS RESULTED IN THE RECOVERY OF CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROGS FROM LARGE PORTIONS OF ITS FORMER RANGE  BULLFROG CLEARED AREAS ARE PROTECTED FROM REINVASION BY THE ACTIVE MONITORING OF BUFFER ZONES WHERE THE PRESENCE OF BULLFROGS AND THEIR REMOVAL PROTECT THE CLEARED AREAS BEHIND THESE ZONES  THIS AGREEMENT WILL ALLOW TRAVEL TO AND FROM THE FIELD SITES THAT INCLUDE THE TWO MAJOR BUFFER ZONES IN SOUTHEASTERN ARIZONA TO MONITOR AND REMOVE BULLFROGS FROM OCTOBER 2022 THROUGH MARCH 2023  NEAREST TOWNS TO THESE BUFFER ZONES INCLUDE ARIVACA AND SONOITA  DATA WILL BE COLLECTED, COMPILED, AND SYNTHESIZED, AND A FINAL REPORT WITH MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS WILL BE COMPLETED AND SUBMITTED TO THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  THIS PROJECT WILL BE PERFORMED IN CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICTS 6 AND  7 OF ARIZONA

THE SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE  SDZWA  OPERATES A UNIQUE CONSERVATION BREEDING AND REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE  USFWS , STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES DIVISION OF FORESTRY AND WILDLIFE  DOFAW , AND OTHERS  THE OVERALL MISSION OF THIS PARTNERSHIP IS TO COLLABORATE TO AID IN THE RECOVERY OF ENDANGERED BIRDS, AS PART OF A MULTI FACETED APPROACH TO ECOSYSTEM PROTECTION AND RESTORATION  THE OBJECTIVE IS TO PREVENT IMMINENT EXTINCTION AND RECOVER WILD POPULATIONS OF CRITICALLY ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS USING HUSBANDRY, AVICULTURE, AND CONSERVATION BREEDING TECHNIQUES  THESE SPECIES ARE AMONG THE RAREST BIRDS IN THE WORLD  SINCE THIS HAWAIIAN BIRD PROJECT WAS ESTABLISHED IN 1993, OVER 1150 OFFSPRING FROM 16 DIFFERENT HAWAIIAN BIRD SPECIES HAVE BEEN REARED, AND OVER 840 BIRDS RELEASED INTO THE WILD  THIS PROJECT USES INNOVATIVE SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGIES TO MAXIMIZE THE LIKELIHOOD OF INDIVIDUALS THRIVING IN THE WILD AFTER RELEASE  THIS LONG TERM PROJECT HAS MADE SIGNIFICANT CAPITAL INVESTMENTS IN THE PERMANENT FACILITIES  HOWEVER, A NUMBER OF BUILDINGS ARE AGING AND IN NEED OF SIGNIFICANT REPAIR  IN ADDITION, AKIKIKI ARE FACING IMMINENT EXTINCTION IN THE WILD  THE SDZWA WILL ASSIST WITH AN EFFORT TO BRING AKIKIKI FROM THE WILD INTO HUMAN CARE, BY COLLECTING EGGS AND NESTLINGS, AND TRANSPORTING EGGS, NESTLINGS, AND JUVENILES ADULTS  AS ENDEMIC HAWAIIAN FOREST BIRD POPULATIONS DECLINE IN THE WILD, BRINGING SPECIES INTO HUMAN CARE MAY BE A LAST RESORT TO PREVENT SPECIES EXTINCTION  PRIOR TO THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THIS CONSERVATION BREEDING AND REINTRODUCTION PROGRAM, NO INSTITUTION OR ENTITY HAS DEMONSTRATED THE ABILITY TO CARE FOR AND BREED ENDANGERED HAWAIIAN BIRDS AT A HIGH LEVEL UNDER HUMAN CARE

COASTAL DUNES MILK-VETCH IS AT RISK OF EXTINCTION DUE TO AN EXTREMELY LIMITED AREAL EXTENT, HABITATFRAGMENTATION, AND LOCATION WITHIN AN AREA OF HIGH RECREATIONAL TRAFFIC AND CHANCES FOR ACCIDENTALDISTURBANCE THROUGH ROAD MAINTENANCE, BOAT SALVAGE, AND GOLF COURSE ACTIVITIES. THE INTRODUCTION WILL BE DESIGNED TO INCREASE THE RANGE, AREAL EXTENT, AND ABUNDANCE OF THE SPECIES TO REDUCE THE RISK OF ITS EXTINCTION DUE TOENVIRONMENTAL AND DEMOGRAPHIC RANDOMNESS. IT WILL ALSO INCREASE THE SPECIES' RESILIENCY TO CLIMATE CHANGE, INCLUDING BY INCREASING THE POPULATION AND ESTABLISHING OCCURRENCES IN A RANGE OF MICROSITE CONDITIONS THAT WILL INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD OF PERSISTENCE IN A CHANGING CLIMATE. IT WILL BE IMPLEMENTED AS A SMALL-SCALE ECOLOGICAL EXPERIMENT TO INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF THE ECOLOGICAL FACTORS INFLUENCING COASTAL DUNES MILK-VETCH, SUCH AS SOILS, PLANT COMMUNITY, AND MICROTOPOGRAPHY, WHICH CAN HELP INFORM CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF REMAININGPOPULATIONS.

LUNADA CANYON IS A 20 7 ACRE PARCEL IN THE NORTHERN PORTION OF THE 61 ACRE AGUA AMARGA RESERVE  FIGURE 2  WITHIN  THE GREATER PALOS VERDES NATURE PRESERVE  PVNP  LOCATED IN THE CITY OF RANCHO PALOS VERDES, LOS ANGELES,  CALIFORNIA  THE PVNP IS THE PRIMARY CONSERVATION AREA ASSOCIATED WITH THE CITY OF RANCHO PALOS VERDES  CITY   NATURAL COMMUNITY CONSERVATION PLAN HABITAT CONSERVATION PLAN  NCCP HCP   SINCE 1990, THE PALOS VERDES PENINSULA  LAND CONSERVANCY  LAND CONSERVANCY  HAS OWNED AND MANAGED THE LUNADA CANYON AREA OF THE AGUA AMARGA RESERVE   THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS RESTORATION PROJECT IS TO ESTABLISH NATIVE VEGETATION TO SUPPORT THE SUCCESSFUL  REINTRODUCTION AND RECOVERY OF THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED PALOS VERDES BLUE BUTTERFLY  PVBB  WITHIN ITS HISTORIC  RANGE  THE PVBB IS A PALOS VERDES PENINSULA  FIGURE 1  ENDEMIC AND ONE OF THE RAREST BUTTERFLIES IN THE WORLD   HABITAT FOR PVBB CONSISTS OF THE SPECIES  HOST PLANTS, ASTRAGALUS TRICHOPODUS VAR  LONCHUS  OCEAN LOCOWEED  AND  ACMISPON GLABER  DEERWEED , AS WELL AS OTHER EARLY SUCCESSIONAL NATIVE FORB SPECIES THAT PROVIDE NECTAR SOURCES  FOR THE BUTTERFLY  THE CITY SUPPORTED THE LAST REMAINING HABITATS FOR PVBB BEFORE IT WAS THOUGHT TO BE EXTINCT IN  1984  MATTONI 1995 , SO REINTRODUCTION WITHIN THE CITY IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE SPECIES  SURVIVAL AND RECOVERY   CURRENTLY, THERE ARE TWO KNOWN WILD POPULATIONS ON THE PENINSULA  NOT INCLUDING 2020 RELEASE LOCATIONS  WITH AS  LITTLE AS 3 ESTIMATED INDIVIDUALS AT DEFENSE FUEL SUPPLY POINT  DFSP  AND 7 AT LINDEN H  CHANDLER PRESERVE   LUNADA CANYON IS A RELATIVELY NARROW CANYON WITHIN THE AGUA AMARGA RESERVE AND CALIFORNIA NATURAL DIVERSITY  DATABASE RECORDS INDICATE PREVIOUS USE BY PVBB IN THE 1980 S  CURRENTLY, LUNADA CANYON CONSISTS OF INTACT COASTAL  SAGE TITLE: EVALUATION OF LETHAL AND NON-LETHAL RAVEN MANIPULATION TO BENEFIT SAGE-GROUSE IN THE BAKER AND MALHEUR COUNTIES, OREGONHIGH DENSITY OF COMMON RAVENS (CORVUS CORAX; HEREAFTER RAVENS) HAS NEGATIVELY AFFECTED GREATER SAGE-GROUSE (CENTROCERCUS UROPHASIANUS; HEREAFTER SAGE-GROUSE) NEST SUCCESS IN THE GREAT BASIN POPULATION AND LIKELY THE BAKER, OREGON POPULATION. IN OREGON, SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS IN THE BAKER AND COW LAKES PRIORITY AREAS OF CONSERVATION (PACS) HAVE DRAMATICALLY DECLINED OVER THE PAST DECADE RESULTING IN CROSSING ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT THRESHOLDS FOR THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT (BLM). OREGON DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE (ODFW), OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY (OSU), AND A RECENT REGIONAL STUDY HAVE QUANTIFIED HIGH DENSITIES OF RAVENS IN THESE PACS. THIS PROPOSAL IS TO PARTIALLY FUND THE TREATMENT PORTION OF A LONG-TERM STUDY (2017-2024) ASSESSING THE BENEFITS OF LETHAL AND NON-LETHAL RAVEN MANAGEMENT ACTIONS TO BENEFIT SAGE-GROUSE NEAR AND WITHIN THE BAKER AND COW LAKES SAGE-GROUSE PACS, RESPECTIVELY. IN ADDITION, WE HAVE AND WILL CONTINUE TO DIRECTLY EVALUATE THE EFFICACY OF LETHAL AND NON-LETHAL RAVEN MANAGEMENT ACTIONS BY QUANTIFYING LOCAL RAVEN ABUNDANCE AND OCCUPANCY DIRECTLY BEFORE AND AFTER MANAGEMENT ACTIONS. THIS PROJECT HAS AND CONTINUES TO FOCUS ON IDENTIFYING HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS ASSOCIATED WITH HIGH DENSITIES OF RAVENS, RAVEN HABITAT USE (MOVEMENT, FORAGING HABITAT, AND NEST-SITES), AND RAVEN NEST SUCCESS. SIMULTANEOUSLY, WE HAVE AND CONTINUE TO COMPARE SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT USE, NEST SUCCESS, CHICK SURVIVAL, AND POPULATION GROWTH (LEK COUNTS) AMONG YEARS BEFORE AND AFTER LETHAL AND NON-LETHAL RAVEN REMOVAL. THIS ONGOING PROJECT IMPLEMENTING AND EVALUATING LETHAL AND NON-LETHAL RAVEN MANAGEMENT DIRECTLY WILL INFORM MANAGEMENT AGENCIES ABOUT THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THESE MITIGATION STRATEGIES FOR SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT WITH HIGH DENSITIES OF RAVENS IN OREGON. HOWEVER, THE FINDINGS WILL ALSO HAVE IMPLICATIONS NATIONALLY FOR RAVEN MANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE WESTERN UNITED STATES.THIS PROJECT COMPLEMENTS WORK UNDERWAY BY THE MULTI-STAKEHOLDER GROUP, THE BAKER SAGE-GROUSE LOCAL IMPLEMENTATION TEAM, TO ADDRESS THE MOST URGENT THREATS CONSIDERED TO BE CONTRIBUTING TO THE PRECIPITOUS SAGE-GROUSE DECLINE IN THE BAKER PAC. FURTHER, THIS STUDY ALIGNS WITH TASK 5.2 OF THE OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY BY 1) ASSESSING SAGE-GROUSE RESPONSE TO THE CONSERVATION ACTION OF REMOVING RAVENS, 2) FILLING DATA GAPS ASSOCIATED WITH SAGE-GROUSE HABITAT USE, MOVEMENT, AND DEMOGRAPHIC RATES, AND 3) GATHERING INFORMATION ON SAGE-GROUSE RESPONSE TO ANNUAL GRASS AND FIRE. THE OREGON CONSERVATION STRATEGY REFERS TO THE GREATER SAGE-GROUSE CONSERVATION ASSESSMENT AND CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR OREGON (HAGEN 2011) FOR DETAILS ON CONSERVATION ACTIONS AND DATA GAPS OF PARTICULAR NEED FOR SAGE-GROUSE IN OREGON. CONSERVATION ACTIONS INCLUDE MINIMIZING THE EFFECTS OF PREDATION ON ISOLATED AND DECLINING POPULATIONS WHERE PREDATION HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A POTENTIAL LIMITING FACTOR (HAGEN 2011), SUCH AS THE BAKER AND COW LAKES SAGE-GROUSE POPULATIONS. IDENTIFIED DATA GAPS INCLUDE BASIC ECOLOGY, POPULATION ECOLOGY, MIGRATION OF SAGE-GROUSE, AND SAGEBRUSH ECOLOGY (HAGEN 2011). THIS STUDY WILL ALSO IDENTIFY OTHER POTENTIAL CONSERVATION ISSUES FOR SAGE-GROUSE WITHIN THE BAKER, BULLY CREEK, COW LAKES, CROWLEY, AND SOLDIER CREEK PACS, WHICH WILL BE ACHIEVED BY QUANTIFYING SAGE-GROUSE RELATIONSHIPS TO HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS AND ANTHROPOGENIC FEATURES.

LONG-TERM MONITORING OF IMPERILED SPECIES IS NEEDED TO QUANTIFYPOPULATION SIZE, TO DETECT CHANGES IN ABUNDANCE IN RESPONSE TO NATURAL OR ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES, AND TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS. FROM AN ACADEMIC PERSPECTIVE, IT WOULD BE VALUABLE TO CONTINUE MONITORING OKALOOSA DARTERS THEREAFTER TO PROVIDE INSIGHT INTO LONG-TERM POPULATION DYNAMICS AND RESPONSES TO A CHANGING ENVIRONMENT. OKALOOSA DARTERS MAY ALSO SERVE AS AN INDICATOR SPECIES FOR STREAMSTHAT DRAIN INTO BOGGY, ROCKY, AND TOMS BAYOUS.THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT A VISUAL SURVEY OF THE ABUNDANCE OF OKALOOSA DARTERS AT 22 LONG-TERM MONITORING SITES. A SECONDARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE TRAINING AND EXPERIENCE TO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS INTERESTED IN ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCEAND OTHER STEM FIELDS.MONITORING WILL BE COMPLETED DURING THE SUMMER WHEN BOTH ADULT AND RECENT RECRUITS ARE PRESENT AND STREAM CONDITIONS ARE MOST AMENABLE TO UNDERWATER VISUAL CENSUS METHODS. ABUNDANCE OF OKALOOSA DARTERS WILL BE ESTIMATED AT A SUITE OF 22 LONG-TERM MONITORING SITES LOCATED THROUGHOUT EGLIN AFB. THIS INCLUDES A NEW MONITORING SITE ON TOMS CREEK TO PROVIDE A BETTER ESTIMATE FOR THIS GENETICALLY DISTINCT SUBPOPULATION (AUSTIN ET AL. 2011). DISSOLVED OXYGEN, WATER TEMPERATURE, AND CONDUCTIVITY WILL BE MEASURED AT EACH SITE PRIOR TO CONDUCTING VISUAL CENSUSES.

THE MARBLED MURRELET  BRACHYRAMPHUS MARMORATUS    MURRELET   IS A FEDERALLY THREATENED SPECIES UNDER  THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT  MURRELET MONITORING IS PART OF A LONG TERM EFFORT TO EVALUATE THE POPULATION  SIZE AND TRENDS OVER THE PAST 25 YEARS  IT IS AN ESSENTIAL ELEMENT OF THE MURRELET S RECOVERY PLAN AND  NORTHWEST FOREST PLAN  NWFP  EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING  CRAIG STRONG  CRESCENT COASTAL RESEARCH   PROPOSES TO MONITOR MURRELETS FROM SMALL VESSELS AT SEA TO GENERATE STATISTICALLY VALID ESTIMATES OF TOTAL  POPULATION, AS HAS BEEN DONE FOR THE PAST 23 YEARS  INFORMATION IS USED IN MANAGING HABITAT AND  POPULATIONS, WITH SECONDARY BENEFITS OF TRACKING TRENDS IN SEABIRDS AND MARINE MAMMALS WITH RESPECT TO  COASTAL MARINE MANAGEMENT AND CHANGES IN THE CALIFORNIA CURRENT SYSTEM

THIS PROJECT WILL BUILD UPON A NASCENT NORTH PUGET SOUND WORKING GROUP TO MORE EFFECTIVELY FORMALIZE PARTNERSHIPS ACROSS THREE DISTINCT SUBREGIONS (E.G., OLYMPIC PENINSULA, SAN JUAN ISLANDS, MAINLAND ISLANDS) WITH THE GOAL TO ACHIEVE DESIRED HABITAT AND SPECIES CONSERVATION OUTCOMES. IN ADDITION TO THIS BROADER FACILITATION EFFORT, WE WILL USE THIS FRAMEWORK TO HELP IDENTIFY PARTNERS IN THE REGION THAT ARE CURRENTLY, OR DESIRE TO BE, ENGAGED IN TAYLOR'S CHECKERSPOT RECOVERY TO HELP STRATEGIZE AND IMPLEMENT ACTIONS TO ESTABLISH NEW POPULATIONS IN THE REGION. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HELP DEVELOP A SUSTAINABLE FRAMEWORK FOR AN EFFECTIVE WORKING GROUP IN THE NORTH PUGET SOUND REGION THAT CAN PROVIDE TIMELY AND RELEVANT INFORMATION EXCHANGE, COORDINATE COLLABORATIVE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, LOOK FORWARD STRATEGICALLY, AND SHARE RESOURCES.

WE HAVE BEEN WORKING IN ASOTIN CREEK SINCE 2007 TESTING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF LOW-TECH PROCESSBASEDRESTORATION AND HAVE FOUND THAT SUMMER STEELHEAD ABUNDANCE AND PRODUCTIVITY HASINCREASED IN RESTORATION AREAS IN ASOTIN CREEK. BULL TROUT HAVE BEEN CAPTURED BUT ARE AT IN LOWABUNDANCE IN THE LOWER AND MIDDLE PORTIONS OF THE WATERSHED - BUT THEY ARE EXPECTED TO BENEFITFROM THE LOW-TECH RESTORATION. HISTORIC DATA SUGGESTS THERE ARE RESIDENT AND FLUVIAL BULL TROUTTHAT USE THE UPPER ASOTIN TRIBUTARIES - BUT CURRENT DATA IS LACKING. A LARGE WILDFIRE IN THE SUMMEROF 2021 BURNT MUCH OF THE HEADWATERS OF ASOTIN CREEK INCLUDING RIPARIAN AREAS. WE AREPROPOSING TO DO A RAPID ASSESSMENT OF THE DISTRIBUTION AND RELATIVE ABUNDANCE OF BULL TROUT ANDRELATE THAT TO THE FIRE SEVERITY DAMAGE IN TRIBUTARIES, DEVELOP AND EMERGENCY RESTORATIONMITIGATION PLAN, AND IMPLEMENT LOW-TECH RESTORATION (IF APPROPRIATE) IN HIGH PRIORITY AREAS. THISPROJECT WILL ALSO FIT WELL WITH OUR ONGOING 15 YEAR INTENSIVELY MONITORED WATERSHED EXPERIMENTBY PROVIDING INFORMATION ABOUT EXCESS SEDIMENT THREATS AS WELL AS POTENTIAL BUFFERING THEEXISTING 14 KM OF RESTORATION WE HAVE ALREADY IMPLEMENTED.

THE CURRENT ISLAND MARBLE BUTTERFLY CAPTIVE PROPAGATION FACILITY LOCATED WITHIN SAN JUAN ISLAND NATIONAL PARK IS UNDER-EQUIPPED TO MEET FUTURE REARING NEEDS. ADDITIONALLY, IT IS THE SOLE SITE WHERE ISLAND MARBLE BUTTERFLIES ARE RAISED AND STORED OVER-WINTER, RENDERING THE ENTIRE CAPTIVE PROPAGATION PROGRAM VULNERABLE TO A VARIETY OF STOCHASTIC EVENTS. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A FEASIBILITY STUDY AND INITIATE THE SCOPING, OUTREACH, AND RESEARCH NECESSARY TO LOCATE AND DESIGN A SECONDARY REARING FACILITY. THIS EFFORT WILL IDENTIFY AN APPROPRIATE SITE, GENERATE POTENTIAL FUNDING PLANS, IDENTIFY NEEDED COMPLIANCE, AND DRAFT A BUILDING DESIGN. A NEW REARING FACILITY WILL PROVIDE GENERAL SECURITY AND GREATER CAPACITY TO SERVE CURRENT AND FUTURE POPULATION AUGMENTATION GOALS FOR BOTH THE NATIONAL PARK AND THE CANDIDATE CONSERVATION AGREEMENT WITH ASSURANCES PROPERTIES ON SAN JUAN AND LOPEZ ISLANDS.

BEACH AND DUNE MAINTENANCE PRACTICES CONDUCTED BY BEACH MANAGERS  I E , PRIMARILY MUNICIPAL PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENTS  ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST OF NEW JERSEY ARE OFTEN IN DIRECT CONFLICT WITH THE HABITAT NEEDS OF THREATENED AND ENDANGERED BEACH SPECIES, INCLUDING THE FEDERALLY LISTED  THREATENED  PIPING PLOVER  CHARADRIUS MELODUS  AND SEABEACH AMARANTH  AMARANTHUS PUMILUS   THESE PRACTICES ARE UNDERTAKEN TO PRIMARILY ENHANCE RECREATION AND STORM PROTECTION VALUES OF BEACH AND DUNES, BUT OFTEN WITH THE RESULT OF DEGRADING OR DESTROYING HABITAT FOR LISTED SPECIES  THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS FOR THE CONSERVE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY  CWFNJ  TO WORK CLOSELY WITH U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S  SERVICE  NEW JERSEY FIELD OFFICE  NJFO  IN A CONCERTED EFFORT TO PROMOTE AWARENESS, ADOPTION, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NJFO S FORTHCOMING TE FRIENDLY DUNE GUIDELINES  IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SERVICE, CWFNJ WILL   1  HOLD STAKEHOLDER MEETINGS TO IDENTIFY OBSTACLES AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR ADOPTION OF THE GUIDELINES   2  SEEK TO INTEGRATE THE GUIDELINES INTO NEW JERSEY COASTAL RESILIENCE PLANNING AND PROJECTS, AS WELL AS OTHER COASTAL REGULATIONS   3  DEVELOP OUTREACH AND EDUCATION MATERIALS AIMED AT LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS, AND OTHER MATERIALS  INCLUDING A DEDICATED WEB PAGE AND SIGNAGE TEMPLATE  AIMED AT THE BEACH GOING PUBLIC, AND WORK WITH UMBRELLA ORGANIZATIONS TO DISSEMINATE THE MESSAGING  AND  4  HOLD ONE OR TWO WORKSHOPS WITH LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS MUNICIPAL STAFF SO THEY CAN BETTER UNDERSTAND THE GUIDELINES AND TO FACILITATE IMPLEMENTATION OF THEM INTO THEIR ROUTINE BEACH MANAGEMENT PRACTICES

THE LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (LCT) HAS BEEN LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT (ESA) FOR 50 YEARS. TO HELP MOVE THE RECOVERY NEEDLE, AN INTERAGENCY MANAGEMENT OVERSIGHT GROUP (MOG) AND COORDINATING COMMITTEE (CC), REPRESENTED BY STATE AND FEDERAL PARTNERS, WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO IDENTIFY, TARGET, AND IMPLEMENT RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION NEEDS ACROSS NEVADA AND CALIFORNIA. THIS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE NATIONAL SERVICE RIPARIAN TEAM (NRST) AND ASSOCIATED CONTRACTORS TO MEET THE NEEDS OF OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT OF PARTNERS AND COORDINATION AND FACILITATION OF COLLABORATIVE GROUP MEETINGS ASSOCIATED WITH LCT RECOVERY. THE NEVADA DEPARTMENT OF WILDLIFE, IN ASSOCIATION WITH THE NRST, WILL PROCURE A CONTRACTOR TO CONDUCT THIS WORK.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AWARD IS TO FUND RESEARCH BY UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO (UI) ON THE BANBURYSPRINGS LIMPET, AN IDAHO ENDEMIC SNAIL KNOWN FROM ONLY FOUR SMALL SPRINGS. THE SPECIES IS EXPERIENCING A GENERAL DECLINE IN ALL POPULATIONS, AND ONE HAS EXPERIENCED DRASTIC DECLINESIN TWO OF ITS THREE KNOWN COLONIES DUE TO DIRECT HUMAN DISTURBANCE. ALMOST NOTHING IS KNOWN ABOUT THE LIFE HISTORY OF THE BANBURY SPRINGS LIMPET, AND THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE COLLECTION OF LIMPETS FROM KNOWN POPULATIONS FOR PLACEMENT IN AQUARIA AT THE UI HAGERMANFISH CULTURE EXPERIMENT STATION, WHICH IS LOCATED NEAR POPULATIONS OF THIS SPECIES ANDUTILIZES SPRING WATER FROM THE SAME AQUIFER. THE GOALS OF THIS STUDY ARE THE DETERMINATION OF APPROPRIATE AQUARIA CONDITIONS (E.G. LIGHT, WATER QUALITY, SUBSTRATE) FOR SURVIVAL ANDMAINTENANCE OF THE SPECIES; THE COLLECTION OF HABITAT, SURVIVAL, AND LIFE HISTORY DATA; AND, IF BREEDING OCCURS, PROPAGATION. THE AWARD WILL COVER STAFF TIME (PRIMARILY AQUARIA PREPARATION AND MAINTENANCE, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY AND DATA COLLECTION, AND REPORT PREPARATION) AS WELL AS FUNDS TO PURCHASE NECESSARY EQUIPMENT NOT ALREADY OWNED BY THE FACILITY AS WELL AS LAB SUPPLIES TO ENSURE OPTIMAL REARING CONDITIONS AND PRESERVATION OF BIOLOGICAL SAMPLES. AT THE END OF THE AWARD PERIOD, A REPORT DETAILING PROJECT FINDINGS ANDCOPIES OF COLLECTED DATA WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE.
