IN 1992, THE MARBLED MURRELET WAS LISTED UNDER THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT OF 1973 AS ATHREATENED SPECIES IN CALIFORNIA, OREGON, AND WASHINGTON  A RECOVERY PLAN WAS PUBLISHED THATOUTLINED RECOVERY STRATEGIES INCLUDING DEVELOPING AND CONDUCTING STANDARDIZED AT SEA SURVEYS U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE 1997   THESE SURVEYS WERE VIEWED AS IMPORTANT BECAUSE THEYALLOW RESEARCHERS TO MODEL POPULATION TRENDS AND BECAUSE DETECTING CHANGES IN POPULATIONS ARECRITICAL TO EVALUATING THE OUTCOME OF RECOVERY ACTIONS AND ULTIMATELY FOR DETERMINING RECOVERYSUCCESS OR FAILURE  IN ADDITION, WHEN DEVELOPING THE NORTHWEST FOREST PLAN, IT WAS DECIDED THATAT SEA MURRELETS WERE TO BE USED AS ONE OF THE METRICS TO ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE PLAN IN RESPONSE TO THIS RECOVERY GOAL AND THE NEEDS OF THE FOREST PLAN, THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFESERVICE, U S  FOREST SERVICE AND STATE WILDLIFE AGENCIES INITIATED A MARBLED MURRELET MONITORINGSTRATEGY IN 2000  RAPHAEL ET AL  1999, 2007  MILLER ET AL  2006   THE GOAL OF THIS MONITORINGSTRATEGY IS TO ESTIMATE MARBLED MURRELET POPULATION SIZE AND TO DETECT CHANGES IN POPULATION SIZEFOR THE AREA BETWEEN SAN FRANCISCO AND THE WASHINGTON   CANADA BORDER  RESULTS FROM THIS MONITORING EFFORT ARE USED TO EVALUATE ANY USFWS INCIDENTAL TAKE CRITERIA, TO ASSESS RECOVERY PROGRESS, TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE NORTHWEST FOREST PLAN  MADSEN ET AL  1999 , AND EVEN EVALUATE THE DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND TRENDS OF SPECIES OTHER THAN THE MURRELET  PEARSONET AL  ACCEPTED  THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BY PROVIDING INFORMATION TO FEDERAL, STATE, AND PRIVATE RESOURCE MANAGERS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF THE MARBLED MURRELET  THIS PROJECT CONTRIBUTES TO THE OVERALL NORTHWEST FOREST PLAN MARBLED MURRELET EFFECTIVENESS MONITORING EFFORT

OUR PROJECT WILL ASSESS THE CURRENT CHARACTERISTICS AND STATUS OF CANADA LYNX IN WESTERN WASHINGTON BY EMPLOYING GENETIC ANALYSES. WE WILL DETERMINE THE MINIMUM NUMBER OF INDIVIDUALS, SEX RATIO, AND GENETIC DIVERSITY OF THE POPULATION IN THE OKANOGAN LYNX MANAGEMENT ZONE (LMZ; LEWIS 2016), AND ASSESS CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN INDIVIDUALS INHABITING WESTERN WASHINGTON AND SOUTHERN BRITISH COLUMBIA (BC). THIS ASSESSMENT WILL IDENTIFY WHETHER THE POPULATION IS EXPERIENCING NEGATIVE GENETIC EFFECTS OF SMALL SIZE OR LACK OF CONNECTIVITY, IDENTIFY CURRENTLY OCCUPIED LYNX HABITAT, AND DETERMINE KEY AREAS TO TARGET FOREST RESILIENCE MANAGEMENT ACTIONS THAT RESTORE AND MAINTAIN HABITAT FOR LYNX AND THEIR KEY PREY.THIS PROJECT WILL HELP US UNDERSTAND THE CURRENT POPULATION STATUS OF A CARNIVORE OF SIGNIFICANT MANAGEMENT CONCERN THAT FACES SUBSTANTIAL THREATS OF EXTIRPATION FROM WIDESPREADLOSS AND FRAGMENTATION OF ITS REMAINING HABITAT AS A RESULT OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT WILL MEET THE USFWS WASHINGTON ECOLOGICAL SERVICES' STRATEGIC PLAN'S OBJECTIVES BY FILLING DATA GAPS TO RESTORE AND CONSERVE THE POPULATION OF CANADA LYNX AND PROVIDING A MUCH NEEDED GENETIC ASSESSMENT OF A FEDERALLY THREATENED AND STATE ENDANGERED SPECIES IN WASHINGTON; AS WELL AS SURVEYING FOR CASCADE RED FOX, A WASHINGTON CANDIDATESPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THE GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER SALVAGE CAPTIVE REARING PROGRAM IS TO SUPPORT  THE RECOVERY OF THE GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER POPULATION BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF PLOVER  CHICKS THAT FLEDGE EACH YEAR. THE OBJECTIVE OF THE PROGRAM IS TO OPERATE THE CAPTIVE REARING  FACILITY AT THE DETROIT ZOO AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN'S BIOLOGICAL STATION (UMBS) TO RAISE AND  RELEASE CHICKS FROM ABANDONED EGGS.  SALVAGE CAPTIVE REARING IS ONE OF THE ACTION ITEMS IN THE 2003 GREAT LAKES RECOVERY ACTION  PLAN. ACTION ITEM 7 IS DEVELOP EMERGENCY METHODS TO PREVENT EXTIRPATION. THE CURRENT EFFORTS  SUPPORT ITEM 7.21 TO CAPTIVE-REAR ABANDONED EGGS TO SUPPLEMENT NATURAL PRODUCTION. IN 2021,  THE CAPTIVE REARING PROGRAM RELEASED 13 CAPTIVE REARED CHICKS, SUPPLEMENTING THE WILD FLEDGED  POPULATION IN THE FIELD. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE: - PREPARATION OF THE CAPTIVE REARING FACILITY, INCLUDING ASSEMBLING BOTH CONDITIONING PENS. - UPDATING AND PROVIDING REARING PROTOCOLS TO PARTICIPANTS PRIOR TO THE SEASON. - WORKING WITH THE PLOVER MONITORS, UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA, SBDNL, AND THE USFWS TO  ARRANGE FOR TRANSPORTATION OF ABANDONED EGGS OR CHICKS FROM FIELD SITES TO UMBS. - RECRUITING EXPERIENCED SEASONAL INTERNS TO REPLACE DZS STAFF TRAVELING TO UMBS TO  INCUBATE EGGS AND REAR CHICKS. ARRANGE AND SCHEDULE SO THAT STAFF IS AVAILABLE FROM END  OF APRIL THROUGH MID-AUGUST. - PURCHASING ALL NEEDED FEED ITEMS FOR CHICK REARING, PERMANENT AND PORTABLE INCUBATORS AND SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT FOR THE REARING OPERATION. - SUPPORTING SHORT-TERM NEEDS IF, FOR EXAMPLE, A CLUTCH OF EGGS IS PULLED IN THE EVENT OF AN  EMERGENCY. - ASSISTING IN THE RELEASE OF ALL FLEDGED CAPTIVE CHICKS AS NEEDED. - FACILITATING THE REMOVAL, WINTERIZING AND STORAGE OF ALL MATERIALS AND EQUIPMENT AT THE  CONCLUSION OF THE BREEDING SEASONS. - SUPPORTING SLEEPING BEAR DUNES NATIONAL LAKESHORE REMOTE INCUBATION SITE PROGRAM O WORK WITH SBDNL SUPERVISORS ON INCUBATOR/CANDLING TRAINING AS NEEDED. O WORK WITH SBDNL AND USFWS ON SHORT-TERM EGG MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING WHEN  VULNERABLE EGGS SHOULD BE RETURNED TO THE NEST OR CONSIDERED ABANDONED AND  SENT TO UMBS FOR CAPTIVE REARING. - SUPPORTING RELOCATION ACTIVITIES FROM OTHER FIELD SITES O PROVIDE PORTABLE INCUBATORS AND TRAINING ON THEIR USE TO PLOVER MONITORS. O ADVISING MONITORS DURING ABANDONMENT EVENTS SO EGGS CAN BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED  TO UMBS FOR INCUBATION.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO USE GENETIC MONITORING TO PROVIDE NECESSARY INFORMATION TO THE USFWS, WDFW, AND COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT RECOVERY PROGRAM AND SCIENCE TEAM TO UNDERSTAND ANNUAL POPULATION STATUS AND PROPERLY MANAGE CAPTIVE PROPAGATION IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE RECOVERY  THE UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO  UI  HAS LONG BEEN A PARTICIPANT IN THE COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT RECOVERY EFFORTS AND MEMBER OF THE SCIENCE TEAM  OBJECTIVE 1 OF THIS GRANT IS TO CONDUCT GENETIC MONITORING AT RELEASE SITES TO GATHER CRITICAL DEMOGRAPHIC DATA INCLUDING  DETECTING AND COUNTING THE NUMBER OF RABBITS IN THE REINTRODUCTION AREA, EVALUATING SEX RATIOS, APPARENT SURVIVAL RATES AND REPRODUCTION OF RELEASED RABBITS AND RABBITS BORN IN THE WILD AND EVALUATE ALTERNATIVE SAMPLING APPROACHES AND SEASONS FOR GENETIC MONITORING  OBJECTIVE 2 IS TO USE GENETIC MONITORING DATA TO EVALUATE GENETIC PARAMETERS INCLUDING EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE, GENETIC DIVERSITY AND THE PROPORTION OF COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT ANCESTRY IN WILD POPULATION AND THE CAPTIVE BREEDING ENCLOSURES  GENETIC SAMPLES WILL BE COLLECTED FROM RABBITS THROUGH A COMBINATION OF FECAL DNA SAMPLING AND TRAPPING OF INDIVIDUALS  GENETIC DATA WILL BE COLLECTED USING A GTSEQ SNP ANALYSIS OF 250 500 LOCI  RESULTS WILL BE PROVIDED TO MANAGERS MULTIPLE TIMES PER YEAR AT RECOVERY TEAM MEETINGS AND IN WRITTEN REPORTS

HURON PINES AMERICORPS WILL PROVIDE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WHO WILL WORK IN THE MICHIGAN FIELD OFFICE ON ENDANGERED SPECIES OUTREACH AND EDUCATION. THE HURON PINES AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON ENDANGERED SPECIES AND CONSERVATION CAREER AWARENESS TARGETED TO GRADE AND/OR MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS IN THE LANSING, ML AREA. OUTREACH MATERIALS MAY ALSO TARGET THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND/OR CONSERVATION ORGANIZATIONS. THE USFWS WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED BY PARTICIPATING AND COLLABORATING WITH THE RECIPIENT IN IMPLEMENTING THIS PROJECT. SPECIFICALLY THE USFWS WILL ASSIST IN INTERVIEWING AND SELECTING THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS AND PROVIDE REGULAR ON-SITE SUPERVISION OF THE AMERICORPS MEMBERS IN ORDER TO GUIDE, DEVELOP, AND IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT. THE USFWS WILL ALSO PROVIDE TRAINING TO AMERICORPS MEMBERS ON THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT AND MICHIGAN'S ENDANGERED SPECIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL HELP DEVELOP A MONITORING PROGRAM TO EVALUATE RIVERSCAPE HEALTH AND VALIDATE REMOTE SENSING INFORMATION ON RIPARIAN EXTENT. WE WILL ALSO COLLABORATE AND PROVIDE GIS ANALYTICAL WITH THE LCT HABITAT CORE TEAM TO SYNTHESIZE MULTI-SCALAR INFORMATION TO INFORM MONITORING, CONSERVATION, AND RESTORATION PLANNING. THIS WORK WILL BE DOCUMENTED IN REPORTS AND PEER-REVIEWED ARTICLES.

WHITE-NOSE SYNDROME IS A FUNGAL DISEASE RESPONSIBLE FOR UNPRECEDENTED MORTALITY IN HIBERNATING BATS IN NORTH AMERICA. THIS DISEASE HAS SPREAD VERY RAPIDLY SINCE ITS DISCOVERY IN 2007. THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE IS LEADING A MULTI-ORGANIZATIONAL EFFORT TO INVESTIGATE AND MANAGE WNS. GIVEN THE COMPLEXITY OF THE RESPONSE TO THIS DISEASE, A HIGHLY COORDINATED EFFORT IS REQUIRED FOR STATE, FEDERAL, AND TRIBAL WILDLIFE AGENCIES, AND PRIVATE PARTNERS TO RESPOND EFFECTIVELY TO WNS AND CONSERVE BATS.THE SERVICE AND THE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT INSTITUTE RECOGNIZE THE NEED FOR FACILITATION OF MULTI-STATE AND INTERNATIONAL CONSERVATION SCIENCE CENTERED ON FISH AND WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND HABITAT CONSERVATION AND MANAGEMENT CONSISTENT WITH A LANDSCAPE CONSERVATION APPROACH. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO SUPPORT THE OVERALL GOALS OF THE WNS NATIONAL RESPONSE TO FACILITATE CONSERVATION SCIENCE AND ENHANCE COMMUNICATION AMONG PARTNERS IN SETTING COMMON GOALS AND ASSESSING COMMON SCIENCE NEEDS. FUNDS FOR THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH, INFORMATION MANAGEMENT, COMMUNICATION, AND TRAVEL TO FACILITATE ALL OF THE ABOVE.

THE GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER NEST MONITORING IN MICHIGAN'S EASTERN UPPER PENINSULA PROJECT CONDUCTS ANNUAL HABITAT SURVEYS ON SITES KNOWN TO HAVE PIPING PLOVER NESTING ACTIVITY (HISTORIC OR RECENT) AS WELL AS SITES WITH POTENTIAL HABITAT TO IDENTIFY ADDITIONAL NESTING PAIRS, AND TO ASSESS FUTURE MANAGEMENT NEEDS FOR THE SPECIES ALONG GREAT LAKES SHORELINES OF THE EASTERN UPPER PENINSULA OF MICHIGAN. THE GREAT LAKES POPULATION OF PIPING PLOVERS WAS LISTED AS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN 1986, AND THE POPULATION REMAINS EXTREMELY VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION DUE TO BOTH NATURAL AND ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES. SPECIFIC THREATS INCLUDE PREDATION, NEST ABANDONMENT, CONTINUED SHORELINE DEVELOPMENT, HUMAN DISTURBANCE AND INTERFERENCE WITH NESTING ACTIVITIES, INVASIVE PLANTS ENCROACHING ON NESTING HABITAT, AND ENVIRONMENTAL STOCHASTICITY. AT THE CURRENT POPULATION LEVEL, THE REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS OF EACH BREEDING PAIR IS CRITICALLY IMPORTANT TO THE RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES; THEREFORE, INTENSE MONITORING OF NESTS AND ON THE GROUND SURVEYS FOR POTENTIAL HABITAT IS NECESSARY. LED BY LAKE SUPERIOR STATE UNIVERSITY, A MONITORING TEAM OF FACULTY AND STUDENT RESEARCHERS MONITOR AND COLLECT DATA ON PIPING PLOVER NESTING ACTIVITY AT MULTIPLE SITES ALONG THE SHORES OF THE GREAT LAKES THROUGHOUT THE NESTING SEASON. UPON LOCATING A NEST, EXCLOSURES ARE ERECTED AND INCUBATION IS MONITORED DAILY TO ASSURE BOTH PARENTS ARE PRESENT. IN CASES OF ABANDONMENT EGGS ARE REMOVED WITH PERMISSION OF USFWS AND TRANSPORTED TO A CAPTIVE REARING FACILITY. BOTH ADULTS AND CHICKS ARE CENSUSED DAILY UNTIL FLEDGING OCCURS SO THAT ACCURATE POPULATION ESTIMATES AT THE END OF THE BREEDING SEASON CAN BE MADE.
A TEAM OF SCIENTISTS WILL MAKE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A MANUAL ON HOW TO COLLECT THE COMAL SPRINGS RIFFLE  BEETLE FROM THE WILD AND CARE FOR THEM IN CAPTIVITY.

BY LEVERAGING ARCHBOLD'S EXISTING RELATIONSHIPS WITHIN THE SENTINEL LANDSCAPE AND BEYOND, THIS  PARTNERSHIP BUILDS ON REGIONAL SUCCESSES TO INFORM CLASSIFICATION, RECOVERY AND REGULATORY DECISIONS AND  PROMOTE MISSION FLEXIBILITY AND MILITARY READINESS AT AVON PARK AIR FORCE RANGE (APAFR). ARCHBOLD  BIOLOGICAL STATION WILL:  1. LEAD POPULATION MONITORING AND RESEARCH EFFORTS FOR THREE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES  AT APAFR: FLORIDA GRASSHOPPER SPARROW (FGSP), FLORIDA SCRUB-JAY (FSJ), AND RED-COCKADED  WOODPECKER (RCW). POPULATION MONITORING SERVICES WILL INCLUDE PROVIDING ESTIMATES OF  POPULATION SIZE AND OCCUPIED HABITAT AND MAY INCLUDE BANDING AND RESIGHTING TO ESTIMATE  SURVIVAL, PRODUCTIVITY, AND OTHER DEMOGRAPHIC METRICS. MONITORING ALSO MAY INCLUDE NEST  SEARCHING AND MONITORING.  2. ASSESS HABITAT QUALITY FOR THESE SPECIES AND PROVIDE MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO IMPROVE  HABITAT QUALITY, QUANTITY, AND INCREASE DISPERSAL.  3. LEAD POPULATION MANAGEMENT, INCLUDING INTER- AND/OR INTRA- POPULATION TRANSLOCATIONS FOR RCWS  AND FGSPS AS AGREED UPON WITH USFWS, AND NEST PROTECTION FOR FGSPS.  4. LEAD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT FOR RCWS INCLUDING THE INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF ARTIFICIAL  NEST CAVITIES FOR RCWS.  5. PARTICIPATE IN REGIONAL CONSERVATION PLANNING THROUGH NUMEROUS LONG-TERM AND ONGOING  RELATIONSHIPS AND COLLABORATIONS.  6. EMPLOY ITS SOCIAL MEDIA NETWORKS AND ITS LONG-ESTABLISHED CONNECTIONS WITHIN THE LOCAL  COMMUNITY AND WITH SCIENCE JOURNALISTS TO HIGHLIGHT APAFR'S ROLE IN SUCCESSFUL, COLLABORATIVE CONSERVATION AND THE LOCAL, REGIONAL, NATIONAL, AND INTERNATIONAL IMPLICATIONS OF THOSE SUCCESSES.  7. ASSIST USFWS PERSONNEL WITH RESEARCH AND CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES.  DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE:  1. COPIES OF RELATIONAL DATABASES WITH QUERIES TO SUMMARIZE BANDING ACTIVITIES, POPULATION  MONITORING, ESTIMATES OF SURVIVAL, PRODUCTIVITY, AND DISPERSAL WHERE POSSIBLE, AND POPULATION OR  RESOURCE MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES COMPLETED.  2. REPORTS SUMMARIZING THE RESULTS OF THE HABITAT ASSESSMENTS AND HABITAT MANAGEMENT  RECOMMENDATIONS BASED ON THESE ASSESSMENTS.  3. UP-TO-DATE LOCATIONS OF INDIVIDUALS, THEIR NESTS, OR CAVITIES, SHARED ON ARCGIS ONLINE WITH USFWS  AND APAFR ENVIRONMENTAL FLIGHT STAFF.  4. SECTIONS OF COMPONENT PLANS FOR FGSPS, FSJS, AND RCWS INCLUDING SPECIES-SPECIFIC CURRENT STATUS,  MANAGEMENT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES, SPECIES-LEVEL MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT, AND HABITAT-LEVEL  MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT.  THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS WORK ARE:  1. CURRENT INFORMATION ON THE POPULATION SIZE AND POPULATION TRENDS OF FGSPS, FSJS, AND RCWS ON  APAFR.  2. CURRENT INFORMATION ON HABITAT QUALITY AND IMPROVED HABITAT MANAGEMENT FOR FGSPS, FSJS, AND  RCWS. 3. PROGRESS TOWARD RECOVERY GOALS FOR FGSPS, FSJS, AND RCWS.  4. DEVELOPMENT OF COMPONENT PLANS THAT PROMOTE SPECIES RECOVERY AND PROVIDE MISSION FLEXIBILITY  AT APAFR.  THIS WORK WILL HELP USFWS MEET RECOVERY GOALS FOR FGSP, FSJ, AND RCW AT APAFR. HEALTHY POPULATIONS OF  THESE SPECIES PROVIDE MISSION FLEXIBILITY FOR THE US DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE ENABLING THEM TO TRAIN AND  MAINTAIN MILITARY READINESS. ARCHBOLD ADVANCES ITS MISSION BY CONDUCTING THE SCIENCE THAT PROMOTES ON  THE GROUND CONSERVATION.

BULL TROUT HAVE BEEN LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT IN THE US AND THE SPECIES AT RISK ACT IN CANADA. IN RECENT DECADES, VARIOUS CONSERVATION MEASURES AND MANAGEMENT ACTIONS HAVE BEEN DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED TO PROMOTE INFORMED RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES AND POPULATIONS. THESE ACTIONS WERE DEVELOPED BASED ON UNDERSTANDING OF HABITAT NEEDS, DEMOGRAPHIC CHARACTERISTICS, THREATS, AND POTENTIAL LIMITING FACTORS OF THE SPECIES AT THE TIME. HOWEVER, BULL TROUT REMAIN LISTED AS THREATENED AND DEBATE SURROUNDING RECOVERY OF THE SPECIES CONTINUES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT BETWEEN U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND GAME (IDFG) IS TO FACILITATE IMPROVED COORDINATION ON BULL TROUT CONSERVATION WITHIN IDAHO. THE AGREEMENT WILL SUPPORT A BULL TROUT RECOVERY COORDINATOR POSITION OPERATED BY IDFG WHICH WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY WITH THE IDAHO BULL TROUT LEAD FOR THE USFWS. PRIMARY OBJECTIVES FOR THE COLLABORATIVE EFFORT INCLUDE FACILITATION OF BULL TROUT WORK GROUPS ACROSS THE STATE, UPDATING IDAHO BULL TROUT STATUS WITHIN THE SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT FRAMEWORK, REPRESENTING IDAHO BULL TROUT STATUS AND OBJECTIVES IN LARGE RANGE-WIDE FORUMS, AND IMPROVING COORDINATION AND PRIORITIZING OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS

THE PAHRANAGAT ROUNDTAIL CHUB (GILA ROBUSTA JORDANI) IS ENDEMIC TO SPRING WATERS IN THEPAHRANAGAT VALLEY, NV AND WAS LISTED AS ENDANGERED IN 1970. HABITAT SURVEYS HAVE ESTABLISHED THE NEEDFOR A PERMANENT REFUGIA FOR ROUNDTAIL CHUB. AS A RESULT, THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE(USFWS) HAS TRIED TO ESTABLISH A REFUGIUM AT THE COTTONWOOD SPRING POND. HOWEVER, CERTAIN BIOLOGICALAND/OR GEOCHEMICAL CONDITIONS DEVELOP ACUTELY AT THIS SPRING AND POND THAT ARE NOT CONDUCIVE TOPROLONGED FISH SURVIVAL. A POPULATION OF ROUNDTAIL CHUB WAS ESTABLISHED AT NEVADA DEPARTMENT OFWILDLIFE'S (NDOW) KEY PITTMAN WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREA (KPWMA) IN 2004. USFWS HAS MADE TWOATTEMPTS TO ESTABLISH A POPULATION OF ROUNDTAIL CHUB AT COTTONWOOD SPRING ON PAHRANAGAT NATIONALWILDLIFE REFUGE (PNW), AND EACH REINTRODUCTION EXPERIENCED SIGNIFICANT DECLINES. EXTENSIVE EVALUATION OFWATER QUALITY AND HABITAT AT BOTH KPWMA AND COTTONWOOD SPRING WILL PROVIDE FURTHER INSIGHT INTO THECONDITIONS THAT ARE CONDUCIVE TO THE HEALTH OF ROUNDTAIL CHUB AT EACH LOCATION. USFWS SERVICE HASCONDUCTED OFF AND ON SAMPLING PROGRAMS TO EVALUATE WHICH BIOLOGICAL AND/OR GEOCHEMICAL CONDITIONSTHAT MIGHT BE RELATED TO POOR WATER QUALITY AND WHEN THESE CONDITIONS MIGHT OCCUR. NDOW AND USFWSHAVE COMPLETED SAMPLING AROUND THESE ANOXIC TIME PERIODS, HOWEVER, THERE IS A NEED TO INCREASE THESAMPLING RESOLUTION AND PROVIDE A GREATER SUITE OF BIOLOGICAL AND GEOCHEMICAL ANALYTES TO BETTERUNDERSTAND HOW AND WHY DO DECREASES RAPIDLY AND DRAMATICALLY.

SARETT NATURE CENTER (SNC) WILL COORDINATE HABITAT MANAGEMENT EFFORTS ON SIX OF THE NINE REMAINING MITCHELL'S SATYR (MS) SITES IN SOUTHERN MICHIGAN. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES RECOVERY GOALS FOR THE MS, A FEDERALLY LISTED BUTTERFLY SPECIES, BY UNDERTAKING LAND MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING OBJECTIVES OUTLINED INTHE MS CONSERVATION STRATEGY CREATED BY THE MS WORKING GROUP. THE SIX PRIORITIZED SITES WILL BE MANAGED TO INCREASE THE QUALITY OF EXISTING AND POTENTIAL BREEDING HABITAT.

THE CAPTIVE BREEDING COLONY OF AMARGOSA VOLES AT UC DAVIS HAS SERVED AS AN INSURANCE COLONY AGAINST EXTINCTION IN THE WILD, AS A VALUABLE SOURCE OF DATA ON THE BIOLOGY OF THE SPECIES, AND AS A SOURCE OF INDIVIDUALS TO BE REINTRODUCED INTO THE WILD. HOWEVER, SUCCESSFULLY REINTRODUCING VOLES APPEARS TO REQUIRE AN ELABORATE PROCESS OF PAIRING A CAPTIVE VOLE WITH A WILD VOLE FOR A RELATIVELY PROLONGED PERIOD IN CAPTIVITY, AND THEN PERFORMING A VERY GRADUAL SOFT RELEASE OF THE PAIR AT THE INTENDED SITE. THE COST-BENEFIT BALANCE TO THIS ACTIVITY DEPENDS ON HOW MANY RESOURCES ARE AVAILABLE FOR MANAGING THE COLONY, AVAILABILITY OF WILD ANIMALS PERIODICALLY TO SUPPORT COLONY GENETIC VARIABILITY, AND HOW STABLE WILD POPULATIONS ARE. AS OF EARLY 2022, WILD POPULATIONS APPEAR VERY SMALL BUT STABLE IN THE SHORT TERM. DUE TO THE VERY SMALL POPULATION SIZE, BLM (THE MAJOR LANDOWNER) HAS DECLINED TO ALLOW WILD VOLES TO BE REMOVED TO THE COLONY. IMPORTANTLY, GIVEN WHAT WE HAVE LEARNED ABOUT MAINTAINING THIS SPECIES IN CAPTIVITY, A NEW COLONY COULD BE QUICKLY RECONSTITUTED IN THE FUTURE IF NEEDED. AS SUCH, THE PRESENT PLAN IS TO STEP DOWN THE COLONY THROUGH RELEASES INTO THE WILD, SIMULTANEOUSLY OBTAINING DATA ON IMPACTS OF A RAPID FLUX OF VOLES ON NONNATIVE HOUSE MICE, WHICH ARE EXPANDING IN NUMBERS AND RANGE AMONG TECOPA MARSHES. PROPOSED WORK WE WILL STEP DOWN THE CAPTIVE BREEDING COLONY AT UC DAVIS OVER 2022 AND INTO EARLY 2023. THIS WILL BE DONE OVER 3-6 RELEASES VIA THE FOLLOWING STEPS: -AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE, PREPARE COLONY VOLES FOR THE WILD THROUGH EXPOSURE TO WILD FOOD SOURCES. THEY WILL BE GIVEN A SELECTION OF WILD FOODS FOR THE FIVE DAYS THEY ARE HELD IN CAGES PRIOR TO THEIR RELEASE. -PRE-SURVEY RELEASE AND DONOR MARSHES FOR HABITAT QUALITY, WATER DEPTH, HOUSE MOUSE NUMBERS, AND VOLE NUMBERS. MONITORING SPECIFIC TO A GIVEN RELEASE EVENT WILL BE DONE APPROXIMATELY 2-4 WEEKS PRIOR TO PROJECTED RELEASE DATES TO ENSURE HABITAT SUITABILITY BY ESTIMATING THE PERCENT OF BULRUSH COVER, AVERAGE PLANT HEIGHT, LITTER DEPTH, LITTER DENSITY, AND AVERAGE WATER DEPTH WITHIN THE CANDIDATE MARSH. IN ADDITION, THE MARSH WILL BE ASSESSED FOR RESIDENT RODENTS. -PAIR-BOND AS MANY COLONY VOLES AS POSSIBLE WITH WILD VOLES (WILD VOLE NUMBERS LIMITING) AND USE SOFT-RELEASE OF ALL VOLES INTO UNOCCUPIED SOUTHERN VOLES. -RELEASE COLONY VOLES AND BONDED MATES IN LARGE NUMBERS EACH RELEASE WITH THE GOAL OF POTENTIALLY ALLOWING VOLES TO OUTCOMPETE MICE. -EVALUATE POST RELEASE SURVIVAL WITH BIOMARK READERS, CAMERAS, AND TRAPPING SURVEYS; EVALUATE DIFFERENTIAL SURVIVAL AMONG TRANSLOCATED PAIRED COLONY VOLES, UNPAIRED COLONY VOLES, AND WILD VOLES. EVALUATE IMPACTS OF RELEASE ON HOUSE MOUSE AND VOLE SUBPOPULATIONS BY TRAPPING SHORTLY AFTER RELEASE, AND ONE MONTH AFTER RELEASE, WE WILL CONDUCT ANOTHER FOUR DAY LIVE-TRAPPING SURVEY. KAPLAN-MEIER SURVIVAL ANALYSIS. -CAMERA TRAPS WILL BE PLACED AT RELEASE CAGES AND BIOMARK READERS AT THE EDGES OF THE MARSH. PLAN STATES MONITOR FOR 3 MONTHS MINIMUM. THESE WILL MONITOR GENERAL MARSH USE AND POTENTIAL CAPTURE DISPERSAL EVENTS.

THE MAIN GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO RESTORE DEGRADED DESERT TORTOISE HABITAT SITES WITHIN THE BLM LANDS IN THE CHUCKWALLA BENCH, LOCATED WITHIN THE DESERT TORTOISE COLORADO DESERT RECOVERY UNIT. THESE AREAS ARE DEGRADED DUE TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND HISTORICAL ECOSYSTEM MANIPULATION DUE TO THE CONSTRUCTION OF RUN-OFF CONTAINMENT AREAS THAT WERE CONSTRUCTED ALONG INTERSTATE 10 THAT REDUCES AVAILABLE FORAGING SOURCES TO THE TORTOISE IN SOME OF THE AREA. OUR PROJECT AIMS TO RESTORE DESERT TORTOISE HABITAT IN THE EQUIVALENT OF 3 ACRES THAT HAVE BEEN DEGRADED IN THE CHUCKWALLA CRITICAL HABITAT UNIT. THE PROJECT WILL ANALYZE THE IMPACTS OF MANUALLY PLANTING NATIVE PERENNIAL SPECIES IN PREVIOUSLY DISTURBED AREAS, IMPLEMENTING THE BEST PRACTICES OF PLANNING FOR WATER RETENTION AND ACQUISITION OF THE PLANTS, AND THUS MAXIMIZING THEIR LIKELIHOOD OF SURVIVAL. THE PROJECT WILL MONITOR INVASIVE PLANT REESTABLISHMENT, THE SURVIVAL OF THE PLANTED NATIVE FORAGE SPECIES, AND THE SUCCESS OF SEEDED ANNUALS FOR TWO YEARS.THE SECONDARY GOAL IS TO CREATE A SIMILAR PLAN FOR IMPLEMENTING THIS APPROACH ACROSS OTHER IMPORTANT BLM LANDS IN THE ENTIRE DESERT TORTOISE RECOVERY UNIT TO INCREASE NATIVE PLANT COVER, THEREBY IMPROVING THE OVERALL HABITAT CONDITIONS FOR THE SPECIES.

THE CAMP SHELBY BURROWING CRAYFISH (CSBC) WAS RECENTLY REMOVED FROM A LIST OF CANDIDATES FOR THREATENED OR ENDANGERED STATUS ON THE CONDITION THAT THE MISSISSIPPI NATIONAL GUARD (MSARNG) AND THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE (USFS) MONITOR POPULATIONS AND MANAGE THEIR HABITAT. DATA FROM THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) ON THE CSBC HAS INDICATED POSSIBLE POPULATION DECLINES, POTENTIALLY DUE TO DECLINING HABITAT QUALITY (LYMAN AND LEE 2020). AS PITCHER PLANT ABUNDANCE IS A POTENTIAL INDICATOR OF APPROPRIATE CSBC HABITAT QUALITY, A REDUCTION IN BURNING RESULTING IN INCREASED SHRUBBY HABITAT AND FEWER PITCHER PLANTS COULD POSSIBLY EXPLAIN DECLINES. AS WE LACK RECENT DATA ON THE POPULATION STATUS ACROSS THE CSBC DISTRIBUTION, BURROW AND CHIMNEY COUNTS WILL BE PERFORMED ACROSS THEIR RANGE TO DETERMINE IF THE SPECIES IS STILL PRESENT AT ITS HISTORICAL SITES. THE GOALS OF THIS SURVEY WILL BE TO 1) ESTIMATE BURROW AND CHIMNEY DENSITY, 2) VISIT HISTORICAL SITES OF OCCURRENCE TO DETERMINE IF THE SPECIES IS STILL PRESENT, 3) BROADLY CATEGORIZE THE VEGETATION AND QUALITY OF THE SITE, 4) ESTIMATE THE AREA OCCUPIED BY THE SPECIES IN AND AROUND EACH HISTORICAL SITE, AND 5) NOTE PROBLEMS OR ISSUES WITH THE SITES.

MITCHELL'S SATYR BUTTERFLY (MSB) (NEONYMPHA MITCHELLI MITCHELLI) PROPAGATION WAS IDENTIFIED AS A CRITICAL CONSERVATION ACTION BY THEMSB RECOVERY PLAN. EX SITU PROPAGATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO AUGMENT EXISTING MSB POPULATIONS THAT ARE CURRENTLY IN DECLINE AND REINTRODUCE NEW MSB POPULATIONS INTO UNOCCUPIED, SUITABLE HABITAT. THE KALAMAZOO NATURE CENTER HAS BEEN PERMITTED TO COLLECT UP TO TEN FEMALE AND TEN MALE MSB ADULTS FOR PROPAGATION PURPOSES BY THE USFWS, WHOSE OFFSPRING WILL BE USED FOR AUGMENTATION AFTER METAMORPHOSING TO ADULTHOOD IN CAPTIVITY. THIS FUNDING SUPPORTS THIS WORK THROUGH STAFFING AND SUPPLIES.

THE TOLEDO ZOO HAS BEEN WORKING WITH THE MITCHELL'S SATYR BUTTERFLY (MSB), NEONYMPHYA MITCHELLII MITCHELLII, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE MITCHELL'S SATYR WORKING GROUP (MSWG) SINCE 2003. HUSBRANDY AND BREEDING PROTOCOLS WERE DEVELOPED THROUGH WORKING WITH THE EYED-BROWN, SATYRODES EURYDICE, AND IMPLEMENTED WITH THE MSB. IN A BIO-SECURE REARING FACILITY, THE TOLEDO ZOO MAINTAINS A CAPTIVE BREEDING POPULATION OF MSBS AS WELL AS REARS MSBS FROM EGG TO ADULT FOR AUGMENTATION AND REINTRODUCTIONS.THESE FUNDS WILL ALLOW TOLEDO ZOO TO MAINTAIN THE CAPTIVE BREEDING POPULATION OF MITCHELL'S SATYRS AS WELL AS S UPPORT THEIR EFFORTS TO BREED AND REAR BUTTERFLIES FROM EGG TO ADULT FOR RELEASE FOR THE 2022 FIELD SEASON. THE GOAL IS TO AUGMENT MITCHELL'S SATYR POPULATIONS AS WELL AS REINTRODUCE MITCHELL'S SATYRS TO NEW SITES TO REDUCE THE RISK OF EXTINCTION OF THIS ENDANGERED ANIMAL.

TAYLOR'S CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLIES ARE A FEDERALLY-LISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES. CAPTIVE REARING OF THESE  BUTTERFLIES - ALREADY PROVEN SUCCESSFUL IN WASHINGTON STATE - GREATLY INCREASES POTENTIAL SURVIVORSHIP  AND PROVIDES A SOURCE FOR MAINTAINING AND ENHANCING THE EXISTING WILD POPULATION IN OREGON.  COFFEE CREEK CORRECTIONAL FACILITY (CCCF) HAS DEDICATED SPACE AND STAFF TO FEED AND REAR TAYLOR'S  CHECKERSPOT BUTTERFLIES AND TO PROPAGATE THE HOST PLANT THAT IS NEEDED FOR BUTTERFLY EGG-LAYING AND LARVAL  CONSUMPTION. GRANT FUNDS ALLOW FOR THE STAFF TO HAVE PROPER SUPERVISION FROM A PROFESSIONAL TRAINED IN  ANIMAL HUSBANDRY WHO CAN CONTINUALLY EVALUATE THE REARING METHODS AND EQUIPMENT BEING USED TO  ADDRESS AND REMEDY ANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGES IN SURVIVORSHIP, AND TO DOCUMENT AND MODIFY THE REARING  PROTOCOLS AS NEEDED. SUPERVISION ALSO PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY TO EDUCATE THE ADULTS IN CUSTODY (AICS)  WHO SERVE AS STAFF, AND IT PROVIDES THEM WITH EXPERIENCE TO BE USED WHEN SEEKING EMPLOYMENT UPON  RELEASE.  THIS PROJECT CREATES MEANINGFUL JOBS FOR AICS WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY MAXIMIZING BOTH THE EGG-LAYING OF  ADULT TAYLOR'S CHECKERSPOTS BROUGHT IN FOR CAPTIVE CULTURE AND THE SURVIVORSHIP OF THE SUBSEQUENT STAGES  OF DEVELOPMENT OF THE EGGS THROUGH LARVAL INSTARS AND PUPATION. THE MORE OFFSPRING AVAILABLE FOR  RELEASE, THE MORE LIKELY THE TAYLOR'S CHECKERSPOTS WILL BE ABLE TO ESTABLISH THEMSELVES AS A SELF-SUSTAINING  POPULATION IN OREGON - A GOAL THAT MAY TAKE SEVERAL YEARS TO ESTABLISH. THE PROPOSED CAPTIVE REARING FOR  2022-2023 IS A CONTINUATION OF ON-GOING EFFORTS THAT HAVE ALREADY DEMONSTRATED HIGH SURVIVORSHIP OF  TAYLOR'S CHECKERSPOTS, WITH SEVERAL HUNDRED LARVAE AND PUPAE SUCCESSFULLY RELEASED EACH YEAR OVER THE  PAST FIVE YEARS.

THIS PROJECT EXPANDS ON CURRENT RPBB SURVEY EFFORTS PERFORMED BY MICHIGAN NATURAL FEATURES INVENTORY  (MNFI) IN MICHIGAN AND PREVIOUS EFFORTS TO DESCRIBE SPECIES DIVERSITY, DISTRIBUTION, AND CONSERVATION  STATUS FOR MICHIGAN'S BUMBLE BEES (ROWE ET AL. 2019). DECLINES IN RPBB ACROSS THIS SPECIES HISTORIC RANGE  HAVE RESULTED IN A NATIONAL EFFORT TO RECOVER THE SPECIES TO A HEALTHY AND STABLE REPRESENTATION OF  HISTORIC POPULATION LEVELS (USFWS 2021). A PRIMARY FOCUS OF THE RPBB RECOVERY PLAN INCLUDES IDENTIFYING  EXTANT POPULATIONS OF RPBB THROUGHOUT THE SPECIES' HISTORIC RANGE TO PREVENT FURTHER SPECIES LOSS AND TO  BUFFER AGAINST EXPOSURE TO HARMFUL ENVIRONMENTAL PRESSURES, SUCH AS PESTICIDES AND PATHOGENS. THIS  PROJECT AIMS TO IDENTIFY EXTANT POPULATIONS OF RPBB IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION (CONSERVATION UNIT 3),  WHICH IS A NECESSARY FIRST STEP TO EVENTUAL DELISTING OF THE SPECIES (RECOVERY ACTION 4: ASSESS POPULATION  AND HABITAT STATUS AND TRENDS THROUGH MONITORING AND SURVEYS). THIS PROJECT PROVIDES THE FRAMEWORK NECESSARY TO CONTINUE MONITORING AT-RISK BUMBLE BEE SPECIES IN MICHIGAN, OHIO, AND INDIANA AND ALLOWS  FOR THE EVALUATION OF UNDER-SURVEYED LOCATIONS HISTORICALLY OCCUPIED BY RPBB. IF DISCOVERED, HABITAT AND  STRESSOR ASSESSMENTS WOULD PROVIDE SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS TO LAND MANAGERS THAT  WOULD IMPROVE ON THE GROUND HABITAT FOR THIS SPECIES, WHICH IS A PRIMARY STEP TO IMPROVING SPECIES  POPULATION VIABILITY.  FURTHERMORE, TO ACHIEVE THE GOALS OF THE RPBB SPECIES RECOVERY PLAN, ENGAGEMENT FROM THE GENERAL  PUBLIC IS ESSENTIAL. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS THE RECOVERY PLAN BY 1) PROVIDING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION TO THE  PUBLIC AND LAND MANAGERS TO GARNER SUPPORT FOR HABITAT CONSERVATION AT LOCAL AND REGIONAL LEVELS IN  MICHIGAN, 2) ENGAGING THE PUBLIC TO GARNER SUPPORT FOR RPBB CONSERVATION, AND 3) ENGAGING THE PUBLIC IN  RPBB (AND OTHER ASSOCIATED RARE SPECIES OF BUMBLE BEES) MONITORING AND SURVEY EFFORTS THROUGH  COMMUNITY SCIENCE. MICHIGAN CURRENTLY LACKS A COORDINATED COMMUNITY-BASED EFFORT TO MONITOR  POPULATIONS OF AT-RISK BUMBLE BEE SPECIES. SUCH EFFORTS WOULD INCREASE POTENTIAL FOR A STATEWIDE  SAMPLING FOOTPRINT, ALLOWING SURVEYS TO BE CONDUCTED ACROSS MANY UNIQUE HABITAT TYPES DURING BUMBLE  BEE FLIGHT SEASON, AND WOULD SPAN FROM URBAN LANDSCAPES TO PRISTINE NATURAL AREAS (RICHARDSON ET AL.  2019). IMPORTANTLY, SURVEYING THIS BROAD RANGE OF HABITATS ALLOWS FOR DOCUMENTATION OF KEY HABITATS TO  FOCUS BUMBLE BEE CONSERVATION AND HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS, INCLUDING FOCAL HABITATS OUTLINED IN  MICHIGAN'S WAP (PRAIRIES AND SAVANNAS, FENS, DRY NORTHERN FOREST & PINE BARRENS). THIS PROJECT UTILIZES  AN ATLAS APPROACH TO BUMBLE BEE MONITORING ACROSS MICHIGAN, APPLYING AN ESTABLISHED MONITORING  FRAMEWORK TO A STATE LACKING SUCH EFFORT.  THIS PROJECT HAS TWO PRIMARY GOALS: 1) TO COMPLETE STANDARDIZED BUMBLE BEE COMMUNITY SURVEYS  THROUGHOUT THE STATES OF MICHIGAN, OHIO, AND INDIANA, PRIORITIZING EFFORTS IN LOCATIONS WITH HISTORIC  RECORDS OF RPBB, AND 2) TO DEVELOP A COMMUNITY DRIVEN BUMBLE BEE ATLAS PROJECT TO ENGAGE WITH THE  PUBLIC ON BUMBLE BEE EDUCATION, SURVEYING, AND CONSERVATION ACROSS THE STATE OF MICHIGAN.

THE GREAT LAKES POPULATION OF PIPING PLOVERS IS FEDERALLY ENDANGERED AND THIS PROJECT IS AN ONGOING EFFORT TO INCREASE THENUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION TO THAT REQUIRED TO DELIST THE POPULATION. AT THE TIME OF LISTING IN THE MID-1980S, ESTIMATED POPULATION SIZE WAS 12-17 PAIRS. IN 2021, THE POPULATION WAS ESTIMATED AT 71 PAIRS; DELISTING CAN BE EVALUATED WHEN THE POPULATION REACHES 150 PAIRS IN THE U.S. DESPITE THE INCREASE IN BREEDING PAIRS SINCE LISTING, ONGOING EFFORT IS REQUIRED TO PROTECT INDIVIDUAL NESTING PAIRS ON AN ANNUAL BASIS FOR RECOVERY TO BE ACHIEVED. THIS PROPOSED WORK WILL CONTRIBUTE TO RECOVERY BY MEETING THE FOLLOWING GENERAL GOALS AND OBJECTIVES IN 2022-23: (1) PROTECT AND MONITOR ALL KNOWN PIPING PLOVER NESTS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION; (2) ESTIMATE GREAT LAKES PIPING PLOVER POPULATION SIZE (NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS) AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS (CHICKS FLEDGED/PAIR). (3) DOCUMENT DISTRIBUTION OF BREEDING PAIRS OF PIPING PLOVERS IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION; (4) BAND ADULT AND CHICK PIPING PLOVERS AND ANALYZE RESIGHTING DATA; (5) DOCUMENT PATTERNS OF NESTLOCATION AND HABITAT USE OVER TIME, INCLUDING IDENTIFICATION OF PLOVER RESPONSE TO CLIMATE CHANGE; (6) USE GENETIC MATERIAL FROM ABANDONED EGGS, FECAL MATERIAL, BLOOD AND CHEEK SAMPLES TO EXAMINE THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF THE GREAT LAKES POPULATION; (7) COOPERATE WITH DETROIT ZOO TO FACILITATE PIPING PLOVER CAPTIVE REARING PROGRAM FOR ABANDONED EGGS AT THEUNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN BIOLOGICAL STATION. DELIVERABLES WILL BE FINAL REPORTS, INCLUDING MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION RECOMMENDATIONS, TO GRANTING AGENCIES AND GREAT LAKES FEDERAL, STATE AND NON-PROFIT PARTNERS. OUTCOME WILL BE PROGRESS TOWARDS RECOVERY WHICH IS DEPENDENT ON ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS BUT AIDED BY ON THE GROUND PROTECTION AND RESEARCH EFFORTS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE FEDERAL AND STATE AGENCIES THAT DEPEND ON STUDY RESULTS TO MAKE MANAGEMENT AND PROTECTION DECISIONS AND CITIZENS OF THE GREAT LAKES AND BEYOND WHO VALUE AND LEARN FROM THE BIODIVERSITY IN NORTH AMERICA.
THIS PROJECT FOCUSES ON RECOVERY ACTIONS AND AQUATIC/HABITAT SURVEYS TO INFORM UNDERSTANDING OF LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT POPULATION STATUS AND TREND, HABITAT CHARACTERISTICS, AND MANAGEMENT.

THE SALT MARSH HARVEST MOUSE (SMHM; REITHRODONTOMYS RAVIVENTRIS) IS A STATE AND FEDERALLY LISTED ENDANGERED  SPECIES THAT IS RESTRICTED TO SALT AND BRACKISH MARSHES OF THE SAN FRANCISCO, SAN PABLO, AND SUISUN BAY AREAS.  HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION OVER THE PAST CENTURY HAVE REDUCED THE MOUSE'S DISTRIBUTION TO <25% OF ITS  HISTORICAL RANGE. HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION LEAD TO SMALL POPULATIONS WITH AN INCREASED RISK OF EXTINCTION  FROM RANDOM CATASTROPHIC EVENTS, WHICH MAY BECOME MORE FREQUENT WITH RISING SEA LEVEL.  THE RECOVERY PLAN FOR THE SMHM STATES THAT THE RANGE OF GENETIC VARIATION WITHIN THE SPECIES MUST BE MAINTAINED  TO MINIMIZE THE RISK OF INBREEDING DEPRESSION AND ALLOW FOR THE FUTURE EVOLUTION AND RESILIENCE TO ENVIRONMENTAL  CHANGE. THE PLAN CLASSIFIES GENETIC ANALYSES TO DETERMINE THE RELATIONSHIP AMONG POPULATIONS AND GENETIC  EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE AS PRIORITY 1.  WE PROPOSE TO CONDUCT A RANGE-WIDE GENOMIC ANALYSIS OF THE SALT MARSH HARVEST MOUSE. THIS HIGHLY RESOLVING  GENOMIC DATASET WILL BE USED TO INVESTIGATE THE POPULATION SUBSTRUCTURE WITHIN THE SPECIES, WHICH WILL IDENTITY  DISTINCT POPULATIONS AS WELL AS THEIR EVOLUTIONARY RELATIONSHIP. IN ADDITION, WE WILL USE THE GENOMIC DATA TO  PROVIDE A GENOME-WIDE ASSESSMENT OF THE DIVERSITY WITHIN POPULATIONS, INCLUDING AN ASSESSMENT OF GENETIC  EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE.  THE RESULTS FROM THESE ANALYSES WILL PROVIDE VITAL AND TIMELY INFORMATION FOR THE CONSERVATION OF THE SPECIES.  THE IDENTIFICATION OF EVOLUTIONARILY DISTINCT POPULATIONS WILL INFORM CONSERVATION PRIORITIZATION TO FACILITATE  THE PRESERVATION OF THE MAXIMUM AMOUNT OF THE SPECIES DIVERSITY. ESTIMATES OF GENETIC EFFECTIVE POPULATION SIZE  WILL IDENTIFY POPULATIONS WITH SMALL SIZE, REDUCED DIVERSITY, AND POTENTIALLY MORE LIMITED EVOLUTIONARY TOOLS TO  COPE WITH NOVEL STRESSORS. SUCH POPULATIONS SHOULD BE PRIORITIZED FOR ENHANCED CONNECTIVITY. WE WILL WORK CLOSELY  WITH RESOURCE AGENCY PARTNERS TO DISSEMINATE THE RESULTS AND IMPLICATIONS OF THIS WORK TO AID IN CONSERVATION OF  THE SALT MARSH HARVEST MOUSE.

THE FEDERALLY ENDANGERED EASTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHID (PLATANTHERA LEUCOPHAEA)OCCURS AT A SINGLE LOCATION IN THE NORTH-ATLANTIC-APPALACHIAN REGION OF THE U.S. FISH & WILDLIFE SERVICE AT THE CRYSTAL BOG PRESERVE OWNED BY THE NATURE CONSERVANCY IN CRYSTAL, MAINE. THE EASTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHID IS ONE OF THE MOST HIGHLY ENDANGERED SPECIES IN THIS REGION. JUST 10 TO 20 PLANTS ARE DOCUMENTED EACH YEAR IN SURVEYS. THIS RECOVERY PROJECT INCLUDES VARIOUS OBJECTIVES TO RESTORE AND IMPROVE EASTERN PRAIRIE FRINGED ORCHID HABITAT WHERE A KNOWN POPULATION OCCURS, TO INCREASE THE POPULATION THROUGH DIRECT SEEDING AND HAND POLLINATION, TO IDENTIFY SUITABLE HABITAT WITHIN CRYSTAL BOG OUTSIDE OF THE KNOWN POPULATION AREA, TO DEVELOP A PRESCRIBED BURN PLAN FOR FUTURE MANAGEMENT, AND TO MONITOR EXISTING HABITAT CONDITIONS. MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES THAT MAY IMPACT THE STATE THREATED CLAYTON'S COPPER BUTTERFLY (LYCAENA DORCAS CLAYTONI) OR ITS HOST PLANT, SHRUBBY CINQUEFOIL (POTENTILLA FRUTICOSA) WILL BE DISCUSSED WITH MAINE DEPARTMENT OF INLAND FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE.

FURBISH'S LOUSEWORT (PEDICULARIS FURBISHIAE) IS A FEDERALLY ENDANGERED HERBACEOUS PERENNIAL PLANT THAT OCCURS ONTHE INTERMITTENTLY FLOODED AND ICE-SCOURED BANKS OF THE ST. JOHN RIVER IN NORTHERN MAINE AND SPARSELY SO INADJACENT NEW BRUNSWICK, CANADA. IT IS FOUND NOWHERE ELSE IN THE WORLD. THE ENTIRE POPULATION IS COMPRISED OFABOUT 20 SUBPOPULATIONS ASSOCIATED WITH PATCHES OF SUITABLE HABITAT THAT OCCUR WITHIN A 225-KM (140-MILE) SECTIONOF THE ST. JOHN RIVER. THE NUMBER OF FLOWERING STEMS HAS BEEN MONITORED SINCE ABOUT 1980 AND IS CURRENTLY AT ORNEAR A 40-YEAR LOW. SIX OF 15 SUBPOPULATIONS IN MAINE HAVE BEEN LOST, ALL IN DOWNRIVER PORTIONS OF THE SPECIES'RANGE. THIS RECOVERY PROJECT INCLUDES VARIOUS OBJECTIVES TO IDENTIFY FURBISH'S LOUSEWORT HABITAT ALONG THE ST.JOHN RIVER AND DEVELOP PLANS IN ANTICIPATION OF REINTRODUCING THE SPECIES AND OR ENHANCING EXISTINGSUBPOPULATIONS. SPECIFICALLY, BROADSCALE EVALUATIONS OF POTENTIAL LOUSEWORT HABITAT IN THE LOWER ST. JOHN RIVERSEGMENTS, AND OTHER UNSTUDIED AREAS UPSTREAM WILL ALLOW THE MAINE NATURAL AREAS PROGRAM (MNAP) TO MAP SUITABLEHABITAT AND IDENTIFY POTENTIAL SITES FOR RESTORING OR INTRODUCING SUBPOPULATIONS OF THE SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY,PLANS WILL BE INITIATED FOR RESTORING OR INTRODUCING FURBISH'S LOUSEWORT OR ENHANCING EXISTING SUBPOPULATIONS FORAT LEAST 4 SITES. TO DO THIS, MNAP AND THE MAINE FIELD OFFICE OF THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL WORKWITH WILLING LANDOWNERS TO EVALUATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION WORK. THIS WORK WILL INCLUDEIDENTIFYING ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS FOR EVALUATING HABITAT QUALITY AS WELL AS STRESSORS AND BARRIERS THAT MAY BELIMITING ESTABLISHMENT OF THE SPECIES AND IDENTIFY NEXT STEPS FOR RESTORING LOUSEWORT IN THESE AREAS.

THIS PROJECT CONSISTS PRIMARILY OF DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING, GPS LOCATION TRACKING, VEGETATION SAMPLING AND ANALYSIS, AND  HABITAT MODELING AND ANALYSIS FOR MULTIPLE RARE PLANT SPECIES ON AVON PARK AIR FORCE RANGE, HIGHLANDS AND POLK COUNTIES,  FLORIDA. OTHER RELATED ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE COMPILATION OF RARE PLANT LOCATION DATA OVER MULTIPLE YEARS OF  SURVEYS, DATA COLLECTION ON NEW OR POORLY KNOWN RARE PLANT SPECIES, AND POST-FIRE MONITORING OF PLANT REGROWTH AND HABITAT  CHANGES IN RELATIONSHIP TO FIRE FREQUENCY AND SEASONALITY. THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE WORK ON THE REGIONAL CONTEXT OF THE  RARE PLANT SPECIES AND HABITATS AT AVON PARK AIR FORCE RANGE, AND THEIR SIGNFICANCE TO THE PRESERVATION OF BIODIVERSITY IN  CENTRAL FLORIDA.PRODUCTS WILL INCLUDE GIS FILES OF RARE PLANT LOCATIONS, DEMOGRAPHIC MONITORING POINT LOCATIONS, SPREADSHEETS OF MONITORING  DATA, SPREADSHEETS OR DATABASES OF RARE PLANT HABITAT AND POST-FIRE MONITORING DATA, AND REPORTS ON PROJECT RESULTS AND THEIR  SIGNIFICANCE TO LOCAL AND REGIONAL RARE PLANT CONSERVATION.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, NEW JERSEY FIELD OFFICE AND THE CONSERVE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY ARE ENTERING INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOR TASKS RELATED TO THE CONSERVATION OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES OCCURRING ON BEACHES IN OCEAN, ATLANTIC, AND CAPE MAY COUNTIES, NEW JERSEY. FUNDING FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS PROVIDED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, PHILADELPHIA DISTRICT STEMMING FROM A FEDERALLY FUNDED BEACH NOURISHMENT PROGRAM THAT COVERS MOST OF THE MUNICIPAL BEACHES IN THESE THREE COUNTIES. THE MAJOR TASKS COVERED BY THIS AGREEMENT ARE BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANNING, PROTECTIVE FENCING, AND COORDINATION WITH LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS. DELIVERABLE #1 IS A SUMMARY OF PROGRESS ON 5 TO 7 BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANS, INCLUDING COMPLETION OR SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS ON AT LEAST 3 PLANS. DELIVERABLE #2 INCLUDES RAW DATA FOR LOCATIONS OF A LISTED PLANT (SEABEACH AMARANTH) AND A COMPANION REPORT DETAILING THE MUNICIPAL COORDINATION AND TEMPORARY FENCING EFFORTS CARRIED OUT TO PROTECT THESE PLANTS FROM DAMAGE BY PEDESTRIANS, VEHICLES, AND MECHANICAL BEACH RAKES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANNING IS MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING COMMUNICATION AND COOPERATION BETWEEN LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS AND STATE/FEDERAL NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES REGARDING THE CONSERVATION OF LISTED BEACH SPECIES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM PROTECTIVE FENCING IS LONG-TERM INCREASES IN THE NUMBERS OF SEABEACH AMARANTH AND EXPANSION OF ITS GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION IN NEW JERSEY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE AMERICAN PUBLIC (FROM ADVANCING RECOVERY OF LISTED SPECIES), LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS (FROM IMPROVED COMMUNICATION/COORDINATION), THE STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCY (FROM INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS), AND THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (FROM SATISFACTION OF LEGAL OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT).

RELATIVELY FEW STUDIES HAVE BEEN CARRIED OUT ON THE FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO THE SURVIVAL AND BREEDING SUCCESS OF  THE ENDANGERED RETICULATED FLATWOODS SALAMANDER (AMBYSTOMA BISHOPI). SPECIFICALLY, FACTORS THAT INCLUDE RESTORED  VERSUS NON-RESTORED SITES, WET VERSUS DRY YEARS, HABITAT COVER, AND EDNA DETECTION DATA VERSUS TRACKING DATA ARE  CRUCIAL TO DETERMINE IN ORDER FOR THE RETICULATED FLATWOODS SALAMANDER TO PERSIST. WE HAVE AND WILL CONTINUE TO  COLLECT EDNA WATER SAMPLES ONCE A MONTH DURING JANUARY-APRIL FROM 2018-2022 ON EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE. USING THE  ETHANOL-SODIUM ACETATE PRECIPITATION METHOD, WE WILL COLLECT EDNA SAMPLES FROM 23 PONDS AND EXTRACT THE DNA USING  THE DNEASY BLOOD AND TISSUE KIT (QIAGEN). WE WILL USE PCR TO AMPLIFY ANY DNA FOUND AND ANALYZE THOSE PRODUCTS OF  PCR USING GEL ELECTROPHORESIS. POSITIVE BANDS WILL BE SEQUENCED AND RAN THROUGH BLAST TO ENSURE THE DNA IS THAT  OF THE RETICULATED FLATWOODS SALAMANDER. WE WILL RUN CHI-SQUARES AND CLUSTER ANALYSES TO COMPARE FACTORS  CONTRIBUTING TO THE RETICULATED FLATWOODS SALAMANDER SURVIVAL. WE EXPECT TO SEE A HIGHER DETECTION RATE OF  SALAMANDERS DURING WET YEARS, IN RESTORED PONDS WITH LESS HABITAT COVER, AND WITH EDNA DETECTION DATA COMPARED TO  TRACKING DATA. THESE RESULTS WILL INFORM WILDLIFE AND LAND MANAGERS TO MAKE EFFECTIVE DECISIONS IN ORDER TO  ENSURE THE SURVIVAL AND LONGEVITY OF THIS IMPERILED SPECIES.

A NETWORK OF FEDERAL MANATEE PROTECTION AREAS HAS BEEN DESIGNATED AND MARKED THROUGHOUT THE STATE OF FLORIDA FOR THE PURPOSE OF DELINEATING, REGULATING, AND ENFORCING SITE-SPECIFIC BOATING AND ACCESS RESTRICTIONS DESIGNED TO PROTECT STATE AND FEDERALLY PROTECTED FLORIDA MANATEES. THE NETWORK OF STATE AND FEDERAL MARKERS REQUIRES CONTINUAL INSPECTION AND MAINTENANCE TO ENSURE ADEQUATE PROTECTION FOR MANATEES, BOATER SAFETY, AND ENFORCEABILITY.THESE FUNDS WILL ALLOW FWFF TO:1)SUPPORT A REPORTING NETWORK FOR DAMAGED MARKERS.2)EVALUATE REPORTS OF DAMAGED MARKERS TO ASSESS REPORT ACCURACY AND DETERMINE DEGREE OF THREAT POSED BY DAMAGED MARKERS.3)REPORT DAMAGED MARKERS THAT CONSTITUTE NAVIGATION HAZARDS TO THE US COAST GUARD FOR PUBLIC NOTIFICATION.4)TEMPORARILY MARK DAMAGED MARKERS (SIGNS AND BUOYS) TO ALERT BOATERS OF A NAVIGATIONAL HAZARD UNTIL THE DAMAGED MARKERS CAN BE REPAIRED OR REPLACED.5)IMMEDIATELY REPAIR AND/OR REPLACE DAMAGED MARKERS THAT CONSTITUTE SIGNIFICANT HAZARDS TO NAVIGATION.6)MAINTAIN AND UPDATE A WATERWAY ASSET MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND ROUTINELY ASSESS THE CONDITION OF ALL MARKERS IN THE MANATEE PROTECTION AREA NETWORK TO EVALUATE CONDITION AND IDENTIFY REPAIR AND MAINTENANCE NEEDS.7)REPAIR AND MAINTAIN DAMAGED MARKERS THAT DO NOT PRESENT AN IMMEDIATE NAVIGATION HAZARD ON AN "AS NEEDED" BASIS. IN ADDITION TO USFWS MARKER NEEDS, FUNDS PROVIDED BY USFWS COULD BE USED TO INSPECT AND MAINTAIN FWC MARKERS THAT ARE ON THE SAME INSTALLATIONS AS THE FEDERAL MARKERS.8)DOCUMENT COMPROMISED MARKERS THROUGH REPORTS AND PHOTOGRAPHS. FOR ENFORCEMENT PURPOSES, DOCUMENTATION WILL INCLUDE DATE OF DAMAGE REPORT, DESCRIPTION OF RESPONSE EFFORTS (INCLUDING DATE REPAIRS COMPLETED), AND PHOTOGRAPHS OF DAMAGED MARKERS AND REPAIRED MARKERS, ETC.9)SUPPORT EFFORTS TO ASSESS THE NEED AND EFFICACY OF MANATEE PROTECTION ZONES AND THE PLACEMENT OF MANATEE PROTECTION MARKERS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS RESTORATION OF RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE HABITAT ALONG THE LAKE MICHIGAN. THE OBJECTIVE IS TOREDUCE POPULATIONS OF INVASIVE AND EXOTIC WOODY PLANTS AND ACHIEVE HIGHER LIGHT LEVELS MORE CONDUCIVE TO NATIVE POLLINATORPLANT SPECIES GROWTH. THIS WILL INCREASE NECTARING PLANTS, INCREASING FORAGING OPPORTUNITIES FOR RUSTY PATCHED BUMBLE BEE.NUMEROUS ADDITIONAL FEDERAL AND STATE-LISTED PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES WILL ALSO BENEFIT.THIS PROJECT WILL EXPAND UPON THIRTEEN SUCCESSFUL YEARS OF RESTORATION ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON REVERSING THE DEGRADATION OF HIGHQUALITY NATURAL AREAS THROUGH REMOVAL AND CHEMICAL TREATMENT OF PERVASIVE AND DISRUPTIVE INVASIVE SPECIES. THIS PROJECT WILLFUND CRITICAL FOLLOW-UP ON INVASIVE SPECIES REGROWTH AND CANOPY THINNING OF NATIVE TREE SPECIES. SPECIES TO BE TREATED INCLUDE100% OF NON-NATIVE WOODY SPECIES, 100% OF COTTONWOOD (POPULUS DELTOIDES), QUAKING ASPEN (POPULUS TREMULOIDES), SANDBAR WILLOW (SALIX INTERIOR), AND BOXELDER (ACER NEGUNDO), AND CANOPY THINNING TO ACHIEVE 50% CANOPY COVER OF BLACK OAK(QUERCUS VELUTINA) AND BLACK CHERRY (PRUNUS SEROTINA).THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL HIRE QUALIFIED CONTRACTORS TO COMPLETE THE ACTIVITIES OF THE GRANT UTILIZING THESTATE OF ILLINOIS' PROCUREMENT SYSTEM.

THE GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE (GBI), IN COOPERATION WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND OTHER PARTNERS, WILL SUPPORT THE ESTIMATING OF COMMON RAVEN DENSITIES AND DEPREDATION OF MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISE (GOPHERUS AGASSIZII) IN SOUTHERN NEVADA. GBI WILL PROVIDE PRESEASON PREPARATION AND SUPPORT TRAINING IN COLLABORATION WITH USFWS.FIELD WORK WILL BE CONDUCTED TO: 1) ESTIMATE COMMON RAVEN DENSITY (RANDOM POINT COUNTS); 2) RECORD TORTOISE DECOY ENCOUNTER HISTORIES (RANDOM DECOY STATIONS) ; 3) CATALOG RAVEN NESTS WITHIN OR NEAR TO MONITORING AREAS (GEODATABASE); 3) CATALOG SUBSIDIES TO RAVEN POPULATIONS IN SOUTHERN NEVADA (GEODATABASE); 4) CATALOG ROAD KILL OBSERVATIONS WITHIN 5 KM OF A MONITORING AREA (GEODATABASE). TECHNO-TORTS" DECOY STATIONS (3-D PRINTED TORTOISE MODEL PAIRED WITH A PASSIVE INFRARED CAMERA TRAP) WILL BE DEPLOYED TO MONITOR RAVEN ATTACK RATES ON HATCHLING AND JUVENILE TORTOISES (0 TO 10 YEAR-OLD OR ~40 TO 139 MM MCL). THE STUDY WILL OCCUR OVER THREE SPRING AND THREE FALL TORTOISE ACTIVE SEASONS, BEGINNING IN SPRING 2022. TORTOISE DECOY STATIONS WILL BE DEPLOYED AND POINT COUNTS WILL BE CONDUCTED AT RANDOMLY SELECTED SITES (UTM COORDINATES) IN THE FOLLOWING AREAS LOCATIONS THROUGHOUT SOUTHERN NEVADA:"CRITICAL HABITAT UNITS"SUITABLE HABITAT WITHIN BLM-MANAGED LANDS"NATIONAL PARK SERVICE LANDS"NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES"CLARK COUNTY LANDSALL DATA WILL BE REVIEWED AND SUBMITTED TO FWS AT THE END OF THE SEASON.

THE GUAM KINGFISHER (SIHEK) CURRENTLY ONLY EXISTS IN CAPTIVITY AND IS AT RISK OF EXTINCTION UNLESS ITS TOTAL  POPULATION SIZE CAN BE INCREASED. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE SPECIES EXTINCTION RISK BY INCREASING  TOTAL POPULATION SIZE, THROUGH ESTABLISHMENT OF A WILD POPULATION ON PALMYRA ATOLL. THIS WILD POPULATION WILL ACT  AS AN EXTENSION TO THE CAPTIVE POPULATION AND SUBSTANTIALLY INCREASE TOTAL CARRYING CAPACITY, THEREBY STIMULATING  POPULATION GROWTH. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO CONSTRUCT (1) A QUARANTINED REARING FACILITY AT AN AZA  FACILITY AND (2) RELEASE AVIARIES ON PALMYRA ATOLL. THE QUARANTINED REARING FACILITY WILL PROVIDE ADDITIONAL  SPACE TO REAR SIHEK EGGS AND CHICKS FOR RELEASE TO THE WILD. THE FACILITY WILL ALSO ALLOW BIRDS INTENDED FOR  RELEASE TO BE REARED IN PATHOGEN AND VECTOR FREE CONDITIONS, TO ENSURE TRANSLOCATIONS OF SIHEK DO NOT INTRODUCE NOVEL PATHOGENS TO RELEASE SITES. THE RELEASE AVIARIES ARE REQUIRED TO HOLD BIRDS FOR A SHORT PERIOD AFTER  TRANSPORTATION TO PALMYRA ATOLL AS PART OF A 'SOFT' RELEASE WHICH IS AIMED TO TAKE PLACE IN 2022. THIS PROJECT  THEREFORE SUPPORTS THE PRIORITY RECOVERY ACTION TO INCREASE SIHEK POPULATION SIZE, AND AIDS IN THE ULTIMATE GOAL  OF REINTRODUCTION OF SIHEK TO GUAM.  THIS PROJECT WILL CONSTRUCT A NEW QUARANTINED REARING FACILITY FOR SIHEK, WHICH WILL PROVIDE INCREASED CAPACITY  AT AZA FACILITIES FOR REARING SIHEK. THIS WILL ENABLE THE PRODUCTION OF BIRDS FOR RELEASE TO THE WILD WITHOUT  TAKING SPACE NEEDED IN AZA FACILITIES TO MAINTAIN THE CAPTIVE POPULATION. FURTHER, TRANSLOCATION OF SIHEK FROM  MAINLAND US BREEDING FACILITIES TO PALMYRA ATOLL, AS WELL AS OTHER FUTURE WILD RELEASE SITES, NEEDS TO BE DONE  CAREFULLY TO PREVENT ACCIDENTAL CO-INTRODUCTION OF PATHOGENS. IN PARTICULAR, INTRODUCTION OF WEST NILE VIRUS IS A  SERIOUS CONCERN AS THIS HAS BEEN DETECTED IN SIHEK IN COLLECTIONS IN THE US MAINLAND, BUT NOT ON PALMYRA TOLL OR  OTHER PROPOSED RELEASE SITES. THE PROPOSED QUARANTINED REARING FACILITY WILL ALLOW SIHEK EGGS AND CHICKS TO BE  REARED UNDER PATHOGEN AND VECTOR FREE CONDITIONS, AND ALLOW BIRDS INTENDED FOR RELEASE TO BE PLACED REMOTELY FROM  OTHER ANIMAL COLLECTIONS AT BREEDING FACILITIES. THIS WILL ENSURE THAT TRANSLOCATIONS OF SIHEK DO NOT INTRODUCE  NOVEL PATHOGENS TO THE RELEASE SITE. THE QUARANTINE FACILITY IS ALSO DESIGNED SO THAT IT CAN BE MOVED BETWEEN AZA  INSTITUTIONS, OR BE HELD IN A CENTRAL LOCATION TO RECEIVE EGGS FROM BREEDING PAIRS SPREAD ACROSS THE US, TO  ENSURE RELEASED BIRDS ARE UNRELATED TO EACH OTHER AND MAXIMIZE GENETIC DIVERSITY WITHIN THE RELEASE COHORT.  THIS PROJECT WILL ALSO CONSTRUCT THREE RELEASE AVIARIES ON PALMYRA ATOLL, TO HOLD UP TO 9 BIRDS AT A GIVEN TIME.  RELEASE AVIARIES ARE REQUIRED TO HOLD BIRDS FOR A SHORT PERIOD AFTER TRANSPORTATION (APPROXIMATELY ONE MONTH), SO  THAT BIRDS CAN RECEIVE SUPPORTIVE MANAGEMENT WHILE THEY BECOME ACCLIMATIZED TO THE NOVEL WILD ENVIRONMENT (I.E.,  A 'SOFT' RELEASE).  THIS PROJECT WILL REDUCE THE EXTINCTION RISK TO GUAM KINGFISHERS BY INCREASING THE TOTAL POPULATION SIZE THROUGH  INCREASING CAPACITY TO REAR SIHEK IN CAPTIVITY, AND BY SUPPORTING ESTABLISHMENT OF A WILD POPULATION THAT WILL  SUBSTANTIALLY EXPAND TOTAL CARRYING CAPACITY OF THE SIHEK POPULATION. ONCE THE ACTIONS IN THIS PROPOSAL ARE FULLY  IMPLEMENTED AND RELEASES TO PALMYRA ATOLL TAKE PLACE, THE CARRYING CAPACITY FOR THIS SPECIES WILL INCREASE BY UP  TO 20 BREEDING PAIRS, WHICH WOULD REPRESENT A 42% INCREASE IN THE TOTAL NUMBER OF BREEDING PAIRS OF SIHEK, AND  MEAN THAT THE TARGET POPULATION SIZE OF 200 BIRDS CAN BE ACHIEVED (JOHNSON ET AL. 2015, NEWLAND ET AL. 2020).

PROJECTS IN THIS NEW AGREEMENT IMPLEMENT THE TYNDALL INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PLANS THROUGH  NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION EFFORTS THAT HAVE BEEN EXECUTED ON TYNDALL AFB FOR MANY YEARS. THE CONTINUATION OF  THESE PROJECTS IS CRITICAL FOR SPECIES CONSERVATION AS WELL AS MAINTAINING COMPLIANCE WITH CURRENT BIOLOGICAL  OPINIONS AND THE SIKES ACT. BUDGET SHEETS FOR EACH PROJECT ARE PROVIDED FOR REFERENCE AND DETAILED SPENDING  REQUIREMENTS. PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE:  1) ANNUALLY IDENTIFY AND MAP LOCATIONS OF INVASIVE PLANT SPECIES, AND TREAT PRIORITY AREAS. FUNDS WILL SUPPORT  REQUIREMENTS TO CONTROL THE PRESENCE AND SPREAD OF INVASIVE SPECIES AS REQUIRED BY INRMP.  2) IMPLEMENT MITIGATION ACTIVITIES CONSISTING OF ENHANCEMENT OF 71 ACRES OF OFF SITE WETLANDS AND UPLANDS IN  ACCORDANCE WITH TYNDALL AFB REPAIR AIRFIELD DRAINAGE PHASE 1 AND 3 COMPENSATORY MITIGATION PLAN.  3) CONTROLL INVASIVE SPECIES IN WETLANDS AND FLOOD PLAINS FOR MISSION USE, HABITAT IMPROVEMENT, AND PROTECTION OF  LISTED SPECIES. MANAGE AND RESTORE WETLANDS, FLOODPLAINS, RIPARIAN AREAS, AND RELATED PROJECTS, IN ACCORDANCE  WITH (IAW) ALL STATE, FEDERAL AND AIR FORCE REGULATIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE MANIPULATION OF THE PHYSICAL,  CHEMICAL, OR BIOLOGICAL CHARACTERISTICS OF A SITE WITH THE GOAL OF RETURNING NATURAL/HISTORIC FUNCTIONS TO FORMER  DEGRADED WETLANDS, FLOODPLAINS, OR RIPARIAN AREAS. IMPLEMENT RESTORATION ACTIONS TO PROTECT AND RESTORE WETLAND  HYDROLOGY ALL ACROSS TYNDALL.  4) RESTORE AND IMPROVE KEY HABITATS OF MULTIPLE THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, INCLUDING THE ENDANGERED RED  COCKADED WOODPECKER, THE GOPHER TORTOISE, THE EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE AND OTHER SPECIES LISTED IN EGLIN'S INTEGRATED  NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT PLAN, AS WELL AS THE ASSOCIATED IMPERILED LONGLEAF PINE SANDHILLS ECOSYSTEM.  5) PROVIDE SUPPORT AND TECHNICAL EXPERTISE FOR SUBJECT SPECIES, CONDUCT SPECIES AND HABITAT SURVEYS (INCLUDING  EDNA), ASSESS NEEDS, IMPLEMENT PROTECTIONS, PREPARE AND IMPLEMENT MANAGEMENT PRESCRIPTIONS, AND COORDINATE WORK.

THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE SEED COLLECTION TO PROVIDE SEED NEEDED TO BEGIN SEED AMPLIFICATION FOR THESE SPECIES IDENTIFIED AS HIGH PRIORITY. THIS PROJECT WILL COMPLETE THE WILD SEED COLLECTION OF VICIA AMERICANA AND LUPINUS OREGANUS ACROSS THEIR RANGES ON PUBLIC AND PRIVATE LANDS WITHIN THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY AND DOUGLAS COUNTY. WORK WILL INCLUDE MONITORING PHENOLOGY STATUS TO COLLECT SEED WHEN IT IS MOST VIABLE. WORK WILL ALSO INCLUDE COORDINATING FIELD COLLECTION. SEED WILL ALSO BE CLEANED AS NEEDED. ALL RESULTING COLLECTIONS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE NRCS PLANT MATERIAL CENTER. DATA WILL BE COLLECTED ON LOCATION, TIME, AND AMOUNT COLLECTED. THIS DATA WILL BE PROVIDED TO USFWS.

THE GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE (GBI), IN COOPERATION WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) DESERT TORTOISE RECOVERY OFFICE (DTRO), WILL SUPPORT RANGE-WIDE MONITORING OF MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISE (GOPHERUS AGASSIZII). RANGE-WIDE MONITORING UTILIZES LINE DISTANCE SAMPLING (LDS) TO ESTIMATE DESERT TORTOISE DENSITY AND TRACK STATUS TRENDS RELATED TO MOJAVE DESERT TORTOISES. GBI WILL RECRUIT AND TRAIN, IN COLLABORATION WITH FWS, A SEASONAL FIELD CREW TO SURVEY TRANSECTS ASSIGNED BY FWS. GBI CREW WILL ADHERE TO PROTOCOLS ESTABLISHED BY FWS DTRO, UTILIZING WELL-TRAINED BIOLOGISTS AND PROVEN FIELD OPERATIONAL SYSTEMS. ALL DATA WILL BE REVIEWED AND SUBMITTED TO FWS AT THE END OF THE SEASON.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER: F22AS00093CFDA(S): 15.657APPLICANT NAME: GREENBELT LAND TRUST INC.DESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF THE APPLICANT'S PROJECT:PRAIRIE SPECIES MONITORING ON GREENBELT LAND TRUST PROPERTIESPROJECT ABSTRACT:THIS PROJECT BENEFITS TWO AT RISK SPECIES IN THE PRAIRIES OF WESTERN OREGON. IT IMPLEMENTS CRITICAL MEASURES TO SUPPORT THE DE-LISTING (REMOVAL FROM THE FEDERAL ENDANGERED SPECIES LIST) OF BRADSHAW'S LOMATIUM (A RECENTLY DELISTED ENDANGERED SPECIES) AND TO REDUCE THE NEED TO LIST THE OREGON VESPER SPARROW (A CANDIDATE SPECIES FOR LISTING UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT). PROPOSED ACTIONS FOR BRADSHAW'S LOMATIUM INCLUDE THE MONITORING PRESCRIBED BY USFWS UPON DELISTING THE SPECIES. DATA GAINED WILL INFORM THE SERVICE'S UNDERSTANDING OF THE SPECIES' STATUS, WHILE ALSO HELPING LAND MANAGERS UNDERSTAND HABITAT RESTORATION NEEDS AND ENABLING BETTER SITE MANAGEMENT FOR ONE OF THE LARGEST KNOWN AND PROTECTED POPULATIONS OF SPECIES ON THE EASTERN SIDE OF THE WILLAMETTE VALLEY. PROPOSED ACTIONS FOR OREGON VESPER SPARROW WILL PROVIDE CRITICAL INFORMATION NEEDED TO MANAGE THE LIMITED REMAINING LOCATIONS OF THIS SPECIES IN OREGON AND WASHINGTON. LIVESTOCK GRAZING HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS AN ESSENTIAL TOOL TO ACHIEVE THE HABITAT CONDITIONS REQUIRED BY OREGON VESPER SPARROW BUT REQUIRES ONGOING TRACKING OF SITE CONDITIONS AND VESPER SPARROW POPULATIONS TO MAXIMIZE NEST SUCCESS AND PRODUCTIVITY. WORK WILL BE COMPLETED AT ONE OF THE FEW PROTECTED AND MANAGED SPECIES STRONGHOLDS NEAR CORVALLIS, OREGON.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, NEW JERSEY FIELD OFFICE AND CONSERVE WILDLIFE FOUNDATION OF NEW JERSEY ARE ENTERING INTO A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FOR TASKS RELATED TO THE CONSERVATION OF FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES ON THE BEACHES OF MONMOUTH COUNTY, NEW JERSEY. FUNDING FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS PROVIDED BY THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS, NEW YORK DISTRICT STEMMING FROM A FEDERALLY FUNDED BEACH NOURISHMENT PROGRAM THAT COVERS ALL OF THE COUNTY'S MUNICIPAL BEACHES. THE MAJOR TASKS COVERED BY THIS AGREEMENT ARE BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANNING, PROTECTIVE FENCING, AND COORDINATION WITH LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS. DELIVERABLE #1 IS AN ANNUAL SUMMARY OF PROGRESS ON 3-5 BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANS, INCLUDING COMPLETION OR SUBSTANTIAL PROGRESS ON AT LEAST 2 PLANS. DELIVERABLE #2, ALSO ANNUAL, INCLUDES RAW DATA FOR THE LOCATIONS OF A LISTED PLANT (SEABEACH AMARANTH) AND A COMPANION REPORT DETAILING THE MUNICIPAL COORDINATION AND TEMPORARY FENCING EFFORTS CARRIED OUT TO PROTECT THESE PLANTS FROM DAMAGE BY PEDESTRIAN, VEHICLES, AND MECHANICAL BEACH RAKES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM BEACH MANAGEMENT PLANNING IS MAINTAINING AND IMPROVING COMMUNICATION AND COOPERATION BETWEEN LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS AND STATE/FEDERAL NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCIES REGARDING THE CONSERVATION OF LISTED BEACH SPECIES. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME FROM THE PROTECTIVE FENCING IS LONG TERM INCREASES IN THE NUMBERS OF SEABEACH AMARANTH AND EXPANSION OF ITS GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION IN NEW JERSEY. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE AMERICAN PUBLIC (FROM ADVANCING THE RECOVERY OF LISTED SPECIES), LOCAL BEACH MANAGERS (FROM IMPROVED COMMUNICATION/COORDINATION), THE STATE NATURAL RESOURCE AGENCY (FROM INCREASED EFFECTIVENESS OF CONSERVATION EFFORTS), AND THE U.S. ARMY CORPS OF ENGINEERS (FROM SATISFACTION OF LEGAL OBLIGATIONS UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT).

THE PROPOSED EFFORT WILL BUILD ON AN EXISTING CESU GRANT THAT IS USING GEOSPATIAL AND REMOTE SENSING ANALYSES TO INFER THE STATUS AND RESILIENCE OF RIPARIAN HABITATS THAT MAY BE POPULATED BY THE LAHONTAN CUTTHROAT TROUT (ONCORHYNCHUS CLARKII HENSHAWI). THESE ANALYSES ARE FACILITATED BY THE USE OF THE WETLAND LEVEL 1 ASSESSMENT TOOLBAR (WETBAR) THAT WAS DEVELOPED TO INTEGRATE SATELLITE AND CLIMATE DATA INTO THE ARCGIS SOFTWARE ENVIRONMENT. THE EFFORT WILL CREATE MAP PRODUCTS FOR RIPARIAN ZONES AND MODIFICATIONS TO THE WETBAR SOFTWARE TO PROVIDE ADDITIONAL PARAMETERS RELATED TO QUALITY, RESILIENCE, AND CONNECTIVITY OF LCT HABITAT, INCLUDING THE USE OF HIGHER RESOLUTION SATELLITE IMAGERY FROM PLANET LABS. WORKING WITH COLLABORATORS FROM UTAH STATE UNIVERSITY AND FEDERAL AGENCIES, DR. MCGWIRE WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF PEER-REVIEWED PUBLICATIONS THAT SYNTHESIZE FIELD DATA WITH REMOTELY SENSED MEASUREMENTS

THIS PROJECT WILL MAP THE EXTENT OF REMAINING MOUNDED VERNAL POOL HABITAT ACROSS THE ROGUE RIVER VALLEY  OF JACKSON COUNTY, OREGON AND ASSESS ITS CURRENT CONDITION USING REMOTE SENSING, GIS TOOLS, AND EXPERT  ANALYSIS. THE PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY AND EVALUATE HABITAT AREAS FOR PROTECTION IN SUPPORT OF THE USFWS  VERNAL POOL HABITAT CONSERVATION AND SPECIES RECOVERY TARGET OF 4,300 PROTECTED ACRES FOR ESA-LISTED  VERNAL POOL FAIRY SHRIMP (BRANCHINECTA LYNCHI), COOK'S DESERT PARSLEY (LOMATIUM COOKII), AND LARGEFLOWERED  WOOLLY MEADOWFOAM (LIMNANTHES PUMILA SSP. GRANDIFLORA). PROJECT DELIVERABLES WILL INCLUDE  NEW HABITAT MAPPING AND HIGH-RESOLUTION LIDAR GROUND SURFACE TOPOGRAPHY AS GIS FEATURE CLASSES AND  RASTERS, AND A WRITTEN REPORT WITH RECOMMENDATIONS ON AREA FOR USFWS PROTECTION OR FURTHER  INVESTIGATION.

IN SUPPORT OF THE USFWS MISSION TO RECOVER FEDERALLY LISTED SPECIES SUCH AS THE THREATENED DAKOTA SKIPPER, AND TO CONSERVE GRASSLANDS, THE NORTH DAKOTA FIELD OFFICE PROPOSES TO CONDUCT POLLINATOR SURVEYS IN THE STATE OF NORTH DAKOTA. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THESE OBJECTIVES, WE PROPOSE TO BEGIN SURVEILLANCE FOR THE AT-RISK POLLINATORS INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE DAKOTA SKIPPER AND WESTERN BUMBLEBEE, IN SUITABLE HABITAT THROUGH THE STATE. THE INFORMATION IS THEN TO BE USED TO INFORM HOW MITIGATION FUNDS ARE EXPENDED TO THE BENEFIT OF POLLINATORS AT-RISK. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS BETWEEN THE USFWS AND NDNRT. THE USFWS WILL PROVIDE NDNRT WITH THE FUNDING AND ASSISTANCE TO CONDUCT THE SURVEYS. ADDITIONALLY THE USFWS WILL PROVIDE FUNDING AND ASSISTANCE TO ANALYZE DATA COLLECTED TO INFORM/IMPLEMENT GRASSLAND CONSERVATION. THESE SURVEYS WILL HELP US TO DETERMINE HOW TO BEST SPEND THE MITIGATION FUNDING ASSOCIATED WITH ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT CONSULTATIONS.

THE MONOMY-PLEASANT BAY SYSTEM OF CAPE COD, MASSACHUESTTS FUNCTIONS AS A PRIORITY 1 STAGING AREA FOR RED KNOTS AND HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A WESTERN HEMISPHERE SHOREBIRD RESERVE NETWORK SITE OF REGIONAL IMPORTANCE. THIS AREA PROVIDES CRITICAL RESOURCES FOR AN ESTIMATED 1,500 - 2,000 KNOTS ANNUALLY (DOWN FROM EST, 5,000 A DECADE AGO) COMPRISED OF BIRDS FROM MULTIPLE WINTERING RECOVERY UNITS, INCLUDING 100-300 JUVENILES. THROUGHOUT THE LAST FEW DECADES, THERE HAS BEEN A SHIFT IN THE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF KNOTS WITHIN THE MONOMOY-PLEASANT BAY SYSTEM, BUT THE CAUSE OF THIS SHIFT IS POORLY UNDERSTOOD. ONE HYPOTHESIS IS THA THE DISPLACEMENT OF KNOTS IS BEING DRIVEN BY THE SHIFTING DISTRIBUTION OF THEIR INVERTEBRATE PREY. TO TEST THIS HYPOTHESIS, TRADITIONAL METHODS AND A NEW ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA METABARCODING) TECHNIQUE WILL BE USED TO CHARACTERIZE THE BENTHIC INVERTEBRATE COMMUNITY IN TERMS OF DISTIRBUTION, ABUNDANCE, AND PHENOLOGY. SECOND, THE ACUTAL DIET OF THE KNOTS WILL BE INFERRED WITH THE METABARCODING ANALYSIS OF FECAL SAMPLES. THIS APPROACH WILL ALLOW FOR THE DOCUMENTATION OF PHENOLOGICAL CHANGES IN PREY ABUNDANCE AND DIVERSITY IN THE MONOMOY-PLEASANT BAY SYSTEM IN TANDEM WITH KNOT PREY CONSUMPTION. IF PROVEN EFFECTIVE, THIS PROTOCOL AND USE OF EDNA CAN BE COST-EFFECTIVE TOOL TO RAPIDLY CHARATERIZE PREY COMMUNITIES MONITOR CLIMATE-DRIVEN PHENOLOGICAL SHIFTS IN PREY SPECIESM AND INVESTIGATING SHIFTS IN ABUNDANCE OF SHOREBIRDS AT A GIVEN SITE. IN ADDITION, THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS SEVERAL OF THE DRAFT RED KNOT RECOVERY ACTIVITIES INCLUDING CHARACTERIZATION AND MANAGMENT OF A PRIORITY 1 STOPOVER AREA, ASSESSMENT OF THE RESPONSES OF KNOTS AND THEIR PREY TO STORM EVENTS AND COASTAL ENGINEERING PROJECTS, MONITORING OF PREY RESOURCES, AND DISTURBANCE MANAGEMENT RELATED TO THE AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY.

THE GOAL OF THE COMPLETED PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE USFWS WITH AN UPDATED DRAFT IN ( 1) YEAR AND A FINAL DRAFT  WHOOPING CRANE INTERNATIONAL RECOVERY PLAN UPDATE (PLAN) WITHIN (2.5) YEARS OF THE PROJECT'S INITIATION. UPDATES  WILL INCLUDE REVISING THE PLAN'S VISION, CONSERVATION MISSION, THREATS TO BE AMELIORATED, AND A RECOVERY STRATEGY  OUTLINE. REVISIONS WILL BE OBJECTIVELY MADE TO RECOVERY CRITERIA ( DOWNLISTING AND DELISTING) AS MEASURABLE  THRESHOLDS TO GAUGE RECOVERY PROGRESS. RECOVERY ACTIONS WILL BE REVISED ALONG WITH ESTIMATES OF TIME AND COST FOR  ACHIEVING BOTH DOWNLISTING AND DELISTING GOALS AND FOR STRATEGICALLY MEETING THE RECOVERY VISION. ICF WILL  UTILIZE THE POPULATION VIABILITY ANALYSIS (PV A) REPORT ALONG WITH THE DRAFT SPECIES STATUS ASSESSMENT (SSA) TO  DRAFT A REVISED RECOVERY PLAN. FOLLOWING A RIGOROUS REVIEW OF THE PLAN'S UPDATE, IT WILL BE SUBMITTED TO USFWS.  INTERNATIONAL CRANE FOUNDATION WILL RESPOND TO PUBLIC AND USFWS COMMENTS RECEIVED, SUGGESTED PLAN MODIFICATIONS  AND EDITS, AND UNDERTAKE ALL REQUIRED REVISIONS. A FINAL DRAFT PLAN WILL BE SUBMITTED TO USFWS WITHIN THE  ALLOTTED PROJECT PERFORMANCE PERIOD. A WORKSHOP WILL BE SCHEDULED TO ASSIST IN THE REVISION OF THE PLAN, AND AN  ADDITIONAL WORKSHOP SCHEDULED TO RESPOND TO BOTH PUBLIC COMMENTS AND THOSE GENERATED BY THE USFWS TEAM. THE  APPLICANT WILL ENGAGE THE SERVICES OF AN INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR FOR PROVIDING ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL AND POPULATION  MODELING EXPERTISE, AND WITH HAVING PREVIOUS WHOOPING CRANE CONSERVATION PLANNING EXPERIENCE AND RELEVANCY THAT  ARE INTENDED TO INFORM THE PLAN'S UPDATES AND REVISIONS.

RANGEWIDE SURVEYS FOCUSING ON DETECTION OF ADULT SEASIDE HOARY ELFIN BUTTERFLIES (CALLOPHRYS POLIOS MARITIMA) TO ACQUIRE POPULATION ESTIMATES FOR THE PURPOSE OF ASSESSING THE STATUS OF THE SPECIES AND DETERMINING WHETHER FEDERAL PROTECTIONS MAY BE WARRANTED. GENERAL NOTES ON HABITATS, HOSTPLANT ABUNDANCE, AND THREATS TO HABITATS AND ADULT BUTTERFLIES WILL BE INCLUDED. PROJECT INCLUDES TRAINING OF USFWS PERSONNEL TO ENABLE THE SERVICE TO CONDUCT FUTURE SURVEYS INDEPENDENTLY. THE BUDGET IS FOR SURVEYS OF ALL SITES, BUT THE PROJECT PROVIDES TWO YEARS TO COMPLETE ALL SURVEYS TO ACCOUNT FOR POSSIBLE POOR WEATHER DURING THE SURVEY PERIOD, WHICH COULD REQUIRE AN ADDITIONAL YEAR TO COMPLETE ALL NEEDED VISITS.

THE ENDANGERED HINE'S EMERALD DRAGONFLY (SOMATOCHLORA HINEANA) OCCURS IN A VERY LIMITED NUMBER OF ISOLATED LOCATIONS IN THE MIDWESTERN UNITED STATES AND SOUTHERN CANADA. THE LOWER DESPLAINES RIVER VALLEY (LDRV) IN NORTHEASTERN ILLINOIS SUPPORTS THE MOST THREATENED POPULATION KNOWN. DUE TO HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION, THE LDRV HINES EMERALD DRAGONFLY POPULATION IS ESTIMATED TO PRODUCE ONLY 80-320 ADULTS/YEAR. SMALL POPULATIONS IN FRAGMENTED LANDSCAPES ARE EXTREMELY VULNERABLE TO LOSS OF GENETIC DIVERSITY AND IMMINENT EXTIRPATION. THE REMNANT LDRV HINE'S EMERALD DRAGONFLY POPULATION IS QUITE UNUSUAL IN THAT IT RETAINS A HIGH LEVEL OF GENETIC DIVERSITY, SOMETHING THAT IS LACKING IN MANY OF THE LARGER POPULATIONS. THIS MAY MAKE THE LDRV POPULATION ESPECIALLY CRITICAL FOR THE LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF THE HINES EMERALD DRAGONFLY WHICH FACES HABITAT ALTERATION DRIVEN BY DEVELOPMENT AND CLIMATE CHANGE. THE LDRV POPULATION IS AT A POINT WHERE IT ALMOST CERTAINLY REQUIRES HUMAN INTERVENTION IF IT IS TO AVOID EXTIRPATION IN THE NEAR FUTURE. INCREASING THE SIZE AND CONNECTIVITY OF ENDANGERED SPECIES POPULATIONS IS OFTEN ACCOMPLISHED BY ACQUIRING AND RESTORING DEGRADED HABITATS, OR BY CREATING NEW HABITATS. SUCH ACTIONS ARE DIFFICULT FOR THE LDRV HINE'S EMERALD DRAGONFLY POPULATION BECAUSE IT SURVIVES IN THE URBAN AND INDUSTRIAL CHICAGO REGION. AN ALTERNATIVE APPROACH FOR CONSERVING SMALL POPULATIONS IS AUGMENTATION THROUGH THE RELEASE OF INDIVIDUALS RAISED IN CAPTIVITY. THE LIFE CYCLE OF DRAGONFLIES INCLUDES EGG, LARVAL, AND ADULT STAGES. DRAGONFLIES GENERALLY EXPERIENCE HIGH LEVELS OF MORTALITY IN THE EARLY LARVAL STAGES, ESPECIALLY SHORTLY AFTER HATCHING WHEN SURVIVORSHIP RATES CAN BE BELOW 0.1%. THIS MEANS THAT CAPTIVE-REARING LARVAE UNDER CONTROLLED CONDITIONS HAS GREAT POTENTIAL TO GENERATE LARGE NUMBERS FOR AUGMENTING NATURAL POPULATIONS SIMPLY BY USING INDIVIDUALS THAT WOULD HAVE DIED ANYWAY. PROTOCOLS FOR CAPTIVE-REARING OF HINES EMERALD DRAGONFLY LARVAE HAVE BEEN IN DEVELOPMENT FOR OVER 10 YEARS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH DAKOTA IN COOPERATION WITH THE GENOA NATIONAL FISH HATCHERY, THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES, AND THE FOREST PRESERVE DISTRICT OF DUPAGE COUNTY'S, URBAN STREAM RESEARCH CENTER. MUCH PROGRESS HAS BEEN MADE, WITH OVER 120 ADULT HINES EMERALD DRAGONFLIES BEING RELEASED INTO THE LDRV POPULATION OVER THE LAST 5 YEARS. IT IS CRITICAL THAT THESE EFFORTS BE MAINTAINED, BOTH TO BENEFIT FOR THE LDRV POPULATION AND TO GAIN KNOWLEDGE APPLICABLE TO THE HINE'S EMERALD DRAGONFLY OVER ITS ENTIRE RANGE. DESPITE THE INITIAL SUCCESS OF THE CAPTIVE REARING PROGRAM THERE SIGNIFICANT ISSUES STILL NEED TO BE ADDRESSED AND THIS PROJECT USES A COMBINATION OF FIELD AND LABORATORY STUDIES TO ADDRESS THEM. THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE: 1) TO REFINE THE HED CAPTIVE-REARING PROTOCOLS TO INCREASE SURVIVORSHIP OF EARLY LARVAL STAGES TO GENERATE MORE ADULTS FOR RELEASE INTO WILD, 2) TO DEVELOP APPROACHES FOR MAINTAINING THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF LDRV BY DIVERSIFYING EGG COLLECTION SITES, AND THROUGH MONITORING FOR ARTIFICIAL SELECTION IN CAPTIVE REARED LARVAE, AND 3) TO ATTEMPT TO ENHANCE THE PRODUCTIVITY OF EXISTING HABITAT BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF CRAYFISH BURROWS WHICH PROVIDE ESSENTIAL DROUGHT AND OVERWINTERING REFUGIA FOR HINE'S EMERALD DRAGONFLY LARVAE. CAPTIVE REARING WAS THE TOP PRIORITY IN THE 5-YEAR REVIEW OF THE STATUS OF THE HINE'S EMERALD DRAGONFLY AND THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES VARIOUS HIGH PRIORITY ACTIONS IN THE RECOVERY PLAN. COLLECTIVELY THIS PROJECT IS DIRECTED AT INCREASING THE VIABILITY AND PRESERVING THE HIGH GENETIC DIVERSITY OF THE LDRV HINES EMERALD DRAGONFLY POPULATION WHILE DEVELOPING CONSERVATION APPROACHES THAT ARE FULLY APPLICABLE TO THE HINES EMERALD DRAGONFLY ACROSS ITS RANGE WHERE POPULATIONS ARE OF UNKNOWN SIZE AND STATUS.

THE PROPOSED WORK WILL OPTIMIZE CONSERVATION BREEDING AND REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS FOR CAPTIVE-BRED  MOUNTAIN YELLOW-LEGGED FROGS (MYLF) IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA. EFFORTS FOCUS ON TOP PRIORITY RECOVERY ACTIONS  IN THE MYLF RECOVERY PLAN AND IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY (2, 3) THAT DIRECTLY ADDRESS DOWNLISTING CRITERIA  (E.G., INCREASING NUMBERS OF FREE-LIVING MYLF; DISEASE MITIGATION). PROPOSED WORK SPECIFICALLY FOCUSES ON  (1) CAPTIVE PROPAGATION OF LARGER NUMBERS OF MYLF ANNUALLY, (2) POPULATION AUGMENTATION AND REESTABLISHMENT OF MYLF, AND (3) CHARACTERIZING AND ADDRESSING THE IMPACTS OF THE AMPHIBIAN CHYTRID  FUNGUS. IN DOING SO THE PROPOSED ACTIVITIES WILL ALSO ENHANCE REPRODUCTIVE FITNESS, REINTRODUCTION  STRATEGIES, AND POST-RELEASE MONITORING. THE ACTIVITIES EXPLICITLY WORK TOWARDS INCREASING REPRESENTATION  (PRESERVING AND ENHANCING GENETIC DIVERSITY IN CAPTIVE POPULATIONS), REDUNDANCY (REINTRODUCING MYLF AT  NEW SITES), AND RESILIENCE (EXAMINING STRATEGIES FOR CHYTRID MITIGATION, CLIMATE CHANGE/DROUGHT MITIGATION  (E.G. LAKE RELEASES), AND METHODS FOR INCREASING SURVIVAL OF REINTRODUCED FROGS). THE METHODS USED IN THIS  PROPOSAL TO PRODUCE, HEAD-START, AND REINTRODUCE FROGS HAVE BEEN IMPLEMENTED SUCCESSFULLY IN THE PAST  BY OUR PROGRAM; THE PROPOSED WORK ON CHYTRID IS BASED OFF OF METHODS USED FOR NORTHERN YLF POPULATIONS.  THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT LEAD BY THE SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LOS  ANGELES ZOO, OMAHA'S HENRY DOORLY ZOO AND AQUARIUM, THE AQUARIUM OF THE PACIFIC, THE SANTA ANA ZOO,  THE BIG BEAR ALPINE ZOO, BIRCH AQUARIUM AT SCRIPPS INSTITUTION OF OCEANOGRAPHY, U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE  SERVICE, CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FISH AND WILDLIFE, THE U.S. GEOLOGICAL SURVEY, AND THE U.S. FOREST SERVICE

THIS CURRENT PROJECT IS PART OF A THREE-YEAR EFFORT TO ADVANCE THE RECOVERY OF THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG BY USING GENOMIC MARKERS TO QUANTIFY THE GENETIC DIVERSITY OF EXISTING CAPTIVE, REINTRODUCED, AND WILD POPULATIONS. THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG IS LISTED AS A THREATENED SPECIES UNDER THE U.S. ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. EVERY SPECIES LISTED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT HAS A RECOVERY PLAN THAT SERVES AS A ROAD MAP FOR ACTIONS THAT WILL LEAD TO THE SPECIES NO LONGER NEEDING THE PROTECTIONS AFFORDED BY THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. THIS PROJECT WILL PRIMARILY ADDRESS THREE PRIORITY 1 RECOVERY ACTIONS FOR THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG THAT ARE OUTLINED IN ITS RECOVERY PLAN: IDENTIFY THE GENETIC RELATIONSHIPS OF POPULATIONS, ESTABLISH REFUGIA POPULATIONS, AND ESTABLISH NEW OR RE-ESTABLISH FORMER POPULATIONS. THE NEW INFORMATION WILL FORM THE BASIS FOR DEVELOPING A GENETIC MANAGEMENT PLAN TO GUIDE RECOVERY IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SPECIES BY A LONGSTANDING PARTNERSHIP. THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG PARTNERSHIP IS A HIGHLY EFFECTIVE COLLABORATION THAT WORKS ACROSS STATE, FEDERAL, AND PRIVATE JURISDICTIONS TO ACHIEVE RANGE-WIDE CONSERVATION ACTIONS FOR THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG. YEAR ONE OF THE OVERALL PROJECTFOCUSED ON SAMPLE AND  SITE DATA COLLECTION, PRELIMINARY SEQUENCING TO DETERMINE APPROPRIATE SEQUENCING DEPTH AND  BALANCE BETWEEN SEQUENCE DEPTH AND NUMBER OF SAMPLES, AND PREPARING BIOINFORMATICS STUDY  DESIGN. DURING YEAR TWO, MARIAN UNIVERSITY COMPLETE REMAINING SEQUENCING OF THE SAMPLES COLLECTED FROM FROGS, ANALYZE OF THE MILLIONS OF DNA STRANDS PRODUCED ACROSS MANY HUNDREDS OF SAMPLES, AND BEGIN PREPARING A REPORT. WE HAVE ALSO BUDGETED FOR MEETINGS WITH THE CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROG PARTNERSHIP TO DISCUSS THE PROGRESS OF THE WORK AND PROVIDE CONTEXT FOR HOW  THESE ACTIVITIES FIT WITH OTHER ONGOING AND FUTURE MANAGEMENT EFFORTS FOR THE SPECIES. THE CURRENT FUNDED ACTIVITIES FOR YEAR TWO WILL OCCUR DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2022.

THIS PROJECT, FOCUSED ON THE DPS OF COASTAL MARTEN, WILL COMBINE TELEMETRY WITH THE DEVELOPMENT AND APPLICATION OF GENETIC TOOLS BASED ON GUIDANCE IN THE RECOVERY OUTLINE. USING TISSUE SAMPLES, AFFORDABLE DNA FINGERPRINTING WILL BE AVAILABLE WHICH WILL ALLOW MANAGERS TO IDENTIFY MARTEN INDIVIDUALS, SEX, AND GENETIC DIVERSITY USING SCATS. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE USED TO ASSESS INBREEDING DEPRESSION AND BARRIERS TO GENE FLOW FROM A BANK OF PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED SCAT, COMBINED WITH ADDITIONAL SAMPLES COLLECTED DURING TELEMETRY STUDIES. TELEMETRY DATA WILL INFORM HOW MARTEN MOVE THROUGH THE LANDSCAPE AND WILL INFORM HOW TO MANAGE FOR INCREASED CONNECTIVITY AMONG SUBPOPULATIONS.THE SERVICE WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED BY:THE SERVICE WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE APPLICANT TO INFORM THE STUDY DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF FIELD AND LAB WORK. THIS INCLUDES INFORMING DISCRETE PROJECT LOCATIONS, FIELD ASSISTANCE, AND INPUT ON REPORTS.
RANGE-WIDE RECOVERY STATUS ASSESSMENT OF THREATENED NELSON'S CHECKERMALLOW (SIDALCEA NELSONIANA)

THE FEDERALLY LISTED EASTERN INDIGO SNAKE (DRYMARCHON COUPERI) HAS DECLINED ACROSS MUCH OF ITS RANGE AND CONTINUES TO FACE A VARIETY OF THREATS TO LONG-TERM POPULATION PERSISTENCE. EXTENSIVE WORK IN RECENT YEARS HAS FOCUSED ON LEVERAGING DATA COLLECTED FROM ACROSS THIS SPECIES' RANGE TO CONSTRUCT SPATIALLY-EXPLICIT POPULATION VIABILITY MODELS THAT CAN BE USED TO ASSESS THE VIABILITY OF POPULATIONS AND PREDICT THEIR RESPONSE TO VARIOUS MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES. DESPITE THESE ADVANCES, RELATIVELY LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT SITE-SPECIFIC DEMOGRAPHIC PROCESSES AND POPULATIONS STRUCTURES THAT COULD BE USED TO FURTHER REFINE ESTIMATES OF POPULATION VIABILITY. THUS, WE WILL USE EXISTING DATASETS, INCLUDING MARK-RECAPTURE AND RADIO TELEMETRY DATA, TO ESTIMATE DEMOGRAPHIC PARAMETERS (E.G., ABUNDANCE AND DENSITY) IN SELECT INDIGO SNAKE POPULATIONS. THESE ESTIMATES WILL THEN BE USED TO UPDATE THE RESULTS OF EXISTING POPULATION VIABILITY MODELS. ULTIMATELY, WE WILL USE THESE PREDICTIONS TO PROVIDE BOTH SITE-SPECIFIC MANAGEMENT RECOMMENDATIONS AS WELL AS BROAD TYPES OF DETAILED DEMOGRAPHIC DATA AT KEY SITES ACROSS THE INDIGO SNAKES' RANGE.

THESE FUNDS WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE ZOO TO ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF ENGINEERING DRAWINGS NECESSARY TO CONSTRUCT AN ANIMAL HOLDING FACILITY AND TO ASSIST IN BUILDING THE FACILITY. THE ZOO WILL RUN THE FACILITY ONCE IT IS COMPLETED. THESE FUNDS MAY ALSO BE USED TO DEVELOP OUTREACH MATERIALS TO EDUCATE THE PUBLIC ABOUT THE ZOO'S EFFORTS TO RESTORE NATIVE ANIMAL COMMUNITIES IN OREGON AND SURROUNDING STATES. THIS GRANT ADDRESSES ONE ASPECT OF THE OVERALL PROJECT: DISPLAY DEVELOPMENT FOR SPECIES FOR WHICH THE SERVICE HAS RECOVERY RESPONSIBILITIES, SUCH AS UPDATING A SEA OTTER EXHIBIT AND THE CONDOR EXHIBIT. IN THIS CASE THE FUNDS ARE FOR THE ZOO'S EFFORTS ON BEAVER, THE OREGON STATE MAMMAL AND A KEYSTONE SPECIES BENEFITING NUMEROUS OTHER SPECIES THROUGHOUT OREGON.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF PROJECT TASKS BETWEEN FEDERAL FISCAL YEARS 2019, 2020, AND 2021 (FY 19, FY20, AND FY 21) THAT WILL BENEFIT FOREST CONSERVATION, POLLINATOR SPECIES, AND FOREST-DWELLING BATS ON FORT KNOX AND IN KENTUCKY.  
THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL BE SUBSTANTIALLY INVOLVED IN PROJECTS UNDER THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY.  IN PARTICULAR, THE SERVICE WILL 
BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE FOLLOWING: ASSISTING WITH THE IDENTIFICATION AND PLANNING OF PROPOSED PROJECTS, COORDINATING WITH ASSISTING AGENCIES 
AND OTHER PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT PROJECTS, AND REVIEWING PROJECT PROPOSALS THAT WILL BE FUNDED.  AS THE RECIPIENT, KNLT WILL PROVIDE POLLINATOR 
SURVEYS AND FOREST INVENTORY WORK ON PRIORITIZED PORTIONS OF FORT KNOX.

ECOLOGICAL SERVICES PROGRAM PROVIDES FEDERAL FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE ON A COMPETITIVE BASIS TO STATES, LANDOWNERS, EDUCATORS, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, RESEARCHERS AND OTHER POTENTIAL PARTNERS TO SECURE INFORMATION ABOUT ENDANGERED, THREATENED OR CANDIDATE SPECIES, TO AID IN THE RECOVERY OF THESE SPECIES, TO AVERT LISTING OF SPECIES PURSUANT TO THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT, AND TO HELP CONSERVE THE ECOSYSTEMS UPON WHICH THESE SPECIES DEPEND.

THESE FUNDS ARE TO SUPPORT THE HAWAII CONSERVATION ALLIANCE'S WORK IN CARRYING OUT A NUMBER OF ESSENTIAL FUNCTIONS THAT BENEFIT THE GENERAL PUBLIC BY INFORMING THEM ON CRITICAL CONSERVATION ISSUES. RELEASE CAPTIVE BRED PYGMY RABBITS TO ONE OR MORE RELEASE AREAS.

COORDINATE ACTIVITIES OF THE COLUMBIA BASIN PYGMY RABBIT SCIENCE ADVISORY GROUP.
OBTAIN ANY NECESSARY FEDERAL, STATE, AND LOCAL PERMITS.
